6	0	"<br>you might want to look in windows FAQ for this one, but here is my best<br>explanation.  But I can't guarantee that I'm not way off base...<br><br>The permenant swap file is read/written to by windows by talking<br>directly to the hard disk controller card.  The controller card must<br>use the protocal set up by western digital (or something like that).<br>Windows creates a file called spart.par in your windows directory that<br>points to that file.  It then uses the physical information about your<br>disk to index to information in that file.<br><br>compressed disks are actually ""logical"" disks.  These disks have different<br>characteristics than the actual physical disk.  Furthermore, the information<br>on the compressed disks must be uncompressed before it is used.  (i.e it must<br>go through the decompression program that traps disk reads at the operating<br>system level or the BIOS level).  Because of this ""inbetween"" program, windows<br>cannot use direct methods to read from the ""logical"" disk.<br><br>a permenant swap file is only there to ""reserve"" an area of the disk that<br>windows can use and to block that space from DOS.  Windows would theoretically<br>not even have to access the file from DOS to use that disk space. (I don't<br>know if it does or doesn't...but it checks for it somewhere everytime you<br>boot windows.)<br><br>a temporary swap file is just a normal DOS file that is accessed by windows<br>via DOS and the BIOS.  If a disk compression program or other TSR is loaded<br>the file access must go through DOS...TSR'S (disk compression)...and BIOS in<br>order to be access. (i.e. NEVER USE A TEMPORARY SWAP FILE...NEVER)<br><br>more on permenent swap files...<br><br>i'm sure everyone who has an uncompressed part of their compressed hard disk<br>has seen the message ""you have selected a swap file greater than the suggested<br>size...windows will only use the size suggested...do you wan't to create this<br>swap file anyway"" or something like that.<br><br>well, a friend of mine (ROBERT) called microsoft and asked them what and why.<br>what they said is that windows checks the amount of free disk space and<br>divides that number by 2.  Then it checks for the largest contiguous block<br>of free disk space.  Windows then suggests the smaller of the two numbers.<br><br>They also said that under absolutely no circumstances...NONE!...will windows<br>uses a swap file larger than the suggested size.  Well...that's what he <br>said!<br><br>I call bull@#$#.  If this is true why does windows report the memory is<br>available to me if it's not going to use it?<br><br>any takers?<br><br>James"	"<br>you might want to look in windows FAQ for this one, but here is my best<br>explanation.  But I can't guarantee that I'm not way off base...<br><br>The permenant swap file is read/written to by windows by talking<br>directly to the hard disk controller card.  The controller card must<br>use the protocal set up by western digital (or something like that).<br>Windows creates a file called spart.par in your windows directory that<br>points to that file.  It then uses the physical information about your<br>disk to index to information in that file.<br><br>compressed disks are actually ""logical"" disks.  These disks have different<br>characteristics than the actual physical disk.  Furthermore, the information<br>on the compressed disks must be uncompressed before it is used.  (i.e it must<br>go through the decompression program that traps disk reads at the operating<br>system level or the BIOS level).  Because of this ""inbetween"" program, windows<br>cannot use direct methods to read from the ""logical"" disk.<br><br>a permenant swap file is only there to ""reserve"" an area of the disk that<br>windows can use and to block that space from DOS.  Windows would theoretically<br>not even have to access the file from DOS to use that disk space. (I don't<br>know if it does or doesn't...but it checks for it somewhere everytime you<br>boot windows.)<br><br>a temporary swap file is just a normal DOS file that is accessed by windows<br>via DOS and the BIOS.  If a disk compression program or other TSR is loaded<br>the file access must go through DOS...TSR'S (disk compression)...and BIOS in<br>order to be access. (i.e. NEVER USE A TEMPORARY SWAP FILE...NEVER)<br><br>more on permenent swap files...<br><br>i'm sure everyone who has an uncompressed part of their compressed hard disk<br>has seen the message ""you have selected a swap file greater than the suggested<br>size...windows will only use the size suggested...do you wan't to create this<br>swap file anyway"" or something like that.<br><br>well, a friend of mine (ROBERT) called microsoft and asked them what and why.<br>what they said is that windows checks the amount of free disk space and<br>divides that number by 2.  Then it checks for the largest contiguous block<br>of free disk space.  Windows then suggests the smaller of the two numbers.<br><br>They also said that under absolutely no circumstances...NONE!...will windows<br>uses a swap file larger than the suggested size.  Well...that's what he <br>said!<br><br>I call bull@#$#.  If this is true why does windows report the memory is<br>available to me if it's not going to use it?<br><br>any takers?<br><br>James"	W

8	1	"486-33 DX, 16 mb of ram<br>on a Novell 3.11 network<br>Monitor:  NEC 4FGe, capable of 76 Hz vertical refresh rate<br><br>Major considerations:<br><br>I expect I will work mostly in windows, but with some DOS<br>applications and I would want decent speed in DOS.  I do mostly word<br>processing, database and communications--not much intensive graphics.<br><br>With a 15"" monitor, I expect I will work mostly in 800X600 and 256<br>colors seems plenty, but I'd like like the image to be sharp, fast,<br>and rock solid.<br><br>Other considerations:<br><br>I sometimes run a Unix clone (Coherent) and I understand that some<br>companies (e.g. Diamond?) don't encourage the third-party<br>development of drivers.<br><br>I might move to OS/2 if I decide I need better speed and reliability<br>than I get with Windows for my database work and multitasking.<br><br>I don't have a local bus motherboard--I'm not sure how much to invest<br>in an ISA video board (versus getting something less expensive now and<br>upgrading to local bus later).<br><br>I like buying things from companies that treat their customers well.<br><br>If you have any advice for me, I'd love to hear it via email or post.<br><br>Thanks.<br>"	"486-33 DX, 16 mb of ram<br>on a Novell 3.11 network<br>Monitor:  NEC 4FGe, capable of 76 Hz vertical refresh rate<br><br>Major considerations:<br><br>I expect I will work mostly in windows, but with some DOS<br>applications and I would want decent speed in DOS. 10	1	" I am having no end of trouble trying to set it up.  It will<br> dial and connect just fine--at 9600 baud.  But if I try to<br> set the comm at 19k2, 38.4k or 56kbps, the stupid thing<br> connects, but just gives garbage (it connects 14.4k).  <br> His machine (a dx48633) has a 16550AFN UART, so that's<br> not the problem.<br><br> It seems to me that the stupid thing wants to talk to  <br> a comm program _at_ 14.400bps, even though it will take<br> dialing instructions at 56k (and respond OK, etc. to <br> other commands).  I don't have a comm program that can<br> do precisely 14.4k.  <br><br> I looked at the manual but it was unclear.  All I know is,<br> I didn't have this trouble with the Intel--it came<br> ready to connect this way.  Do I need to initialize it<br> any way in particular?<br><br> Also, it's _using_ V.42bis and V.42 (and MNP5) when connecting<br> here (i.e., at 9600, since our tests at 14k4 are zip so far)<br> but it doesn't _say_ so there.  any ideas?<br><br> (BTW:  I tried the initialization string that I use for<br> my modem, but it just gives ERROR on that one)<br><br>"	" I am having no end of trouble trying to set it up.  It will<br> dial and connect just fine--at 9600 baud.  But if I try to<br> set the comm at 19k2, 38.4k or 56kbps, the stupid thing<br> connects, but just gives garbage (it connects 14.4k).  <br> His machine (a dx48633) has a 16550AFN UART, so that's<br> not the problem.<br><br> It seems to me that the stupid thing wants to talk to  <br> a comm program _at_ 14.400bps, even though it will take<br> dialing instructions at 56k (and respond OK, etc. to <br> other commands). 11	0	"On my own I was able to find out about Codebase, Accsys, and Q+E. Codebase<br>and Accsys are C libraries without SQL. Q+E is a Windows application<br>that can be communicated through Windows DDE calls, where you send a SQL<br>string and receive the results.<br><br>Most people wrote to tell me about the Paradox Engine from Borland. Other <br>products mentioned were: Microsoft's ODBC, Accsys, Quadbase, Codebase,<br>RBASE, and Q+E. Only ODBC, Quadbase, RBASE, and Q+E have SQL.<br><br>For myself, I decided on Codebase, mostly because it has an ANSI C<br>portability version that runs under DOS, UNIX, etc, and includes the<br>source code, and portability is important in my application. It works<br>with DBASE, FoxPro, or Clipper files.<br><br>However, I feel that Microsoft's ODBC looks very promising.<br>It's mostly a formalisation of building and submitting SQL queries, and<br>formatting query results. As the responses say, it's available via ftp,<br>except it's effectively unusuable without two manuals:<br>the ""ODBC Programmer's Reference"" and the ""ODBC SDK Guide"". Moreover,<br>ODBC doesn't actually interpret SQL and liase with databases, that's <br>up to drivers that should be provided by database manufacturers. Also,<br>it's Windows only (it's actually an extension to the Windows SDK). <br>Nevertheless, it's a start at a SQL interface standard, and should<br>make life interesting in the future.<br><br>Here's my original post, followed by the responses, separated by <br>a line of asterisks (*).<br><br><br>****************************************************************************<br><br>Borland has a product called Paradox Engine that does just what you want. <br>The current version is 3.0, which is fully compatible with (ack) Paradox<br>4.0.  (Why the versions are different, I don't know. PD Engine 2.0 was<br>compatible with Pdox 3.0 and 3.5...).  It consists of a rather broad<br>library of functions for accesing database files from both Pascal (I think<br>turbo Pascal 5.5 and up) and C (I think either Microsoft or Borland).<br><br>Now.. reading the box... it's ""Borland Paradox Engine & Database<br>Frameworks"".  Works with any Borland C/C++, Mocrosoft C 6.01 or later,<br>Turbo C++ for Windows, Turbo Pascal 6.0 or later, TP for Windows 1.0 or<br>later.  For Framework applications, BC++ 3.0 or later or MS C/C++ 7.0. It<br>does have support for object useage...<br><br>I haven't had a real chance to really use it myself... but it looks fairly<br>complete... I'm planning to use it this summer.<br>-Rick<br>-- <br>+--------------------------------------------------------------------------+<br>+--------------------------------------------------------------------------+<br><br>****************************************************************************<br><br>Borland has a product which is called Paradox Engine. <br>I do not know about MS.<br><br>The paradox engine I know very well, and it definitiely<br>not a replacement for SQL, but it will enable you to<br>save and restore records, has locking, et al. Supposedly<br>the Paradox for Windows was impemented on top of it.<br><br><br>---------------------------------------------------------<br><br>Charles Parker     Phone.(800) 669 9165<br>Technical Support   (617) 498 3321<br>CenterLine Software, Inc.     Fax.(617) 868 6655<br><br>cparker@centerline.com<br>                                       cyberspace<br>momma, don't let yer children grow up to be ^ cowboys ...<br>---------------------------------------------------------<br><br><br>****************************************************************************<br><br>I know Borland has a library of routines for accessing PARADOX from within<br>a C program. They recently came out with version 3.0. This works with both<br>Borland and Microsoft's C compiler.<br><br>    shailesh bhobe<br>    (708) 979-7101<br>    att!psp!smb2<br><br><br>****************************************************************************<br><br>  MS has put their ODBC SDK into the public domain; it's<br> _big_ (I believe 1.8 MB), but worth downloading over a<br> fast link. Look at ftp.uu.net in vendor/microsoft/odbc-sdk.<br><br> Also some companies are starting to provide SQL engines; I<br> just got one for RBASE, not exactly cheap at $450, but it<br> allows programs in C or VBASIC (under DOS or Windows) to talk<br> to data bases using SQL functions in your code.<br><br> hth<br><br> Walter Knopf<br> Fermilab<br><br> knopf@fnal.fnal.gov<br><br><br>****************************************************************************<br><br>   Check out the ODBC toolikt from Microsoft.  It is available on<br>ftp.uu.net:vendor/microsoft/odbc-sdk.  This is the way that we've<br>chosen to access databases from all of our apps.<br>mj<br>-- <br>+----------------------------------------------------------------------------+<br>+----------------------------------------------------------------------------+<br><br><br>****************************************************************************<br><br>Borland sells the ""Paradox Engine"" which is a C language interface to<br>Paradox, dBase, Btrieve, ans ASCI files.  They also sell ""Database Frameworks""<br>which includes the engine plus a collection (with source) of C++ classes<br>for using the engine.<br><br>-- <br>Earl Roethke<br>eroethke@ems.cdc.com<br><br><br>****************************************************************************<br><br>I actualy have Paradox Engine.  It is a library of functions (large model)<br>for accessing the Paradox's databases.  It seems to be working fine,<br>but I never did try it thouroughly.  It costs ~200$.<br><br>Hope it will help you...<br><br><br>From: David Lefebvre <david@hp817.speedware.com><br><br>****************************************************************************<br><br>Borland provides a database lib called Paradox Engine which can access<br>and use the database files aswell as many other things.<br><br>Gary.<br><br>-- <br>``````````` bell@nellads.cc.monash.edu.au `````````````````````````````````````<br><br>****************************************************************************<br><br>Paradox Engine is the library  for Paradox .<br><br><br>Artur Babecki<br>artur@ii.uj.edu.pl<br><br>****************************************************************************<br><br>Borland sells the Paradox Engine -- which has all the Paradox calls in it.<br>Its hardly SQL though.  You can do searches on key fields and on <br>indivual fields, but no comparison operators like <, >=....<br><br>so its pretty painful (in my opinion) do do anything besides simple<br>retrieval and inserts/updates.<br><br>I'm currently using it (I have an eval copy..) and I've linked it in to<br>some entry screens I've written.<br><br>The Engine library adds about 100K to the size of the program, but you can<br>load it as an overlay using Borland's VROOM manager.<br><br>Now Borland claims that later versions of the engine will have SQL support<br>but they don't really expect it till late in the year... or even next year<br>They are trying to get thrid parties to help out..<br><br>If you have any other questions -- let me know...<br><br>Mike Kamlet<br>mike@vpnet.chi.il.us<br><br><br>****************************************************************************<br><br>Yes, borland sells their Paradox Engine separately.  It has C, C++, and<br>Pascal interfaces, although the underlying interface is in 'C'. Well at<br>least for version 2.0 of the Engine which I have (costed $99 at Egghead).<br>They now have version 3.0 of the engine, and a separate C++ class package<br>for it.<br><br><br>-- <br>Michael D. Kersenbrock<br>ADC Kentrox - Portland, Oregon<br>michaelk@kentrox.com<br>uunet!kentrox!michaelk<br><br><br>****************************************************************************<br><br>I've used AccSys for Paradox (new version is almost ready for Paradox<br>4.0) to access Paradox files from C.  Its pretty good.  Not SQL<br>though.  Have heard of Borland Paradox Engine or some such which is<br>supposed to do likewise, but not sure of what it is exactly.<br><br>Hope this helps, good luck!<br>chris<br><br>From: fernand@slinky.cs.nyu.edu (Christopher Fernandes)<br><br>****************************************************************************<br><br>Borland sells their ""Paradox Engine (3.0)"".  It's a library of functions<br>for accessing paradox DB files.  It comes with libraries for:<br>MS C 7.0<br>BCC 3.1<br>Turbo Pascal (v??)<br>and I believe it comes with Turbo Pascal/Win libraries as well.<br>The C libraries come in both DOS and Windows flavors (the win stuff <br>being dll's).  <br><br>When I got it, it also came with Crystal Reports which<br>is a graphical report generator.  It allows you to create a generic<br>form and use it within a compiled program using Pdox Engine.  I don't<br>know if they still offer it or what the current price is, I paid <br>something like $50-$60 for an upgrade from the earlier version though...<br><br>Hope this helps...<br><br>-David Taylor<br>---<br><br><br>****************************************************************************<br><br><br>If you want to do SQL from within your programs, check out QuadBase. I don't<br>have their address oops -- yes I do!    :<br>QuadBase Systems, Inc.<br>790 Lucerne Dr #51<br>Sunnyvale, CA 94086 (USA)<br><br>phone: 408-738-6989 (voice)  408-738-6980 (fax)<br><br>Ask for the SQL/Win demo disk.<br><br>It looked good to me (I have a background in embedded SQL in Ingres -- this<br>looked real similar). It's a little expensive, but if you order the demo<br>and then just wait they will probably send you a special offer that'll<br>probably run about $500 US. Good luck!<br><br>Best,<br>                             Tom DeLosh<br><br>From: delosh@emunix.emich.edu (Tom Delosh)<br><br><br>****************************************************************************<br><br>Borland has the Paradox Engine library.  It has libraries for<br>both C and Pascal to access Paradox files under DOS/Windows.  <br>But for Paradox, I believe you'd have buy have the SQL Link <br>since Pdox itself isn't SQL compliant.  I've used the engine <br>for over a year now and have been pretty satisfied with it.  <br>Under DOS, it's a real pig.  It tacks on about 120K to the size of <br>your programs.<br><br>tim ma<br>associate programmer<br>university of utah<br>email:  tim@src.cppa.utah.edu<br><br>****************************************************************************<br><br>I don't know about Microsoft, but Borland sells the Paradox Engine for C/C++ &<br>Pascal (in one package).  And if you want dBase compatible files there is a <br>library called CodeBase from Sequiter software that works with C/C++.<br><br>From: davidr@rincon.ema.rockwell.com (David J. Ray)<br><br><br>****************************************************************************<br><br><br>We're using Q+E database libraries to do what you describe.<br>It's a set of DLL's accessed through a common API to talk to most of the<br>major database formats. We're using it to build an application that<br>queries several databases using SQL queries. _All_ access using Q+E is<br>done using SQL. The package is available through Microway in Melbourne. I<br>believe it is produced by Pioneer Systems in the US. We have no<br>association with Microway or Pioneer Systems other than being satisfied<br>customers.  Feel free to mail me for further information.<br><br>Chris <br>(Programming for NSW National Parks and Wildlife Service)<br>-- <br>-------------------------------------------------------------------------------<br>Chris Hutchinson                       Box U302<br>Research Programmer                    University of New England<br>chris@sulaw.law.su.OZ.AU               Armidale NSW 2351<br>(067) 727 014<br><br><br>****************************************************************************<br><br>Paradox Engine 3.0 provides a complete set of C libraries for <br>accessing Paradox tables. However, it seems that it supports <br>only Borland/Turbo C and MicroSoft C. When I tried to compile <br>the engine's sample applications with the Waterloo WATCOM C/C++<br>(32-bit) compiler, it complains that the library file LLIBCE.LIB <br>is missing even though I am quite certain that the file is NOT<br>part of WATCOM C or the engine. Anybody have any success with <br>other C compilers?<br><br>Ron.K.Ng@hydro.on.ca<br>--------------------<br><br><br>****************************************************************************<br><br>I'm currently developing an app. with Borland's ""Paradox Engine<br>for C"" (it also comes in Pascal), which has recently gone to version 3.0<br>(I.e., PX Engine 3.0 is compatible with Paradox 4.0, and downward compat.<br>w/3.5).  There are indeed C libs for Fox access, but I can't think of the<br>names offhand - I'm sure someone has already written you in that regard -<br>(I think I just saw an add for a Fox lib in the ""C Users Journal"", which<br>is a good place to look for this type of package in general, by the way).<br>I've been paying my dues to learn a lot of the quirks of PX Eng. over the<br>past year - wouldn't recommend it for a complex multiuser app.--but I'm<br>staying with it for now--it's like a bad marriage: I've got too much time<br>invested in learning and work-arounds!  But if your interest is limited<br>to a simple single-user interface (you want to build your own SQL engine,<br>I take it), PX Engine will do the job easily - it doesn't sound like<br>you'll be bumping into any of the gotchas.  If you do, write me; I may<br>be able to point you in the right direction.<br><br>From: raymond@cruzio.santa-cruz.ca.us (raymond)<br><br>****************************************************************************<br><br>Borland has a ""Paradox Engine and Database Framework 3.0"" which gives you<br>a ""C"" (and assembler?) API to Paradox databases.  This is part of ""BOCA""<br>-- Borland's Object Component Architecture.  They have technical briefs<br>on BOCA, PdoxEng, and other products of theirs.<br><br>From: jdm@jumbo.Read.TASC.COM (James D. McNamara)<br>-------------------  James D. McNamara | TASC  --------------------<br>55 Walkers Brook Drive | Reading, MA 01867-3238 | 617-942-2000x2948<br><br>****************************************************************************<br>"	"On my own I was able to find out about Codebase, Accsys, and Q+E. Codebase<br>and Accsys are C libraries without SQL. Q+E is a Windows application<br>that can be communicated through Windows DDE calls, where you send a SQL<br>string and receive the results.<br><br>Most people wrote to tell me about the Paradox Engine from Borland. Other <br>products mentioned were: Microsoft's ODBC, Accsys, Quadbase, Codebase,<br>RBASE, and Q+E. Only ODBC, Quadbase, RBASE, and Q+E have SQL.<br><br>For myself, I decided on Codebase, mostly because it has an ANSI C<br>portability version that runs under DOS, UNIX, etc, and includes the<br>source code, and portability is important in my application. It works<br>with DBASE, FoxPro, or Clipper files.<br><br>However, I feel that Microsoft's ODBC looks very promising.<br>It's mostly a formalisation of building and submitting SQL queries, and<br>formatting query results. As the responses say, it's available via ftp,<br>except it's effectively unusuable without two manuals:<br>the ""ODBC Programmer's Reference"" and the ""ODBC SDK Guide"". Moreover,<br>ODBC doesn't actually interpret SQL and liase with databases, that's <br>up to drivers that should be provided by database manufacturers. Also,<br>it's Windows only (it's actually an extension to the Windows SDK). <br>Nevertheless, it's a start at a SQL interface standard, and should<br>make life interesting in the future.<br><br>Here's my original post, followed by the responses, separated by <br>a line of asterisks (*).<br><br><br>****************************************************************************<br><br>Borland has a product called Paradox Engine that does just what you want. <br>The current version is 3.0, which is fully compatible with (ack) Paradox<br>4.0.  (Why the versions are different, I don't know. PD Engine 2.0 was<br>compatible with Pdox 3.0 and 3.5...).  It consists of a rather broad<br>library of functions for accesing database files from both Pascal (I think<br>turbo Pascal 5.5 and up) and C (I think either Microsoft or Borland).<br><br>Now.. reading the box... it's ""Borland Paradox Engine & Database<br>Frameworks"".  Works with any Borland C/C++, Mocrosoft C 6.01 or later,<br>Turbo C++ for Windows, Turbo Pascal 6.0 or later, TP for Windows 1.0 or<br>later.  For Framework applications, BC++ 3.0 or later or MS C/C++ 7.0. It<br>does have support for object useage...<br><br>I haven't had a real chance to really use it myself... but it looks fairly<br>complete... I'm planning to use it this summer.<br>-Rick<br>-- <br>+--------------------------------------------------------------------------+<br>+--------------------------------------------------------------------------+<br><br>****************************************************************************<br><br>Borland has a product which is called Paradox Engine. <br>I do not know about MS.<br><br>The paradox engine I know very well, and it definitiely<br>not a replacement for SQL, but it will enable you to<br>save and restore records, has locking, et al. Supposedly<br>the Paradox for Windows was impemented on top of it.<br><br><br>---------------------------------------------------------<br><br>Charles Parker     Phone.(800) 669 9165<br>Technical Support   (617) 498 3321<br>CenterLine Software, Inc.     Fax.(617) 868 6655<br><br>cparker@centerline.com<br>                                       cyberspace<br>momma, don't let yer children grow up to be ^ cowboys ...<br>---------------------------------------------------------<br><br><br>****************************************************************************<br><br>I know Borland has a library of routines for accessing PARADOX from within<br>a C program. They recently came out with version 3.0. This works with both<br>Borland and Microsoft's C compiler.<br><br>    shailesh bhobe<br>    (708) 979-7101<br>    att!psp!smb2<br><br><br>****************************************************************************<br><br>  MS has put their ODBC SDK into the public domain; it's<br> _big_ (I believe 1.8 MB), but worth downloading over a<br> fast link. Look at ftp.uu.net in vendor/microsoft/odbc-sdk.<br><br> Also some companies are starting to provide SQL engines; I<br> just got one for RBASE, not exactly cheap at $450, but it<br> allows programs in C or VBASIC (under DOS or Windows) to talk<br> to data bases using SQL functions in your code.<br><br> hth<br><br> Walter Knopf<br> Fermilab<br><br> knopf@fnal.fnal.gov<br><br><br>****************************************************************************<br><br>   Check out the ODBC toolikt from Microsoft. They also sell ""Database Frameworks""<br>which includes the engine plus a collection (with source) of C++ classes<br>for using the engine.<br><br>-- <br>Earl Roethke<br>eroethke@ems.cdc.com<br><br><br>****************************************************************************<br><br>I actualy have Paradox Engine.  It is a library of functions (large model)<br>for accessing the Paradox's databases.  It seems to be working fine,<br>but I never did try it thouroughly.  It costs ~200$.<br><br>Hope it will help you...<br><br><br>From: David Lefebvre <david@hp817.speedware.com><br><br>****************************************************************************<br><br>Borland provides a database lib called Paradox Engine which can access<br>and use the database files aswell as many other things.<br><br>Gary.<br><br>-- <br>``````````` bell@nellads.cc.monash.edu.au `````````````````````````````````````<br><br>****************************************************************************<br><br>Paradox Engine is the library  for Paradox .<br><br><br>Artur Babecki<br>artur@ii.uj.edu.pl<br><br>****************************************************************************<br><br>Borland sells the Paradox Engine -- which has all the Paradox calls in it.<br>Its hardly SQL though.  You can do searches on key fields and on <br>indivual fields, but no comparison operators like <, >=....<br><br>so its pretty painful (in my opinion) do do anything besides simple<br>retrieval and inserts/updates.<br><br>I'm currently using it (I have an eval copy..) and I've linked it in to<br>some entry screens I've written.<br><br>The Engine library adds about 100K to the size of the program, but you can<br>load it as an overlay using Borland's VROOM manager.<br><br>Now Borland claims that later versions of the engine will have SQL support<br>but they don't really expect it till late in the year... or even next year<br>They are trying to get thrid parties to help out..<br><br>If you have any other questions -- let me know...<br><br>Mike Kamlet<br>mike@vpnet.chi.il.us<br><br><br>****************************************************************************<br><br>Yes, borland sells their Paradox Engine separately. But if your interest is limited<br>to a simple single-user interface (you want to build your own SQL engine,<br>I take it), PX Engine will do the job easily - it doesn't sound like<br>you'll be bumping into any of the gotchas. 14	1	"IDE does not do DMA.  This is because it's like te PC AT hard disk<br>interface.  The controller moves a sector to some buffer memory on the<br>controller card, then the CPU moves the data from the buffer to main<br>memory where it's needed.  If IDE doesn't work this way, then it's not<br>compatible.<br><br>Heck, if IDE used DMA, then you'd hear all kinds of complaints about<br>ISA bus systems with more than 16M RAM not working with their IDE<br>drives.  16M is the DMA addressing limit of the ISA bus, and if IDE<br>did DMA there would be trouble.<br><br>(BTW, there are DMA-enabling signals in the IDE cable spec, but the<br>last report I heard was that they are never implemented, because it<br>would require a different kind of IDE adapter and different drivers.)"	"IDE does not do DMA.  This is because it's like te PC AT hard disk<br>interface.  The controller moves a sector to some buffer memory on the<br>controller card, then the CPU moves the data from the buffer to main<br>memory where it's needed.  If IDE doesn't work this way, then it's not<br>compatible.<br><br>Heck, if IDE used DMA, then you'd hear all kinds of complaints about<br>ISA bus systems with more than 16M RAM not working with their IDE<br>drives.  16M is the DMA addressing limit of the ISA bus, and if IDE<br>did DMA there would be trouble.<br><br>(BTW, there are DMA-enabling signals in the IDE cable spec, but the<br>last report I heard was that they are never implemented, because it<br>would require a different kind of IDE adapter and different drivers.)"	H

18	1	"Anyway, here's  description of the card:  It is a 16-bit card, although<br>I noticed that none of the contacts in the 16-bit extension are connected<br>to anything.  It has 4 NS16550AN chips in sockets, and 4 corresponding<br>connecters labeled COM1 - COM4.  There is also an external female connector<br>with 37 pins.  There are 8 banks of 8 switches, 2 banks of 4 switches, and<br>7 jumpers.  I believe that I have determined, by following traces, that<br>SW5 and SW6 (12 switches in all) control the interrupt level for each of<br>the COM ports.  SW5[1-4] are for IRQ3, SW5[5-8] are for IRQ4, and SW6[1-4]<br>are for IRQ5.  The other switches are beyond my meager ability to follow.<br>      <br>The only identification printed on the board is ""MULTI SERIAL PORT BOARD""<br>across the bottom.  There is a box for serial number, but it is blank.<br>Immediately below the words ""SERIAL NO"", but not in the box left for<br>the S/N, are the numbers ""1990 2 8"".<br><br>Anyone have any clues?  Your help is greatly appreciated.<br>"	"Anyway, here's  description of the card:  It is a 16-bit card, although<br>I noticed that none of the contacts in the 16-bit extension are connected<br>to anything. 25	0	"<br>This isn't entirely true. It is true that TrueType fonts are<br>larger than their ATM counterparts, but ATM fonts *do* get minimal<br>compression. Running Stacker 3.0 report generator, I get:<br><br>  File Type:      Compression Ratio:<br>  -------------   ------------------<br>  *.TTF (TrueType)     1.4:1.0<br>  *.PFB (ATM)          1.1:1.0<br>  *.PFM (ATM Metric)  11.8:1.0<br><br>Although the metric files are small, they compress quite largely.<br>And, as you can see, even the regular .PFB files have *some* compression.<br><br>So, doing the math on one such comparitive font file:<br><br>TTF Times = 83260 bytes/1.4 = 59471 bytes (compressed)<br>PFB Times = 51549 bytes/1.1 = 46862 bytes (Compressed)<br><br>You still win out, even if the ATM Times font *isn't* compressed.<br><br>Your mileage may vary depending on compression program.<br>"	"<br>This isn't entirely true. It is true that TrueType fonts are<br>larger than their ATM counterparts, but ATM fonts *do* get minimal<br>compression. Running Stacker 3.0 report generator, I get:<br><br>  File Type:      Compression Ratio:<br>  -------------   ------------------<br>  *.TTF (TrueType)     1.4:1.0<br>  *.PFB (ATM)          1.1:1.0<br>  *.PFM (ATM Metric)  11.8:1.0<br><br>Although the metric files are small, they compress quite largely.<br>And, as you can see, even the regular .PFB files have *some* compression.<br><br>So, doing the math on one such comparitive font file:<br><br>TTF Times = 83260 bytes/1.4 = 59471 bytes (compressed)<br>PFB Times = 51549 bytes/1.1 = 46862 bytes (Compressed)<br><br>You still win out, even if the ATM Times font *isn't* compressed.<br><br>Your mileage may vary depending on compression program.<br>"	W	
26	1	"<br><br><br><br>Yeah, there is absolutely no use for VLB except for video graphics.<br>And no IDE could possibly take advantage the VLB, because it runs at<br>8 Mhz and 16 bits. Do people forget that the IDE was specifically<br>designed to interface directly with the AT ISA bus? We've seen<br>IDEs come out for EISA, XT ISA, and now even MCA, but at all times<br>it was a 16 bit standard, running at somewhere near 8-10 Mhz. When<br>you run an IDE off of the VLB, there's no way that you're running it<br>at 33 Mhz, it would burn up. Of course same goes for SCSI, ESDI, whatever,<br>none of them run at CPU speed.<br><br>The only way to gain advantage with a VLB IDE is to hook it up to<br>a caching controller. I suspect it would be much, much better to<br>get a software disk cache instead, since you get write-caching as well.<br><br><br>I've seen some Fuji IDE drives going as high as 1G."	"<br><br><br><br>Yeah, there is absolutely no use for VLB except for video graphics.<br>And no IDE could possibly take advantage the VLB, because it runs at<br>8 Mhz and 16 bits. Do people forget that the IDE was specifically<br>designed to interface directly with the AT ISA bus? We've seen<br>IDEs come out for EISA, XT ISA, and now even MCA, but at all times<br>it was a 16 bit standard, running at somewhere near 8-10 Mhz. When<br>you run an IDE off of the VLB, there's no way that you're running it<br>at 33 Mhz, it would burn up. Of course same goes for SCSI, ESDI, whatever,<br>none of them run at CPU speed.<br><br>The only way to gain advantage with a VLB IDE is to hook it up to<br>a caching controller. I suspect it would be much, much better to<br>get a software disk cache instead, since you get write-caching as well.<br><br><br>I've seen some Fuji IDE drives going as high as 1G."	H

41	1	"<br>I can't speak for MAG Innovision but as far as NEC is concerned, they are<br>adjusted to ""factory-spec"" before leaving the central USA distribution point<br>(MA) for the eastern Canadian market. Now, here's the key: NEC *knows* that<br>the >=15"" monitors' adjustments are very sensitive to shipping over<br>distances (with all the bumps, rough handling, and such) and therefore<br>*expect* and (at least in theory) *require* that the local *distributor*<br>(not dealer) have it adjusted at the *local* service centre (Bull HN<br>Information Systems in Toronto) before sale. This is the correct and<br>probably only way of having any chance of receiving a ""perfect"" monitor<br>(the definition of ""perfect"" seems to depend on how picky one is, in my<br>case quite :).<br><br><br>I, for one, was not willing to accept what I considered a substandard<br>monitor and, after two months of wrangling and direct contact with NEC,<br>finally received a satisfactorily adjusted monitor (not perfect, IMHO,<br>but a major improvement over what the dealer and distributor were trying<br>convince me was ""normal""). The short answer is no, don't accept these<br>""imperfections"" as ""normal"" because for the premium one pays for the<br>larger screen monitors, one has a right to expect higher quality, and<br>if you're persistent, you'll receive it.<br><br>"	"<br>I can't speak for MAG Innovision but as far as NEC is concerned, they are<br>adjusted to ""factory-spec"" before leaving the central USA distribution point<br>(MA) for the eastern Canadian market. Now, here's the key: NEC *knows* that<br>the >=15"" monitors' adjustments are very sensitive to shipping over<br>distances (with all the bumps, rough handling, and such) and therefore<br>*expect* and (at least in theory) *require* that the local *distributor*<br>(not dealer) have it adjusted at the *local* service centre (Bull HN<br>Information Systems in Toronto) before sale. This is the correct and<br>probably only way of having any chance of receiving a ""perfect"" monitor<br>(the definition of ""perfect"" seems to depend on how picky one is, in my<br>case quite :).<br><br><br>I, for one, was not willing to accept what I considered a substandard<br>monitor and, after two months of wrangling and direct contact with NEC,<br>finally received a satisfactorily adjusted monitor (not perfect, IMHO,<br>but a major improvement over what the dealer and distributor were trying<br>convince me was ""normal""). The short answer is no, don't accept these<br>""imperfections"" as ""normal"" because for the premium one pays for the<br>larger screen monitors, one has a right to expect higher quality, and<br>if you're persistent, you'll receive it.<br><br>"	H

54	0	"I think the support droid was malfunctioning and confused the disk space<br>limit with the virtual address space limit.  As far as the disk is<br>concerned, you are limited only by the amount of contiguous free space.<br>The limit that causes the message, ""Windows will only use ...,"" is the<br>amount of virtual address space that the Virtual Memory Manager will<br>create, and this is a function of the amount of free memory that you have<br>when Windows starts.<br><br>In the [386enh] section of SYSTEM.INI, you can specify a parameter:<br><br> PageOverCommit=multiplier<br><br>The following description is from the Windows Resource Kit:<br><br> This entry specifies the multiplier what determines the amount of<br> linear address space the VMM will create for the system, which is<br> computed by rounding up the amount of available physical memory to<br> the nearest 4 MB and then multiplying that value by the value<br> specified for PageOverCommit=.  Increasing this value increases the<br> amount of available linear address space, causing the size of data<br> structures to increase.  This also increases paging activity<br> proportionately and can slow down the system.  You can specify a<br> value between 1 and 20.  The default is 4.  To change this entry,<br> you must edit SYSTEM.INI.<br>"	"I think the support droid was malfunctioning and confused the disk space<br>limit with the virtual address space limit.  As far as the disk is<br>concerned, you are limited only by the amount of contiguous free space.<br>The limit that causes the message, ""Windows will only use ...,"" is the<br>amount of virtual address space that the Virtual Memory Manager will<br>create, and this is a function of the amount of free memory that you have<br>when Windows starts.<br><br>In the [386enh] section of SYSTEM.INI, you can specify a parameter:<br><br> PageOverCommit=multiplier<br><br>The following description is from the Windows Resource Kit:<br><br> This entry specifies the multiplier what determines the amount of<br> linear address space the VMM will create for the system, which is<br> computed by rounding up the amount of available physical memory to<br> the nearest 4 MB and then multiplying that value by the value<br> specified for PageOverCommit=.  Increasing this value increases the<br> amount of available linear address space, causing the size of data<br> structures to increase.  This also increases paging activity<br> proportionately and can slow down the system.  You can specify a<br> value between 1 and 20.  The default is 4.  To change this entry,<br> you must edit SYSTEM.INI.<br>"	W

61	0	"1. WORKSPACES 1.10 (wspace.zip)<br>                                This was the smallest and simplest<br>   of the workspace managers that I found.  It is very easy to use.<br>   It displays a small window, containing 6 buttons, plus an extra<br>   button for configuration purposes.  One annoying feature was the<br>   title window that is first presented when it is run - you must press<br>   a key (not a mouse button!) for the thing to go away.  Also, it would<br>   have been nice if there was an ""ALWAYS ON TOP"" setting for the little<br>   window containing the workspace buttons.  Maybe some user-specified<br>   strings on the buttons instead of the numbers one to six might be<br>   a nice feature.  The simplicity and ease of use of this workspace<br>   manager makes it an attractive package.<br><br>2. WORKSHIFT 1.6 (wrksft16.zip)<br>                               While this workspace manager offered a<br>   few features that WORKSPACES 1.10 lacked, it was quite time consuming<br>   to set things up.  With WORKSPACES 1.10, all but the first workspace<br>   is initially empty.  With WORKSHIFT 1.6, you need to take ""snapshots""<br>   of how you want each of your workspaces to look like - i.e. what <br>   applications they contain.  Also, the main window is quite large,<br>   but this does allow you to have a small view of what is in each workspace.<br>   With WORKSPACES 1.10, there was no facility for viewing what was in<br>   a workspace without switching to it.  WORKSHIFT 1.6 provides this<br>   viewing functionality which is quite useful.<br><br>3. BIGDESK 2.30 and BACKMENU (backdesk.zip)<br>                            This is an interesting package, which contains<br>   a few other goodies as well as a workspace manager.  Other goodies<br>   include ""Backmenu"", which provides a pop-up root menu when you<br>   press a certain mouse button - just like in X-Windows.  The menu<br>   is totally configurable, offering unlimited depth of cascading menus,<br>   which is provides quite handy access to applications.  You could<br>   say it is a menu-based alternative to the program manager.  Also<br>   bundled in ""backdesk.zip"" is a program called ""WRUN"", which allows<br>   you to run windows applications from a DOS shell under WINDOWS<br>   instead of using the File Manager to run applications.  <br>   The actual workspace manager is called BIGDESK 2.30.  BIGDESK works quite<br>   differently to the other two workspace managers in that it<br>   doesn't provide a certain number of disjoint and separate workspaces.<br>   In fact, it basically enlarges your desktop by a configurable amount,<br>   and you choose which region of the desktop you want your screen to<br>   focus in on.  This means you can have windows overlapping between different<br>   viewing regions, unlike the first two workspace managers in which<br>   each workspace was isolated from the other one.  The BIGDESK control window<br>   allows to to move windows around your enlarged desktop.  Basically<br>   the control window provides a small scale view of your viewing area<br>   while your actual computer screen provides a large scale or blow-up<br>   of a particular section."	"1. WORKSPACES 1.10 (wspace.zip)<br>                                This was the smallest and simplest<br>   of the workspace managers that I found. 64	1	"There are 2 banks of jumpers. The first one is labeled as follows:<br>C1<br>C2<br>S2<br>P2<br>P1<br>G<br><br>The second bank is labeled ""IRQ"" and has the following labels:<br>5C<br>5S<br>4<br>3<br>3S<br>2C<br>2S<br><br>I have determined that the C1 & C2 jumpers tell it to address the first<br>serial port as COM1 or COM2. The P1,P2 jumpers tell it to use the printer<br>port as LPT1 or LPT2. I am guessing that the ""G"" enables the game port and<br>the ""S2"" SHOULD enable the second serial port, but I can't get it to work. I<br>have tried numerous setting on the IRQ bank without success. I assume that<br>this bank must tell the card which IRQ's to use for both ports, but I don;t<br>know how. 66	1	"So you add the BusLogic drivers to the config.sys on the CD-ROM boot disk, and<br>REM out the Adaptec drivers.<br><br>Then you install the whole 1st half of the Beta.. and it won't work! IBM<br>nicely copies in the Adaptec drivers once again. (Thanks IBM!) So.. REM out<br>the Adaptec drivers once more.. and reboot. If you have everything in the<br>right order.. it will work.<br><br>Things are pretty smooth through the rest of the installation.. except OS/2<br>will try to install the Adaptec SCSI drivers once again at the end... so.. you<br>are off to more REM statements and more fun. <br><br>The BT 542Bk comes with drivers and costs the same as the Adaptec cards that<br>do not come with drivers. The DOS drivers work great. This card can easily be<br>configured to work with 8 different sets of I/O ports (and you can use<br>multiple host adapters in one machine) If you get a new card.. it will also be<br>able to support up to 8 GB drives under DOS.<br><br>Hope this helps..<br><br>- Dan<br><br>"	"So you add the BusLogic drivers to the config.sys on the CD-ROM boot disk, and<br>REM out the Adaptec drivers.<br><br>Then you install the whole 1st half of the Beta.. and it won't work! IBM<br>nicely copies in the Adaptec drivers once again. (Thanks IBM!) So.. REM out<br>the Adaptec drivers once more.. and reboot. If you have everything in the<br>right order.. it will work.<br><br>Things are pretty smooth through the rest of the installation.. except OS/2<br>will try to install the Adaptec SCSI drivers once again at the end... so.. you<br>are off to more REM statements and more fun. <br><br>The BT 542Bk comes with drivers and costs the same as the Adaptec cards that<br>do not come with drivers. The DOS drivers work great. This card can easily be<br>configured to work with 8 different sets of I/O ports (and you can use<br>multiple host adapters in one machine) If you get a new card.. it will also be<br>able to support up to 8 GB drives under DOS.<br><br>Hope this helps..<br><br>- Dan<br><br>"	W

72	0	": >We need to write an on-line help for our application.  We don't have<br>: >Windows Software Developer's Toolkit (yet :-) ). 78	0	"TrueType is a much richer and more robust hinting language than Type 1 (the hinting<br>of diagonals for instance, which TT does and Type 1 cannot). If you check out the<br>Windows 3.1 core fonts (Times, Arial, Courier, Symbol, Wingdings) you'll see what can<br>be done with TT. There are other fonts out there that have been hand-hinted and not<br>just converted. Some of the Microsoft TT Font Pack 2 fonts are hinted very well.<br><br><br>Again, not true. The characters in a TT or Type 1 font depend on the maker. If someone<br>converts a Type 1 font to TT they'll only get the characters in the font of orgin. TT<br>allows for much more flexibility in this area as well. You can have thousands of glyphs<br>in a TT font file (Mac/PS/Windows/Unicode char set) and use the characters appropriate<br>for the particular platform you are running the font on. For instance, all or our fontpack<br>2 TT fonts have the Mac/Windows char set in them. The metrics of the fonts are such that<br>if the font is brought over to the mac the user will have access to the full mac char set.<br><br><br><br>Hope this clears up some of the confusion. Feel free to contact me if anyone would like<br>more info.<br><br>Regards,"	"TrueType is a much richer and more robust hinting language than Type 1 (the hinting<br>of diagonals for instance, which TT does and Type 1 cannot). If you check out the<br>Windows 3.1 core fonts (Times, Arial, Courier, Symbol, Wingdings) you'll see what can<br>be done with TT. The characters in a TT or Type 1 font depend on the maker. If someone<br>converts a Type 1 font to TT they'll only get the characters in the font of orgin. TT<br>allows for much more flexibility in this area as well. 87	1	"I think VGA-Copy can do what you need. <br>If you create a new floppy for your a: drive (that is the 5 1/4""), turn on<br>the ""modify"" switch of vga-copy.<br>When you boot using this diskette, a message appears:<br><br>This is no system disk, you can<br>1) replace disk with another,<br>2) boot from Harddisk or<br>3) switch drives and reboot (that is, a: becomes b:, b: becomes a:)<br>Type your choice:<br><br>When you select the third item, you can boot from b: which is now called a: .<br>Seems to work very good, for example booting drdos6 from the installation disks<br>in 3.5"" format was no problem for a friend of mine (I have only a 3.5"" a: drive)<br><br>Hope that helps<br>Robert<br><br>P.S.: VGA-Copy is shareware, so it's easy to get. 96	1	"You realize, of course, that inevitably some anal retentive moron is<br>going to come along and wag his fingers and his jowls in outrage that<br>personal politics are more important than [SMCAP][BOLD][Font:God<br>999pt.]The Law[smcap][bold][font].<br><br>But that's irrelevant to the problem here.  Windows came with my<br>system, but on 5.25"" disks.  I hate using 5.25"" disks, so I copied<br>them over to high density 3.5""'s using xcopy.  It worked fine.  In<br>fact, for a while I was changing configurations and whatnot so much<br>that I decided to try putting them on the hard disk.  Not only can you<br>copy them over with one disk per directory, but if you want to, you<br>can simply copy them all into one directory.  Makes it a lot nicer<br>when you're switching printer emulations around.<br><br>Norton 6.0 I don't have much experience with, but when a friend's<br>system crashed, we restored from a backup rather than from the<br>originals, and it worked fine.  This would imply that arj a -r norton<br>c:\nu would create a workable backup, and if you did a full install<br>the first time, you've got the whole thing.<br><br>Never played with WP for Windows; I'm not too big of a fan of anything<br>from Utah.<br><br>Good luck....<br><br>Disclaimer: Don't Copy That Floppy! ISA, EISA: PC,XT,AT,E-ISA,ISA, and EISA I/O timing and specs.<br>   by Edward Solari, Copyright 1992<br>   ISBN: 0-929392-15-9<br><br>4. AT Bus Design<br>   by Edward Solari, Copyright 1990<br>   ISBN: 0-929392-08-6<br><br>5. Interfacing to the IBM PC/XT<br>   by Eggebrecht, Lewis C. Copyright 1990<br><br> Do you have any comments on any of them?<br><br> Please reply by e-mail,"	H

99	1	 Question: I have a 170 MB hard drive which currently has 10 MB left.<br>How much space will DoubleSpace allow me to have?? 100	1	"<br>I get different transfer rates out of my IDE when I change my ISA bus speed.<br><br><br>IDE is just a variant of the old IBM- MFM AT controller.  (at least that's<br>how it looks from a software point of view).  It was never meant to be<br>an all-encompassing protocal/standard to be implimented across different<br>platforms.<br><br>Is there any argument that <br>IDE can (or can't) transfer data from the IDE drive at least as fast as the<br>drive is able to provide the data?  Are SCSI versions of IDE drives able<br>to deliver higher sustained transfer rates to their SCSI interface (because<br>of a higher RPM platter, different arrangement of heads, etc?)?<br><br><br>If data is going from one drive to another, and if SCSI has the ability to<br>perform that transfer without the data having to go through the CPU or main<br>memory, then yes, that is the optimal way to do it.  As far as I know, IDE<br>can't do that.  But when the CPU wants data from both drives (data to be stored<br>in main memory) are you saying that SCSI can grab data from both drives <br>at the same time *and* store/transfer that data to main memory also at the<br>same time?  Working off 1 IRQ and 1 DMA channel on an ISA (or whatever) bus?<br><br><br>A friend of mine just got a Maxtor 245 meg IDE drive for $320.  (that's 245<br>million bytes, or 234 mega-bytes).  With the basic $20 interface, he gets<br>close to 1 meg/sec transfer on his 286-20.  Does your figure include a few<br>hundred $$$ for SCSI drivers?<br><br><br>So you're saying that SCSI would have been the default interface type,<br>considering that the vast majority of PC's don't have cd-rom drives or<br>tape backups or etc?  That most PC's only have (or had) 1 hard drive and<br>run DOS?  That SCSI hard drives cost a lot more than MFM or RLL drives<br>at the time?  (and how common were SCSI drives under 80 megs 4 to 10 years<br>ago?)  There's a lot more than the lack of a common interface card that<br>prevented SCSI from becoming the connection medium of choice.<br><br><br>But on that point, is it faster?  This is what all this is about.  Do you<br>get more performance for the money.  For all the people that will only have<br>a single hard drive in their system (regardless of the OS) will the SCSI<br>choice really give them more performance than IDE?<br><br><br>True, but expandibility can also start on the bus, which means the option<br>is there for cd-rom drives or tape backups that run off their own cards.<br><br><br>No argument.  This is always held up to the first time SCSI buyer as the<br>best reason.  But how many SCSI devices will the first time SCSI buyer<br>eventually acquire?  Again does it make sense to go SCSI for a single<br>hard drive system?<br><br><br>With all the postings on the SCSI I or II specs, are you really sure that<br>PC and Apple SCSI hard drives are compatible?  And even if they are, <br>is the data accessible from either machine (ie are there no formatting/<br>partitioning or file table differences?)  Is it really plug'n'play?<br><br><br>So the C: drive on the connor becomes a logical D: drive to DOS.  Is this<br>really a problem?  <br><br><br>After having two IDE drives in my system for temporary file transfers,<br>I have never seen any differences when switching between drives, nor<br>have I ever seen any differences when transfering files between drives or<br>to/from the same drive.<br><br><br>That is nice (as long as the power supply can keep up).  I do believe that<br>there is the possibility for up to 4 IDE drives on a PC.<br>"	"<br>I get different transfer rates out of my IDE when I change my ISA bus speed.<br><br><br>IDE is just a variant of the old IBM- MFM AT controller. Does your figure include a few<br>hundred $$$ for SCSI drivers?<br><br><br>So you're saying that SCSI would have been the default interface type,<br>considering that the vast majority of PC's don't have cd-rom drives or<br>tape backups or etc?  That most PC's only have (or had) 1 hard drive and<br>run DOS?  That SCSI hard drives cost a lot more than MFM or RLL drives<br>at the time?  (and how common were SCSI drives under 80 megs 4 to 10 years<br>ago?)  There's a lot more than the lack of a common interface card that<br>prevented SCSI from becoming the connection medium of choice.<br><br><br>But on that point, is it faster?  This is what all this is about.  Do you<br>get more performance for the money. 104	1	"My investigations indicate that drive C is a type 27 (1024 cylinders, 9 sides).<br>When CMOS set this way, COMPSURF runs happily, with 13 bad blocks.<br><br>I use PREPARE to Hotfix the one internal drive.<br><br>Install will proceed ""successfully"", but when I try to boot the server, it<br>reports that the software is not serialised for this hardware.<br><br>Internal examination indicates that the keycard is present, and there is one<br>disk drive (or at least one large single unit). <br><br>Attempts to configure a second drive in CMOS result in drive not ready<br>errors.<br><br>Questions:<br>=========<br>The software is Netware 286 Level II and I can see burnt on to the screen<br>SFT Netware 286 Level II V2.0a. However, to configure netware for level II<br>(mirrored or duplexed disks) requires a second disk, yes? <br><br>So how is the Novell Server 286A normally configured?<br><br>1. Can I install SFT Netware 286 Level II V2.0a as Level I, or is this what<br>is causing my serialisation error?<br>2. Is the Novell Server 286A normally equipped with two hard drives, one of<br>which has failed?<br>3. Would this mean I can not install the network software because it will not<br>be serialised for this hardware with a failed drive?<br>4. What else can cause a serialisation error?<br>5. What happens if the keycard fails?<br>6. Am I doing something wrong? Can someone knowledgeable offer some comments<br>and guides.<br><br>Thanks for your time.<br><br>Apology:<br>=======<br>I appreciate that I have posted this request somewhat widely. As I'm<br>dealing with somewhat archaic hardware and software I'm hoping that by casting<br>my net further, I'm more likely to capture someone who has met this system<br>before. I believe I can justify the groups to which I am posting. Please<br>feel free to correct me if you feel this is an inappropriate place to post<br>this.<br><br>"	"My investigations indicate that drive C is a type 27 (1024 cylinders, 9 sides).<br>When CMOS set this way, COMPSURF runs happily, with 13 bad blocks.<br><br>I use PREPARE to Hotfix the one internal drive.<br><br>Install will proceed ""successfully"", but when I try to boot the server, it<br>reports that the software is not serialised for this hardware.<br><br>Internal examination indicates that the keycard is present, and there is one<br>disk drive (or at least one large single unit). <br><br>Attempts to configure a second drive in CMOS result in drive not ready<br>errors.<br><br>Questions:<br>=========<br>The software is Netware 286 Level II and I can see burnt on to the screen<br>SFT Netware 286 Level II V2.0a. 105	1	The screen looks great (Windows) at 640x480 but total shit at 1024x768.<br>There are lots of lines and the image is sorta blurry.<br><br>Is there anything I can do.  Do you think it is the monitor?  I know<br>that it is Interlaced at that res but still.<br><br>thanks for the help	The screen looks great (Windows) at 640x480 but total shit at 1024x768.<br>There are lots of lines and the image is sorta blurry.<br><br>Is there anything I can do.  Do you think it is the monitor?  I know<br>that it is Interlaced at that res but still.<br><br>thanks for the help	H	
106	1	"In going with the modern trend, the Orchid P9000 card only supports 16 colors<br>in 640x480 mode without a driver.  Of course, this breaks any DOS program<br>which uses SVGA modes (like most of my CD-ROMs).  The Compudyne Whiplash VGA,<br>Orchid Fahrenheit 1280, and Orchid F. VLB all share this limitation.  Those<br>are all S3 cards, which means it is an S3 problem for them (the P9000 uses<br>a Weitek VGA chip which also doesn't support them).  The Hercules Graphite<br>card does seem to have these modes, but I didn't run the same test cases as<br>I did on the other boards during the brief time I had it.  It was able to<br>print the splash screen for the Grolier's Encyclopedia, though, which the S3<br>cards just printed as hash, which is why I suspect the SVGA modes are supported.<br><br>The supported resolutions really annoy me.  You can do 1280x1024 at 75Hz if<br>you tell the driver you have an NEC 5FG (they only have about six monitors<br>listed plus 'Generic', and if you choose Generic you can't get any high<br>refreshes at ALL).  But at 1024x768 you are limited to 70Hz.  Seems to me<br>that the hardware should be able to support the bandwidth (if it can do 75Hz<br>at 1280 it sure should be able to do it at 1024!).  Higher vertical resolution<br>was the main reason I bought the card over the Orchid F. VLB I currently have,<br>and it will do 1024x768x70 Hz as well.<br><br>The higher graphics modes all crash HP Dashboard.  I just got off the phone<br>with Orchid, and with the 1.1 drivers (I don't know what I have) he was unable<br>to recreate the problem.  On the plus side, their tech rep was as helpful as<br>he could be and booted up the program on his computer to verify he didn't have<br>the problem.  He didn't know why they limited the refresh to 70 Hz either.<br><br>The board is faster that the OFVLB for most things according to the Hercules<br>Speedy program. This program tests various operations and reports the results<br>in pixels/second.  I don't have the numbers for the Graphite card, but they<br>were close to half of the OFVLB (ie, slower) but that was running in a 20MHz<br>386, ISA, so the numbers aren't really comparable.  The following numbers<br>were all obtained using a 486, 33 MHz, AIR motherboard (UMC chipset), with<br>8 MB memory.  I give ranges because the program reports the numbers as it<br>computes them, and these tend to jump around a bit.<br><br><br>K means thousand (not 1024), M means million, pixels per second<br><br>             Orchid Fahrenheit VLB                  Orchid P9000<br>Chip                 S3 805                          Weitek 9000<br>DIB to Screen        182K - 190K                     228K - 240K<br>Memory to Screen     5.9M - 6.2M                     8.4M - 8.9M<br>Screen to Screen     14M - 14.8M                     29M - 30.8M<br>Vector, solid        2.4M                            2.8M - 2.9M<br>Vector, styled       55K - 58K                       449K - 473K<br>Polygon, shaded      1.8M - 2.1M                     1.6M - 1.9M<br>Polygon, hatched     6.9M - 7.9M                     1.3M - 1.7M<br>Ternary Rops         1.9M - 2.4M                     477K - 520K<br>Font                 130K - 160K                     46K - 55K / 1.2M<br><br>The DIB to Screen test takes a device independent bitmap of a face and transfers<br>it to the screen.  I have no idea what is being done internally as far as<br>conversions go.  The memory to screen takes the same face and copies it to<br>the screen, my guess is after it has been rasterized into a bitmap that can<br>just be copied to the video display.  The screen to screen test copies that<br>face from place to place on the screen.  Awesome!  Interestingly, the solid<br>vectors and shaded polygons show no improvement, and hatched polygons (ie,<br>filled with cross-hatching) and Ternary Rops (whatever they are.  Graphics<br>operations like XORs maybe????) are a dead loss on the 9000.  I give two<br>numbers for the 9000 fonts, because I think they are caching.<br>When the fonts are first drawn on the screen they are done fairly slowly --<br>1/3 the speed of the OFVLB.  Then the speed increases dramatically.  Sounds<br>like programming to a benchmark to me....<br><br>I make no claims that these numbers mean anything at all.  Its just what<br>I saw when I ran them on my computer.  I normally don't write disclaimers,<br>but this time maybe I'd better.  My testing is totally unconnected with my<br>work (I program under UNIX on Decstations) is done completely without the<br>knowledge, blessing, or equipment of my company."	"In going with the modern trend, the Orchid P9000 card only supports 16 colors<br>in 640x480 mode without a driver.  Of course, this breaks any DOS program<br>which uses SVGA modes (like most of my CD-ROMs).  The Compudyne Whiplash VGA,<br>Orchid Fahrenheit 1280, and Orchid F. VLB all share this limitation.  Those<br>are all S3 cards, which means it is an S3 problem for them (the P9000 uses<br>a Weitek VGA chip which also doesn't support them).  The Hercules Graphite<br>card does seem to have these modes, but I didn't run the same test cases as<br>I did on the other boards during the brief time I had it.  It was able to<br>print the splash screen for the Grolier's Encyclopedia, though, which the S3<br>cards just printed as hash, which is why I suspect the SVGA modes are supported.<br><br>The supported resolutions really annoy me.  You can do 1280x1024 at 75Hz if<br>you tell the driver you have an NEC 5FG (they only have about six monitors<br>listed plus 'Generic', and if you choose Generic you can't get any high<br>refreshes at ALL).  But at 1024x768 you are limited to 70Hz.  Seems to me<br>that the hardware should be able to support the bandwidth (if it can do 75Hz<br>at 1280 it sure should be able to do it at 1024!). VLB I currently have,<br>and it will do 1024x768x70 Hz as well.<br><br>The higher graphics modes all crash HP Dashboard.  I just got off the phone<br>with Orchid, and with the 1.1 drivers (I don't know what I have) he was unable<br>to recreate the problem.  On the plus side, their tech rep was as helpful as<br>he could be and booted up the program on his computer to verify he didn't have<br>the problem.  He didn't know why they limited the refresh to 70 Hz either.<br><br>The board is faster that the OFVLB for most things according to the Hercules<br>Speedy program. This program tests various operations and reports the results<br>in pixels/second.  I don't have the numbers for the Graphite card, but they<br>were close to half of the OFVLB (ie, slower) but that was running in a 20MHz<br>386, ISA, so the numbers aren't really comparable.  The following numbers<br>were all obtained using a 486, 33 MHz, AIR motherboard (UMC chipset), with<br>8 MB memory.  I give ranges because the program reports the numbers as it<br>computes them, and these tend to jump around a bit.<br><br><br>K means thousand (not 1024), M means million, pixels per second<br><br>             Orchid Fahrenheit VLB                  Orchid P9000<br>Chip                 S3 805                          Weitek 9000<br>DIB to Screen        182K - 190K                     228K - 240K<br>Memory to Screen     5.9M - 6.2M                     8.4M - 8.9M<br>Screen to Screen     14M - 14.8M                     29M - 30.8M<br>Vector, solid        2.4M                            2.8M - 2.9M<br>Vector, styled       55K - 58K                       449K - 473K<br>Polygon, shaded      1.8M - 2.1M                     1.6M - 1.9M<br>Polygon, hatched     6.9M - 7.9M                     1.3M - 1.7M<br>Ternary Rops         1.9M - 2.4M                     477K - 520K<br>Font                 130K - 160K                     46K - 55K / 1.2M<br><br>The DIB to Screen test takes a device independent bitmap of a face and transfers<br>it to the screen.  I have no idea what is being done internally as far as<br>conversions go.  The memory to screen takes the same face and copies it to<br>the screen, my guess is after it has been rasterized into a bitmap that can<br>just be copied to the video display.  The screen to screen test copies that<br>face from place to place on the screen.  Awesome!  Interestingly, the solid<br>vectors and shaded polygons show no improvement, and hatched polygons (ie,<br>filled with cross-hatching) and Ternary Rops (whatever they are.  Graphics<br>operations like XORs maybe????) are a dead loss on the 9000.  I give two<br>numbers for the 9000 fonts, because I think they are caching.<br>When the fonts are first drawn on the screen they are done fairly slowly --<br>1/3 the speed of the OFVLB.  Then the speed increases dramatically.  Sounds<br>like programming to a benchmark to me....<br><br>I make no claims that these numbers mean anything at all.  Its just what<br>I saw when I ran them on my computer.  I normally don't write disclaimers,<br>but this time maybe I'd better.  My testing is totally unconnected with my<br>work (I program under UNIX on Decstations) is done completely without the<br>knowledge, blessing, or equipment of my company."	H	
107	0	"<br><br>                                                       ^<br>                                                      Novell is at least<br>                                                      demoing windows apps<br>                                                      running under UNIXWare.<br><br><br>                                   ^           ^<br>                                Try MKS.     MKS &<br>                                           others, esp.<br>                                              EMX<br><br>Note here: the MKS toolkit (for DOS/Windows & OS/2) gives you a good<br>suite of standard UNIX utilities.  There are other similar systems from<br>other vendors as well.  The EMX system for OS/2 gives you most of the<br>standard UNIX system calls for recompiling your UNIX programs under<br>OS/2.  Not quite the same thing as actually running UNIX programs<br>directly in either case, but EMX makes OS/2 almost as compatible with<br>UNIX systems as many UNIX systems are with each other.  And, best of<br>all, EMX is free.  :-)<br><br>There is a similar system (GO32) for DOS, but it doesn't work with<br>Windows, as far as I know.<br><br><br>Should add in the cost for DOS with both Geos and Windows, neither of<br>which is a standalone OS at this point.  Neither OS/2 nor UNIX requires<br>DOS.<br><br>BTW, two of the best unices I've seen for the pee cee are UNIXWare ($300<br>for the personal edition) and LINUX (free).  So I don't agree that ""a<br>good one costs $400-$700.""  :-)<br><br>And, if you really want to check out the various options available to<br>you, you should also look into DESQview and DESQview/X.<br><br>cheers"	"<br><br>                                                       ^<br>                                                      Novell is at least<br>                                                      demoing windows apps<br>                                                      running under UNIXWare.<br><br><br>                                   ^           ^<br>                                Try MKS.     MKS &<br>                                           others, esp.<br>                                              EMX<br><br>Note here: the MKS toolkit (for DOS/Windows & OS/2) gives you a good<br>suite of standard UNIX utilities.  There are other similar systems from<br>other vendors as well.  The EMX system for OS/2 gives you most of the<br>standard UNIX system calls for recompiling your UNIX programs under<br>OS/2.  Not quite the same thing as actually running UNIX programs<br>directly in either case, but EMX makes OS/2 almost as compatible with<br>UNIX systems as many UNIX systems are with each other.  And, best of<br>all, EMX is free.  :-)<br><br>There is a similar system (GO32) for DOS, but it doesn't work with<br>Windows, as far as I know.<br><br><br>Should add in the cost for DOS with both Geos and Windows, neither of<br>which is a standalone OS at this point.  Neither OS/2 nor UNIX requires<br>DOS.<br><br>BTW, two of the best unices I've seen for the pee cee are UNIXWare ($300<br>for the personal edition) and LINUX (free).  So I don't agree that ""a<br>good one costs $400-$700.""  :-)<br><br>And, if you really want to check out the various options available to<br>you, you should also look into DESQview and DESQview/X.<br><br>cheers"	W

112	1	"The article in PC Mag 4/27/93:29 was talking about SCSI-1 {SCSI-2 uses<br>TEN (10) devices in it native mode, outside its native mode it behaves a<br>lot like SCSI-1 (7 devices, slower through put}<br><br>From your own figures SCSI-1 is indeed twice ESDI as the article pointed out<br>as for ""20% faster then IDE"" that seems to be 8-bit SCSI-1 using a SCSI-2 <br>contoler chip {The Mac Quadra uses a SCSI-2 controler chip for its SCSI-1<br>and gets 6MB/s through put for asynchronous {8-bit} SCSI-1, far in excess of a<br>normal SYNCHRONOUS SCSI-1 output} 120% of 8.3 is 9.96 which is near<br>the burst of a SCSI-1 machine with a SCSI-2 controller chip.<br><br>The PC world seems to have SCSI-1 and SCSI-2 mixed up.  Fact is SCSI-2 <br>controler chips allow near SCSI-2 speeds through a SCSI-1 device<br>{As shown in the Mac Quadra} which skews some of the data of SCSI-1 vs<br>IDE or ESDI test. I agree that the article COULD have stated that the ""20%<br>faster then IDE"" came off a SCSI-1 device with a SCSI-2 chip.  Maybe it<br>was there and the EDITOR killed it because the article was dealing with<br>SCSI-1 NOT SCSI-2 and he did not understand the effect of a SCSI-1 device<br>with a SCSI-2 controller chip.<br>SCSI-1 chips are limited to 5/MB max.  SCSI-1 devices with SCSI-2 chips<br>{becoming common} produce up to 10Mb/s in 8-bit mode and 20MB/s in 16-bit<br>mode {the fast version, SCSI-1 ports cannot use wide SCSI}.  Of cource<br>the prime piece of wierdness is that SCSI-1 devices HAVE SCSI-2 chips<br>{or more accurately the machine does}. This allows the best of BOTH<br>worlds: high SCSI-2 speeds and cheeper SCSI-1 costs {FULL SCSI-2 hardware<br>(port, electronic controller, etc) is VERY expensive.  It ALSO creates<br>a logistic NIGHTMARE as to how fast SCSI-1 goes."	"The article in PC Mag 4/27/93:29 was talking about SCSI-1 {SCSI-2 uses<br>TEN (10) devices in it native mode, outside its native mode it behaves a<br>lot like SCSI-1 (7 devices, slower through put}<br><br>From your own figures SCSI-1 is indeed twice ESDI as the article pointed out<br>as for ""20% faster then IDE"" that seems to be 8-bit SCSI-1 using a SCSI-2 <br>contoler chip {The Mac Quadra uses a SCSI-2 controler chip for its SCSI-1<br>and gets 6MB/s through put for asynchronous {8-bit} SCSI-1, far in excess of a<br>normal SYNCHRONOUS SCSI-1 output} 120% of 8.3 is 9.96 which is near<br>the burst of a SCSI-1 machine with a SCSI-2 controller chip.<br><br>The PC world seems to have SCSI-1 and SCSI-2 mixed up.  Fact is SCSI-2 <br>controler chips allow near SCSI-2 speeds through a SCSI-1 device<br>{As shown in the Mac Quadra} which skews some of the data of SCSI-1 vs<br>IDE or ESDI test. I agree that the article COULD have stated that the ""20%<br>faster then IDE"" came off a SCSI-1 device with a SCSI-2 chip.  Maybe it<br>was there and the EDITOR killed it because the article was dealing with<br>SCSI-1 NOT SCSI-2 and he did not understand the effect of a SCSI-1 device<br>with a SCSI-2 controller chip.<br>SCSI-1 chips are limited to 5/MB max.  SCSI-1 devices with SCSI-2 chips<br>{becoming common} produce up to 10Mb/s in 8-bit mode and 20MB/s in 16-bit<br>mode {the fast version, SCSI-1 ports cannot use wide SCSI}.  Of cource<br>the prime piece of wierdness is that SCSI-1 devices HAVE SCSI-2 chips<br>{or more accurately the machine does}. This allows the best of BOTH<br>worlds: high SCSI-2 speeds and cheeper SCSI-1 costs {FULL SCSI-2 hardware<br>(port, electronic controller, etc) is VERY expensive.  It ALSO creates<br>a logistic NIGHTMARE as to how fast SCSI-1 goes."	H

122	1	"Seriously, busmastering adapter have their own DMA ability, they don't use<br>the motherboards on-board DMA(which is *MUCH* slower).<br><br>ISA has no bus arbitration, so if two busmastering cards in 1 ISA system<br>try to do DMA xfers on the same DMA channel the system will lock or <br>crash.(I forget)<br><br>Their are 8 DMA channels in an ISA system. 0-7. 0-3 are 8-bit & 4-7 are<br>16-bit.<br><br>The system uses DMA 0, a SoundBlaster uses DMA 1.<br><br>I could buy a busmastering XGA-2 video card & a busmastering SCSI HA.<br><br>In order for them to work properly, I would have to find out what DMA<br>channel the XGA-2 card uses and then simply configure the SCSI HA to<br>use a different DMA channel for its DMA xfers.<br><br>I don't know if multiple DMA xfers can go on at the same time on ISA.<br>I'm not sure if they can on EISA systems either.<br><br>I do know that on EISA/MCA systems, you can allow BM cards to use the<br>same DMA channel."	"Seriously, busmastering adapter have their own DMA ability, they don't use<br>the motherboards on-board DMA(which is *MUCH* slower).<br><br>ISA has no bus arbitration, so if two busmastering cards in 1 ISA system<br>try to do DMA xfers on the same DMA channel the system will lock or <br>crash.(I forget)<br><br>Their are 8 DMA channels in an ISA system. 0-7. 0-3 are 8-bit & 4-7 are<br>16-bit.<br><br>The system uses DMA 0, a SoundBlaster uses DMA 1.<br><br>I could buy a busmastering XGA-2 video card & a busmastering SCSI HA.<br><br>In order for them to work properly, I would have to find out what DMA<br>channel the XGA-2 card uses and then simply configure the SCSI HA to<br>use a different DMA channel for its DMA xfers.<br><br>I don't know if multiple DMA xfers can go on at the same time on ISA.<br>I'm not sure if they can on EISA systems either.<br><br>I do know that on EISA/MCA systems, you can allow BM cards to use the<br>same DMA channel."	H
