129	1	" Western Digital Corporation<br> Technical Support Group<br> P.O. Box 19665<br> Irvine, CA  92713-9665<br><br>The Super BIOS is for any WD XT hard drive controller card in the<br>WD1002 series.<br><br>The BIOS on my system would only handle up to 20mb drives.<br><br>The responses to my request for help follow my .sig.  Warning: It's long.<br><br>Keith<br><br>--<br>_____________________________<br>__-----____--___--__-----____ D. Keith Rice<br>__--__--___--__--___--__--___ University of North Texas<br>__--___--__--_--____--___--__ Department of Computer Science<br>__--___--__----_____--__--___ Denton, Texas, USA<br>__--___--__--_--____--_--____<br>__--__--___--__--___--__--___ drice@ponder.csci.unt.edu<br>__-----____--___--__--___--__ drice@cs.unt.edu<br>_____________________________<br><br><========================== responses below ==========================><br><br>From ravalent@mailbox.syr.edu Sat Apr  3 16:45:03 1993<br>Received: from mailbox.syr.EDU by ponder (5.61/1.36)<br> id AA15218; Sat, 3 Apr 93 16:45:00 -0600<br>From: ravalent@mailbox.syr.edu (Bob Valentine)<br>Received: from mothra.syr.EDU by mailbox.syr.edu (4.1/CNS)<br> id AA16647; Sat, 3 Apr 93 17:44:49 EST<br>Received: by mothra.syr.EDU (4.1/Spike-2.0)<br> id AA03607; Sat, 3 Apr 93 17:43:27 EST<br>Date: Sat, 3 Apr 93 17:43:27 EST<br>Message-Id: <9304032243.AA03607@mothra.syr.EDU><br>To: drice@ponder<br>Status: OR<br><br>To: drice@ponder.csci.unt.edu<br>Subject: Re: Drive/Controller Compatibility<br>Newsgroups: comp.sys.ibm.pc.hardware<br>In-Reply-To: <drice.733866833@ponder><br>Organization: Syracuse University, Syracuse, NY<br>Cc: <br><br><br>     Ah, finally a question I can answer.   I mess with this older<br>stuff alot.   Kinda fun.  8)<br><br>     First problem I can forsee is that the ST-251 will not be<br>compadible with that WD card unless it has the right bios rom.  <br><br>    Check the numbers on it.  It should be the only non-smt chip on<br>the board.  Slightly below center, and left.    The bios should read <br>either :     62-000042-015 or<br>             62-000094-0x2<br><br>     If the last 3 digits are 013, you got problems.<br><br><br>    Looks right.   W5 and W7 are factory jumped (with a trace) between<br>pins 1 and 2 to select the primary controller address.<br><br><br>    Looks right.<br>  <br>[art deleted]<br><br><br>      I notice you left out the S1 jumper table settings.   Those are<br>what control what drive the controller thinks it has.   If you have<br>the 62-000042-015 rom, set it like this:<br><br>              5 + +    open<br>              6 + +    open             <br>              7 + +    open        <br>              8 + +    open<br>              4 + +    closed<br>              3 + +    closed<br>              2 + +    open<br>              1 + +    open<br><br>    Note:   those are how WD runs the numbers on the jumper block.<br>Top to bottom.   +'s represent the jumper pins.    Pins 3,4, and 8<br>select the first drive setting (drive 0) and pins 1,2 and 7 select the<br>second drive (drive 1).   <br><br>      If you have the 62-000094 rom, it's a auto-config, and I'll have<br>to look up how to do it... I don't have the big book right here.<br><br><br>      See above.  You might have problems if the S1 jumpers are not<br>right.   Also,  at the risk of being insulting, make sure the cables<br>are on right and good. 8).    On the jumper on the 251, try moving it<br>to the opposite side of the drive.    It's one or the other.   <br>     The narrow data cable goes to J2.   I've thrown it on J3 a few<br>times and banged my head for a day.....<br><br><br>     Dunno.    IBM roms had to be later than 10/27/82.   A quick way<br>to check is to boot dos and run debug.   Enter:<br>       <br>        -d f000:fff5 fffc    (the - is the debug prompt)<br>   <br>    This will return the rom date, if it's of any use.<br><br><br>      If I oversimplified any of the above, I appologize.     It's<br>just hard to know what caliber of person I'm talking to. 8).<br><br>                     -->   Bob Valentine  <--  <br>                  --> ravalent@mailbox.syr.edu <--  <br><br><br><br>From chpp@unitrix.utr.ac.za Mon Apr  5 06:33:46 1993<br>Received: from unitrix.utr.ac.za by ponder (5.61/1.36)<br> id AA16194; Mon, 5 Apr 93 06:32:59 -0500<br>Received: by unitrix.utr.ac.za (Smail3.1.28.1 #1)<br> id m0nfpMA-0001X7C; Mon, 5 Apr 93 13:28 GMT<br>Message-Id: <m0nfpMA-0001X7C@unitrix.utr.ac.za><br>From: chpp@unitrix.utr.ac.za (Prof P. Piacenza)<br>Subject: ST251<br>To: drice@ponder<br>Date: Mon, 5 Apr 1993 13:28:49 +0200 (GMT)<br>X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL11]<br>Mime-Version: 1.0<br>Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII<br>Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit<br>Content-Length: 24559     <br>Status: OR<br><br><br>If you are using a TWISTED 34-way cable then move the jumper <br>on your drive to the neighbouring pins   :8::::::.  Make sure that<br>the twisted cable is for a hard disk (and not a floppy disk) - the<br>coloured stripe (pin 1) should be furthest from the twist.<br><br>This may also help.<br><br><br>                             PRODUCTS FOR XT SYSTEMS<br>     <br>     <br>     HARD DISK CONTROLLERS FOR MFM HARD DISK DRIVES<br>                                  Reference NOTE 1.<br>     <br>          <br>          WD1002A-WX1, feature F300R - Half-slot size hard disk controller <br>          card with an ST506/ST412 interface.  It supports 2 MFM drives <br>          with up to 16 heads and 1024 cylinders and is jumper <br>          configurable for secondary addressing and default drive tables.  <br>          Built in ROM BIOS supports non-standard drive types, virtual <br>          drive formatting, dual drive operation, bad track formatting and <br>          dynamic formatting.  This board features a power connector for <br>          filecard applications and it will also operate in AT systems. <br>          Please note that this controller card will be unavailable from <br>          the manufacturer (Western Digital) after March, 1989.  Reference <br>          NOTE 2.<br>          <br>          WDXT-GEN, feature F300R - Half-slot size hard disk controller <br>          card with an ST506/ST412 interface.  It  supports 2 MFM hard <br>          disk drives with up to 8 heads and 1024 cylinders.  Built-in ROM <br>          BIOS supports non-standard drive types, virtual drive <br>          formatting, dual drive operation, bad track formatting and <br>          dynamic formatting.  Please note that this controller card will <br>          be unavailable from the manufacturer (Western Digital) after <br>          March, 1989.<br>          <br>          WD1004A-WX1, feature F300R - Half-slot size disk controller <br>          card  with an ST506/ST412 interface.  It supports 2 MFM drives <br>          with up to 16 heads and 1024 cylinders and is jumper <br>          configurable for secondary addressing and default drive tables.  <br>          Built in ROM BIOS supports non-standard drive types, virtual <br>          drive formatting, dual drive operation, bad track formatting and <br>          dynamic formatting.  This board features a power connector for <br>          filecard applications and it will also operate in AT systems.  <br>          Reference NOTE 2.<br>          <br>          WDXT-GEN2, feature F300R - Half-slot size hard disk controller   <br>          card with an ST506/ST412 interface.  It supports 2 MFM hard disk <br>          drives with up to 8 heads and 1024 cylinders.  Built-in ROM BIOS <br>          supports non-standard drive types, virtual drive formatting, <br>          dual drive operation, bad track formatting and dynamic <br>          formatting.  Reference NOTE 2.<br>          <br>          <br>     <br>     HARD DISK CONTROLLERS FOR RLL HARD DISK DRIVES<br>                                  Reference NOTE 2.<br>     <br>          <br>          WD1002-27X, feature F301R - Half-slot size hard disk controller <br>          card with an ST506/ST412 interface.  It supports 2 RLL hard disk <br>          drives with up to 16 heads and 1024 cylinders and is jumper <br>          configurable for secondary addressing and default drive tables.  <br>          Built in ROM BIOS supports non-standard drive types, virtual <br>          drive formatting, dual drive operation, bad track formatting and <br>          dynamic formatting.  This board features a power connector for <br>          filecard applications and it will also operate in AT systems.   <br>          Please note that this controller card will be unavailable from <br>          the manufacturer (Western Digital) after March, 1989.  Reference <br>          NOTE 2.<br>          <br>          WD1002A-27X, feature 300R - Half-slot size hard disk controller <br>          with an ST506/ST412 interface.  It supports 2 RLL drives with up <br>          to 16 heads and 1024 cylinders. Built-in ROM BIOS supports non-<br>          standard drive types, virtual drive formatting, bad track <br>          formatting and dynamic formatting.  Please note that this <br>          controller card will be unavailable from the manufacturer     <br>          (Western Digital) after March, 1989.<br>          <br>          WD1004-27X, feature F301R - Half-slot size hard disk controller  <br>          card with an ST506/ST412 interface.  It supports 2 RLL hard    <br>          disk drives with up to 16 heads and 1024 cylinders and is jumper <br>          configurable for secondary addressing and default drive tables.  <br>          Built in ROM BIOS supports non-standard drive types, virtual    <br>          drive formatting, dual drive operation, bad track formatting     <br>          and dynamic formatting.  This board features a power connection <br>          for filecard applications and it will also operate in AT <br>          systems.  Reference NOTE 2.<br>          <br>          WD1004A-27X, feature F300R - Half-slot size hard disk <br>          controller  with an ST506/ST412 interface.  It supports 2 RLL <br>          drives with up to 16 heads and 1024 cylinders.  Built-in ROM <br>          BIOS supports non-standard drive types, virtual drive <br>          formatting, bad track formatting and dynamic formatting.<br>          <br>          NOTE 1:  AT&T 6300 - The AT&T 6300 and the AT&T 6300 PLUS <br>          contain system BIOS chips that support the hard disk drive.  <br>          When using a Western Digital XT controller card the system will <br>          not ""boot.""  To solve this problem, one of the ROM BIOS chips <br>          must be disabled.  To disable the BIOS on your Western Digital  <br>          XT controller card, you must remove the jumper at position W-3 <br>          or add a jumper at position R-23 (depending on which model of XT <br>          controller you are using).<br>          <br>                                       -2-<br><br><br>          <br>          NOTE 2:  TANDY 1000 SYSTEMS - The WD1002A-WX1, WD1004A-WX1, <br>          WDXT-GEN2 and the WD1004-27X can be modified to operate in <br>          Tandy 1000 series computers, models SX, TX and the original or <br>          ""A"" version.  These computers utilize an interrupt of 2 (IRQ2) <br>          instead of IRQ5, the IBM standard.  To modify the WD1002A-WX1 or <br>          the WD1002-27X to operate in these systems, you must cut the <br>          etch between pin 1 and pin 2 at jumper position W-7.  Then <br>          solder pin 2 and pin 3 at the position (W-7).  To complete the <br>          modification, a jumper must be added to position 7 of switch S-1 <br>          (2 rows of 8 pins).  PLEASE NOTE THAT ANY PHYSICAL MODIFICATION <br>          TO YOUR WESTERN DIGITAL HARD DISK CONTROLLER VOIDS THE WARRANTY <br>          ON YOUR BOARD.  To modify the WD1004A-WX1, WDXT-GEN2 or the <br>          WD1004-27X for your Tandy 1000 system, a zero ohm resister must <br>          be soldered to jumper position W-27.  This will change the <br>          interrupt from IRQ5 to IRQ2.<br>     <br>     <br>     XT CONTROLLERS FOR FLOPPY DISK DRIVES<br>     <br>          <br>          WD1002A-FOX - Half-slot floppy disk controller for XT or AT  <br>          systems.  Four versions of the board are available:<br>                Feature F001 supports two floppy disk drives.<br>                Feature F002 supports four floppy disk drives and includes <br>                an optional 37-pin control, data and power connector and <br>                an optional 4-pin power connector.<br>                Feature F003 supports two floppy disk drives and includes<br>                a ROM BIOS that will enable your system to recognize <br>                floppy disk drive that may not be supported by your AT<br>                system ROM BIOS.  The optional ROM BIOS will also allow<br>                this controller card to operate high density floppy disk<br>                drives in an XT system.<br>                Feature F004 supports four floppy disk drives and includes<br>                an optional 37-pin control, data and power connector, an<br>                optional 4-pin power connector and a ROM BIOS that will <br>                enable your system to recognize floppy disk drives that <br>                may not be supported by your AT system ROM BIOS.  The <br>                optional ROM BIOS will also allow this controller card to <br>                operate high density floppy disk drives in an XT system.<br>                <br>                <br>                                       -3-<br><br><br><br>                             PRODUCTS FOR AT SYSTEMS<br>     <br>      <br>     HARD DISK CONTROLLERS FOR MFM HARD DISK DRIVES - NO FLOPPY SUPPORT<br>     <br>          <br>          WD1003-WAH, feature F003R - Hard disk controller card with an   <br>          ST506/ST412 interface.  It supports 2 MFM drives with up to 16 <br>          heads and 2048 cylinders, 3:1 interleave.<br>          <br>          WD1003V-MM1, feature F300R - Hard disk controller card with an  <br>          ST506/ST412 interface. It supports 2 MFM drives with up to 16  <br>          heads and 2048 cylinders, 2:1 interleave.  The ""V"" boards can   <br>          run in high speed AT systems (10 to 16 megahertz system speed).<br>          <br>          WD1006-WAH , feature F001R - Hard disk controller card with     <br>          an ST506/ST412 interface.  It supports 2 MFM drives with up to <br>          16 heads and 2048 cylinders, 1:1 interleave.<br>              <br>          WD1006V-MM1, feature F300R - Hard disk controller card with an  <br>          ST506/ST412 interface.  It supports 2 MFM drives with up to 16  <br>          heads and 2048 cylinders, 1:1 interleave and faster data     <br>          transfer due to ""look ahead caching.""  The ""V"" boards can run in <br>          high speed AT systems (10 to 16 megahertz system speed).<br>          <br>          <br>     HARD DISK CONTROLLERS FOR MFM HARD DISK DRIVES AND FLOPPY DISK DRIVES<br>     <br>     <br>          WD1003-WA2, feature F003R - Hard disk controller card with an  <br>          ST506/ST412 interface, full AT form factor.  It supports 2 MFM <br>          drives with up to 16  heads and 2048 cylinders, at 3:1 <br>          interleave and 2 floppy disk drives (360K and 1.2 MB).<br>          <br>          WD1003A-WA2, feature F003R - Hard disk controller card with an <br>          ST506/ST412 interface, full XT form factor.  It supports 2 MFM <br>          drives with up to 16 heads and 2048 cylinders, at 3:1 interleave <br>          and 2 floppy disk drives (360K and 1.2 MB).<br>          <br>          WD1003V-MM2, feature F300R - Hard disk controller card with an  <br>          ST506/ST412 interface.  It supports a maximum of 2 MFM drives <br>          with up to 16  heads and 2048 cylinders at 2:1 interleave, and 2 <br>          floppy disk drives (5-1/4"" 360K, 1.2Mb; 3-1/2"" 720K, 1.44Mb).   <br>          The ""V"" boards can run in high speed AT systems, (10 to 16 <br>          megahertz system speed).<br>          <br>          WD1006V-MM2, feature F300R - Hard disk controller card with an   <br>          ST506/ST412 interface.  It supports a maximum of 2 MFM drives <br>          with up to 16 heads and 2048 cylinders at 1:1 interleave and <br>          faster data transfer due to ""look ahead caching"" and 2 floppy <br>          disk drives (5-1/4"" 360K, 1.2 Mb; 3-1/2"" 720K, 1.44 Mb).  The <br>          ""V"" boards can run in high speed AT systems, (10 to 16 megahertz <br>          system speed).<br>          <br>     <br>                                       -4-<br><br><br>     HARD DISK CONTROLLERS FOR RLL HARD DISK DRIVES - NO FLOPPY SUPPORT <br>     <br>          <br>          WD1003-RAH - Hard disk controller card with an ST506/ST412 <br>          interface.  It supports 2 RLL hard disk drives with up to 16  <br>          heads and 2048 cylinders at 3:1 interleave. <br>          <br>          WD1003V-SR1 - Hard disk controller card with an ST506/ST412 <br>          interface.  It supports a maximum of 2 RLL hard disk drives with <br>          up to 16 heads and 2048 cylinders at 2:1 interleave. The ""V"" <br>          boards can run in high speed AT systems (10 to 16 megahertz <br>          system speed).<br>                Feature F301R includes an optional ROM BIOS that allows <br>                the user to define the drive's parameters. <br>                Feature F300R does not include the ROM BIOS and you must  <br>                use the drive tables on your system's ROM BIOS that must <br>                contain the appropriate drive parameters.<br>                <br>          <br>          WD1006-RAH - Hard disk controller card with an ST506/ST412 <br>          interface.  It supports a maximum of 2 RLL hard disk drives with <br>          up to 16 heads and 2048 cylinders, 1:1 interleave.<br>                Feature F001R includes an optional ROM BIOS that provides  <br>                additional drive parameter tables.<br>                Feature F300R does not include the ROM BIOS and you must   <br>                use the drive tables on your system's ROM BIOS that must <br>                contain the appropriate drive parameters.<br>                <br>          <br>          WD1006V-SR1 - Hard disk controller card with an ST506/ST412     <br>          interface.  It supports 2 RLL hard disk drives with up to 16 <br>          heads and 2048 cylinders, 1:1 interleave and faster data <br>          transfer due to ""look ahead caching.""  The ""V"" boards can run in <br>          high speed AT  systems (10 to 16 megahertz system speed).<br>                Feature F301R includes an optional ROM BIOS that allows  <br>                the user to define the drive's parameters.           <br>                Feature F300R does not include the ROM BIOS and you must  <br>                use the drive tables on your system's ROM BIOS that must <br>                contain the appropriate drive parameters.<br>                <br>                 <br>     <br>     HARD DISK CONTROLLERS FOR RLL HARD DISK DRIVES AND FLOPPY DISK DRIVES<br>     <br>     <br>          WD1003-RA2, feature F001R -  Hard disk controller card with an  <br>          ST506/ST412 interface.  It supports a maximum of 2 RLL hard disk <br>          drives with up to 16  heads and 2048 cylinders, at 3:1 <br>          interleave, and 2 floppy disk drives (5-1/4"" 360K, 1.2 Mb).<br>          <br>          <br>     <br>                                       -5-<br><br>          <br>          WD1003V-SR2 -  Hard disk controller card with an ST506/ST412    <br>          interface.  It supports a maximum of 2 RLL hard disk drives with <br>          up to 16 heads and 2048 cylinders, at 2:1 interleave, and 2 <br>          floppy disk drives, (5-1/4"" 360K, 1.2 Mb; 3-1/2"" 720K, 1.44 <br>          Mb).  The ""V"" boards run in high speed AT systems (10 to 16 <br>          megahertz system speed).<br>                Feature F301R includes an optional ROM BIOS that allows   <br>                the user to define the drive's parameters.<br>                Feature 300R does not include the ROM BIOS and you must<br>                use the drive tables on your system's ROM BIOS that must <br>                contain the appropriate drive parameters.<br>                <br>          <br>          WD1006V-SR2 -  Hard disk controller card with an ST506/ST412   <br>          interface.  It supports a maximum of 2 RLL hard disk drives with <br>          up to 16 heads, 2048 cylinders and 2 floppy disk drives (5-1/4"" <br>          360K, 1.2 Mb; 3-1/2"" 720K, 1.44 Mb).   It also features 1:1 <br>          interleave and faster data transfer due to  ""look ahead <br>          caching"".  The ""V"" boards can run in high speed AT  systems (10 <br>          to 16 megahertz system speed).              <br>                Feature F301R includes an optional ROM BIOS that allows <br>                the user to define the drive's parameters.<br>                Feature 300R does not include the ROM BIOS and you must   <br>                use the drive tables on your system's ROM BIOS that must <br>                contain the appropriate drive parameters.<br>                <br>                 <br>     <br>     HARD DISK CONTROLLERS FOR ESDI HARD DISK DRIVES - NO FLOPPY SUPPORT -<br>     <br>          <br>          WD1007A-WAH - This controller card will support up to 2 ESDI <br>          hard disk drives, 10 megabit per second data transfer rate and <br>          1:1 interleave.        <br>                Feature F301R  includes an optional ROM BIOS with ""shadow <br>                RAM"" that will enable the controller card to interface <br>                with all types of ESDI drives without modifying the system <br>                ROM BIOS.<br>                Feature F300R does not include the ROM BIOS and you must <br>                use the drive tables on your system's ROM BIOS that must <br>                contain the appropriate drive parameters.<br>                <br>          WD1007V-SE1/ME1 - This controller card will support up to 2 ESDI <br>          hard disk drives, 15 megabit per second data transfer rate and <br>          1:1 interleave.  The ""V"" boards can run in high speed AT <br>          systems, (10 to 16 megahertz system speed).<br>                Feature F301R includes an optional ROM BIOS with ""shadow <br>                RAM"" that will enable the controller card to interface <br>                with all types of ESDI drives without modifying the system <br>                ROM BIOS.<br>                Feature F300R does not include the ROM BIOS and you must <br>                use the drive tables on your system's ROM BIOS that must <br>                contain the appropriate drive parameters.<br>                <br>                                       -6-<br>      <br>     HARD DISK CONTROLLERS FOR ESDI HARD DISK DRIVES AND FLOPPY DISK <br>     DRIVES<br>     <br>          <br>          WD1007A-WA2 - This controller card will support up to 2 ESDI <br>          hard disk drives, 10 megabit per second data transfer rate, 1:1 <br>          interleave and 2 floppy disk drives (5-1/4"" 360K, 1.2 Mb; 3-1/2"" <br>          720K, 1.44 Mb).<br>                Feature F301R includes an optional ROM BIOS with ""shadow <br>                RAM"" that will enable the controller card to interface <br>                with all types of ESDI drives without modifying the system <br>                ROM BIOS.<br>                Feature F300R does not include the ROM BIOS and you must <br>                use the drive tables on your system's ROM BIOS that must <br>                contain the appropriate drive parameters.<br>                <br>          <br>          WD1007V-SE2/ME2 - This controller card will support up to 2 ESDI <br>          hard disk drives, 15 megabit per second data transfer rate, 1:1 <br>          interleave and 2 floppy drives (5-1/4"" 360K, 1.2 Mb; 3-1/2"" <br>          720K, 1.44 Mb).  The ""V"" boards can run in high speed AT systems <br>          (10 to 12 megahertz bus speed).<br>                Feature F301R includes an optional ROM BIOS with ""shadow <br>                RAM"" that will enable the controller card to interface <br>                with all types of ESDI drives without modifying the system <br>                ROM BIOS.<br>                Feature F300R does not include the ROM BIOS and you must <br>                use the drive tables on your system's ROM BIOS that must <br>                contain the appropriate drive parameters.<br>                <br>                <br>          WD1007A-WA4 - This controller card will support up to 2 ESDI <br>          hard disk drives, 10 megabit per second data transfer rate, 1:1 <br>          interleave and 2 floppy disk drives (5-1/4"" 360K, 1.2 Mb; 3-1/2"" <br>          720K, 1.44 Mb).  This board also has a serial port and parallel <br>          port.<br>                Feature F301R includes an optional ROM BIOS with ""shadow <br>                RAM"" that will enable the controller card to interface <br>                with all types of ESDI drives without modifying the system <br>                ROM BIOS.<br>                Feature F300R does not include the ROM BIOS and you must <br>                use the drive tables on your system's ROM BIOS that must <br>                contain the appropriate drive parameter. <br>                <br>                <br>                                       -7-<br><br><br>      <br>     HARD DISK CONTROLLERS FOR SCSI HARD DISK DRIVES<br>     <br>          <br>          7000-ASC - A SCSI host adapter that serves as an interface <br>          between the AT bus and the SCSI bus.  All necessary drivers and <br>          receivers are included, permitting direct cable connections to <br>          the SCSI bus through a 50 pin connector and to the AT bus <br>          through two edge connectors.  The 7000-ASC utilizes jumper  <br>          configurable options that enable the address space, DMA channels <br>          and interrupt requests to be selected to suit the end user's <br>          application.  The board also features word data transfer at 4 <br>          megabytes per second (synchronous), an on-board floppy disk <br>          controller and a ROM BIOS.  Please note that the 7000-ASC <br>          operates using standard DOS 3.2 or DOS 3.3 only.<br>          <br>          7000-FASST2 - This SCSI host adapter card provides the same <br>          features as the 7000-ASC plus additional support capabilities <br>          using software developed by Columbia Data Products.  The 7000-<br>          FASST2 will support MS-DOS 3.2-3.3, Compaq DOS 3.31, PC-DOS 4.0, <br>          PC-MOS/386 version 2.1, XENIX, Microsoft Windows, Novell and <br>          Sytos tape backup.<br>          <br>          WDATXT-FASST KIT - An ""unintelligent"" SCSI host adapter that is <br>          compatible with the IBM XT, AT and compatible systems.  It uses <br>          a 50 pin external SCSI bus ""D"" connector with a standard 50 pin <br>          internal SCSI cable.  The WDATXT-FASST can be used as  both a <br>          target and an initiator and it serves as an excellent tool for <br>          SCSI designers.  It also provides a low cost alternative for end-<br>          users desiring to install a SCSI peripheral device such as a <br>          hard disk drive or a tape backup unit. The kit includes an 8-bit <br>          SCSI HBA board, manual, FASST software diskettes and an internal <br>          SCSI cable.<br>          <br>          SYTOS TAPE BACKUP - (Utility for 7000-FASST) - FASST-SYTOS - <br>          FASST version of Sytos tape backup utilities.  MS-DOS <br>          compatible, it runs with FASST software products Revision 3.3+.<br>          <br>          <br>     HARD DISK CONTROLLERS FOR PS/2 MODEL 50, 60, 80 SYSTEMS  <br>     (MICROCHANNEL ARCHITECTURE)<br>     <br>          <br>          WD1006V-MC1, feature F300R - Hard disk controller with an <br>          ST506/ST412 interface for microchannel systems.  It supports 2 <br>          MFM drives with up to 16 heads and 2048 cylinders, 1:1 <br>          interleave and faster data transfer due to ""look ahead <br>          caching.""  The""V"" boards can run in high speed AT systems (10 to <br>          16 megahertz system speed).<br>          <br>     <br>                                       -8-<br><br><br>          <br>          WD1007V-MC1, feature F300R - This controller card will support <br>          up to 2 ESDI hard disk drives, 15 megabit per second transfer <br>          rate and it contains a ROM BIOS with ""shadow RAM"" that will <br>          enable the controller card to interface with all types of ESDI <br>          hard disk drives without modifying the system BIOS.  It uses 1:1 <br>          interleave.  The ""V"" boards can run in high speed AT systems, <br>          (10 to 12 megahertz bus speed).<br>          <br>          <br>     <br>     CONTROLLERS FOR FLOPPY DISK DRIVES ONLY<br>     <br>          <br>          WD1002A-FOX - Half-slot floppy disk controller for XT or AT <br>          systems.  Four versions of the board are available:<br>                Feature F001 supports two floppy disk drives.<br>                Feature F002 supports four floppy disk drives and includes <br>                an optional 37-pin control, data and power connector and <br>                an optional 4-pin power connector.<br>                Feature F003 supports two floppy disk drives and includes <br>                a ROM BIOS that will enable your system to recognize     <br>                floppy disk drives that may not be supported by your AT <br>                system ROM BIOS.  The optional ROM BIOS will also allow <br>                this controller card to operate high density floppy disk<br>                drives in an XT system.<br>                Feature F004 supports four floppy disk drives and includes <br>                an optional 37-pin control, data and power connector, an <br>                optional 4-pin power connector and a ROM BIOS that will <br>                enable your system to recognize floppy disk drives that <br>                may not be supported by your AT system ROM BIOS.  The <br>                optional ROM BIOS will also allow this controller card to <br>                operate high density floppy disk drives in an XT system.<br>                <br><br><br>-- <br>    Prof. L. I mess with this older<br>stuff alot.   Kinda fun.  8)<br><br>     First problem I can forsee is that the ST-251 will not be<br>compadible with that WD card unless it has the right bios rom.  <br><br>    Check the numbers on it.  It should be the only non-smt chip on<br>the board.  Slightly below center, and left.    The bios should read <br>either :     62-000042-015 or<br>             62-000094-0x2<br><br>     If the last 3 digits are 013, you got problems.<br><br><br>    Looks right.   W5 and W7 are factory jumped (with a trace) between<br>pins 1 and 2 to select the primary controller address.<br><br><br>    Looks right.<br>  <br>[art deleted]<br><br><br>      I notice you left out the S1 jumper table settings.   Those are<br>what control what drive the controller thinks it has.   If you have<br>the 62-000042-015 rom, set it like this:<br><br>              5 + +    open<br>              6 + +    open             <br>              7 + +    open        <br>              8 + +    open<br>              4 + +    closed<br>              3 + +    closed<br>              2 + +    open<br>              1 + +    open<br><br>    Note:   those are how WD runs the numbers on the jumper block.<br>Top to bottom.   +'s represent the jumper pins.    Pins 3,4, and 8<br>select the first drive setting (drive 0) and pins 1,2 and 7 select the<br>second drive (drive 1).   <br><br>      If you have the 62-000094 rom, it's a auto-config, and I'll have<br>to look up how to do it... I don't have the big book right here.<br><br><br>      See above.  You might have problems if the S1 jumpers are not<br>right.   Also,  at the risk of being insulting, make sure the cables<br>are on right and good. 8).    On the jumper on the 251, try moving it<br>to the opposite side of the drive.    It's one or the other.   <br>     The narrow data cable goes to J2.   I've thrown it on J3 a few<br>times and banged my head for a day.....<br><br><br>     Dunno.    IBM roms had to be later than 10/27/82.   A quick way<br>to check is to boot dos and run debug.   Enter:<br>       <br>        -d f000:fff5 fffc    (the - is the debug prompt)<br>   <br>    This will return the rom date, if it's of any use.<br><br><br>      If I oversimplified any of the above, I appologize.     It's<br>just hard to know what caliber of person I'm talking to. 8).<br><br>                     -->   Bob Valentine  <--  <br>                  --> ravalent@mailbox.syr.edu <--  <br><br><br><br>From chpp@unitrix.utr.ac.za Mon Apr  5 06:33:46 1993<br>Received: from unitrix.utr.ac.za by ponder (5.61/1.36)<br> id AA16194; Mon, 5 Apr 93 06:32:59 -0500<br>Received: by unitrix.utr.ac.za (Smail3.1.28.1 #1)<br> id m0nfpMA-0001X7C; Mon, 5 Apr 93 13:28 GMT<br>Message-Id: <m0nfpMA-0001X7C@unitrix.utr.ac.za><br>From: chpp@unitrix.utr.ac.za (Prof P. Piacenza)<br>Subject: ST251<br>To: drice@ponder<br>Date: Mon, 5 Apr 1993 13:28:49 +0200 (GMT)<br>X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL11]<br>Mime-Version: 1.0<br>Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII<br>Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit<br>Content-Length: 24559     <br>Status: OR<br><br><br>If you are using a TWISTED 34-way cable then move the jumper <br>on your drive to the neighbouring pins   :8::::::.  Make sure that<br>the twisted cable is for a hard disk (and not a floppy disk) - the<br>coloured stripe (pin 1) should be furthest from the twist.<br><br>This may also help.<br><br><br>                             PRODUCTS FOR XT SYSTEMS<br>     <br>     <br>     HARD DISK CONTROLLERS FOR MFM HARD DISK DRIVES<br>                                  Reference NOTE 1.<br>     <br>          <br>          WD1002A-WX1, feature F300R - Half-slot size hard disk controller <br>          card with an ST506/ST412 interface.  It supports 2 MFM drives <br>          with up to 16 heads and 1024 cylinders and is jumper <br>          configurable for secondary addressing and default drive tables.  <br>          Built in ROM BIOS supports non-standard drive types, virtual <br>          drive formatting, dual drive operation, bad track formatting and <br>          dynamic formatting.  This board features a power connector for <br>          filecard applications and it will also operate in AT systems. <br>          Please note that this controller card will be unavailable from <br>          the manufacturer (Western Digital) after March, 1989.  Reference <br>          NOTE 2.<br>          <br>          WDXT-GEN, feature F300R - Half-slot size hard disk controller <br>          card with an ST506/ST412 interface.  It  supports 2 MFM hard <br>          disk drives with up to 8 heads and 1024 cylinders.  Built-in ROM <br>          BIOS supports non-standard drive types, virtual drive <br>          formatting, dual drive operation, bad track formatting and <br>          dynamic formatting.  Please note that this controller card will <br>          be unavailable from the manufacturer (Western Digital) after <br>          March, 1989.<br>          <br>          WD1004A-WX1, feature F300R - Half-slot size disk controller <br>          card  with an ST506/ST412 interface.  It supports 2 MFM drives <br>          with up to 16 heads and 1024 cylinders and is jumper <br>          configurable for secondary addressing and default drive tables.  <br>          Built in ROM BIOS supports non-standard drive types, virtual <br>          drive formatting, dual drive operation, bad track formatting and <br>          dynamic formatting. It supports 2 MFM hard disk <br>          drives with up to 8 heads and 1024 cylinders.  Built-in ROM BIOS <br>          supports non-standard drive types, virtual drive formatting, <br>          dual drive operation, bad track formatting and dynamic <br>          formatting.  Reference NOTE 2.<br>          <br>          <br>     <br>     HARD DISK CONTROLLERS FOR RLL HARD DISK DRIVES<br>                                  Reference NOTE 2.<br>     <br>          <br>          WD1002-27X, feature F301R - Half-slot size hard disk controller <br>          card with an ST506/ST412 interface.  It supports 2 RLL hard disk <br>          drives with up to 16 heads and 1024 cylinders and is jumper <br>          configurable for secondary addressing and default drive tables.  <br>          Built in ROM BIOS supports non-standard drive types, virtual <br>          drive formatting, dual drive operation, bad track formatting and <br>          dynamic formatting.  This board features a power connector for <br>          filecard applications and it will also operate in AT systems.   <br>          Please note that this controller card will be unavailable from <br>          the manufacturer (Western Digital) after March, 1989.  Reference <br>          NOTE 2.<br>          <br>          WD1002A-27X, feature 300R - Half-slot size hard disk controller <br>          with an ST506/ST412 interface.  It supports 2 RLL drives with up <br>          to 16 heads and 1024 cylinders. Built-in ROM BIOS supports non-<br>          standard drive types, virtual drive formatting, bad track <br>          formatting and dynamic formatting.  Please note that this <br>          controller card will be unavailable from the manufacturer     <br>          (Western Digital) after March, 1989.<br>          <br>          WD1004-27X, feature F301R - Half-slot size hard disk controller  <br>          card with an ST506/ST412 interface.  It supports 2 RLL hard    <br>          disk drives with up to 16 heads and 1024 cylinders and is jumper <br>          configurable for secondary addressing and default drive tables.  <br>          Built in ROM BIOS supports non-standard drive types, virtual    <br>          drive formatting, dual drive operation, bad track formatting     <br>          and dynamic formatting.  This board features a power connection <br>          for filecard applications and it will also operate in AT <br>          systems.  Reference NOTE 2.<br>          <br>          WD1004A-27X, feature F300R - Half-slot size hard disk <br>          controller  with an ST506/ST412 interface.  It supports 2 RLL <br>          drives with up to 16 heads and 1024 cylinders.  Built-in ROM <br>          BIOS supports non-standard drive types, virtual drive <br>          formatting, bad track formatting and dynamic formatting.<br>          <br>          NOTE 1:  AT&T 6300 - The AT&T 6300 and the AT&T 6300 PLUS <br>          contain system BIOS chips that support the hard disk drive.  <br>          When using a Western Digital XT controller card the system will <br>          not ""boot.""  To solve this problem, one of the ROM BIOS chips <br>          must be disabled.  To disable the BIOS on your Western Digital  <br>          XT controller card, you must remove the jumper at position W-3 <br>          or add a jumper at position R-23 (depending on which model of XT <br>          controller you are using).<br>          <br>                                       -2-<br><br><br>          <br>          NOTE 2:  TANDY 1000 SYSTEMS - The WD1002A-WX1, WD1004A-WX1, <br>          WDXT-GEN2 and the WD1004-27X can be modified to operate in <br>          Tandy 1000 series computers, models SX, TX and the original or <br>          ""A"" version.  These computers utilize an interrupt of 2 (IRQ2) <br>          instead of IRQ5, the IBM standard.  To modify the WD1002A-WX1 or <br>          the WD1002-27X to operate in these systems, you must cut the <br>          etch between pin 1 and pin 2 at jumper position W-7.  Then <br>          solder pin 2 and pin 3 at the position (W-7).  To complete the <br>          modification, a jumper must be added to position 7 of switch S-1 <br>          (2 rows of 8 pins).  PLEASE NOTE THAT ANY PHYSICAL MODIFICATION <br>          TO YOUR WESTERN DIGITAL HARD DISK CONTROLLER VOIDS THE WARRANTY <br>          ON YOUR BOARD.  To modify the WD1004A-WX1, WDXT-GEN2 or the <br>          WD1004-27X for your Tandy 1000 system, a zero ohm resister must <br>          be soldered to jumper position W-27.  This will change the <br>          interrupt from IRQ5 to IRQ2.<br>     <br>     <br>     XT CONTROLLERS FOR FLOPPY DISK DRIVES<br>     <br>          <br>          WD1002A-FOX - Half-slot floppy disk controller for XT or AT  <br>          systems.  Four versions of the board are available:<br>                Feature F001 supports two floppy disk drives.<br>                Feature F002 supports four floppy disk drives and includes <br>                an optional 37-pin control, data and power connector and <br>                an optional 4-pin power connector.<br>                Feature F003 supports two floppy disk drives and includes<br>                a ROM BIOS that will enable your system to recognize <br>                floppy disk drive that may not be supported by your AT<br>                system ROM BIOS.  The optional ROM BIOS will also allow<br>                this controller card to operate high density floppy disk<br>                drives in an XT system.<br>                Feature F004 supports four floppy disk drives and includes<br>                an optional 37-pin control, data and power connector, an<br>                optional 4-pin power connector and a ROM BIOS that will <br>                enable your system to recognize floppy disk drives that <br>                may not be supported by your AT system ROM BIOS. It supports 2 MFM <br>          drives with up to 16 heads and 2048 cylinders, at 3:1 interleave <br>          and 2 floppy disk drives (360K and 1.2 MB).<br>          <br>          WD1003V-MM2, feature F300R - Hard disk controller card with an  <br>          ST506/ST412 interface.  It supports a maximum of 2 MFM drives <br>          with up to 16  heads and 2048 cylinders at 2:1 interleave, and 2 <br>          floppy disk drives (5-1/4"" 360K, 1.2Mb; 3-1/2"" 720K, 1.44Mb).   <br>          The ""V"" boards can run in high speed AT systems, (10 to 16 <br>          megahertz system speed).<br>          <br>          WD1006V-MM2, feature F300R - Hard disk controller card with an   <br>          ST506/ST412 interface.  It supports a maximum of 2 MFM drives <br>          with up to 16 heads and 2048 cylinders at 1:1 interleave and <br>          faster data transfer due to ""look ahead caching"" and 2 floppy <br>          disk drives (5-1/4"" 360K, 1.2 Mb; 3-1/2"" 720K, 1.44 Mb).  The <br>          ""V"" boards can run in high speed AT systems, (10 to 16 megahertz <br>          system speed).<br>          <br>     <br>                                       -4-<br><br><br>     HARD DISK CONTROLLERS FOR RLL HARD DISK DRIVES - NO FLOPPY SUPPORT <br>     <br>          <br>          WD1003-RAH - Hard disk controller card with an ST506/ST412 <br>          interface. It supports a maximum of 2 RLL hard disk drives with <br>          up to 16 heads and 2048 cylinders at 2:1 interleave. The ""V"" <br>          boards can run in high speed AT systems (10 to 16 megahertz <br>          system speed).<br>                Feature F301R includes an optional ROM BIOS that allows <br>                the user to define the drive's parameters. <br>                Feature F300R does not include the ROM BIOS and you must  <br>                use the drive tables on your system's ROM BIOS that must <br>                contain the appropriate drive parameters.<br>                <br>          <br>          WD1006-RAH - Hard disk controller card with an ST506/ST412 <br>          interface. It also features 1:1 <br>          interleave and faster data transfer due to  ""look ahead <br>          caching"". The ""V"" boards can run in high speed AT systems <br>          (10 to 12 megahertz bus speed).<br>                Feature F301R includes an optional ROM BIOS with ""shadow <br>                RAM"" that will enable the controller card to interface <br>                with all types of ESDI drives without modifying the system <br>                ROM BIOS.<br>                Feature F300R does not include the ROM BIOS and you must <br>                use the drive tables on your system's ROM BIOS that must <br>                contain the appropriate drive parameters.<br>                <br>                <br>          WD1007A-WA4 - This controller card will support up to 2 ESDI <br>          hard disk drives, 10 megabit per second data transfer rate, 1:1 <br>          interleave and 2 floppy disk drives (5-1/4"" 360K, 1.2 Mb; 3-1/2"" <br>          720K, 1.44 Mb).  This board also has a serial port and parallel <br>          port.<br>                Feature F301R includes an optional ROM BIOS with ""shadow <br>                RAM"" that will enable the controller card to interface <br>                with all types of ESDI drives without modifying the system <br>                ROM BIOS.<br>                Feature F300R does not include the ROM BIOS and you must <br>                use the drive tables on your system's ROM BIOS that must <br>                contain the appropriate drive parameter. <br>                <br>                <br>                                       -7-<br><br><br>      <br>     HARD DISK CONTROLLERS FOR SCSI HARD DISK DRIVES<br>     <br>          <br>          7000-ASC - A SCSI host adapter that serves as an interface <br>          between the AT bus and the SCSI bus.  All necessary drivers and <br>          receivers are included, permitting direct cable connections to <br>          the SCSI bus through a 50 pin connector and to the AT bus <br>          through two edge connectors.  The 7000-ASC utilizes jumper  <br>          configurable options that enable the address space, DMA channels <br>          and interrupt requests to be selected to suit the end user's <br>          application.  The board also features word data transfer at 4 <br>          megabytes per second (synchronous), an on-board floppy disk <br>          controller and a ROM BIOS.  Please note that the 7000-ASC <br>          operates using standard DOS 3.2 or DOS 3.3 only.<br>          <br>          7000-FASST2 - This SCSI host adapter card provides the same <br>          features as the 7000-ASC plus additional support capabilities <br>          using software developed by Columbia Data Products.  The 7000-<br>          FASST2 will support MS-DOS 3.2-3.3, Compaq DOS 3.31, PC-DOS 4.0, <br>          PC-MOS/386 version 2.1, XENIX, Microsoft Windows, Novell and <br>          Sytos tape backup.<br>          <br>          WDATXT-FASST KIT - An ""unintelligent"" SCSI host adapter that is <br>          compatible with the IBM XT, AT and compatible systems.  It uses <br>          a 50 pin external SCSI bus ""D"" connector with a standard 50 pin <br>          internal SCSI cable.  The WDATXT-FASST can be used as  both a <br>          target and an initiator and it serves as an excellent tool for <br>          SCSI designers.  It also provides a low cost alternative for end-<br>          users desiring to install a SCSI peripheral device such as a <br>          hard disk drive or a tape backup unit. The kit includes an 8-bit <br>          SCSI HBA board, manual, FASST software diskettes and an internal <br>          SCSI cable.<br>          <br>          SYTOS TAPE BACKUP - (Utility for 7000-FASST) - FASST-SYTOS - <br>          FASST version of Sytos tape backup utilities.  MS-DOS <br>          compatible, it runs with FASST software products Revision 3.3+.<br>          <br>          <br>     HARD DISK CONTROLLERS FOR PS/2 MODEL 50, 60, 80 SYSTEMS  <br>     (MICROCHANNEL ARCHITECTURE)<br>     <br>          <br>          WD1006V-MC1, feature F300R - Hard disk controller with an <br>          ST506/ST412 interface for microchannel systems.  It supports 2 <br>          MFM drives with up to 16 heads and 2048 cylinders, 1:1 <br>          interleave and faster data transfer due to ""look ahead <br>          caching.""  The""V"" boards can run in high speed AT systems (10 to <br>          16 megahertz system speed).<br>          <br>     <br>                                       -8-<br><br><br>          <br>          WD1007V-MC1, feature F300R - This controller card will support <br>          up to 2 ESDI hard disk drives, 15 megabit per second transfer <br>          rate and it contains a ROM BIOS with ""shadow RAM"" that will <br>          enable the controller card to interface with all types of ESDI <br>          hard disk drives without modifying the system BIOS.  It uses 1:1 <br>          interleave.  The ""V"" boards can run in high speed AT systems, <br>          (10 to 12 megahertz bus speed).<br>          <br>          <br>     <br>     CONTROLLERS FOR FLOPPY DISK DRIVES ONLY<br>     <br>          <br>          WD1002A-FOX - Half-slot floppy disk controller for XT or AT <br>          systems.  Four versions of the board are available:<br>                Feature F001 supports two floppy disk drives.<br>                Feature F002 supports four floppy disk drives and includes <br>                an optional 37-pin control, data and power connector and <br>                an optional 4-pin power connector.<br>                Feature F003 supports two floppy disk drives and includes <br>                a ROM BIOS that will enable your system to recognize     <br>                floppy disk drives that may not be supported by your AT <br>                system ROM BIOS.  The optional ROM BIOS will also allow <br>                this controller card to operate high density floppy disk<br>                drives in an XT system.<br>                Feature F004 supports four floppy disk drives and includes <br>                an optional 37-pin control, data and power connector, an <br>                optional 4-pin power connector and a ROM BIOS that will <br>                enable your system to recognize floppy disk drives that <br>                may not be supported by your AT system ROM BIOS.  The <br>                optional ROM BIOS will also allow this controller card to <br>                operate high density floppy disk drives in an XT system.<br>                <br><br><br>-- <br>    Prof. L. 134	0	"    1. TrueType font files are at least 1/3 larger than their Type-1<br> equivalents.  If you are using a disk compressor, though, be aware<br> that TrueType fonts will compress, whereas Type-1 fonts will not<br> (they are encrypted).<br><br>    2. With a 300 dpi laser printer, the ""artificial bold"" version of a<br> TrueType font is indistingishable from the original, forcing me to<br> install the actual bold (and bold-italic, etc.) variants if I want<br> to use them.  Type-1 PostScript fonts under ATM generate a visually<br> distinct bold variant from the base font.  I realize that the<br> artificial bold font that ATM generates is aesthetically inferior<br> to the hand-generated bold TrueType variant, but it is sufficient<br> for my needs, and not having to install bold variants saves me 50%<br> on disk space (uncompressed).<br>"	"    1. TrueType font files are at least 1/3 larger than their Type-1<br> equivalents.  If you are using a disk compressor, though, be aware<br> that TrueType fonts will compress, whereas Type-1 fonts will not<br> (they are encrypted).<br><br>    2. With a 300 dpi laser printer, the ""artificial bold"" version of a<br> TrueType font is indistingishable from the original, forcing me to<br> install the actual bold (and bold-italic, etc.) variants if I want<br> to use them.  Type-1 PostScript fonts under ATM generate a visually<br> distinct bold variant from the base font.  I realize that the<br> artificial bold font that ATM generates is aesthetically inferior<br> to the hand-generated bold TrueType variant, but it is sufficient<br> for my needs, and not having to install bold variants saves me 50%<br> on disk space (uncompressed).<br>"	W

141	1	"Phone support is quick and competent from many mail order firms, but not so<br>quick and not so competent from others (Gateway included).  But my experience<br>with computer retailers (which is significant) has lead to the conclusion that<br>sales personnel and retail-technical personnel are forbidden to actually learn<br>about the products they sell.  Talk about incompetent!  O.K., so a few percent<br>of their answers are correct, but those salesmen don't even realize how stupid<br>they are.   ...  .......  O.K.  ...I'll settle down now....  .... let me<br>catch my breath.....  ..<br><br>Fact: retail stores never provide a better value in terms of price per product.<br><br>Retail outlets are desirable, however, to those people who aren't interested<br>in learning about computers enough to make their own decisions.  This is fine;<br>for example most of my education about carpeting, wall paper, lawn mowers,<br>microwave ovens, etc. has come from sales personnel.  I assume I must be an<br>idiot.  But I don't care about those things.  I do, however, care about my<br>computer - i.e. I demand features and performance, and I'll be damned if I'll<br>pay some high-school drop out commission on an over-rated, over-priced system<br>and in the process be subjected to his distorted B.S.<br><br>G.L." 146	0	"I have (had) several problems with the card.<br>- Applications crashed when moving the mouse (VGA mode). Fixed by removing<br>  the line STACKS=0,0 from config.sys. The default value STACKS=9,256<br>  does just fine.<br>- Random white pixels all over the screen when moving the mouse, in a<br>  256 color graphical mode (the hardware cursor modes). Fixed by turning<br>  off the hardware scroll (""24xmode scrolloff"") before entering the graphics<br>  mode. This also fixed the problem of the windowed DOS boxes under windows.<br>  With the hardware scroll enabled, applications write garbage outside the<br>  window.<br>- The screensavers do not remove the cursor in 256 color modes (hardware<br>  cursor). I don't know if this is a windows problem or a driver problem.<br>  Clearly there should be two types of cursor removing functions: a remove-<br>  for-draw, which can be ignored for hardware cursors and a remove-<br>  unconditionally. Do other cards with hardware cursors have the same problem?<br>- The VESA driver does not support the 640x480x16M TrueColor mode. (Universal<br>  VESA drivers do not run at all).<br>"	"I have (had) several problems with the card.<br>- Applications crashed when moving the mouse (VGA mode). Fixed by removing<br>  the line STACKS=0,0 from config.sys. The default value STACKS=9,256<br>  does just fine.<br>- Random white pixels all over the screen when moving the mouse, in a<br>  256 color graphical mode (the hardware cursor modes). Fixed by turning<br>  off the hardware scroll (""24xmode scrolloff"") before entering the graphics<br>  mode. This also fixed the problem of the windowed DOS boxes under windows.<br>  With the hardware scroll enabled, applications write garbage outside the<br>  window.<br>- The screensavers do not remove the cursor in 256 color modes (hardware<br>  cursor). I don't know if this is a windows problem or a driver problem.<br>  Clearly there should be two types of cursor removing functions: a remove-<br>  for-draw, which can be ignored for hardware cursors and a remove-<br>  unconditionally. Do other cards with hardware cursors have the same problem?<br>- The VESA driver does not support the 640x480x16M TrueColor mode. (Universal<br>  VESA drivers do not run at all).<br>"	H

148	0	"(Taken from one of my lecture notes)<br><br> "" ...  The alternative approach (to CISC),<br> which has been adopted by many in<br> recent years, has come to be known as ""RISC"": the Reduced<br> Instruction Set Computer.  This can be characterised simply as<br> ""Simpler is Faster""; by simplifying the design (e.g.  by reducing<br> the variety of instructions & addressing modes), the hardware can be<br> designed to run faster.  Even at the cost of needing more<br> instructions, the same task can be done more quickly by the simpler,<br> faster design.<br><br> A typical RISC processor will:<br><br>    o provide a large number of registers (e.g.  32);<br><br>    o perform all data operations on registers;<br><br>    o provide few addressing modes (e.g. immediate or 'register + offset');<br><br>    o only allow load & store operations to access memory;<br><br>    o only use a few instruction formats;<br><br>    o only support a few data types (e.g. integer, unsigned, floating)."	"(Taken from one of my lecture notes)<br><br> "" ...  The alternative approach (to CISC),<br> which has been adopted by many in<br> recent years, has come to be known as ""RISC"": the Reduced<br> Instruction Set Computer.  This can be characterised simply as<br> ""Simpler is Faster""; by simplifying the design (e.g.  by reducing<br> the variety of instructions & addressing modes), the hardware can be<br> designed to run faster.  Even at the cost of needing more<br> instructions, the same task can be done more quickly by the simpler,<br> faster design.<br><br> A typical RISC processor will:<br><br>    o provide a large number of registers (e.g.  32);<br><br>    o perform all data operations on registers;<br><br>    o provide few addressing modes (e.g. immediate or 'register + offset');<br><br>    o only allow load & store operations to access memory;<br><br>    o only use a few instruction formats;<br><br>    o only support a few data types (e.g. integer, unsigned, floating)."	H	
149	0	"In a nutshell the problem is that I lose the first 0.625 inches of<br>information from my left margin, be it white space or TrueType font<br>output, and margins are not preserved on subsequent pages past the<br>first.<br><br>WordPerfect had a workaround consisting of using the ""Default"" location<br>for the printers instead of ""Tractor"" or ""Manual"".  They have also filed<br>this as a bug and are continuing to investigate it.<br><br>MS Write, of course, has no problem with these printer drivers, proving that<br>Microsoft knows something the rest of us don't!  Are you surprised?  I'm<br>not.<br><br>Publish It!/WIN is still investigating this problem, and while I was consider-<br>my options (rejecting the one about buying an $800 DTP package, for *surely*<br>they wouldn't have this problem, right?) I stumbled onto a global workaround.<br><br>WORKAROUND<br>----------<br>Go into the Windows 3.1 control panel, select printers, select your Citizen<br>printer driver, select SETUP, and select a custom size of 850 x 1132.  Like<br>magic, all of your problems will go away.<br><br>Ask me no questions and I'll tell you no lies!<br><br>-- Mike<br><br><br>------------------------------------------------------------------------<br>Disclaimer: My opinions do not necessarily reflect those of my employer.<br>========================================================================"	"In a nutshell the problem is that I lose the first 0.625 inches of<br>information from my left margin, be it white space or TrueType font<br>output, and margins are not preserved on subsequent pages past the<br>first.<br><br>WordPerfect had a workaround consisting of using the ""Default"" location<br>for the printers instead of ""Tractor"" or ""Manual"".  They have also filed<br>this as a bug and are continuing to investigate it.<br><br>MS Write, of course, has no problem with these printer drivers, proving that<br>Microsoft knows something the rest of us don't!  Are you surprised?  I'm<br>not.<br><br>Publish It!/WIN is still investigating this problem, and while I was consider-<br>my options (rejecting the one about buying an $800 DTP package, for *surely*<br>they wouldn't have this problem, right?) I stumbled onto a global workaround.<br><br>WORKAROUND<br>----------<br>Go into the Windows 3.1 control panel, select printers, select your Citizen<br>printer driver, select SETUP, and select a custom size of 850 x 1132.  Like<br>magic, all of your problems will go away.<br><br>Ask me no questions and I'll tell you no lies!<br><br>-- Mike<br><br><br>------------------------------------------------------------------------<br>Disclaimer: My opinions do not necessarily reflect those of my employer.<br>========================================================================"

165	1	"I thought this was a neat feature until I noticed that<br>when an image is re-sized, the scanning frequency is<br>necessarily changed.  This causes digital multiscan<br>monitors like my MAG MX17F to get confused as to which<br>mode to use if the frequency gets too far from the<br>standard selections.  For this reason, I use the<br>""factory defaults"" for position/size on the ATI card<br>and adjust each mode individually (only the first time)<br>at the monitor.  The MAG (and many other multiscan<br>monitors) has (have) the ability to recall these settings<br>the next time each mode is ""detected"".<br>-- <br><br>=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-="	"I thought this was a neat feature until I noticed that<br>when an image is re-sized, the scanning frequency is<br>necessarily changed. 173	0	"<br>  I had the same problem.  At first, I thought it was the video driver and <br>  made sure I had the most current drivers, because the problem was most<br>  evident at SVGA resolution modes.  It didn't help and after a bit of<br>  experimentation, determined that the problem existed in standard VGA<br>  resolution mode. It was just much less noticeable.<br>  <br>  My mouse was an older MS serial version I bought second hand in 1990. It<br>  worked just fine in DOS and DOS based graphic applications.  On the <br>  guess that the problem was with the resolution of the mouse, I borrowed<br>  a new mouse (a MS bus model) and tried it.  That solved the problem.<br>  So, if your mouse is old, you may want to try replacing it for a newer<br>  one.<br>  <br><br><br>-- <br>signoff"	"<br>  I had the same problem. And how much would it cost?<br><br>Along those lines, what kind of transfer rate could I see with my IDE HD's if I<br>were to buy the top-of-the-line IDE caching controller for my 200Mb, 15ms HD?<br>And how much would it cost?<br><br>I actually have a PAS-16, and could (what a waste I guess it would be...) hook<br>up a SCSI HD through it's SCSI port which yields an optimum of 690Kb/sec.<br>Actually, I have a borrowed 12ms Fujitsu HD hooked up through it now (and<br>own the Trantor HD drivers for the PAS-16 SCSI port). 177	1	"I recently purchased a CH Flightstick.  There aren't any suction cups and<br>no tension adjusters but otherwise it seems to be an excellent joystick. <br>I'm currently using it for the Wing Commander series and Red Baron.  Works<br>quite well.  The large base does not require a steadying hand and so<br>leaves it free.  The buttons provide good tactile response (you can hear<br>and feel them well).  There are other models made by CH that can go up or<br>down in features.<br><br>For price comparison Gravis analogue joysticks sell for ~$35.00 here<br>compared to the $45.00 I paid for a CH Flightstick.  I think the extra<br>$10.00 is worth it just in feel.  Best thing to do is to ask a salesperson<br>to let you try them out or at least feel it before you buy.<br><br>Just another note, analogue joysticks are best for flightsims or something<br>that needs sensitive touch.  If you're only playing games such as Castle<br>Wolfenstein or some other game that only uses digital input (ie. only up,<br>down, left, etc. instead of 'how much right') you might want to look into<br>a Gravis gamepad.  They look like a Nintendo control pad but I don't know<br>much beyond that."	"I recently purchased a CH Flightstick. 179	1	"don't believe everything you are told.  I can tell you that mixing them <br>between 'banks' ok, and I can't see why mixing in one bank is not unless <br>they are of different speeds ( e.g. mixing of 60ns and 100ns SIMMs in one <br>bank ).  The two only differ in the type of chips it uses.  Assuming that <br>the SIMMS are 1Mx9 ( 9 bit wide ), here is the two equivalent <br>configuration.  The 3-chip SIMM uses two 4-bit wide 4Mbit (1M of 4-bit <br>nibbles ) and one 1-bit wide 1Mbit chip ( for a total of 9-bit wide 1Mbyte <br>).  The 9-bit SIMM uses nine 1-bit wide 1Mbit chips.  These are equivalent <br>because of the way that it is 'pinned' on the SIMM board.  At the SIMM <br>interface, they both act as 9-bit wide 1MByte SIMMS ( 2*4+1=9*1 ).  [sorry <br>if too techie for ya].<br><br><br>MG>>  Similarly, one cannot plug in two 1MB SIMMs and one 4MB SIMMs to <br>gi<br>MG>> the system a total of 6 MEG. Why is that so ?? If my system supports<br>MG>> of 8 MEG (it has 8 SIMM slots), can I plug in 4 4MB SIMMs to give my<br>MG>> 16MB ??<br><br>That sounds correct.  the problem is that if your computer takes 9-bit <br>wide SIMMs, you can not mix different sizes in one bank.  Why you ask?  <br>Simple,  if you understand why there is banks.  Assuming you have a 32-bit <br>CPU ( 386DX or 486 ), the data bus (e.g. the mechanism to retrieve data <br>from memory ) is 32-bits wide, so the computer expects to see 32 bits when <br>it asks for data.  To get that bandwidth ( 32-bit wide ), the motherboard <br>links 4 1Mx9 ( one bit is not data, but parity, so I will ignore that in <br>this simple explaination ) to get 32bits [ (9-1)*4=32 bits ].  That means <br>that a SIMM in a bank stores only 1/4 of the 32 bit wide data.  If you <br>have a 16-bit bus, two 1Mx9 SIMMs are linked together to get 16-bit wide <br>data, which is the reason why 286 banks are 2 SIMMs wide, and 32-bit banks <br>are 4 SIMMs wide.  If your computer required 1Mx36 ( e.g. 32-bit wide data <br>with 4 parity bits, used in some PS/2s and ASTs ), you could upgrade by <br>one SIMM at a time.<br><br>Hope that this message is not over your head, but the answer to your <br>question was not simple.  I could of just said, 'because I said so.'<br><br>-rdd    <br><br>---<br> . WinQwk 2.0b#0 . Unregistered Evaluation Copy<br> * KMail 2.95d W-NET HQ, hal9k.ann-arbor.mi.us, +1 313 663 4173 or 3959<br>                                                  "	"don't believe everything you are told.  I can tell you that mixing them <br>between 'banks' ok, and I can't see why mixing in one bank is not unless <br>they are of different speeds ( e.g. mixing of 60ns and 100ns SIMMs in one <br>bank ).  The two only differ in the type of chips it uses.  Assuming that <br>the SIMMS are 1Mx9 ( 9 bit wide ), here is the two equivalent <br>configuration.  The 3-chip SIMM uses two 4-bit wide 4Mbit (1M of 4-bit <br>nibbles ) and one 1-bit wide 1Mbit chip ( for a total of 9-bit wide 1Mbyte <br>).  The 9-bit SIMM uses nine 1-bit wide 1Mbit chips.  These are equivalent <br>because of the way that it is 'pinned' on the SIMM board.  At the SIMM <br>interface, they both act as 9-bit wide 1MByte SIMMS ( 2*4+1=9*1 ).  [sorry <br>if too techie for ya].<br><br><br>MG>>  Similarly, one cannot plug in two 1MB SIMMs and one 4MB SIMMs to <br>gi<br>MG>> the system a total of 6 MEG. Why is that so ?? If my system supports<br>MG>> of 8 MEG (it has 8 SIMM slots), can I plug in 4 4MB SIMMs to give my<br>MG>> 16MB ??<br><br>That sounds correct.  the problem is that if your computer takes 9-bit <br>wide SIMMs, you can not mix different sizes in one bank.  Why you ask?  <br>Simple,  if you understand why there is banks.  Assuming you have a 32-bit <br>CPU ( 386DX or 486 ), the data bus (e.g. the mechanism to retrieve data <br>from memory ) is 32-bits wide, so the computer expects to see 32 bits when <br>it asks for data.  To get that bandwidth ( 32-bit wide ), the motherboard <br>links 4 1Mx9 ( one bit is not data, but parity, so I will ignore that in <br>this simple explaination ) to get 32bits [ (9-1)*4=32 bits ].  That means <br>that a SIMM in a bank stores only 1/4 of the 32 bit wide data.  If you <br>have a 16-bit bus, two 1Mx9 SIMMs are linked together to get 16-bit wide <br>data, which is the reason why 286 banks are 2 SIMMs wide, and 32-bit banks <br>are 4 SIMMs wide.  If your computer required 1Mx36 ( e.g. 32-bit wide data <br>with 4 parity bits, used in some PS/2s and ASTs ), you could upgrade by <br>one SIMM at a time.<br><br>Hope that this message is not over your head, but the answer to your <br>question was not simple.  I could of just said, 'because I said so.'<br><br>-rdd    <br><br>---<br> . WinQwk 2.0b#0 . Unregistered Evaluation Copy<br> * KMail 2.95d W-NET HQ, hal9k.ann-arbor.mi.us, +1 313 663 4173 or 3959<br>                                                  "		
180	1	-- Michael<br>	-- Michael<br>

192	1	"There are two 'problems':<br>(1) the BIOS TOD routine which updates the BIOS clock uses only 1 bit<br>    for day increment, so a second wrapping of the clock past midnight<br>    will get lost if no one calls the BIOS to read the clock in the<br>    meantime, and<br>(2) the BIOS resets the day wrap indicator on the first 'get date'<br>    call from ANYBODY (after the wrap indicator has been set). So<br>    unless the first BIOS 'get date' call after midnight is done by<br>    the DOS 'kernel' (which is the only part of DOS which knows how to<br>    increment the date, the day wrap indication is normally lost.<br>My guess is that Kevin's 'menu' system uses BIOS calls to read the<br>clock (in order to display the time), and is hence the entity which<br>causes the day wrap indication to get lost. Even if the 'menu' system<br>'notices' the day 'wrap' (which I think is indicated by a non-zero<br>value in AL), there really isn't any particularly good way to tell DOS<br>about it, so that DOS can update the day. The menu system 'should' use<br>DOS calls to get the time, which would cause the DOS 'kernel' to do<br>the BIOS call, and the wrap indicator would hence be processed<br>properly.  Possibly, though, the 'menu' system can't easily use DOS<br>calls for time, because DOS is not reentrant, and perhaps time<br>incrementing ofters occur while the 'menu' system is 'inside' some<br>other DOS call."	"There are two 'problems':<br>(1) the BIOS TOD routine which updates the BIOS clock uses only 1 bit<br>    for day increment, so a second wrapping of the clock past midnight<br>    will get lost if no one calls the BIOS to read the clock in the<br>    meantime, and<br>(2) the BIOS resets the day wrap indicator on the first 'get date'<br>    call from ANYBODY (after the wrap indicator has been set). So<br>    unless the first BIOS 'get date' call after midnight is done by<br>    the DOS 'kernel' (which is the only part of DOS which knows how to<br>    increment the date, the day wrap indication is normally lost.<br>My guess is that Kevin's 'menu' system uses BIOS calls to read the<br>clock (in order to display the time), and is hence the entity which<br>causes the day wrap indication to get lost. Even if the 'menu' system<br>'notices' the day 'wrap' (which I think is indicated by a non-zero<br>value in AL), there really isn't any particularly good way to tell DOS<br>about it, so that DOS can update the day. The menu system 'should' use<br>DOS calls to get the time, which would cause the DOS 'kernel' to do<br>the BIOS call, and the wrap indicator would hence be processed<br>properly.  Possibly, though, the 'menu' system can't easily use DOS<br>calls for time, because DOS is not reentrant, and perhaps time<br>incrementing ofters occur while the 'menu' system is 'inside' some<br>other DOS call."

The only downside is that now I have to order another computer.<br><br>I would really like to try Gateway again, I'm just very turned off by the<br>prospect of having to try and get through to Customer Service or Tech Support<br>again...  I think their products are great for the most part, but I'm<br>beginning to wonder if the savings are worth the potential aggravation.<br>Are other mail order companies as difficult to contact?  I know Gateway is<br>booming, and for good reason, but I don't know if I can take it again.<br>Oh well, I feel better now...<br>"	" 1 - Ordered a DX2/50 w/ Ultrastor 34F Local Bus HD controller<br> 2 - Receive system 10 days after ordering (Happy)<br> 3 - Discover Ultrastor 14F ISA HD Controller inside (unhappy)<br> 4 - Call Gateway, receive the correct controller in 5 days <br>  (getting happier)<br> 5 - New controller doesn't work (unhappy again)<br> 6 - Call Gateway again, get another controller in 5 more days<br>   (cooling off, the end is in sight)<br> 7 - This controller doesn't work either, motherboard is bad<br>  (VERY unhappy)<br><br>Gateway's solution:  They will order me a new motherboard (5 more days)<br> and have on-site service install it for me.<br>BUT, I have to take a day off of work because the service people<br>only work 9-5 M-f.  I say, no way I've already blown about 20 hours<br>with this, about 10 of them on hold and I don't have the time or $$<br>to take a day off work.  Also, my 30 day return period is almost over and<br>I've only been able to use the thin for about 10 minutes.  So, the whole <br>thing is going back.  <br>  I was extremely upset when I began this post because the support rep told me<br>that I would have to pay shipping not only for the returned system, but also<br>the two hard drive controllers they had sent me.  Fortunately, I just spoke<br>to customer service and they are going to have UPS come and pick everything<br>up gratis. The only downside is that now I have to order another computer.<br><br>I would really like to try Gateway again, I'm just very turned off by the<br>prospect of having to try and get through to Customer Service or Tech Support<br>again...  I think their products are great for the most part, but I'm<br>beginning to wonder if the savings are worth the potential aggravation.<br>Are other mail order companies as difficult to contact?  I know Gateway is<br>booming, and for good reason, but I don't know if I can take it again.<br>Oh well, I feel better now...<br>"
