201	1	"Several problems:<br><br>1) The ad specified 16.7 million colors at 640x480 resolution with 1MB<br>   of VRAM, which is what I have. This color depth is NOT SUPPORTED<br>   with video BIOS version 1.00 and drivers version 1.01. A max of 65K<br>   colors are supported at 640x800 and 800x600 resolutions with 1MB<br>   VRAM.<br><br>2) With the 65K color choice I notice two minor irritations:<br><br>   a) Under NDW, when an entry in a list is highlighted (such as in an<br>      Open menu) and then is deselected, a faint vertical line often<br>      remains where the left edge of the highlighted rectangle used to<br>      be.<br><br>   b) With Word for Windows, when you use shading in a table, the<br>      display shows the INVERSE of the shading; for example, if you<br>      shade the cell as 10%, the display is 90% (the printout is OK).<br><br>3) The big killer bug is using the Borland C++ Integrated Development<br>   Environment. The problem occurs when you click on the Turbo Debugger<br>   icon (or use the Debugger option in the Run command), and the<br>   debugger application goes to VGA character mode (as it is designed<br>   to do). The screen goes haywire, and is largely unreadable. The<br>   Turbo Debugger display is all garbled.<br><br>   Through trial and error, I have found that when the disrupted screen<br>   is displayed you should do [Alt-Spacebar] followed by the letter<br>   ""R"". This instructs Turbo Debugger to refresh the screen, and it<br>   does this satisfactorily. I wish I didn't have to do this.<br><br>   The bug is more than with the Diamond drivers. The same disruptive<br>   behavior happens with the standard VGA driver that comes with<br>   Windows. There must be something in the video card that mishandles<br>   the VGA mode.<br>   <br>   The problem is not my monitor. The same bug shows up when I use<br>   another monitor in place of my usual one.<br><br>I still like this video card, and am hoping its problems will be<br>remedied (they do offer a 5 year warranty).<br>"	"Several problems:<br><br>1) The ad specified 16.7 million colors at 640x480 resolution with 1MB<br>   of VRAM, which is what I have. This color depth is NOT SUPPORTED<br>   with video BIOS version 1.00 and drivers version 1.01. A max of 65K<br>   colors are supported at 640x800 and 800x600 resolutions with 1MB<br>   VRAM.<br><br>2) With the 65K color choice I notice two minor irritations:<br><br>   a) Under NDW, when an entry in a list is highlighted (such as in an<br>      Open menu) and then is deselected, a faint vertical line often<br>      remains where the left edge of the highlighted rectangle used to<br>      be.<br><br>   b) With Word for Windows, when you use shading in a table, the<br>      display shows the INVERSE of the shading; for example, if you<br>      shade the cell as 10%, the display is 90% (the printout is OK).<br><br>3) The big killer bug is using the Borland C++ Integrated Development<br>   Environment. The problem occurs when you click on the Turbo Debugger<br>   icon (or use the Debugger option in the Run command), and the<br>   debugger application goes to VGA character mode (as it is designed<br>   to do). The screen goes haywire, and is largely unreadable. The<br>   Turbo Debugger display is all garbled.<br><br>   Through trial and error, I have found that when the disrupted screen<br>   is displayed you should do [Alt-Spacebar] followed by the letter<br>   ""R"". This instructs Turbo Debugger to refresh the screen, and it<br>   does this satisfactorily. I wish I didn't have to do this.<br><br>   The bug is more than with the Diamond drivers. The same disruptive<br>   behavior happens with the standard VGA driver that comes with<br>   Windows. There must be something in the video card that mishandles<br>   the VGA mode.<br>   <br>   The problem is not my monitor. The same bug shows up when I use<br>   another monitor in place of my usual one.<br><br>I still like this video card, and am hoping its problems will be<br>remedied (they do offer a 5 year warranty).<br>"		
202	1	"As promised, here are the summary of opinions on DoubleDisk Gold v.6.0.<br>People seem to be quite happy with the product. There is no much of<br>opinion on how good it is compared to the industry leader Stacker 3.0.<br>(Superstor Pro is not considered since it is slower than Stacker although<br>just as reliable - BYTE Magazine's conclusion ;-) ), so it's hard to make<br>any decision to go with Stacker or with DoubleDisk Gold v6.0. <br>However, it seems that at $39.95, it is quite a buy.<br><br>Buddy Christyono<br>buddy@optics.ece.wisc.edu<br>-------------------------------------------------------------------------<br>summary of replies<br>-------------------------------------------------------------------------<br>Hello Buddy,<br><br>I do not have DD Gold 6.0 experience.  I just ordered it.  I currently have<br>DD 2.3 (the last version).  I am very pleased with its performance.<br><br>Here is my suggestion...<br><br>1)  If you do not have any compression software currently, I would go with<br> DOS 6.0's compression.  All the discussion on the net indicates that<br> for $50 you get the compression (built into the OS), plus the other<br> utilities that you would pay way more than $50 for.  Besides, you <br> are now at DOS6.0 (whatever that means...)<br><br>2)  If you have DoubleDisk 2.3 already (like I do), the cost is $29.95<br> for the upgrade.  After thinking about it and asking the net, I<br> decided that I could not go wrong with the update cost!<br> I have never suffered from performance of DD.  I have a 12ms HD with<br> large SW packages in both compressed and uncompressed format.  It<br> works great.  Not delays.  I think the ""A"" is better than ""B"" <br> arguements are a lot of bunk... they are all comparable in performance.<br> I am looking forward to being able to ""LOADHIGH"" the DD sw.  That<br> has been an annoyance.<br><br>3)  If you have Stacker, et.al. currently, I would not see it worth the<br> effort to upgrade.<br><br>Just my $.02 ...<br><br>Regards,<br>Mark Bagdy<br>----------------------------------------------------------------<br>Buddy,<br><br>I got the same mailer. About 2 weeks ago I got DDG and installed it. The<br>documentation was, in my opinion, easy to follow. I used the automatic<br>installation (not the custom) and everything went smoothly.<br><br>There were some specific instructions on a readme file for dealing with 386max<br>& QEMM. DDG has an uninstall (unlike DOS6.0) if you need it. My system has a<br>203Mb hard drive. before installing DDG I had ~5Mb free. After DDG I had<br>~197Mb free. Pretty good statistics considering that my 8Mb permanent windows<br>swap file stayed on the uncompressed portion (along with other drivers and<br>such).<br><br>I have had no problems whatsoever. I have noticed no slowdown (other than it<br>takes a little longer to boot) either in windows or dos. So far I am a very<br>happy camper.<br><br>-Bruce<br>-- <br>  Bruce F. Steinke                    | ""Never know when you're going to<br>  bsteinke@dsd.es.com                 |  need a good piece of rope.""<br>  Software Technical Support Engineer |               Sam Gamgee<br>  Evans & Sutherland Computer Corp.   |      <My mail, My Opinions><br>---------------------------------------------------------------------------<br><br> I have been using DoubleDisk Gold for a little more than a month on<br>a 486DX 33Mhz, 120MB Seagate drive, running DOS & Windows in 386 enhanced<br>mode.<br> I ran some tests and concluded that the speed of a DoubleDisk drive<br>with a drive read cache is about equal to the bare drive without a cache.<br> I have no complaints about reliability.  It was very easy to install.<br>The only problem I had was with Castle Wolfenstein 3-D.  I assumed the game<br>was trying to bypass DOS disk access and moved the game to the non-compressed<br>region of the disk.  Since then the game has never given me a problem. <br>There was never any damage to the DoubleDisk drive.<br> Compression performance for the whole disk has held steady <br>around 1.8:1.  This is lower than expected but about 20% (size) of my files <br>are compressed image files and some large zip files.  <br><br>If you have any more specific questions let me know.<br>Dan<br>---------------------------------------------------------------------------<br><br>I bought it an have been happy with it.  I use it on both MFM and IDE 40<br>MB drives.  I was using DoubleDisk before Gold came out.  That is the<br>same product MSDOS 6.0 is shipping with.  No problems with either<br>product.<br>"	"As promised, here are the summary of opinions on DoubleDisk Gold v.6.0.<br>People seem to be quite happy with the product. 216	0	"My current home project is to build a huge paddle keyboard for a <br>physically handicapped relative of mine.  My goal is for this keyboard<br>to look exactly like an AT sytle keyboard to its host system.<br>This will be a highly endowed keyboard with a Little PCL from Z World<br>at its heart.  The only thing I lack is detailed information on the<br>hardware signaling that the 486 (with  Windows 3.1  and DOS 5.0) will be <br>expecting.  My project is independant of Windows, my hope is that some of<br>you fellow Window's users/programmers will recognize what I need and be <br>willing to point me in the right direction. <br><br>I have The Winn L. Rosch Hardware Bible (2nd edition).  The HB gives<br>most (if not all) of the information I will need concerning scan codes <br>and even a wire diagram for the PS/2 style connector I will need, but it <br>leaves a number of important questions unanswered.<br>1.  Is it synchronous or asynchronous serial communication?  I'm<br>    guessing synchronous since the host is providing a clock.  In either<br>    event, how is the data framed?<br>2.  Is it half-duplex or truly one way?  I'm guessing half-duplex<br>    since the host can turn LEDs on and off.<br>3.  Are there any chipsets available for communicating with the ""AT<br>    keyboard standard"" (other than by cannibalizing a real keyboard)?<br><br>If anyone knows of a book or article (or any other written source of<br>information) on the above, please advise me at gamet@erg.sri.com.<br>Whatever I do it must be safe for I cannot afford to replace the 486 in<br>the event of a booboo.<br><br>Thank you for your time.<br>Danke fuer Ihre Zeit."	"My current home project is to build a huge paddle keyboard for a <br>physically handicapped relative of mine.  My goal is for this keyboard<br>to look exactly like an AT sytle keyboard to its host system.<br>This will be a highly endowed keyboard with a Little PCL from Z World<br>at its heart.  The only thing I lack is detailed information on the<br>hardware signaling that the 486 (with  Windows 3.1  and DOS 5.0) will be <br>expecting.  My project is independant of Windows, my hope is that some of<br>you fellow Window's users/programmers will recognize what I need and be <br>willing to point me in the right direction. <br><br>I have The Winn L. Rosch Hardware Bible (2nd edition).  The HB gives<br>most (if not all) of the information I will need concerning scan codes <br>and even a wire diagram for the PS/2 style connector I will need, but it <br>leaves a number of important questions unanswered.<br>1.  Is it synchronous or asynchronous serial communication?  I'm<br>    guessing synchronous since the host is providing a clock.  In either<br>    event, how is the data framed?<br>2.  Is it half-duplex or truly one way?  I'm guessing half-duplex<br>    since the host can turn LEDs on and off.<br>3.  Are there any chipsets available for communicating with the ""AT<br>    keyboard standard"" (other than by cannibalizing a real keyboard)?<br><br>If anyone knows of a book or article (or any other written source of<br>information) on the above, please advise me at gamet@erg.sri.com.<br>Whatever I do it must be safe for I cannot afford to replace the 486 in<br>the event of a booboo.<br><br>Thank you for your time.<br>Danke fuer Ihre Zeit."

Fire up gcc to compile libc and kernel at the<br> same time running X11R5.<br><br><br> Bad memory, bad motherboard, bad cache.<br><br><br> change wait state of RAM.<br> turn off turbo.<br> change bus speed<br> swap RAM.<br>"	"<br> Linux + gcc. 225	1	"Too right it does!<br><br><br>The --VERY VERY FIRST-- thing you do is make sure that --ALL-- files on<br>the floppies that you can currently read in the drive, which aren't<br>already on your HD or another floppy (if you have -two- floppy drives)<br>get copied to your HD (and/or to a floppy in your other drive).<br><br>If you don't do this before fixing the alignment problem you have kissd<br>those files goodbye.  (Well, you can -try- to re-misalign the drive back<br>to read your floppies, but don't count on be able to do so!)<br><br>Generally, head alignment is something I'd only trust to a good repair<br>shop (though there are/have been DIY guides)."	"Too right it does!<br><br><br>The --VERY VERY FIRST-- thing you do is make sure that --ALL-- files on<br>the floppies that you can currently read in the drive, which aren't<br>already on your HD or another floppy (if you have -two- floppy drives)<br>get copied to your HD (and/or to a floppy in your other drive).<br><br>If you don't do this before fixing the alignment problem you have kissd<br>those files goodbye.  (Well, you can -try- to re-misalign the drive back<br>to read your floppies, but don't count on be able to do so!)<br><br>Generally, head alignment is something I'd only trust to a good repair<br>shop (though there are/have been DIY guides)."

233	0	"Some background:  I have a Leading Edge 486sx25 with Phoenix BIOS.  When I  <br>first got it it had 4Mg of memory.  It ran windows fine (not too many  <br>GPF's).  Then, a couple of weekends ago, I installed Lotus 123 for windows  <br>(with ATM), a game card and an additional 4  1Mg SIMMS.  The Leading edge  <br>machine is kind of strange, in that it has the IDE controler built into  <br>the motherboard, the CPU is actually on a sparate board that plugs into  <br>the motherboard and the SIMMS it uses are Macintosh SIMMS! Apparently I  <br>was told that the Leading Edge had the parity bit built into the mother  <br>board.  The original 4Mg 80ns SIMMS where of the 2 chip variety from  <br>SAMSUNG, and the ones I installed are 8 chip SIMMS. They are recognized  <br>fine by the BIOS RAM check. The game card is a generic $20 gamecard.<br><br>The reason why I mention the hardware like this is that sometimes  <br>rebooting the machine using the reset button or ctl-alt-del still leaves  <br>the machine kind of flaky, but turning it on and off doesn't. <br><br>I haven't tried taking out the RAM or the game card, because as I said  <br>these GPF are not reproducible at will.  I have gone through and entire  <br>day using the computer with no problems and then I might get 5 or so GPF's  <br>in the sppace of 20 minutes?<br><br>What can I do.  This situation is most annoying... Are there any good  <br>diagnostic tools for hardware? Do you think that this might be a software  <br>problem (ie EMM386 etc.)? If it helps, i have manage to get GPF's on After  <br>Dark, quicken, Paint shop pro. A lot of them have been in user.exe or  <br>gdi.exe.<br><br>Any help is truly appreciated.....<br><br>-Eric"	"Some background:  I have a Leading Edge 486sx25 with Phoenix BIOS.  When I  <br>first got it it had 4Mg of memory.  It ran windows fine (not too many  <br>GPF's).  Then, a couple of weekends ago, I installed Lotus 123 for windows  <br>(with ATM), a game card and an additional 4  1Mg SIMMS.  The Leading edge  <br>machine is kind of strange, in that it has the IDE controler built into  <br>the motherboard, the CPU is actually on a sparate board that plugs into  <br>the motherboard and the SIMMS it uses are Macintosh SIMMS! Apparently I  <br>was told that the Leading Edge had the parity bit built into the mother  <br>board.  The original 4Mg 80ns SIMMS where of the 2 chip variety from  <br>SAMSUNG, and the ones I installed are 8 chip SIMMS. They are recognized  <br>fine by the BIOS RAM check. The game card is a generic $20 gamecard.<br><br>The reason why I mention the hardware like this is that sometimes  <br>rebooting the machine using the reset button or ctl-alt-del still leaves  <br>the machine kind of flaky, but turning it on and off doesn't. <br><br>I haven't tried taking out the RAM or the game card, because as I said  <br>these GPF are not reproducible at will.  I have gone through and entire  <br>day using the computer with no problems and then I might get 5 or so GPF's  <br>in the sppace of 20 minutes?<br><br>What can I do.  This situation is most annoying... Are there any good  <br>diagnostic tools for hardware? Do you think that this might be a software  <br>problem (ie EMM386 etc.)? If it helps, i have manage to get GPF's on After  <br>Dark, quicken, Paint shop pro. A lot of them have been in user.exe or  <br>gdi.exe.<br><br>Any help is truly appreciated.....<br><br>-Eric"		
234	1	": >IDE:  Integrated Device Electronics <br>: > currently the most common standard, and is mainly used for medium sized <br>: > drives. Can have more than one hard drive. Asynchronous Transfer: ~5MB/s max.<br><br>: Why don't you start with the spec-sheet of the ISA bus first?<br>: You can quote SCSI specs till you're blue in the face, but if they<br>: exceed the ISA bus capability, then what's the point?<br><br>Who said ISA was necessary?  EISA or VLB are the only interfaces worth<br>investing thousands of dollars (e.g. a new pc's worth of money ) in .<br><br>: Who says IDE is limited to 5 megs/sec?  What about VLB-IDE?  Does anyone<br>: know how they perform?<br><br>You didn't read to carefully.  VLB-IDE uses the same connection mechanism<br>as standard IDE.  If transfer rate is limited by IDE, whether it's<br>interfaced to ISA, EISA or VLB matters not.<br><br>: >So at its LOWEST setting SCSI-2 interface in Asynchronous SCSI-1 mode AVERAGES <br>: >the through put MAXIMUM of IDE in asynchronous mode.  In full SCSI-2 mode<br>: >it blows poor IDE out the window, down the street, and into the garbage can.<br>: As implimented on what system?  <br><br>On mine, for one thing.  SCSI blows IDE out of the water, hands down.  If<br>IDE has better throughput, why isn't it used on workstations and file<br>servers?  <br><br>: >The problem becomes can the drive mechanisim keep up with those through put<br>: >rates and THAT is where the bottleneck and cost of SCSI-2 comes from.  NOT<br>: >the interface itself but more and more from drive mechanisims to use the<br>: >SCSI-2 through put.  <br><br>: Given the original question (SCSI used only as a single hard drive<br>: controller),  is it then necessary to get a SCSI drive that will do<br>: at least 5, maybe 10 megs/sec for the SCSI choice to make any sence?<br>: What does a 200-400 meg 5 megs/sec SCSI drive cost?<br><br>No, that's the nice thing -- on a multitasking OS, SCSI can use both drives<br>at once.  I've got unix loaded on one of my pcs (along with windogs) and the OS can only use one of the two IDE drives at one time.  It's pretty ugly.<br><br>I just bought at Quantum 240 for my mac at home.  I paid $369 for it.  I<br>haven't seen IDE drives cheaper.<br><br>: The original CGA cart back in '84 was $300.  I think the original EGA card<br>: (or PGA?) was $800.  SCSI has stood relatively alone in not coming down<br>: in price, mainly because we're talking about PC's and not Sun's or Sparc<br>: or SGI or (name your favorite unix workstation).  That is, after millions<br>: of PC buying decisions over the years, SCSI has had plenty of time to<br>: come down in price.<br><br>No, actually, we're talking about SCSI being expensive simply because<br>nobody did a common interface for the PC.  If they had a common (read:<br>easily implemented) method of adding scsi to a PC (like as in a Sun or<br>Mac), then you'd find SCSI the connection medium of choice.<br><br>: I won't argue that the SCSI standard makes for a good, well implimented<br>: data highway, but I still want to know why it intrinsically better<br>: (than IDE, on an ISA bus) when it comes to multi-tasking OS's when<br>: managing data from a single SCSI hard drive.<br><br>On a single drive, SCSI is more expensive.  But, you bought your PC for<br>expandibility, so, you'd want to add more drives or whatever.  The<br>following are why I find SCSI intrinsically better than IDE:<br><br>A (partial?) list:<br> 1.  You can add many different types of devices and access them <br> concurrently.<br> 2.  A SCSI device works on many different machines (I have a mac<br> and a PC at home and moving hard drives between them is VERY nice<br> with SCSI -- hook them up and away they go)<br> 3.  SCSI devices work together better than IDE devices.  For<br> instance, recently, I added an older connor 100 meg IDE to a maxtor<br> 212 meg IDE.  The connor *MUST* be setup as the slave.  It will<br> work no other way.  On SCSI, you set the address, check the<br> termination, plug it in, and away it goes.<br> 4.  I have a problem with IDE's mutual exclusion - I notice that<br> the time it takes to switch from accessing drive c: to drive d: is<br> quite long as compared to the time it takes to switch from drive c:<br> to d: on a SCSI system.  Under a multitasking OS, this is very<br> noticable, as many things can be going on at once.<br><br>One neat thing that I've noticed lately (a fringe benefit) has been the<br>ability to add older (almost dead) drives as storage on a SCSI system with<br>little problem -- we've got a bunch of almost dead 20 meg drives that I've<br>added to my PC.  I've now got the interface full, but, it does allow me to<br>have 4 20 meg drives, 1 240 meg drive, 1 tape drive, and 1 105 meg drive<br>all on the same card.  <br><br>Simply put, SCSI is handier than IDE.  No mysterious jumpers to figure out.<br><br>Greg."	": >IDE:  Integrated Device Electronics <br>: > currently the most common standard, and is mainly used for medium sized <br>: > drives. Can have more than one hard drive. Asynchronous Transfer: ~5MB/s max.<br><br>: Why don't you start with the spec-sheet of the ISA bus first?<br>: You can quote SCSI specs till you're blue in the face, but if they<br>: exceed the ISA bus capability, then what's the point?<br><br>Who said ISA was necessary?  EISA or VLB are the only interfaces worth<br>investing thousands of dollars (e.g. a new pc's worth of money ) in .<br><br>: Who says IDE is limited to 5 megs/sec?  What about VLB-IDE?  Does anyone<br>: know how they perform?<br><br>You didn't read to carefully.  VLB-IDE uses the same connection mechanism<br>as standard IDE. In full SCSI-2 mode<br>: >it blows poor IDE out the window, down the street, and into the garbage can.<br>: As implimented on what system?  <br><br>On mine, for one thing. NOT<br>: >the interface itself but more and more from drive mechanisims to use the<br>: >SCSI-2 through put.  <br><br>: Given the original question (SCSI used only as a single hard drive<br>: controller),  is it then necessary to get a SCSI drive that will do<br>: at least 5, maybe 10 megs/sec for the SCSI choice to make any sence?<br>: What does a 200-400 meg 5 megs/sec SCSI drive cost?<br><br>No, that's the nice thing -- on a multitasking OS, SCSI can use both drives<br>at once. I paid $369 for it.  I<br>haven't seen IDE drives cheaper.<br><br>: The original CGA cart back in '84 was $300.  I think the original EGA card<br>: (or PGA?) was $800.  SCSI has stood relatively alone in not coming down<br>: in price, mainly because we're talking about PC's and not Sun's or Sparc<br>: or SGI or (name your favorite unix workstation).  That is, after millions<br>: of PC buying decisions over the years, SCSI has had plenty of time to<br>: come down in price.<br><br>No, actually, we're talking about SCSI being expensive simply because<br>nobody did a common interface for the PC.  If they had a common (read:<br>easily implemented) method of adding scsi to a PC (like as in a Sun or<br>Mac), then you'd find SCSI the connection medium of choice.<br><br>: I won't argue that the SCSI standard makes for a good, well implimented<br>: data highway, but I still want to know why it intrinsically better<br>: (than IDE, on an ISA bus) when it comes to multi-tasking OS's when<br>: managing data from a single SCSI hard drive.<br><br>On a single drive, SCSI is more expensive.  But, you bought your PC for<br>expandibility, so, you'd want to add more drives or whatever.  The<br>following are why I find SCSI intrinsically better than IDE:<br><br>A (partial?) list:<br> 1.  You can add many different types of devices and access them <br> concurrently.<br> 2.  A SCSI device works on many different machines (I have a mac<br> and a PC at home and moving hard drives between them is VERY nice<br> with SCSI -- hook them up and away they go)<br> 3.  SCSI devices work together better than IDE devices.  For<br> instance, recently, I added an older connor 100 meg IDE to a maxtor<br> 212 meg IDE.  The connor *MUST* be setup as the slave.  It will<br> work no other way.  On SCSI, you set the address, check the<br> termination, plug it in, and away it goes.<br> 4.  I have a problem with IDE's mutual exclusion - I notice that<br> the time it takes to switch from accessing drive c: to drive d: is<br> quite long as compared to the time it takes to switch from drive c:<br> to d: on a SCSI system.  Under a multitasking OS, this is very<br> noticable, as many things can be going on at once.<br><br>One neat thing that I've noticed lately (a fringe benefit) has been the<br>ability to add older (almost dead) drives as storage on a SCSI system with<br>little problem -- we've got a bunch of almost dead 20 meg drives that I've<br>added to my PC.  I've now got the interface full, but, it does allow me to<br>have 4 20 meg drives, 1 240 meg drive, 1 tape drive, and 1 105 meg drive<br>all on the same card.  <br><br>Simply put, SCSI is handier than IDE.  No mysterious jumpers to figure out.<br><br>Greg."		
235	0	"has anybody tried to compile CTRLTEST from the MFC/SAMPLES directory,<br>after compiling the MFC-libs with BWC ?<br><br>Seems to me, that BWC isn't able to distinguish pointers to overloaded<br>functions.<br>For example, imagine the following 2 (overloaded) functions:<br>void same_name ( void ) <br>void same_name ( int )<br> <br>After trying the whole day, I think, with BWC its impossible to take the<br>adress of one of the above two functions and assign it to a properly defined<br>function pointer. <br>Am I right ? Has anybody else had this problem ?" It includes WYSIWYG<br>design tools for easy creation of tables, reports, forms and queries and a<br>database programming language called Access Basic.<br>THe purpose of the group will be to provide help to people who use Access's <br>WYSIWYG design tools to create simple databases as well as to people who use <br>Access Basic to create complex databases.<br><br>RATIONALE:<br>Eventhough Access is a new RDBMS, it is very popular because of its Graphical<br>Development enviroment and its initial low price.<br>Been a version 1.0 product means that all Access users are Novices.<br>For that reason a newsgroup is needed where Access users can discuss <br>their experiences with the product and answer each other's questions." 258	0	"RISC used to mean ""Reduced Instruction Set Computer"", true.  They<br>still use the same acronym, but only to be familiar.  What RISC really<br>means is a recently-designed CPU.  :-)<br><br>In general, most RISC CPUs are like this:<br><br>    A large number (32 or more) of general-purpose registers<br>    A fixed instruction size, usually 32 bits<br>    An instruction may make only one memory reference<br>    Memory references must be aligned<br>    There are delayed branches (branch after the next instruction) or<br>a target prediction bit (probably will/won't branch)<br>    Instructions may complete out of order relative to the instruction<br>stream"	"RISC used to mean ""Reduced Instruction Set Computer"", true.  They<br>still use the same acronym, but only to be familiar.  What RISC really<br>means is a recently-designed CPU.  :-)<br><br>In general, most RISC CPUs are like this:<br><br>    A large number (32 or more) of general-purpose registers<br>    A fixed instruction size, usually 32 bits<br>    An instruction may make only one memory reference<br>    Memory references must be aligned<br>    There are delayed branches (branch after the next instruction) or<br>a target prediction bit (probably will/won't branch)<br>    Instructions may complete out of order relative to the instruction<br>stream"

263	0	"<br>They are working ok, but your definitions in QVTNET.INI and QVTHOST.RC are<br>incorrect (see below).<br><br><br>No, I don't think so. You are using QVTNET and NOVELL concurrently, aren't<br>you? They use different packet types, so QVTNET (TCP/IP) and NOVELL (IPX/SPX)<br>should be able to coexist just fine. PKTMUX is required if you are using<br>different TCP/IP-Packages concurrently.<br><br><br>There is the first problem: You didn't specify hostnames, just IP-Addresses.<br>Your file should look like this:<br><br>137.112.5.2        <Name of your Nameserver><br>137.112.199.50     <Name of your Router><br><br><br>Here you should only specify your hostname, without the domain part.<br><br><br>Instead, use router=<Name of your Router>, as specified in your QVTHOST.RC<br>I know the release notes for 3.31 say that IP addresses should work also,<br>but  apparently they don't.<br><br><br>Here, too, you should use the hostname of the nameserver instead of the<br>IP address.<br><br>It worked fine for me that way, although I could not specify more than<br>one nameserver. The relnotes say it should be possible to specify up to<br>three nameservers, separated by commas, but it didn't work.<br><br>Hope it helps,<br>Richard<br>"	"<br>They are working ok, but your definitions in QVTNET.INI and QVTHOST.RC are<br>incorrect (see below).<br><br><br>No, I don't think so. You are using QVTNET and NOVELL concurrently, aren't<br>you? They use different packet types, so QVTNET (TCP/IP) and NOVELL (IPX/SPX)<br>should be able to coexist just fine. PKTMUX is required if you are using<br>different TCP/IP-Packages concurrently.<br><br><br>There is the first problem: You didn't specify hostnames, just IP-Addresses.<br>Your file should look like this:<br><br>137.112.5.2        <Name of your Nameserver><br>137.112.199.50     <Name of your Router><br><br><br>Here you should only specify your hostname, without the domain part.<br><br><br>Instead, use router=<Name of your Router>, as specified in your QVTHOST.RC<br>I know the release notes for 3.31 say that IP addresses should work also,<br>but  apparently they don't.<br><br><br>Here, too, you should use the hostname of the nameserver instead of the<br>IP address.<br><br>It worked fine for me that way, although I could not specify more than<br>one nameserver. The relnotes say it should be possible to specify up to<br>three nameservers, separated by commas, but it didn't work.<br><br>Hope it helps,<br>Richard<br>"

289	0	" THe best sound conversion program I've ever seen is SoundTool, which<br>is shareware from Germany.  I found a copy somewhere in wuarchive.wustl.edu<br>a long time ago, but I don't know offhand what directory it was under.  It's<br>GREAT at converting files of all types, including Mac, NExT, Sun, and<br>various PC formats... It's also a great player and editor, with various<br>special effects that put Windows' Sound Recorder to shame.  It requires a<br>driver for various sound cards... The only builtin one is for the pc speaker<br>(and even that sounds pretty good), but if you're just using it to convert<br>things, you can convert them in SoundTool and then play them in Sound<br>Recorder.<br><br>Give it a try!<br><br>Bret"	" THe best sound conversion program I've ever seen is SoundTool, which<br>is shareware from Germany. It's<br>GREAT at converting files of all types, including Mac, NExT, Sun, and<br>various PC formats... It's also a great player and editor, with various<br>special effects that put Windows' Sound Recorder to shame.  It requires a<br>driver for various sound cards... The best advice I've heard when buying monnitors<br>is to actually look at the specific one you will buy (as opposed to model)<br>since monitor manufacturing even from ""Big Names"" still tends to produce<br>alot of monitors with visible defects.<br><br><br>                              Rithea Hong<br>                       (r0h7630@tamuts.tamu.edu)<br>End of File, Press RETURN to quit<br><br>Just to name two at the top of my list of crap monitor makers are,<br>SONY & MAGNAVOX...Sam"

304	0	"<br><br><br><br>I contacted Lotus about this problem today.  It has been reported previously<br>and there is a fix.  Apparantly the problem only occurs when TAB characters<br>are used immediately preceding the equation frame.  The work around when<br>equations are expected to touch the right margin is to delete at least one<br>preceding TAB and use SPACE to align the frame (or use set frame where<br>placed w/no text wrap around).  Unforutnately, once the page run-on has<br>occured you are hosed. So the moral of the story is use only SPACE characters<br>to align equation frames.<br><br>Hope this helps the rest of you who have already contacted me with this <br>problem." 310	1	<br>The problem is with ISA bus-masters which<br>can only address the first 16MBs of system<br>memory.  Bus-masters do not use the CPU<br>nor the system DMA to do the actual data<br>transfer but transfer their data directly<br>to the system RAM.<br><br>rp93	<br>The problem is with ISA bus-masters which<br>can only address the first 16MBs of system<br>memory. 312	0	"<br>You'll probably want to delete any damaged executables and reload them<br>fresh.  Data files should be examined and repaired.<br><br><br>You're not stupid.  Smartdrive caches things, and Windows also runs a<br>swap file which may contain data also.  All of this is pretty risky<br>stuff in a PC environment.<br><br><br>A reasonably accurate prediction...<br><br><br>Here's a brief description of how DOS stores files:<br><br>There are three pieces to a file.  The directory entry, the FAT chain,<br>and the data area.  You can think of these as a sheet of lined<br>notebook paper, a sheet of graph paper, and a stack of 3X5 cards.<br><br>The directory entry (notebook paper) holds the file name, actual size,<br>and first cluster number.  It also holds some other information that's not<br>important right now.<br><br>The File Allocation Table (FAT) chain (graph paper) tells where to find<br>the actual data.  Each square of graph paper holds a number.  If the<br>number is zero, the cluster associated with this box is available.  If it<br>holds a ""magic"" number, it is either the last piece of a file or a bad<br>(unuseable) spot on the disk.  Any other number tells which cluster<br>contains the next section of the file.<br><br>The data area (3X5 cards) is where the actual information is stored.<br>The data area is organized as clusters of a fixed size; storage is<br>doled out in ""chunks"" of one cluster each.  (In your case, one cluster<br>is 2048 bytes.)  As a cluster is filled, another is allocated.<br><br>To read a file, you first look at the directory entry to get the<br>starting cluster number.  Now you read the data from that cluster.<br>Next, look at the FAT entry for the cluster you just read.  This will<br>tell you the cluster number for the next chunk of the file.<br>Naturally, these numbers are usually sequential, but they can jump<br>around and even go backwards.  Continue reading, one cluster at a<br>time, as you walk this chain through the FAT, until you hit the marker<br>which says it's the last cluster in the file.<br><br>CHKDSK is the DOS utility that checks the sanity and coherence of<br>the directories and the FAT and can bludgeon most flaws into<br>submission.  It doesn't have any intelligence, so you have to<br>double-check anything it ""fixes"".<br><br>Now let's do a bit of a post-mortem:<br><br><br>All of these files have sizes (according to the FAT) which don't match<br>the size reported in their directory entries.  CHKDSK /F will alter<br>the directory entries to match the FAT size.  (In other words,   the<br>directory entry for CVPIC.EXE may say the file is 64,877 bytes long.<br>But CHKDSK found a FAT chain of 43 clusters attached to it.  (My numbers,<br>obviously, are made up.))<br><br><br>Disk space was found which is allocated in the FAT, but is not attached<br>to any directory entry.  CHKDSK /F gives you the option of converting these<br>""lost chains"" to files.  You can then examine the files (FILE0000.CHK<br>through FILE0223.CHK) and rename or discard them.  Or, if you tell<br>CHKDSK _not_ to convert them to files, then those clusters will simply<br>be marked ""available"" in the FAT.<br><br><br><br>...<br><br><br>These files are both referencing the _same_ data cluster.  Obviously,<br>one of them (at least) must be wrong.  It's interesting to note that<br>C:\386SPART.PAR is your Windows swap file...<br><br>To fix this, you should copy each cross-linked file to a new name.<br>This will ""fix"" the cross-link by giving the files unique data spaces.<br>Now delete the cross-linked files.  Examine the copies and try to<br>assemble them properly.  Good luck.  (Hint:  ""Missing pieces"" are<br>likely to be found in those ""lost chains"" at the top...)<br><br><br>Your disk is pretty close to full.  This may be the actual cause of<br>the problem; perhaps Windows needed to expand its swapfile by an<br>amount which exceeded available disk space...<br><br>In any case, the short summary is that something trashed your FAT.<br>There are utilities that can mirror your FAT and help repair damage<br>after something like this, but you have to run them _before_ the<br>problem occurs.  Sorry.<br><br><br>-- <br>----------------------------------------------------<br>Gordon S. Hlavenka           cgordon@vpnet.chi.il.us<br>Vote straight ticket Procrastination party Dec. 3rd!<br>-- "	"<br>You'll probably want to delete any damaged executables and reload them<br>fresh. Obviously,<br>one of them (at least) must be wrong.  It's interesting to note that<br>C:\386SPART.PAR is your Windows swap file...<br><br>To fix this, you should copy each cross-linked file to a new name.<br>This will ""fix"" the cross-link by giving the files unique data spaces.<br>Now delete the cross-linked files.  Examine the copies and try to<br>assemble them properly.  Good luck. This may be the actual cause of<br>the problem; perhaps Windows needed to expand its swapfile by an<br>amount which exceeded available disk space...<br><br>In any case, the short summary is that something trashed your FAT.<br>There are utilities that can mirror your FAT and help repair damage<br>after something like this, but you have to run them _before_ the<br>problem occurs. 346	1	"No, VL-bus IDE is no faster than ISA IDE.  The IDE interface is<br>fundamentally nothing more than an extension of the ISA bus, and if<br>you hook it to VL-bus it'll work as fast as the slower of the two,<br>meaning ISA speed.<br><br><br>On the other hand, I wouldn't expect it to be *slower*..."	"No, VL-bus IDE is no faster than ISA IDE.  The IDE interface is<br>fundamentally nothing more than an extension of the ISA bus, and if<br>you hook it to VL-bus it'll work as fast as the slower of the two,<br>meaning ISA speed.<br><br><br>On the other hand, I wouldn't expect it to be *slower*..."

355	1	"Every partition (whether it is the entire disk or not) has two FATs and<br>an initial directory.<br><br>If you have a small disk (50 meg or less), I would recommend that it remain<br>a single partition. 363	1	"SCSI is not complex. It is just the way the industry uses and talks about it.<br>There are THREE key differences in SCSI; the controller chip, the port, and<br>the software.  THAT IS IT.<br>Let us look as SCSi in from THIS stand point.<br><br>SCSI-1: asynchronous and synchronous modes {SOFTWARE SCSI DRIVER ONLY}<br> asynchronous is slower then synchronous mode {only 0-3MB/s vs. 0-5MB/s}<br> synchronous speeds can be reached by most SCSi-1 divices with a<br> rewrite of the software driver {As is the case for the Mac Quadra.}<br><br>SCSI-2 {8-bit}: THIS is the main source for the confusion. This differs from<br> SCSI-1 ONLY in the controler chip in most machines.  In the Mac and some PCs<br> this is called 'fast SCSI-1' because it uses SCSI-1 ports and software drivers<br> AND can produce SCSI-2 SPEEDS through SCSI-1 INSPITE of this even in the <br> slower asynchronous mode.  Average speed in asynchronous SCSi-1 mode <br> 4-6MB/s with 8MB/s{See in both Quadras and higher end PCs} Synchronous<br> mode just allows a higher burst rate {10/MB/s}<br><br>SCSI-2 {16-bit}: TWO versions-Wide/Fast.  Wide SCSI-2 requires TWO things<br> over 8-bit SCSI-2:  a SCSI-2 software driver and a wide SCSI port on the<br> machine and the external device.<br> Fast SCSI-2 also requires TWO things over 8-bit SCSI-2: SCSI-2 driver<br> software and that the RECIEVING devise support 16-bit fast SCSI-2.<br> Speed of both is the same: 8-12MB/s with 20MB/s burst.<br><br>SCSI-2 {32-bit}:  Also know as Wide AND Fast SCSI.  Over 8-bit SCSI-2 this<br> requires: SCSI-2 driver software, wide SCSI-2 port, and that the RECIEVING<br> devices ALSO have a 32-bit mode SCSI-2 chip.  As expected this is VERY<br> expencive.  Speed: 15-20MB/s with 40MB/s bursts<br> "	"SCSI is not complex. It is just the way the industry uses and talks about it.<br>There are THREE key differences in SCSI; the controller chip, the port, and<br>the software.  THAT IS IT.<br>Let us look as SCSi in from THIS stand point.<br><br>SCSI-1: asynchronous and synchronous modes {SOFTWARE SCSI DRIVER ONLY}<br> asynchronous is slower then synchronous mode {only 0-3MB/s vs. 0-5MB/s}<br> synchronous speeds can be reached by most SCSi-1 divices with a<br> rewrite of the software driver {As is the case for the Mac Quadra.}<br><br>SCSI-2 {8-bit}: THIS is the main source for the confusion. This differs from<br> SCSI-1 ONLY in the controler chip in most machines.  In the Mac and some PCs<br> this is called 'fast SCSI-1' because it uses SCSI-1 ports and software drivers<br> AND can produce SCSI-2 SPEEDS through SCSI-1 INSPITE of this even in the <br> slower asynchronous mode.  Average speed in asynchronous SCSi-1 mode <br> 4-6MB/s with 8MB/s{See in both Quadras and higher end PCs} Synchronous<br> mode just allows a higher burst rate {10/MB/s}<br><br>SCSI-2 {16-bit}: TWO versions-Wide/Fast.  Wide SCSI-2 requires TWO things<br> over 8-bit SCSI-2:  a SCSI-2 software driver and a wide SCSI port on the<br> machine and the external device.<br> Fast SCSI-2 also requires TWO things over 8-bit SCSI-2: SCSI-2 driver<br> software and that the RECIEVING devise support 16-bit fast SCSI-2.<br> Speed of both is the same: 8-12MB/s with 20MB/s burst.<br><br>SCSI-2 {32-bit}:  Also know as Wide AND Fast SCSI.  Over 8-bit SCSI-2 this<br> requires: SCSI-2 driver software, wide SCSI-2 port, and that the RECIEVING<br> devices ALSO have a 32-bit mode SCSI-2 chip.  As expected this is VERY<br> expencive.  Speed: 15-20MB/s with 40MB/s bursts<br> "		
364	0	" I struggled with the margin problem for ages as well, until I<br>finally got hold of the shareware binary editor BEAV133, and dug into<br>NOTEPAD.EXE (there is no SETUP facility to force NOTEPAD to default to <br>0.0 margins- it's hardwired into code!!!). <br><br> Do a SEARCH for "".75"", then change the offending bytes to "".00"", <br>et viola. Who are the guys who hardcode these ""options"" anyway?<br><br> I'm interested in whether the problem only rears it's ugly head for <br>certain printers- I'm using an old Epson LX-800 (or is that EX-800? never can <br>remember)."	" I struggled with the margin problem for ages as well, until I<br>finally got hold of the shareware binary editor BEAV133, and dug into<br>NOTEPAD.EXE (there is no SETUP facility to force NOTEPAD to default to <br>0.0 margins- it's hardwired into code!!!). <br><br> Do a SEARCH for "".75"", then change the offending bytes to "".00"", <br>et viola. Who are the guys who hardcode these ""options"" anyway?<br><br> I'm interested in whether the problem only rears it's ugly head for <br>certain printers- I'm using an old Epson LX-800 (or is that EX-800? never can <br>remember)."

370	1	"I have included the assembly code that I am running and the C++ code<br>that I am trying to use.  If anyone can show me something that I<br>am doing blatantly incorrectly or that I am missing because of my lack<br>of knowledge about RS-232 serial communications, please e-mail me.<br>I wrote the assembly language to wait for a character to be received and<br>then to check it against the 0x20 character, if a 0x20 is received, <br>the LEDs will indicate this.  Two C++ programs that I have written do<br>nothing, but set up COM port 2 and send the 0x20 character.  One uses<br>the bioscom() function in bios.h the other uses the software interrupt<br>int86() function in dos.h.  I have triple checked the baud rate ( 2400 )<br>the parity ( none ) the stop bits ( 1 ) the character length ( 8 bits )<br>and the interrupt calls for ( 0x14 ).  Currently, I am at a loss as<br>to what may be wrong.  Any hardware gurus out there want to comment?<br><br><br>      Thanks alot,<br>      Hubert De Jesus<br>      dejesus@eniac.seas.upenn.edu<br><br><br>      INTEL ASM<br><br>COMMAND     EQU     3000H                ;Command Register on 8155<br>PORTA       EQU     3001H                ;Port A on 8155<br>TIMERLO     EQU     3004H                ;High 8 bits of 8155 Timer<br>TIMERHI     EQU     3005H                ;Low 8 bits of 8155 Timer<br>UARTDATA    EQU     E000H                ;UART Data Register<br>UARTCMD     EQU     E001H                ;UART Command Register<br><br>            ORG     4000H                ;SRAM location<br>     MVI     A,08H   ;Set Low Timer Bits<br>            STA     TIMERLO<br>            MVI     A,40H   ;Set High Timer Bits<br>            STA     TIMERHI<br>            MVI     A,11111101B          ;Start Timer & Enable Port A<br>            STA     COMMAND<br><br>            MVI     A,11H                ;Display 11 on 7-segment LEDs<br>            STA     PORTA<br><br>            MVI     A,00H   ;Clear UART Command<br>            STA     UARTCMD<br>            STA     UARTCMD<br>            STA     UARTCMD<br>            MVI     A,01000000B   ;Internally reset UART <br>            STA     UARTCMD<br>     LDA     UARTDATA             ;Remove extraneous data<br>      MVI     A,01001111B          ;Init UART for 8 data bits,<br>            STA     UARTCMD              ;  no parity, 1 stop bit, 64x async<br>            MVI     A,00100111B          ;Enable Transmit and Receive<br>            STA     UARTCMD<br><br>INIT:       LDA     UARTCMD   ;Read Status Register<br>            ANI     02H                  ;Is RxRDY?<br>            JZ      INIT                 ;No, loop<br><br>            LDA     UARTDATA             ;Read Data Character<br>            CPI     ' '                  ;Is Character = 0x20?<br>            JNZ     INIT                 ;No, loop<br>     <br>            MVI     A,22H                ;Character received, <br>            STA     PORTA                ;  Display 22 on 7-segment LEDs<br>            HLT<br>            END<br><br>                              C++ using BIOSCOM()<br><br>#include <stdio.h><br>#include <stdlib.h><br>#include <bios.h><br><br>#define INIT          0<br>#define SEND          1<br>#define RECEIVE       2<br>#define STATUS        3<br><br>#define COM2          1<br><br>void<br>main()<br>{<br>   char abyte;<br><br>   abyte = 0xa3;<br>   bioscom( INIT, abyte, COM2 );<br>   printf( ""Initialized COMM PORT 2\n"" );<br><br>   while( !( bioscom( STATUS, 0, COM2 ) & 0x4000 ) )<br>     ;<br>   abyte = ' ';<br>   bioscom( SEND, abyte, COM2 );<br>   printf( ""Sent start character\n"" );<br>}<br><br><br>           C++ using INT86()<br><br>#include <stdio.h><br>#include <stdlib.h><br>#include <dos.h><br>#include <bios.h><br><br>main()<br>{<br>   union REGS registers;<br>  <br>   registers.h.ah = 0x00;<br>   registers.h.al = 0xa7; <br>   registers.x.dx = 0x01;<br>   int86( 0x14, &registers, &registers );<br>   printf( ""COM2 Initialized\n"" );"	"I have included the assembly code that I am running and the C++ code<br>that I am trying to use. 372	1	"Why don't you start with the spec-sheet of the ISA bus first?<br>You can quote SCSI specs till you're blue in the face, but if they<br>exceed the ISA bus capability, then what's the point?<br><br>Who says IDE is limited to 5 megs/sec?  What about VLB-IDE?  Does anyone<br>know how they perform?<br><br><br>As implimented on what system?  <br><br><br>Given the original question (SCSI used only as a single hard drive<br>controller),  is it then necessary to get a SCSI drive that will do<br>at least 5, maybe 10 megs/sec for the SCSI choice to make any sence?<br>What does a 200-400 meg 5 megs/sec SCSI drive cost?<br><br><br>The original CGA cart back in '84 was $300.  I think the original EGA card<br>(or PGA?) was $800.  SCSI has stood relatively alone in not coming down<br>in price, mainly because we're talking about PC's and not Sun's or Sparc<br>or SGI or (name your favorite unix workstation).  That is, after millions<br>of PC buying decisions over the years, SCSI has had plenty of time to<br>come down in price."	"Why don't you start with the spec-sheet of the ISA bus first?<br>You can quote SCSI specs till you're blue in the face, but if they<br>exceed the ISA bus capability, then what's the point?<br><br>Who says IDE is limited to 5 megs/sec?  What about VLB-IDE?  Does anyone<br>know how they perform?<br><br><br>As implimented on what system?  <br><br><br>Given the original question (SCSI used only as a single hard drive<br>controller),  is it then necessary to get a SCSI drive that will do<br>at least 5, maybe 10 megs/sec for the SCSI choice to make any sence?<br>What does a 200-400 meg 5 megs/sec SCSI drive cost?<br><br><br>The original CGA cart back in '84 was $300.  I think the original EGA card<br>(or PGA?) was $800.  SCSI has stood relatively alone in not coming down<br>in price, mainly because we're talking about PC's and not Sun's or Sparc<br>or SGI or (name your favorite unix workstation).  That is, after millions<br>of PC buying decisions over the years, SCSI has had plenty of time to<br>come down in price."		
373	0	"NAME:   comp.os.ms-windows.nt.setup<br>STATUS:  Unmoderated.<br>PURPOSE: Discussions about setting up and installing Windows NT, and about<br>  system and peripheral compatability issues for Windows NT.<br><br>NAME:  comp.os.ms-windows.nt.misc<br>STATUS:  Unmoderated.<br>PURPOSE: Miscellaneous non-programming discussions about using Windows NT,<br>  including issues such as security, networking features, console<br>  mode and Windows 3.1 (Win16) compatability.<br><br>RATIONALE:<br> Microsoft NT is the newest member of the Microsoft Windows family<br> of operating systems (or operating environments for those who wish<br> to argue about the meaning of an ""OS"").  The family ranges from<br> Modular Windows through Windows 3.1 and Windows for Workgroups to<br> Windows NT at the high end.  To date, Microsoft has shipped over<br> 50,000 beta copies and pre-release SDKs of Windows NT -- the<br> actual release is slated for May/June '93.<br><br> While Windows NT has an entirely new design internally, it shares<br> an application programming interface with the other members of the<br> Windows family; its Win32 API includes the Win16 API used in Win-<br> dows 3.1, and the Win32s API subset (Win32 less threads, networking<br> and security) can be used to create 32-bit applications for<br> Windows 3.1.<br><br> The user interface is also practically identical to that of Windows<br> 3.1, with the addition of logins and a few other features.  It uses<br> Program Manager, File Manager and other applets, and generally pre-<br> sents an identical appearance to the user.  Many of the announced<br> Windows NT applications are ports of existing Windows 3.1 apps, and<br> NT also runs existing 3.1 applications.<br><br> Thus, it appears logical that Windows NT should share the following<br> groups with the other members of the Windows family:<br>  comp.os.ms-windows.apps<br>  comp.os.ms-windows.programmer.tools<br>  comp.os.ms-windows.programmer.misc<br>  comp.os.ms-windows.programmer.win32<br> <br> The following groups are also clearly applicable to Windows NT as<br> well as Windows 3.1:<br>  comp.os.ms-windows.announce<br>  comp.os.ms-windows.advocacy<br> <br> In conclusion, the only clear argument for the separation of the<br> Windows 3.1 and Windows NT hierarchies is different internal<br> structures of Windows 3.1 and Windows NT.  And yet operating<br> systems such as OS/2, Macintosh OS, Xenix and Coherent all have<br> undergone major rewrites without having been split into separate<br> newsgroup hierarchies.<br><br> Further, Windows 3.1 is due for a major rewrite itself in 1994 --<br> when the fully 32-bit, protected-mode and with-DOS-built-in next-<br> generation Windows, ""Chicago"", debuts next year, surely it should<br> remain in the same hierarchy.  And what, then, would be the jus-<br> tification for separating Windows NT from other Windows versions?<br><br><br>DISCUSSION PERIOD:<br> The discussion period will run from 27 April, 1992 to 18 May, 1993.  <br><br>VOTING:<br> The CFV (Call for Votes) will be issued around 19 May, 1993, based on<br> the feedback received during the discussion period.  No votes will<br> be accepted prior to the CFV." And yet operating<br> systems such as OS/2, Macintosh OS, Xenix and Coherent all have<br> undergone major rewrites without having been split into separate<br> newsgroup hierarchies.<br><br> Further, Windows 3.1 is due for a major rewrite itself in 1994 --<br> when the fully 32-bit, protected-mode and with-DOS-built-in next-<br> generation Windows, ""Chicago"", debuts next year, surely it should<br> remain in the same hierarchy. 374	1	"<br><br><br>I suggest that you go direct to the original (and preferred...best quality)<br>source for all of this, just as you would (at least, should) for the chips<br>themselves:  National Semiconductor.  you can reach them at 1-800-272-9959.<br>they no longer package the data sheets in a book, as they did when I got<br>mine, but you can get them as individual sets of data sheets.  you want, as<br>a minimum, the following:<br><br>   *) 2 sets of data sheets:<br>      *) NS16450/INS8250A/NS16C450/INS82C50A<br>      *) NS16550AF<br><br>   *) 2 application notes (yes, GET THESE!):<br>      *) AN-491 The NS16550A: UART Design and Application Considerations<br>      *) AN-493 A Comparison of the INS8250, NS16450 and NS16550AF Series<br>         of UARTs<br><br>both of the application notes I listed have proven to be AT LEAST as<br>valuable as the data sheets themselves (more, actually). 393	0	"Try the following:<br>   1) Turn off disk write cache for the disk you are downloading to.  The<br>       cache will save up so much that when it grabs control of the machine<br>       it takes too long to write to disk and you loose characters.<br><br>   2) Use a different UART for your serial line.  The old UART's (8250 or 16450)<br>       can only buffer one character internally.  The new UART's (16550) can<br>       buffer 16, which should be plenty for most situations.  You can run<br>       \windows\msd.exe to find out what UART is on the machine."	"Try the following:<br>   1) Turn off disk write cache for the disk you are downloading to.  The<br>       cache will save up so much that when it grabs control of the machine<br>       it takes too long to write to disk and you loose characters.<br><br>   2) Use a different UART for your serial line.  The old UART's (8250 or 16450)<br>       can only buffer one character internally.  The new UART's (16550) can<br>       buffer 16, which should be plenty for most situations.  You can run<br>       \windows\msd.exe to find out what UART is on the machine."

Also, it would change brightness <br>when I switched modes and I was constantly having to fiddle with the <br>controls. Is<br>this inherent in all DDE systems or just peculiar to MSACCESS<br>or VB?<br><br>2) It is easy to query an Access database from VB using the<br>DDE SQL command,<br>(provided the above limitation is overcome by using short<br>field and table<br>names) but how is one meant to update a database?<br>   a) A DDE SQL UPDATE command does not seem to work.<br>   b) Initiating an Access macro using a DDE Execute command<br>from VB cannot<br>      be used because when the macro requests information from<br>VB using a<br>      second DDE channel the programs dead lock until time-<br>outs occur.<br>      (The VB to Access channel has to close before the Access<br>to VB channel<br>      is initiated, I guess.)<br>   c) Access does not allow VB to DDE POKE the information.<br><br><br>   The way I eventually managed to update a database was by<br>sending key-<br>   strokes from VB to Access using the SendKeys command. This<br>technique has<br>   the problem that Access cannot be minimised and it must<br>always be in a<br>   state ready to respond to the sequence of key-strokes VB<br>sends.<br><br>Are all the above statements correct or have I made incorrect<br>assumptions?<br>Are there any better work arounds to the above? Are there any<br>signs of an<br>ODBC driver for Access?"	"1) There seems to be a limit of 255 characters for a DDE Topic<br>string. Is<br>this inherent in all DDE systems or just peculiar to MSACCESS<br>or VB?<br><br>2) It is easy to query an Access database from VB using the<br>DDE SQL command,<br>(provided the above limitation is overcome by using short<br>field and table<br>names) but how is one meant to update a database?<br>   a) A DDE SQL UPDATE command does not seem to work.<br>   b) Initiating an Access macro using a DDE Execute command<br>from VB cannot<br>      be used because when the macro requests information from<br>VB using a<br>      second DDE channel the programs dead lock until time-<br>outs occur.<br>      (The VB to Access channel has to close before the Access<br>to VB channel<br>      is initiated, I guess.)<br>   c) Access does not allow VB to DDE POKE the information.<br><br><br>   The way I eventually managed to update a database was by<br>sending key-<br>   strokes from VB to Access using the SendKeys command. 403	1	"From a recent BYTE magazine i got the following:<br><br>[Question and part of the answer deleted]<br><br>  If you are handy with a soldering iron, the loopback plugs are easy to<br>make.  On a serial RS-232 nine-pin port, use a female DB-9 connector and<br>connect pins 1 to 7 to 8; 2 to 3; and 4 to 6 to 9.  For serial RS-232 <br>25-pin ports, you'll need a female DB-25 connector with pins 1 to 7;<br>2 to 3; 4 to 5 to 8; 6 to 11 to 20 to 22; 15 to 17 to 23; and 18 to 25<br>connected.  To test a Centronics 25-pin parallel port, you'll need to<br>connect pins 1 to 13; 2 to 15; 10 to 16; 11 to 17; and 12 to 14 in a male<br>DB-25 connector.<br><br>     -Stan Wszola<br>---<br><br>I haven't tried it. Use at own risk."	"From a recent BYTE magazine i got the following:<br><br>[Question and part of the answer deleted]<br><br>  If you are handy with a soldering iron, the loopback plugs are easy to<br>make.  On a serial RS-232 nine-pin port, use a female DB-9 connector and<br>connect pins 1 to 7 to 8; 2 to 3; and 4 to 6 to 9.  For serial RS-232 <br>25-pin ports, you'll need a female DB-25 connector with pins 1 to 7;<br>2 to 3; 4 to 5 to 8; 6 to 11 to 20 to 22; 15 to 17 to 23; and 18 to 25<br>connected.  To test a Centronics 25-pin parallel port, you'll need to<br>connect pins 1 to 13; 2 to 15; 10 to 16; 11 to 17; and 12 to 14 in a male<br>DB-25 connector.<br><br>     -Stan Wszola<br>---<br><br>I haven't tried it. Use at own risk."

407	1	"as someone else already mentioned, don't ""carry thru"" the other 23 pins.<br><br>plan A, minimal null modem:<br> SG(7)   -  SG(7)<br> TD(2)   -  RD(3)<br> RD(3)   -  TD(2)<br>if you're transfering files betwen 2 PCs, this ought to work (unless<br>you have a persnickity comm program).<br><br>plan B, null modem with modem control:<br> SG(7)   -  SG(7)<br> TD(2)   -  RD(3)<br> RD(3)   -  TD(2)<br> DCD(8)  -  DTR(20)<br> DTR(20) -  DCD(8)<br>some comm software will wait for DCD before transferring anything.<br>such software will raise DTR to enable the modem to accept a call.<br>with this cable, each side's DTR will drive the other's DCD.<br><br>plan C, null modem with hardware flow control:<br> SG(7)   -  SG(7)<br> TD(2)   -  RD(3)<br> RD(3)   -  TD(2)<br> RTS(4)  -  CTS(5)<br> CTS(5)  -  RTS(4)<br>for high-speed transfers, you want the flow control.<br><br>plan D, deluxe null modem (combine B and C):<br> SG(7)   -  SG(7)<br> TD(2)   -  RD(3)<br> RD(3)   -  TD(2)<br> RTS(4)  -  CTS(5)<br> CTS(5)  -  RTS(4)<br> DCD(8)  -  DTR(20)<br> DTR(20) -  DCD(8)<br>this one is ideal.  it leaves out DSR and RI (rarely used anymore).<br>if you're really paranoid, or you just have an 8th wire to spend,<br>you might add:<br> FG(1)   -  FG(1)<br><br>the pin numbers above are (obviously) for 25-pin connectors.<br>i don't have a 9-pin pinout handy.<br>"	"as someone else already mentioned, don't ""carry thru"" the other 23 pins.<br><br>plan A, minimal null modem:<br> SG(7)   -  SG(7)<br> TD(2)   -  RD(3)<br> RD(3)   -  TD(2)<br>if you're transfering files betwen 2 PCs, this ought to work (unless<br>you have a persnickity comm program).<br><br>plan B, null modem with modem control:<br> SG(7)   -  SG(7)<br> TD(2)   -  RD(3)<br> RD(3)   -  TD(2)<br> DCD(8)  -  DTR(20)<br> DTR(20) -  DCD(8)<br>some comm software will wait for DCD before transferring anything.<br>such software will raise DTR to enable the modem to accept a call.<br>with this cable, each side's DTR will drive the other's DCD.<br><br>plan C, null modem with hardware flow control:<br> SG(7)   -  SG(7)<br> TD(2)   -  RD(3)<br> RD(3)   -  TD(2)<br> RTS(4)  -  CTS(5)<br> CTS(5)  -  RTS(4)<br>for high-speed transfers, you want the flow control.<br><br>plan D, deluxe null modem (combine B and C):<br> SG(7)   -  SG(7)<br> TD(2)   -  RD(3)<br> RD(3)   -  TD(2)<br> RTS(4)  -  CTS(5)<br> CTS(5)  -  RTS(4)<br> DCD(8)  -  DTR(20)<br> DTR(20) -  DCD(8)<br>this one is ideal.  it leaves out DSR and RI (rarely used anymore).<br>if you're really paranoid, or you just have an 8th wire to spend,<br>you might add:<br> FG(1)   -  FG(1)<br><br>the pin numbers above are (obviously) for 25-pin connectors.<br>i don't have a 9-pin pinout handy.<br>"		
408	0	"Q: Which version of Adobe PS will we clone?<br> Aside from the level 1 and level 2 issues, Adobe has in the past released<br> new code that incorporates modifications/upgrades/fixes just as all other<br> software vendors do. The level 2 stuff may seem sound now, but I assure<br> you,changes will become more frequent as their customer list begins to<br> dwindle in the face of competition. This allows them to shift people to<br> maintenance, as well as design efforts for level 3.<br><br>Q: Do we duplicate the bugs, or do we make it work correctly?<br> From the LaserWriter to the LaserJet 4 there have been bugs. (If I had<br> a number to call at HP or Adobe, they'ld have heard from me.) Deciding<br> which approach to take depends on which printer you want to emulate.<br><br>Q: Do we follow the Red Book, or do we follow someone's implementation?<br> Without a doubt, there are differences between the Red Book and Adobe's<br> PS. With level 2 many issues have been refined but the Red Book does<br> leave big, big holes in the implementation specific stuff. It would be<br> nice it the Red Bood at least pined things down enough so that two<br> different implementations of Adobe's PS don't do the exact opposite given<br> an identical set of conditions.<br><br>Q: PSCRIPT.DRV?<br> Having done a lot of PS clone testing myself, the unfortunate side of<br> testing is the limited number of sources for test files. The primary<br> source we use is Genoa. And having characterizes their 1992 PS ATS files,<br> (1300+ of them) over half are taken from PSCRIPT.DRV. It may not ideal,<br> but the ATS files are what the printer vendors use. I'm sure that Adobe<br> uses them too, but Adobe's output is by definition correct, even if its<br> wrong.<br><br>Yes, there are some very poor clones. We've seen them here at Rastek (a sub<br>of Genicom which has its own clone called GeniScript). Some are poor for lack<br>of design, some are poor because they followed the Red Book, and some are poor<br>because the vendors don't know what PS is."	"Q: Which version of Adobe PS will we clone?<br> Aside from the level 1 and level 2 issues, Adobe has in the past released<br> new code that incorporates modifications/upgrades/fixes just as all other<br> software vendors do. The level 2 stuff may seem sound now, but I assure<br> you,changes will become more frequent as their customer list begins to<br> dwindle in the face of competition. This allows them to shift people to<br> maintenance, as well as design efforts for level 3.<br><br>Q: Do we duplicate the bugs, or do we make it work correctly?<br> From the LaserWriter to the LaserJet 4 there have been bugs. (If I had<br> a number to call at HP or Adobe, they'ld have heard from me.) Deciding<br> which approach to take depends on which printer you want to emulate.<br><br>Q: Do we follow the Red Book, or do we follow someone's implementation?<br> Without a doubt, there are differences between the Red Book and Adobe's<br> PS. With level 2 many issues have been refined but the Red Book does<br> leave big, big holes in the implementation specific stuff. It would be<br> nice it the Red Bood at least pined things down enough so that two<br> different implementations of Adobe's PS don't do the exact opposite given<br> an identical set of conditions.<br><br>Q: PSCRIPT.DRV?<br> Having done a lot of PS clone testing myself, the unfortunate side of<br> testing is the limited number of sources for test files. The primary<br> source we use is Genoa. And having characterizes their 1992 PS ATS files,<br> (1300+ of them) over half are taken from PSCRIPT.DRV. It may not ideal,<br> but the ATS files are what the printer vendors use. I'm sure that Adobe<br> uses them too, but Adobe's output is by definition correct, even if its<br> wrong.<br><br>Yes, there are some very poor clones. We've seen them here at Rastek (a sub<br>of Genicom which has its own clone called GeniScript). Some are poor for lack<br>of design, some are poor because they followed the Red Book, and some are poor<br>because the vendors don't know what PS is."

418	0	"I've been using Managing Your Money for several years, and I have<br>several friends who use Quicken, though I've not used it myself.  My<br>overall impression is that Quicken is a financial accounts manager<br>while Managing Your Money will help you more completely manage your<br>finances.<br><br>Here are some features that I believe Managing Your Money and Quicken share:<br><br> The ability to keep records for each of your financial accounts:<br> checking, savings, charge, cash, or brokerage.  You can reconcile<br> your account statements with the records the program keeps.<br><br> The ability to make a budget and track your spending against that<br> budget.<br><br> A Checkfree module which will allow you to use the Checkfree bill<br> paying service to pay your bills via your modem.<br> <br> The ability to print checks on your printer.<br><br> The ability to keep loan records and set up automatic loan payments.<br><br> The ability to import stock quotations to keep your brokerage accounts<br> up to date.  I know Managing Your Money can do this automatically<br> via modem.  Quicken probably can as well, but I'm not sure about it.<br><br> The ability to export tax information to popular tax preparation<br> programs.<br><br><br>Here are some features that I believe Managing Your Money has that<br>Quicken does not:<br><br> A tax prediction module.  This looks at your accounts and budget to<br> predict your tax liability for the coming year.  It's usefull to fine<br> tune your withholding so Uncle Sam doesn't get his due too early.<br><br> An insurance and vital records module.  This is a place to keep<br> records of your insurance policies as well as other vital records.<br> It can also compute your life expectancy.<br><br> A financial analysis module.  This computes compound interest, <br> effects of inflation, loan payments term or interest, yield to<br> maturity for bonds, savings account yields, days between dates, and<br> loan amortization schedules.  It also has functions to help you <br> decide whether to refinance your mortgage, whether you can afford<br> a particular home, whether a particular rental property is a good<br> investment, whether you should buy lease or rent, and whether<br> a particular investment's cash flow is adequate for your situation.<br> This module can also help you plan for retirement and for helping<br> your kids with their tuition.  <br><br> A net worth module.  This is a place to record all your assets<br> and liabilities.  Your net worth can be computed from this <br> information.  Any assets or liabilities recorded in other modules<br> are automatically included here.<br><br> A ""desk"" module.  This includes a small word processor, a card file<br> you can use to store names, addresses, phone numbers and other vital<br> information about friends and associates, a perpetual calander, a<br> rudimentary calculator, a to-do list, a reminder list, an appointment<br> list, and a place to record your phone calls (for those who need to<br> track such things).  Your appointments, reminders and to-do list<br> can be made to display automatically when you start the program.<br><br>There are probably some things listed above that Quicken has, but I'm almost<br>sure that Quicken doesn't do everything I've listed.  If I'm wrong, I'm sure<br>hordes of Quicken devotees will flame me to a crisp.<br><br>One thing that Quicken has that Managing Your Money does not yet have is a <br>Windows version.  MECA software is rumored to be working on a Windows version<br>of Managing Your Money for release late this year." This looks at your accounts and budget to<br> predict your tax liability for the coming year. It also has functions to help you <br> decide whether to refinance your mortgage, whether you can afford<br> a particular home, whether a particular rental property is a good<br> investment, whether you should buy lease or rent, and whether<br> a particular investment's cash flow is adequate for your situation.<br> This module can also help you plan for retirement and for helping<br> your kids with their tuition.  <br><br> A net worth module.  This is a place to record all your assets<br> and liabilities.  Your net worth can be computed from this <br> information. 427	1	V for Video - the origional intention of the bus was to speed up<br>the bus so that large memory to memory transfers would be faster.<br>This is espically useful in transfering data from main memory to<br>video memory.<br><br>Since there are usually 3 VLB slots card makers have been making <br>cards to fit in the other two. <br><br>How about an VLB ethernet card? Move the data into the card at<br>130 odd MB/s and then wait for it to tickle onto the net at<br>just over 1Mb/s.<br><br>[ Do do however free the local bus for other cards ]<br><br>Some times you need fast busses and sometimes you don't!<br><br><br>Guy	V for Video - the origional intention of the bus was to speed up<br>the bus so that large memory to memory transfers would be faster.<br>This is espically useful in transfering data from main memory to<br>video memory.<br><br>Since there are usually 3 VLB slots card makers have been making <br>cards to fit in the other two. <br><br>How about an VLB ethernet card? Move the data into the card at<br>130 odd MB/s and then wait for it to tickle onto the net at<br>just over 1Mb/s.<br><br>[ Do do however free the local bus for other cards ]<br><br>Some times you need fast busses and sometimes you don't!<br><br><br>Guy

432	0	"Hi<br>     I have never used MYM so I can not help you with the comparison of the<br>two products.  I am, however,  a devoted Quicken user, and I can tell you<br>how to set up the weekly, monthly, quarterly, yearly transactions.  First<br>use the Memorize feature (CTRL-M) to record the recurring transactions. <br>Next, define a transaction group which uses these memorized transactions<br>and specify the frequency that it should be used (i.e. monthly).  Quicken<br>will/can not automatically make the transactions for you, but now all you<br>do is recall the group and all of the individual transactions will be<br>entered at once.  Additionally if you are using the Bill Minder, it will<br>remind you when each transaction group is due.  For example, you could have<br>three transaction groups.  One for payments at the beginning of the month,<br>middle of the month, and one for quarterly payments.  I hope this helps."	"Hi<br>     I have never used MYM so I can not help you with the comparison of the<br>two products.  I am, however,  a devoted Quicken user, and I can tell you<br>how to set up the weekly, monthly, quarterly, yearly transactions.  First<br>use the Memorize feature (CTRL-M) to record the recurring transactions. <br>Next, define a transaction group which uses these memorized transactions<br>and specify the frequency that it should be used (i.e. monthly).  Quicken<br>will/can not automatically make the transactions for you, but now all you<br>do is recall the group and all of the individual transactions will be<br>entered at once.  Additionally if you are using the Bill Minder, it will<br>remind you when each transaction group is due.  For example, you could have<br>three transaction groups.  One for payments at the beginning of the month,<br>middle of the month, and one for quarterly payments.  I hope this helps."

436	1	"The quality difference is very noticable and is almost worth the wait (for<br>the PS processing) - I'm rather impatient.<br><br>We were using it for B&W camera images (RS-170).  The gray scale image was<br>accepted by MS Word and handed to the Winjet PS printer driver which converts<br>the image into postscript and then hands it off to the Winjets postscript<br>processor.  The postscript is rendered into RAM (lots of it) and when it<br>is done it shoots it directly to the printer.  The PS processor can also<br>accept PS files created from other sources including DOS applications, but<br>Windows has to be running at the time of printing.  The PS processor is<br>responsible for the halftoning and I'd say it does a pretty good job.  Our<br>camera images came out very good in my opinion.  (not as good as Laser Master's<br>demo though).<br><br>I don't know how many other similar products are out there but I would be<br>surprised if there are several." The PS processor is<br>responsible for the halftoning and I'd say it does a pretty good job.  Our<br>camera images came out very good in my opinion. 437	1	"<br><br>    The joystick reads in anolog values through a digital port. How?<br>    You send a command to the port to read it, then you time how long<br>    it takes for the joystick port to set a certain bit.  This time<br>    is proportional to the joystick position.  Obviously, since time<br>    is used as a position, you cannot get rid of this ridiculus waste <br>    of time.  If you wrote your own routine instead of the BIOS, it<br>    would speed it up some, but the time would still be there.<br><br>-- "	"<br><br>    The joystick reads in anolog values through a digital port. How?<br>    You send a command to the port to read it, then you time how long<br>    it takes for the joystick port to set a certain bit.  This time<br>    is proportional to the joystick position.  Obviously, since time<br>    is used as a position, you cannot get rid of this ridiculus waste <br>    of time.  If you wrote your own routine instead of the BIOS, it<br>    would speed it up some, but the time would still be there.<br><br>-- "

442	1	"On the other hand, we just ran into a problem with that here<br>at work on a Gateway computer (4DX-33V).  It has a Modem on COM1,<br>a Mouse on COM2, and the other serial port was set to COM3 (which<br>normally uses the same interrupt as COM1).  We had a real fight<br>with a board when trying to use IRQ5, and discoverd the problem<br>was that Gateway had set it up such that COM3 used IRQ5.  As soon<br>as we disabled COM3, our problems went away.  Grumble ... after<br>several days of trying to figure out why the interrupt didn't work." 446	1	"<br><br><br>One of the monitors I reviewed for the June issue of Windows Magazine was<br>the Mitsubishi.  I also reviewed a new Nanao, the F550iW, which has just<br>been released.  Last year for the May '92 issue of Windows, I reviewed<br>several monitors, including the Nanao T560i.  There's no question that the<br>Nanao monitors are the best available this year, just as they were last<br>year.  The difference between my ranking of the best in Windows and the<br>ranking in Windows Sources is due mainly to a difference in the testing<br>criteria and the scoring.  I used different tests than they did, and I<br>scored differently.  There's nothing wrong with the Mitsubishi, and it<br>scored very highly in my tests, but it was a few points shy of perfect.<br><br>Incidentally, one of the things everyone should do when they're reading<br>reviews of any product, whether it's monitors or mice, is to read the<br>criteria and methodology carefully.  Unless you know how the product<br>testing was done, and on what the scores are based, you can't possibly<br>know what they really mean.  Just seeing that I rank a monitor differently<br>from Windows Sources is meaningless without knowing how we did the<br>ranking.  Likewise, it's impossible to tell whether a monitor will meet<br>your needs unless you know how we did the testing.  After all, some of<br>what we do may not apply to you.  Likewise, some of what we do may apply<br>more closely in one review than in another.  You can't always tell<br>anything from reading the 300 or so words of commentary we write if you<br>don't also understand the scoring."	"<br><br><br>One of the monitors I reviewed for the June issue of Windows Magazine was<br>the Mitsubishi.  I also reviewed a new Nanao, the F550iW, which has just<br>been released. The difference between my ranking of the best in Windows and the<br>ranking in Windows Sources is due mainly to a difference in the testing<br>criteria and the scoring. Just seeing that I rank a monitor differently<br>from Windows Sources is meaningless without knowing how we did the<br>ranking.
