447	1	"You, the Net, are my last resort, or I'll just change my job :-)<br>This might be a FAQ (e.g. mixing controllers) but haven't seen any.<br><br>Sys: 486/33, AMI BIOS, and your run-of-the mill multi-I/O card with<br>serials/paral/floppies and <br> - IDE controller ""clone"" Gw2760-EX<br>  there are no jumpers affecting the HD or ctrller :-( <br> - Quantum ProDrive LPS (3"" 105M type 47: 755cyl, 16hds, 17spt).<br><br>Pb: I want to bring in this (2nd hand, neat price):<br> - Maxtor XT-B380E (~330M, <15ms, BIOS type 1, ctrller manages<br>  the real geom: 1630cyl, 8hds, 52spt)<br> - Western Digital WD1007V-SE1 ESDI ctrller: no floppies.<br>  (jumpers set IRQ 14/15, hw port addr 1F0/170,<br>  and BIOS addr CC00/C800, and other floppy/format stuff)<br><br>Goal: have the WD ESDI as a secondary/controller and have both disks <br>simultaneously working. Being able to boot from the ESDI too would be <br>a nice bonus but is not expected.<br><br>Ultimate goal: have room for Linux et al.<br>Ex of scheme I have in mind: boot from IDE (HD or floppy) and mount<br>the ESDI as root. Not booting from ESDI, or even from HD, is acceptable.<br><br>I have tried numerous (all!!) combinations to no avail. They work alone,<br>or can coexist witout hang-ups but can't access the ESDI or the IDE, <br>depending on setup/jumpers.<br><br>Useful suggestions might be:<br>- How do I tell the BIOS setup about two ctrllers (I guess the 2nd HD<br>is expected to hang off the same ctrller as the 1st).<br>- Do I need some driver to make it work?<br>- --- "" --- some new BIOS/chip for any of these cards?<br>- do I have to buy another controller to make them HDs happy? IDE<br>is cheaper; ESDI is hard to find and rather costly. I'm not <br>rich or I wouldnt' try to scavenge around, so soft slns are preferred.<br>- adapters of some sort; I can hold a soldering iron, and can change<br>a chip or put a jumper!<br><br>Also useful:<br>- BBS or Hot-line of Western Digital.<br>- ftp archives with relevant info.<br>- expert stores in Toronto, Ontario area (that would be a miracle! haven't<br>seen any really knowledgeable ppl in a while)<br>- any hints into inner workings of the system ... <br>- anything else that helped you in similar situations (prayers :-) )<br><br>Direct or posted replies are ok.<br> Many thanks,<br>   Cat."	"You, the Net, are my last resort, or I'll just change my job :-)<br>This might be a FAQ (e.g. mixing controllers) but haven't seen any.<br><br>Sys: 486/33, AMI BIOS, and your run-of-the mill multi-I/O card with<br>serials/paral/floppies and <br> - IDE controller ""clone"" Gw2760-EX<br>  there are no jumpers affecting the HD or ctrller :-( <br> - Quantum ProDrive LPS (3"" 105M type 47: 755cyl, 16hds, 17spt).<br><br>Pb: I want to bring in this (2nd hand, neat price):<br> - Maxtor XT-B380E (~330M, <15ms, BIOS type 1, ctrller manages<br>  the real geom: 1630cyl, 8hds, 52spt)<br> - Western Digital WD1007V-SE1 ESDI ctrller: no floppies.<br>  (jumpers set IRQ 14/15, hw port addr 1F0/170,<br>  and BIOS addr CC00/C800, and other floppy/format stuff)<br><br>Goal: have the WD ESDI as a secondary/controller and have both disks <br>simultaneously working. Being able to boot from the ESDI too would be <br>a nice bonus but is not expected.<br><br>Ultimate goal: have room for Linux et al.<br>Ex of scheme I have in mind: boot from IDE (HD or floppy) and mount<br>the ESDI as root. Not booting from ESDI, or even from HD, is acceptable.<br><br>I have tried numerous (all!!) combinations to no avail. They work alone,<br>or can coexist witout hang-ups but can't access the ESDI or the IDE, <br>depending on setup/jumpers.<br><br>Useful suggestions might be:<br>- How do I tell the BIOS setup about two ctrllers (I guess the 2nd HD<br>is expected to hang off the same ctrller as the 1st).<br>- Do I need some driver to make it work?<br>- --- "" --- some new BIOS/chip for any of these cards?<br>- do I have to buy another controller to make them HDs happy? 450	0	"I tried to respond by email, but all attempts bounced.<br><br>The condition of the Ctrl key BEFORE you press the mouse button makes no<br>difference whatsoever.  You have to be holding the Ctrl key when you<br>RELEASE the mouse button if you want to force a copy operation.<br><br>Here's a simple experiment.  Select a file and begin to drag it (no Ctrl<br>key).  Notice that the file's icon disappears from the listing window.  Now<br>watch what happens to that icon as you press and release the Ctrl key<br>(keeping the mouse button pressed all the while).  In addition, the icon<br>that you are dragging will show a ""+"" while you are holding the Ctrl key,<br>indicating that the file is being copied rather than moved.<br>"	"I tried to respond by email, but all attempts bounced.<br><br>The condition of the Ctrl key BEFORE you press the mouse button makes no<br>difference whatsoever. Select a file and begin to drag it (no Ctrl<br>key).  Notice that the file's icon disappears from the listing window.  Now<br>watch what happens to that icon as you press and release the Ctrl key<br>(keeping the mouse button pressed all the while).  In addition, the icon<br>that you are dragging will show a ""+"" while you are holding the Ctrl key,<br>indicating that the file is being copied rather than moved.<br>"

461	1	"IBM<br>HD Interfaces {limited to hard drives by design or lack of development}:<br>[...]<br>IDE:  Integrated Device Electronics <br> currently the most common standard, and is mainly used for medium sized <br> drives. Can have more than one hard drive. Asynchronous Transfer: ~5MB/s max.<br><br>So at its LOWEST setting SCSI-2 interface in Asynchronous SCSI-1 mode AVERAGES <br>the through put MAXIMUM of IDE in asynchronous mode.  In full SCSI-2 mode<br>it blows poor IDE out the window, down the street, and into the garbage can.<br>The problem becomes can the drive mechanisim keep up with those through put<br>rates and THAT is where the bottleneck and cost of SCSI-2 comes from.  NOT<br>the interface itself but more and more from drive mechanisims to use the<br>SCSI-2 through put.  The cost of SCSI interface is a self fulliling<br>prophisy: few people buy SCSI because it is so expencive for the PC, which<br>in turn convices makes that mass producing SCSI {which would reduce its<br>cost} is unwarented, and so SCSI is expencive. {That is the effect of the<br>Rule of Scale: the more items sold the less EACH item has to bare the brunt<br>the cost of manufacture and so the less each item has to cost}"	"IBM<br>HD Interfaces {limited to hard drives by design or lack of development}:<br>[...]<br>IDE:  Integrated Device Electronics <br> currently the most common standard, and is mainly used for medium sized <br> drives. Can have more than one hard drive. Asynchronous Transfer: ~5MB/s max.<br><br>So at its LOWEST setting SCSI-2 interface in Asynchronous SCSI-1 mode AVERAGES <br>the through put MAXIMUM of IDE in asynchronous mode.  In full SCSI-2 mode<br>it blows poor IDE out the window, down the street, and into the garbage can.<br>The problem becomes can the drive mechanisim keep up with those through put<br>rates and THAT is where the bottleneck and cost of SCSI-2 comes from.  NOT<br>the interface itself but more and more from drive mechanisims to use the<br>SCSI-2 through put.  The cost of SCSI interface is a self fulliling<br>prophisy: few people buy SCSI because it is so expencive for the PC, which<br>in turn convices makes that mass producing SCSI {which would reduce its<br>cost} is unwarented, and so SCSI is expencive. {That is the effect of the<br>Rule of Scale: the more items sold the less EACH item has to bare the brunt<br>the cost of manufacture and so the less each item has to cost}"

": How do I set up Windows so that I can play MIDI files?<br>If you install the Soundblaster windows drivers correctly, and have<br>the latest drivers, the media player should be setup to play files<br>authored to Microsoft's Multimedia midi authoring standard (General<br>Midi), see the section in the back of the Voyetra manual in the<br>Soundblaster midi upgrade kit.<br>You'll find that midi files exist with all kinds of different<br>mappings, so don't expect them to always sound correct without using<br>some kind of midi file editor, such as Voyetra's Sequencer Plus."

The sampling rate can be arranged by an interleave mode where<br>the time equivalent sampling yields 2, 4 or 8 times higher sampling rate than<br>the A/D-Converter uses in non interleave mode.<br><br>The board must content an A/D-Converter similar to Analog Devices AD 9028 or <br>AD 9038 or if available a faster on.<br><br>If you a PC-Board (16-bit slot, ISA) with this specification or better, please<br>send me an EMail<br><br>hansch@cdc2.ikph.uni-hannover.dbp.de<br><br>or a Telefax to: ++49 / 511 / 7629353<br><br><br>Thanks in advance for your help !<br><br>Sincerely<br><br>     Matthias Hansch<br>     IKPH, University of Hannover, Germany<br><br><br><br>---<br><br>Andreas Heinbokel<br><br>heinboke@tnt.uni-hannover.de"	"<br>HIGHSPEED  ANALOG-DIGITAL PC-BOARD<br><br>Hello LAdies and Gentleman !<br><br>I am looking for a highspeed A/D PC-Board with a sampling rate above 250 MHz an a<br>resolution of 8-bit. The sampling rate can be arranged by an interleave mode where<br>the time equivalent sampling yields 2, 4 or 8 times higher sampling rate than<br>the A/D-Converter uses in non interleave mode.<br><br>The board must content an A/D-Converter similar to Analog Devices AD 9028 or <br>AD 9038 or if available a faster on.<br><br>If you a PC-Board (16-bit slot, ISA) with this specification or better, please<br>send me an EMail<br><br>hansch@cdc2.ikph.uni-hannover.dbp.de<br><br>or a Telefax to: ++49 / 511 / 7629353<br><br><br>Thanks in advance for your help !<br><br>Sincerely<br><br>     Matthias Hansch<br>     IKPH, University of Hannover, Germany<br><br><br><br>---<br><br>Andreas Heinbokel<br><br>heinboke@tnt.uni-hannover.de"		
469	1	"When it comes to local dealers:<br><br>- Have fun getting consistently good support.  Most of their ""techs"" are<br>re-treaded salesmen, not trained technicians, with a high turnover rate.<br><br>- Have fun getting in-warranty work done quickly and courteously.<br><br>- Have fun getting out-of-warranty work done cheaply, or even done<br>period, unless you are on a paid service contract.<br><br>Having been both a service technician, and a service manager, at a<br>ComputerLand franchise and another retail computer place, I know what<br>I'm talking about. <br><br>I also know the ""local service"" scam that retail computer dealers like<br>to push when they're selling.  It's that same old song that car dealers<br>having been singing for years -- ""Buy from me and you'll get good<br>service. We always treat our customers right!  Buy from my competition<br>and you'll be sorry if you need service."" <br><br>Experienced mail order buyers know that there are some mail order<br>companies that give excellent service, including overnight replacement parts, <br>on-site calls, etc. There are probably some local dealers that can give you<br>good service, too. But if you think all local dealers give consistenly good <br>service, you are wrong.  I have many anectdotes to prove my point, <br>but I'm sure there are others on the net can do a better job than I can."	"When it comes to local dealers:<br><br>- Have fun getting consistently good support.  Most of their ""techs"" are<br>re-treaded salesmen, not trained technicians, with a high turnover rate.<br><br>- Have fun getting in-warranty work done quickly and courteously.<br><br>- Have fun getting out-of-warranty work done cheaply, or even done<br>period, unless you are on a paid service contract.<br><br>Having been both a service technician, and a service manager, at a<br>ComputerLand franchise and another retail computer place, I know what<br>I'm talking about. <br><br>I also know the ""local service"" scam that retail computer dealers like<br>to push when they're selling.  It's that same old song that car dealers<br>having been singing for years -- ""Buy from me and you'll get good<br>service. We always treat our customers right!  Buy from my competition<br>and you'll be sorry if you need service."" <br><br>Experienced mail order buyers know that there are some mail order<br>companies that give excellent service, including overnight replacement parts, <br>on-site calls, etc. There are probably some local dealers that can give you<br>good service, too. But if you think all local dealers give consistenly good <br>service, you are wrong.  I have many anectdotes to prove my point, <br>but I'm sure there are others on the net can do a better job than I can."

472	0	"<br><br><br>Hi,<br><br>If you have developed your own windows application you must have a <br>SDK of some sort that contains the HC.EXE or HC31.EXE file to <br>compile and generate .HLP files out of .RTF files.<br>RTF files are generated by a wordprocessor like Word for Dos or W4W.<br><br>If this is not the solution be more specific about your application.<br><br>Mario"	"<br><br><br>Hi,<br><br>If you have developed your own windows application you must have a <br>SDK of some sort that contains the HC.EXE or HC31.EXE file to <br>compile and generate .HLP files out of .RTF files.<br>RTF files are generated by a wordprocessor like Word for Dos or W4W.<br><br>If this is not the solution be more specific about your application.<br><br>Mario"

Future evaluation will determine if one is needed.<br><br>PURPOSE: <br>Access is a new RDBMS for the Windows Operating System. It includes WYSIWYG<br>design tools for easy creation of tables, reports, forms and queries and a<br>database programming language called Access Basic.<br>THe purpose of the group will be to provide help to people who use Access's <br>WYSIWYG design tools to create simple databases as well as to people who use <br>Access Basic to create complex databases.<br><br>RATIONALE:<br>Eventhough Access is a new RDBMS, it is very popular because of its Graphical<br>Development enviroment and its initial low price.<br>Been a version 1.0 product means that all Access users are Novices.<br>For that reason a newsgroup is needed where Access users can discuss <br>their experiences with the product and answer each other's questions." Polytron ?).                                       <br><br>I have seen people ask about development in multiple platforms, so I assume that<br>ours is not a new problem. 476	1	"SCSI-1 {with a SCSI-1 controler chip} range is indeed 0-5MB/s<br>and that is ALL you have right about SCSI<br>SCSI-1 {With a SCSI-2 controller chip}: 4-6MB/s with 10MB/s burst {8-bit}<br> Note the INCREASE in SPEED, the Mac Quadra uses this version of SCSI-1<br> so it DOES exist. Some PC use this set up too.<br>SCSI-2 {8-bit/SCSI-1 mode}:          4-6MB/s with 10MB/s burst<br>SCSI-2 {16-bit/wide or fast mode}:  8-12MB/s with 20MB/s burst<br>SCSI-2 {32-bit/wide AND fast}:     15-20MB/s with 40MB/s burst<br> <br>By your OWN data the ""Although SCSI is twice as fast as ESDI"" is correct<br>With a SCSI-2 controller chip SCSI-1 can reach 10MB/s which is indeed<br>""20% faster than IDE"" {120% of 8.3 is 9.96}. ALL these SCSI facts have been<br>posted to this newsgroup in my Mac & IBM info sheet {available by FTP on <br>sumex-aim.stanford.edu (36.44.0.6) in the info-mac/report as <br>mac-ibm-compare[version #].txt (It should be 173 but 161 may still be there)}<br><br>Part of this problem is both Mac and IBM PC are inconsiant about what SCSI<br>is which.  Though it is WELL documented that the Quadra has a SCSI-2 chip<br>an Apple salesperson said ""it uses a fast SCSI-1 chip"" {Not at a 6MB/s,<br>10MB/s burst it does not. SCSI-1 is 5MB/s maximum synchronous and Quadra<br>uses ANsynchronous SCSI which is SLOWER}  It seems that Mac and IBM see<br>SCSI-1 interface and think 'SCSI-1' when it maybe a SCSI-1 interface driven<br>in the machine by a SCSi-2 controller chip in 8-bit mode {Which is MUCH<br>FASTER then true SCSI-1 can go}."	"SCSI-1 {with a SCSI-1 controler chip} range is indeed 0-5MB/s<br>and that is ALL you have right about SCSI<br>SCSI-1 {With a SCSI-2 controller chip}: 4-6MB/s with 10MB/s burst {8-bit}<br> Note the INCREASE in SPEED, the Mac Quadra uses this version of SCSI-1<br> so it DOES exist. Some PC use this set up too.<br>SCSI-2 {8-bit/SCSI-1 mode}:          4-6MB/s with 10MB/s burst<br>SCSI-2 {16-bit/wide or fast mode}:  8-12MB/s with 20MB/s burst<br>SCSI-2 {32-bit/wide AND fast}:     15-20MB/s with 40MB/s burst<br> <br>By your OWN data the ""Although SCSI is twice as fast as ESDI"" is correct<br>With a SCSI-2 controller chip SCSI-1 can reach 10MB/s which is indeed<br>""20% faster than IDE"" {120% of 8.3 is 9.96}. ALL these SCSI facts have been<br>posted to this newsgroup in my Mac & IBM info sheet {available by FTP on <br>sumex-aim.stanford.edu (36.44.0.6) in the info-mac/report as <br>mac-ibm-compare[version #].txt (It should be 173 but 161 may still be there)}<br><br>Part of this problem is both Mac and IBM PC are inconsiant about what SCSI<br>is which.  Though it is WELL documented that the Quadra has a SCSI-2 chip<br>an Apple salesperson said ""it uses a fast SCSI-1 chip"" {Not at a 6MB/s,<br>10MB/s burst it does not. SCSI-1 is 5MB/s maximum synchronous and Quadra<br>uses ANsynchronous SCSI which is SLOWER}  It seems that Mac and IBM see<br>SCSI-1 interface and think 'SCSI-1' when it maybe a SCSI-1 interface driven<br>in the machine by a SCSi-2 controller chip in 8-bit mode {Which is MUCH<br>FASTER then true SCSI-1 can go}."		
477	1	"The 2 lines are not a result of the high end trinitron tube, these<br>2 wires will be found on all 17"" trinitron tubes (e.g., Mitsubishi 17"",<br>Sony 1604, etc).  On 14"" Sony tubes, you'll find one wire.<br><br>Their level of annoyance is purely subjective.  I'm so happy with the<br>sharpness of the T560i that I don't even notice the lines.<br><br>The T560i uses a Trinitron SA tube which, when viewed as a complete tube,<br>has a larger diameter than the standard Trinitron tube.  This results in <br>a flatter screen than other 17"" monitors using the standard trinitron <br>(which has a vertically flat but not horizontally flat surface), and <br>apparently the ability to provide a tighter beam focus.  <br>"	"The 2 lines are not a result of the high end trinitron tube, these<br>2 wires will be found on all 17"" trinitron tubes (e.g., Mitsubishi 17"",<br>Sony 1604, etc).  On 14"" Sony tubes, you'll find one wire.<br><br>Their level of annoyance is purely subjective.  I'm so happy with the<br>sharpness of the T560i that I don't even notice the lines.<br><br>The T560i uses a Trinitron SA tube which, when viewed as a complete tube,<br>has a larger diameter than the standard Trinitron tube.  This results in <br>a flatter screen than other 17"" monitors using the standard trinitron <br>(which has a vertically flat but not horizontally flat surface), and <br>apparently the ability to provide a tighter beam focus.  <br>"		
478	1	"<br>If you ran dos, you don't need a 16550, because dos runs only ONE task at a<br>time and the whole cpu-power could be used for the transfer. But if you are<br>running a multitasking OS such as OS/2, Unix, etc. ( windows ? :-) ), the<br>cpu cannot work the whole time with one task. <br><br>The result are lost characters or broken transmissions because of timeouts.<br><br><br>NO. The only diffrence is that internal modems have the UART on board,<br>whereas external modems are connected to the computer over a serial port<br>which has the UART on board.<br><br><br>I use a Zyxel1496B with a 16550UART under COHERENT 4.0. I'm very satisfied<br>with it but I think that nearly everyone is satisfied with his own modem.<br><br>Michael"	"<br>If you ran dos, you don't need a 16550, because dos runs only ONE task at a<br>time and the whole cpu-power could be used for the transfer. But if you are<br>running a multitasking OS such as OS/2, Unix, etc. ( windows ? :-) ), the<br>cpu cannot work the whole time with one task. <br><br>The result are lost characters or broken transmissions because of timeouts.<br><br><br>NO. The only diffrence is that internal modems have the UART on board,<br>whereas external modems are connected to the computer over a serial port<br>which has the UART on board.<br><br><br>I use a Zyxel1496B with a 16550UART under COHERENT 4.0. I'm very satisfied<br>with it but I think that nearly everyone is satisfied with his own modem.<br><br>Michael"

480	0	"You could use DOS 6 to do this partly.  You can set up different config.sys<br>and autoexec.bat commands for each user, and they just have to select their<br>menu option on bootup.  Then you can have the autoexec.bat copy the win.ini<br>and system.ini files and change directories for them.  When they exit windows,<br>it can copy back generic .ini files if you want.<br><br>This is the only way I can think of.  There may be some programs somewhere<br>that allow you to do this better, though using DOS 6 allows each person to<br>have a custom config.sys and autoexec.bat."	"You could use DOS 6 to do this partly.  You can set up different config.sys<br>and autoexec.bat commands for each user, and they just have to select their<br>menu option on bootup.  Then you can have the autoexec.bat copy the win.ini<br>and system.ini files and change directories for them.  When they exit windows,<br>it can copy back generic .ini files if you want.<br><br>This is the only way I can think of.  There may be some programs somewhere<br>that allow you to do this better, though using DOS 6 allows each person to<br>have a custom config.sys and autoexec.bat."

484	1	"What is the deal with the IDE transfer rates?  Is anybody getting throughput<br>anywhere close to the platter->controller rate?  I haven't seen anything<br>even close to the 5MB/sec limit of the IDE interface.  These drives are 1:1<br>(non-interleaved), aren't they?<br><br>Here are the rates I get:<br><br>1) sequential read (MSDOS C program that uses bios calls to read 64-sector<br>                    blocks sequentially from outside (first) track inward)<br><br>                     8mhz bus    10mhz bus<br>                     --------    ---------<br>   MAXTOR LXT340:    860KB/sec   976KB/sec<br>   QUANTUM LPS240:   862KB/sec   887KB/sec<br><br>2) disk buffer read (same C program, but re-reads the same block repeatedly<br>                     so in effect is reading the RAM buffer on the drive)<br><br>                     8mhz bus    10mhz bus<br>                     --------    ---------<br>   MAXTOR LXT340:   1046KB/sec  1212KB/sec<br>   QUANTUM LPS240:  1015KB/sec  1276KB/sec<br><br>3) CORETEST V2.7 transfer rate (seems to agree with (2) above)<br><br>                     8mhz bus    10mhz bus<br>                     --------    ---------<br>   MAXTOR LXT340:   1051KB/sec  1224KB/sec<br>   QUANTUM LPS240:  1026KB/sec  1298KB/sec<br><br>I managed to get hold of the QUANTUM LPS240AT product manual and it goes<br>into excrutiating detail describing how the bits get from the platter,<br>through the controller, and out the IDE interface.  Nowhere do I see<br>anything like ""after the bits are whipped of the platter at high speed<br>they sit around in a buffer to thaw before they are sent to the host""<br>(even though I SWEAR that's whats happening ;->).  Here are some relevent<br>quotes from the manual:<br><br>  ""Data is transferred from the disk to the read buffer at a rate of<br>   3.75 MB/s maximum, 1.87MB/s minimum.""  (My calculations show 3121KB/sec<br>   maximum and 1578KB/sec minimum...  disk spins at 4306 RPM with 87<br>   sectors per track on the outside and 44 on the inside)<br><br>  ""Single burst errors of up to 24 bits within one sector can be corrected<br>   'on-the-fly', in real time as they occur, allowing a high degree of<br>   data integrity with no impact to the drive's performance.""  (I take<br>   this to mean error correction isn't the bottleneck)<br><br>  ""For page-mode operations, the data-transfer rate to and from the buffer<br>   RAM is up to 10.0 MB/s. This high transfer rate allows the AT Interface<br>   IC to communicate over the AT bus at a data-transfer rate of 5.0 MB/s,<br>   while the DCS simultaneously controls disk-to-RAM transfers""<br>                 ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^<br>So the thing can even do it's cache pre-fetch WHILE it's sending the<br>requested sector (it has 3 64KB read buffers for pre-fetching, I guess<br>you could call that a cache :-|).<br><br>So when I do a sequential read on the outer tracks, WHY am I getting a<br>measly 862KB/sec when I should be getting around 3MB/sec???<br><br>Any of you hard-disk engineers out there know?<br>"	"What is the deal with the IDE transfer rates?  Is anybody getting throughput<br>anywhere close to the platter->controller rate?  I haven't seen anything<br>even close to the 5MB/sec limit of the IDE interface.  These drives are 1:1<br>(non-interleaved), aren't they?<br><br>Here are the rates I get:<br><br>1) sequential read (MSDOS C program that uses bios calls to read 64-sector<br>                    blocks sequentially from outside (first) track inward)<br><br>                     8mhz bus    10mhz bus<br>                     --------    ---------<br>   MAXTOR LXT340:    860KB/sec   976KB/sec<br>   QUANTUM LPS240:   862KB/sec   887KB/sec<br><br>2) disk buffer read (same C program, but re-reads the same block repeatedly<br>                     so in effect is reading the RAM buffer on the drive)<br><br>                     8mhz bus    10mhz bus<br>                     --------    ---------<br>   MAXTOR LXT340:   1046KB/sec  1212KB/sec<br>   QUANTUM LPS240:  1015KB/sec  1276KB/sec<br><br>3) CORETEST V2.7 transfer rate (seems to agree with (2) above)<br><br>                     8mhz bus    10mhz bus<br>                     --------    ---------<br>   MAXTOR LXT340:   1051KB/sec  1224KB/sec<br>   QUANTUM LPS240:  1026KB/sec  1298KB/sec<br><br>I managed to get hold of the QUANTUM LPS240AT product manual and it goes<br>into excrutiating detail describing how the bits get from the platter,<br>through the controller, and out the IDE interface.  Nowhere do I see<br>anything like ""after the bits are whipped of the platter at high speed<br>they sit around in a buffer to thaw before they are sent to the host""<br>(even though I SWEAR that's whats happening ;->).  Here are some relevent<br>quotes from the manual:<br><br>  ""Data is transferred from the disk to the read buffer at a rate of<br>   3.75 MB/s maximum, 1.87MB/s minimum.""  (My calculations show 3121KB/sec<br>   maximum and 1578KB/sec minimum...  disk spins at 4306 RPM with 87<br>   sectors per track on the outside and 44 on the inside)<br><br>  ""Single burst errors of up to 24 bits within one sector can be corrected<br>   'on-the-fly', in real time as they occur, allowing a high degree of<br>   data integrity with no impact to the drive's performance.""  (I take<br>   this to mean error correction isn't the bottleneck)<br><br>  ""For page-mode operations, the data-transfer rate to and from the buffer<br>   RAM is up to 10.0 MB/s. This high transfer rate allows the AT Interface<br>   IC to communicate over the AT bus at a data-transfer rate of 5.0 MB/s,<br>   while the DCS simultaneously controls disk-to-RAM transfers""<br>                 ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^<br>So the thing can even do it's cache pre-fetch WHILE it's sending the<br>requested sector (it has 3 64KB read buffers for pre-fetching, I guess<br>you could call that a cache :-|).<br><br>So when I do a sequential read on the outer tracks, WHY am I getting a<br>measly 862KB/sec when I should be getting around 3MB/sec???<br><br>Any of you hard-disk engineers out there know?<br>"
