486	1	"One very suspicious point that came up later was that he stated that none<br>of the Windows Accelerator boards have working 16 and/or 24 bit drivers<br>for Windows 3.1.  I easily challenged him on that because I've been<br>running a Diamond 24x in 15 bit mode at home for 4 months now, and I have<br>""Well, Diamond has been working on those drivers much longer.""  Anyway, I<br>just wanted to see if anyone else had any trouble and what they did about<br>it.  Any feedback will be appreciated.<br><br>The system configuration is:<br><br>Gateway 486 DX2/66 Local Bus<br>16 Megs Ram<br>SCSI HD & CD-ROM<br>Ultrastor 34F Local Bus SCSI controller<br>ATI Ultra Pro Local Bus with 2MB VRAM<br>DOS 6.0<br>Windows 3.1<br>Mach 32 drivers version 1.5 (build 59)<br><br>Thanks in advance."	"One very suspicious point that came up later was that he stated that none<br>of the Windows Accelerator boards have working 16 and/or 24 bit drivers<br>for Windows 3.1.  I easily challenged him on that because I've been<br>running a Diamond 24x in 15 bit mode at home for 4 months now, and I have<br>""Well, Diamond has been working on those drivers much longer.""  Anyway, I<br>just wanted to see if anyone else had any trouble and what they did about<br>it.  Any feedback will be appreciated.<br><br>The system configuration is:<br><br>Gateway 486 DX2/66 Local Bus<br>16 Megs Ram<br>SCSI HD & CD-ROM<br>Ultrastor 34F Local Bus SCSI controller<br>ATI Ultra Pro Local Bus with 2MB VRAM<br>DOS 6.0<br>Windows 3.1<br>Mach 32 drivers version 1.5 (build 59)<br><br>Thanks in advance."		
487	1	"     Here's a document that I wrote some time back.  It's slightly<br>out-of-date, now that DOS 6 has been released, but much of it is still<br>useful.<br><br>     -- Darryl Okahata<br> Internet: darrylo@sr.hp.com<br><br>DISCLAIMER: this message is the author's personal opinion and does not<br>constitute the support, opinion or policy of Hewlett-Packard or of the<br>little green men that have been following him all day.<br><br>===============================================================================<br>$Id: adaptec.txt 1.8 1993/01/25 00:55:08 darrylo Rel darrylo $<br>          Hints and Tips for the Adaptec 1540/1542 SCSI adapter<br><br><br>     This document contains hints and tips for getting the Adaptec<br>1540/1542 SCSI adapter to work with various hardware and software<br>packages.  They are based upon my experiences with an Adaptec 1542A<br>controller, and will, hopefully, help others.  However, note that I<br>cannot guarantee that the following will really help you (it works for<br>me), and the information in this document could possibly cause you to<br>lose some or all of your files on your hard disk.<br><br>     IMPORTANT!  BACK UP THE ENTIRE CONTENTS OF YOUR HARD DISK BEFORE<br>TRYING ANYTHING BASED UPON INFORMATION IN THIS DOCUMENT.<br><br>     Copyright 1993, by Darryl Okahata.  This document may be freely<br>copied for personal use only, and may not be reprinted in a for-profit<br>publication without the consent of the author.  Please note that I have<br>no connection with Adaptec other than as a customer.<br><br>Topics covered in this document:<br><br> * Windows 3.1 enhanced mode<br> * Floppy-controller-based tape backup devices<br> * Sound cards<br> * Miscellaneous info<br><br>     Please note that parts of this document contain technical, and<br>sometimes terse, descriptions of problems.<br><br>For reference:<br><br> Adaptec technical support: (800) 959-7274<br> Adaptec BBS (2400/9600): (408) 945-7727<br><br>Please send comments, corrections, etc. via email to me:<br><br> CompuServe: 75206,3074<br> Internet: darrylo@sr.hp.com<br><br><br>***** Windows 3.1 enhanced mode:<br><br>     The Windows 3.1 install program should automatically configure DOS<br>and Windows for use with the Adaptec 1542.  However, just in case<br>something went wrong, I'm going to describe some of the changes needed<br>to get Windows 3.1 working with the 1542.  Also, you may have noticed<br>that installing Windows 3.1 makes your PC run much slower, even when<br>you're not running Windows; methods of speeding it up are discussed in<br>the section called, ""Windows 3.1 runs slowly"".<br><br><br>* MSDOS configuration:<br><br>     The Windows install program adds the SmartDrive disk cache to your<br>CONFIG.SYS and AUTOEXEC.BAT files.  If you follow the instructions,<br>you'll notice that you'll need to use double-buffering with SmartDrive<br>(this is the default setup).  You'll also notice that your system runs<br>much, much slower -- in both Windows *AND* MSDOS.  See the section<br>called, ""Windows 3.1 runs slowly"", for some ways of speeding your system<br>up.<br><br><br>* Windows configuration:<br><br>     To get the Adaptec 1542 to work with Windows, make sure that the<br>""[388Enh]"" section of the SYSTEM.INI file contains the entry:<br><br> VirtualHDIRQ=Off<br><br>I believe that the Windows install program automatically adds this entry<br>to SYSTEM.INI, but I'm not sure.  If this doesn't work for you, you<br>might want to try adding some more lines:<br><br> VirtualHDIRQ=Off<br> SystemROMBreakPoint=false<br> EMMExclude=A000-CFFF<br><br>(You probably don't need the above lines, though.)  The<br>""SystemROMBreakPoint"" entry is used to enable support for memory<br>managers like QEMM/386MAX (only needed if you use such programs).<br><br><br>* Windows 3.1 runs slowly:<br><br>     Once you do get Windows 3.1 running with the 1542, chances are that<br>your system is running much slower than before.  If it's not, it's<br>probably because:<br><br>     1. You happen to be using ASPI4DOS.SYS version 3.1 in your<br> CONFIG.SYS file.  Congratulations -- this appears to be a<br> winning solution.<br><br>     2. You are very lucky.  Whether your luck will hold out remains to<br> be seen ....<br><br>If your system is running much slower than before, this is almost<br>definitely caused by Smartdrive with double-buffering.  According to the<br>Windows documentation, and the Microsoft technical note #Q81808<br>(""SMARTDrive Double Buffering Required with ASPI4DOS.SYS""), you must use<br>Smartdrive with double-buffering enabled.  While this works, it really<br>slows down your PC; I once estimated that this slowed my PC down by a<br>factor of 5 (FIVE).  As I consider this unacceptable, I looked for other<br>solutions.<br><br>     Unfortunately, you cannot just disable double-buffering.  If you<br>do, Windows 3.1 in enhanced mode will not work, and you might even<br>destroy the contents of your hard disk by trying to run Windows 3.1.<br>What you can do is one of the following:<br><br>     1. Use other drivers that provide double-buffering.  It is my<br> opinion that the unbelievable slowness in Smartdrive is caused<br> either by horribly inefficient double-buffering, or by a bug in<br> Smartdrive.<br><br>     2. Use a driver that provides ""VDS"" services (""VDS"" stands for<br> ""Virtual DMA Services"").  This is a standard, which is supported<br> by Windows 3.1, that allows bus-mastering disk controllers (like<br> the 1542) to work with Windows.<br><br>     After trashing my hard disk countless times, I found the following<br>solutions, none of which require using Smartdrive (note, however, that I<br>am now getting occasional parity errors, which are probably *NOT* caused<br>by these solutions, but might be -- see below).  While the following<br>does not require Smartdrive, using some kind of disk cache utility is<br>strongly recommended, as this makes Windows run much, much faster:<br><br>1. If you do not have the ASPI4DOS.SYS driver, or you do not need ASPI<br>   functions (for controlling a CDROM, tape drive, more than two<br>   physical hard disks, etc.), you can add the SCSIHA.SYS driver to your<br>   CONFIG.SYS file, e.g.:<br><br> DRIVER=c:\SCSIHA.SYS /V386<br><br>   (Windows needs the ""/V386"" option.)  This driver MUST be loaded into<br>   LOW memory (it cannot be loaded into high memory), and it occupies<br>   about 16-20K.  As of November 1992, the SCSIHA.SYS driver could be<br>   obtained from the Adaptec BBS at (408)-945-7727 (hopefully, it's<br>   still there).<br><br>2. If you need ASPI functions and have the ASPI4DOS.SYS driver, version<br>   3.0 or 3.0a, you can use both the ASPI4DOS.SYS and SCSIHA.SYS drivers<br>   in your CONFIG.SYS file, e.g.:<br><br> DRIVER=c:\ASPI4DOS.SYS<br> DRIVER=c:\SCSIHA.SYS /V386<br><br>   Amazingly enough, the SCSIHA.SYS driver can also be loaded high<br>   (assuming you have DOS 5.0); I would have thought that this would<br>   crash my system, but it doesn't.  I asked Adaptec's technical support<br>   about this, and they said that loading SCSIHA.SYS high should be fine<br>   as long as ASPI4DOS.SYS is loaded LOW.<br><br>   On my system, NOT using SCSIHA.SYS with ASPI4DOS 3.0a would<br>   occasionally cause Windows 3.1 to crash upon restarting or exiting<br>   Windows, with the additional result of a corrupted disk (some of my<br>   C:\WINDOWS\*.GRP files would be corrupted).  For me, these crashes<br>   usually occurred while making a different program from PROGMAN.EXE<br>   the default Windows shell, and vice-versa.  This is the reason<br>   SCSIHA.SYS may be necessary.<br><br>   I have absolutely no idea if SCSIHA.SYS is necessary with versions of<br>   ASPI4DOS earlier than 3.0.<br><br>   Note that many people can use ASPI4DOS 3.0 or 3.0a without<br>   SCSIHA.SYS; they do not seem to have any problems at all.  I consider<br>   these people lucky.  Others, like me, have had all sorts of problems.<br><br>3. In my opinion, the best, but not necessarily the easiest, solution is<br>   to upgrade to ASPI4DOS 3.1.  The SCSIHA.SYS driver is no longer<br>   needed.  Unfortunately, while you could get previous ASPI4DOS<br>   upgrades from the Adaptec BBS, the ASPI4DOS 3.1 driver is not<br>   available from the Adaptec BBS.  As far as I know, there are only<br>   three ways to get a copy:<br><br>      * You can buy the new (as of November 1992) Adaptec EZ SCSI driver<br> kit, which supposedly includes ASPI4DOS 3.1 as well as other<br> drivers, such as CDROM drivers.  I believe the list price is<br> around $75.<br><br>      * If you already have a copy of an older version of ASPI4DOS, you<br> can supposedly contact Adaptec to upgrade it to EZ SCSI for<br> around $30.<br><br>      * A copy of ASPI4DOS 3.1 is included in Central Point PC Tools 8.0<br> for MSDOS.  Note that the documentation and driver are stored in<br> different directories.  Note further that only ASPI4DOS is<br> included; the CDROM drivers and drivers to support more than two<br> hard disks are not included.  This is where I obtained my copy<br> of ASPI4DOS 3.1.<br><br>Note, however, that I am now getting occasional parity errors with<br>Windows.  In all probability, defective hardware in my PC is causing<br>this, as I upgraded my motherboard just after I found the above<br>solutions.  However, because these parity errors occur only during disk<br>accesses, there is a very small, but definite, possibility that the<br>parity errors are driver-related (for example, changing the bus on/off<br>timing for certain disk transfers might cause this).  I've run various<br>memory tests for hours at a time, and these tests have found no<br>problems.  This problem is probably caused by memory with marginal<br>timing requirements, which cause parity errors during disk transfers<br>(this is why the memory tests didn't find any problems -- the problems<br>show up only under disk I/O).  However, I'm mentioning this just in case<br>it isn't a hardware problem.<br><br><br>***** Floppy-controller-based tape backup devices:<br><br>     There are two possible problems with using the Adaptec 1542 with a<br>floppy-controller-based tape backup device, such as the Colorado Memory<br>Systems Jumbo 250:<br><br>1. Tape backups/restores can take a very long time.  The tape drive<br>   constantly starts, stops, starts, stops, etc.<br><br>2. Tape operations may be erratic, or encounter too many tape errors.<br>   (This problem might be caused by defective hardware on my 1542.<br>   However, I've heard of other people having similar problems, and so<br>   I'm mentioning this just in case it is not a hardware problem on my<br>   1542.)<br><br><br>* Tape backups/restores take a long time:<br><br>     If you have a floppy-controller-based tape backup device, you may<br>have to adjust the Adaptec 1540/1542 ""bus on/off timing"" for best<br>results when using the tape drive.  Normally, while doing a tape backup<br>or restore, the tape drive motor should be continuously running, with<br>only an occasional pause.  However, the default bus timing on the<br>Adaptec 1540/1542 may cause the tape drive motor to start and stop,<br>start and stop, every few seconds.  This causes needless wear to the<br>tape and tape drive (however, note that a dirty tape head or a defective<br>tape drive can also cause this -- make sure your tape heads are clean).<br>This also causes the tape backup or restore to take much, much longer<br>than necessary.<br><br>     The problem here is that these tape backups use the floppy DMA to<br>transfer data in memory to/from the tape drive, and the Adaptec uses DMA<br>to transfer data in memory to/from the hard disk.  The floppy DMA needs<br>to feed data to the tape drive at a certain rate; if the tape drive is<br>not fed data quickly enough by the floppy DMA, the tape drive stops,<br>rewinds a bit, and restarts (once enough data is eventually fed to it).<br>The default bus timing on the Adaptec (which is really DMA timing) is<br>""too large"".  For example, when a backup is done, data has to be<br>transferred from a hard disk to memory, and then from memory to the<br>tape.  Because the default timing on the Adaptec ""hogs"" the memory too<br>much (too much time is spent transferring data from a hard disk to<br>memory), not enough time is spent transferring data from memory to the<br>tape drive.  As a result, the tape drive constantly starts and stops,<br>because data is not fed to it quickly enough.<br><br>     The solution is to change the Adaptec's bus on/off timing.  The<br>default factory setting is 11 microseconds on, and 5 microseconds off.<br>The ""bus on"" timing needs to be lowered to 2-4 microseconds.  This can<br>be done in one of two ways:<br><br>* If you have ASPI4DOS, you can use the ""/n"" option.  For example, I use<br>  a ""bus on"" timing of 4 microseconds, which means that I use the<br>  following line in my CONFIG.SYS file:<br><br> DEVICE=c:\aspi4dos.sys /n4<br><br>  Note that there is NO space between the ""/n"" and the ""4"".<br><br>* If you don't have ASPI4DOS, your only recourse is to try to find a<br>  program called ""SETSCSI.EXE"", which is very difficult to find.  The<br>  reason is that Adaptec, for reasons of their own, does not seem to<br>  want this widely distributed.  I once asked someone who worked for<br>  Adaptec, and they asked me to not upload it anywhere.  If you have<br>  anonymous ftp access to the Internet, you could try using archie to<br>  hunt down a copy; I believe that there are a couple of sites that have<br>  it.  If you do find a copy, you run it like so:<br><br> setscsi -n:4<br><br>  This adjusts the ""bus on"" timing to 4 microseconds.  Running<br>  SETSCSI.EXE without any arguments resets the bus timing back to the<br>  factory defaults.<br><br>  Note that it seems that you cannot use SETSCSI.EXE if you use<br>  ASPI4DOS; SETSCSI.EXE crashed my system if ASPI4DOS was loaded.  I<br>  could use SETSCSI.EXE with SCSIHA.SYS, however.<br><br>Do not lower the ""bus on"" timing below 2 microseconds, or increase it<br>above 11 microseconds.  If you lower it too low, the hard disk<br>throughput will suddenly drop; your system will feel slower.  For me, 4<br>microseconds works fine.  This value may work fine for you, or you may<br>have to adjust it downwards a little.<br><br>     Once you've lowered the ""bus on"" timing, tape backups and restores<br>should run faster.<br><br>     Also, do not experiment with the bus on/off times (with the other<br>options that I have intentionally not described), unless you know what<br>you are doing.  Bad combinations can cause parity errors and worse, by<br>starving memory refresh.<br><br>     A program called BUSTIFIX.EXE exists on the Adaptec BBS.  Unless<br>this has been upgraded since I last checked (which has been a while),<br>this is a self-extracting archive containing a batch file and a couple<br>of other files.  This batch file was supposed to allow one to set the<br>bus on/off times for the 1540/1542 and others.  However, when I tried<br>running this program with my 1542A, my system crashed.  At the time, I<br>was running SCSIHA.SYS, and I didn't check to see if there was a<br>conflict with it.  Maybe this old program works only with the 1542B,<br>although the docs say that it works with the 1542A?<br><br><br>* Erratic tape operations or too many tape errors:<br><br>     This ""problem"" may or may not exist.  Although it existed on my<br>system, a hardware problem just on my particular 1542 could cause it.<br>However, I've heard of other people having similar problems, and so I'm<br>mentioning this just in case it isn't a hardware problem just on my<br>1542.<br><br>     Symptoms of this ""problem"", which persists even after cleaning the<br>tape head:<br><br>1. Backing up to tape encounters ""unusable sector detected"" errors,<br>   resulting in an aborted tape backup.<br><br>2. Tape backup works, but the tape compare fails.<br><br>3. The tape drive starts, stops, starts, stops, etc. much too often.<br>   Unlike the above-mentioned problem (""Tape backups/restores take a<br>   long time""), where the tape drive starts and stops every few seconds,<br>   this kind of starting/stopping occurs every few 10-20 seconds or so.<br><br>4. Fastback Plus 3.1 does not find/see any tape backup devices.  Other<br>   programs, like Central Point Backup and the CMS Jumbo software<br>   (assuming that you have a CMS Jumbo 250 tape drive) can find/see the<br>   tape drive, but Fastback Plus 3.1 cannot.<br><br>5. Too many tape read errors.<br><br>     Although I do not know what is causing this problem, I discovered<br>that using a different floppy controller solves it.  A few months ago, I<br>upgraded my motherboard, which contained an integrated floppy<br>controller.  As I already had a floppy controller on the 1542, I<br>initially disabled the motherboard floppy controller.  After a while, I<br>decided to try disabling the 1542 floppy controller and using the one on<br>the motherboard.  When I did this, the tape drive (a CMS Jumbo 250)<br>reliability increased dramatically, and Fastback Plus 3.1 was suddenly<br>able to find and use the tape drive.<br><br>     I don't know if this was caused by a hardware problem on my 1542.<br>On the one hand, the floppy drives worked great when they were attached<br>to the 1542, which seems to say that there was nothing wrong with the<br>1542.  On the other hand, the tape drive didn't work well attached to<br>the 1542 floppy controller, but it did work when attached to a different<br>controller; this could be an indication of a hardware problem on my<br>1542.  I did change floppy drive cables, and so it is conceivable that<br>the problem was in the cables.  I don't know what the cause really is;<br>however, if you're having similar problems, you might want to consider<br>trying a new floppy controller.<br><br><br>***** Sound cards:<br><br>     Many popular sound cards can play or record digitized sound, and<br>this is typically done using DMA.  Like the tape drive DMA, the<br>Adaptec's DMA can conflict with the sound card DMA.  Unlike that of the<br>tape DMA, this ""conflict"" usually manifests itself as a parity error<br>(your system crashes with a parity error message).  What happens is<br>that, data is being transferred so quickly by the sound card and the<br>Adaptec, memory refresh cannot occur quickly enough, which causes a<br>parity error.  Usually, getting a parity error means that there is a<br>hardware problem with your system; in this case, however, the parity<br>error is not a symptom of bad hardware.<br><br>     I've found that such parity errors typically occur while recording<br>digitized sound, and the chances of such errors increase as you increase<br>the recording fidelity (e.g., higher sampling rate, recording in stereo,<br>recording using 16-bits instead of 8, etc.).<br><br>     Like the tape drive solution, the solution here is to lower the<br>Adaptec's ""bus on"" timing.  See the section on tape drives for<br>information on how this is done.  Note, however, that this may or may<br>not solve the problem; it may only reduce the probability of a parity<br>error.  The software used to record digitized sound can greatly affect<br>this problem (i.e., some software is inefficient).  Disk caches, the<br>speed of your hard disk, and the amount of disk fragmentation can also<br>affect this.<br><br><br>***** Miscellaneous info:<br><br>     This section contains miscellaneous hints, tips, and rumors.  Much<br>of it is merely information that I've heard or read about, and have not<br>verified.  I believe that the following information is correct, but I'm<br>not sure.  Use it at your own risk.<br><br>* With QEMM 6.00, 6.01, and 6.02, you need to specify the ""DB=""<br>  parameter (e.g., ""DB=2""), unless you are using the ASPI4DOS driver.<br>  If you don't, QEMM will crash/hang at bootup.  Although the QEMM<br>  manual mentions this, the install program does not seem to detect that<br>  a 1542 is present and automatically add this option to the QEMM<br>  command line (at least, this occurred with the QEMM 6.00 install<br>  program -- I haven't tested any other version).  Earlier versions of<br>  QEMM probably need this parameter, but I'm not sure (I've never used a<br>  version earlier than 6.00).<br><br>  If you use ASPI4DOS, you do not need to give QEMM the ""DB="" parameter.<br><br>* Some or all versions of the 1542 do not support hard disks over one<br>  gigabyte in size.  To support hard disks with capacities over 1GB, you<br>  need to get a new ROM BIOS from Adaptec.  I'm not sure if this is<br>  still true of the latest 1542Bs being sold by Adaptec.<br><br>* To connect a CDROM drive to the 1542, you need a SCSI CDROM drive and<br>  some drivers.  Note that some CDROM drives have proprietary interfaces<br>  (non-SCSI); these drives cannot be used with the 1542.  You have three<br>  choices for CDROM drivers (I have no idea how well the following<br>  solutions work, or even if they work -- the following is secondhand<br>  information):<br><br>     1. You can buy Adaptec's EZ SCSI driver package, which lists for<br> something like $75.  If you already have older Adaptec drivers,<br> you can supposedly upgrade to EZ SCSI for around $30.  Contact<br> Adaptec for details.  The EZ SCSI package supposedly contains<br> everything that you need.<br><br>     2. You can buy the CorelSCSI! driver package, which is made by the<br> same people that make CorelDRAW!  This package contains CDROM<br> drivers, SCSI tape drivers, WORM drivers, etc.  I do not know<br> the list price, but I've seen this package sold for around<br> $80-$90.  Note that CorelSCSI! does not come with the ASPI4DOS<br> driver, which is needed.  If you do not already have ASPI4DOS,<br> you may be better off getting Adaptec's EZ SCSI instead.<br><br>     3. [This method is obsolete, as the following drivers have been<br> obsoleted by Adaptec's EZ SCSI kit, but I'm mentioning it in<br> case someone already has these drivers.]  You can use the<br> drivers in the Adaptec ASW-1410 kit (ASPI4DOS) and the ASW-410<br> kit (ASPI CDROM drivers).  You will have to get a copy of<br> MSCDEX.EXE (a high-level CDROM driver), if it is not included in<br> the ASW-410 kit, but this is available from several bulletin<br> boards.<br><br>* To use a SCSI tape drive with the 1542, you need software that knows<br>  how to talk to a SCSI tape drive.  Software that I've heard about are<br>  (again, like the above section on CDROM drives, I have no idea how<br>  well the following solutions work, or even if they work -- the<br>  following is secondhand information):<br><br>     1. Central Point PC Tools 8.0 for MSDOS supposedly supports a large<br> number of SCSI tape drives.  It comes with SCSI drivers<br> (ASPI4DOS 3.1) as well as Central Point Backup.<br><br>     2. The CorelSCSI! driver package contains a SCSI tape backup<br> program (see the above section on CDROM drives for more<br> details).  However, note that CorelSCSI! does not come with, but<br> requires, ASPI4DOS.<br><br>* I've seen advertisements that sell the 1542 in three configurations:<br><br>     1. 1542 SCSI controller with hard disk ROM BIOS.<br>     2. 1542 SCSI controller w/BIOS and Adaptec ASPI drivers.<br>     3. 1542 SCSI controller w/BIOS, Adaptec ASPI drivers, and<br> CorelSCSI! drivers/programs.<br><br>  I imagine that Adaptec now sells the 1542 in a fourth configuration:<br><br>     4. 1542 SCSI controller w/BIOS and EZ SCSI drivers (including ASPI<br> drivers).<br><br>* Those people who use Unix might be interested in a version of GNU tar<br>  for MSDOS that talks to a SCSI tape drive via the ASPI4DOS driver (you<br>  need this driver before you can use this program).  I've never used<br>  this version of GNU tar, but I've heard that it works (I don't know<br>  how well, though).  If you have anonymous ftp access to the Internet,<br>  a copy can be found on wsmr-simtel20.army.mil and mirror sites:<br><br> PD1:<MSDOS.DSKUTL><br> ASPIBIN.ZIP  67841 920131 Gnu Tar for SCSI tape drives, Adaptec 154xx<br> ASPIPAT.ZIP  21206 920131 Patches for ASPIBIN relative to Gnu Tar 1.10<br> ASPISRC.ZIP 221370 920131 Src for Gnu Tar for SCSI tape, Adaptec ctrlr<br><br>  I have no idea if a copy can be found on Compuserve; UNIXFORUM might<br>  have it, if any forum does.<br><br>* As far as MSDOS is concerned, the 1542A and the 1542B controllers are<br>  the same; with MSDOS, the 1542A should work as well as the 1542B.<br>  However, the hardware for these two boards is not 100% identical, and<br>  there is at least one (NON-MSDOS) program that initially did not work<br>  with a 1542A, but did work with a 1542B (BSD386 -- a 386 version of<br>  BSD Unix).<br><br>* In case anyone's curious, here's an edited copy of my CONFIG.SYS file:<br><br> FILES=40<br> BUFFERS=40<br> BREAK=ON<br> STACKS=10,256<br> DEVICE=c:\sys\dev\aspi4dos.sys /d /n4<br> DEVICE=C:\QEMM\QEMM386.SYS on RAM ROM DMA=32 ST:M X=F800-FFFF<br> DOS=HIGH,UMB<br> DEVICEHIGH=c:\sys\dev\nnansi.sys<br> DEVICEHIGH=C:\DOS\SETVER.EXE<br> shell = c:\dos\command.com /p<br><br>  Note that I'm using QEMM and ASPI4DOS 3.1.  If I were using ASPI4DOS<br>  3.0 or 3.0a, I'd probably have to use a CONFIG.SYS that looked like:<br><br> FILES=40<br> BUFFERS=40<br> BREAK=ON<br> STACKS=10,256<br> DEVICE=c:\sys\dev\aspi4dos.sys /d /n4<br> DEVICE=C:\QEMM\QEMM386.SYS on RAM ROM DMA=32 ST:M X=F800-FFFF<br> DOS=HIGH,UMB<br> DEVICEHIGH=c:\sys\dev\scsiha.sys /V386<br> DEVICEHIGH=c:\sys\dev\nnansi.sys<br> DEVICEHIGH=C:\DOS\SETVER.EXE<br> shell = c:\dos\command.com /p<br><br>  If I weren't using ASPI4DOS, I'd probably use something that looked<br>  like:<br><br> FILES=40<br> BUFFERS=40<br> BREAK=ON<br> STACKS=10,256<br> DEVICE=c:\sys\dev\scsiha.sys /V386<br> DEVICE=C:\QEMM\QEMM386.SYS on RAM ROM DB=32 DMA=32 ST:M X=F800-FFFF<br> DOS=HIGH,UMB<br> DEVICEHIGH=c:\sys\dev\nnansi.sys<br> DEVICEHIGH=C:\DOS\SETVER.EXE<br> shell = c:\dos\command.com /p<br><br>  However, if I used a floppy-controller-based tape drive, or if I<br>  planned to record high-quality sound from a sound card, I would still<br>  need some way of changing the Adaptec's bus on/off times.  The first<br>  two versions of CONFIG.SYS take care of this, but this last version<br>  doesn't.<br><br>"	"     Here's a document that I wrote some time back.  It's slightly<br>out-of-date, now that DOS 6 has been released, but much of it is still<br>useful.<br><br>     -- Darryl Okahata<br> Internet: darrylo@sr.hp.com<br><br>DISCLAIMER: this message is the author's personal opinion and does not<br>constitute the support, opinion or policy of Hewlett-Packard or of the<br>little green men that have been following him all day.<br><br>===============================================================================<br>$Id: adaptec.txt 1.8 1993/01/25 00:55:08 darrylo Rel darrylo $<br>          Hints and Tips for the Adaptec 1540/1542 SCSI adapter<br><br><br>     This document contains hints and tips for getting the Adaptec<br>1540/1542 SCSI adapter to work with various hardware and software<br>packages.  They are based upon my experiences with an Adaptec 1542A<br>controller, and will, hopefully, help others.  However, note that I<br>cannot guarantee that the following will really help you (it works for<br>me), and the information in this document could possibly cause you to<br>lose some or all of your files on your hard disk.<br><br>     IMPORTANT!  BACK UP THE ENTIRE CONTENTS OF YOUR HARD DISK BEFORE<br>TRYING ANYTHING BASED UPON INFORMATION IN THIS DOCUMENT.<br><br>     Copyright 1993, by Darryl Okahata.  This document may be freely<br>copied for personal use only, and may not be reprinted in a for-profit<br>publication without the consent of the author.  Please note that I have<br>no connection with Adaptec other than as a customer.<br><br>Topics covered in this document:<br><br> * Windows 3.1 enhanced mode<br> * Floppy-controller-based tape backup devices<br> * Sound cards<br> * Miscellaneous info<br><br>     Please note that parts of this document contain technical, and<br>sometimes terse, descriptions of problems.<br><br>For reference:<br><br> Adaptec technical support: (800) 959-7274<br> Adaptec BBS (2400/9600): (408) 945-7727<br><br>Please send comments, corrections, etc. via email to me:<br><br> CompuServe: 75206,3074<br> Internet: darrylo@sr.hp.com<br><br><br>***** Windows 3.1 enhanced mode:<br><br>     The Windows 3.1 install program should automatically configure DOS<br>and Windows for use with the Adaptec 1542.  However, just in case<br>something went wrong, I'm going to describe some of the changes needed<br>to get Windows 3.1 working with the 1542.  Also, you may have noticed<br>that installing Windows 3.1 makes your PC run much slower, even when<br>you're not running Windows; methods of speeding it up are discussed in<br>the section called, ""Windows 3.1 runs slowly"".<br><br><br>* MSDOS configuration:<br><br>     The Windows install program adds the SmartDrive disk cache to your<br>CONFIG.SYS and AUTOEXEC.BAT files.  If you follow the instructions,<br>you'll notice that you'll need to use double-buffering with SmartDrive<br>(this is the default setup).  You'll also notice that your system runs<br>much, much slower -- in both Windows *AND* MSDOS.  See the section<br>called, ""Windows 3.1 runs slowly"", for some ways of speeding your system<br>up.<br><br><br>* Windows configuration:<br><br>     To get the Adaptec 1542 to work with Windows, make sure that the<br>""[388Enh]"" section of the SYSTEM.INI file contains the entry:<br><br> VirtualHDIRQ=Off<br><br>I believe that the Windows install program automatically adds this entry<br>to SYSTEM.INI, but I'm not sure.  If this doesn't work for you, you<br>might want to try adding some more lines:<br><br> VirtualHDIRQ=Off<br> SystemROMBreakPoint=false<br> EMMExclude=A000-CFFF<br><br>(You probably don't need the above lines, though.)  The<br>""SystemROMBreakPoint"" entry is used to enable support for memory<br>managers like QEMM/386MAX (only needed if you use such programs).<br><br><br>* Windows 3.1 runs slowly:<br><br>     Once you do get Windows 3.1 running with the 1542, chances are that<br>your system is running much slower than before.  If it's not, it's<br>probably because:<br><br>     1. You happen to be using ASPI4DOS.SYS version 3.1 in your<br> CONFIG.SYS file.  Congratulations -- this appears to be a<br> winning solution.<br><br>     2. You are very lucky.  Whether your luck will hold out remains to<br> be seen ....<br><br>If your system is running much slower than before, this is almost<br>definitely caused by Smartdrive with double-buffering.  According to the<br>Windows documentation, and the Microsoft technical note #Q81808<br>(""SMARTDrive Double Buffering Required with ASPI4DOS.SYS""), you must use<br>Smartdrive with double-buffering enabled.  While this works, it really<br>slows down your PC; I once estimated that this slowed my PC down by a<br>factor of 5 (FIVE).  As I consider this unacceptable, I looked for other<br>solutions.<br><br>     Unfortunately, you cannot just disable double-buffering.  If you<br>do, Windows 3.1 in enhanced mode will not work, and you might even<br>destroy the contents of your hard disk by trying to run Windows 3.1.<br>What you can do is one of the following:<br><br>     1. Use other drivers that provide double-buffering.  It is my<br> opinion that the unbelievable slowness in Smartdrive is caused<br> either by horribly inefficient double-buffering, or by a bug in<br> Smartdrive.<br><br>     2. Use a driver that provides ""VDS"" services (""VDS"" stands for<br> ""Virtual DMA Services"").  This is a standard, which is supported<br> by Windows 3.1, that allows bus-mastering disk controllers (like<br> the 1542) to work with Windows.<br><br>     After trashing my hard disk countless times, I found the following<br>solutions, none of which require using Smartdrive (note, however, that I<br>am now getting occasional parity errors, which are probably *NOT* caused<br>by these solutions, but might be -- see below).  While the following<br>does not require Smartdrive, using some kind of disk cache utility is<br>strongly recommended, as this makes Windows run much, much faster:<br><br>1. If you do not have the ASPI4DOS.SYS driver, or you do not need ASPI<br>   functions (for controlling a CDROM, tape drive, more than two<br>   physical hard disks, etc.), you can add the SCSIHA.SYS driver to your<br>   CONFIG.SYS file, e.g.:<br><br> DRIVER=c:\SCSIHA.SYS /V386<br><br>   (Windows needs the ""/V386"" option.)  This driver MUST be loaded into<br>   LOW memory (it cannot be loaded into high memory), and it occupies<br>   about 16-20K.  As of November 1992, the SCSIHA.SYS driver could be<br>   obtained from the Adaptec BBS at (408)-945-7727 (hopefully, it's<br>   still there).<br><br>2. If you need ASPI functions and have the ASPI4DOS.SYS driver, version<br>   3.0 or 3.0a, you can use both the ASPI4DOS.SYS and SCSIHA.SYS drivers<br>   in your CONFIG.SYS file, e.g.:<br><br> DRIVER=c:\ASPI4DOS.SYS<br> DRIVER=c:\SCSIHA.SYS /V386<br><br>   Amazingly enough, the SCSIHA.SYS driver can also be loaded high<br>   (assuming you have DOS 5.0); I would have thought that this would<br>   crash my system, but it doesn't.  I asked Adaptec's technical support<br>   about this, and they said that loading SCSIHA.SYS high should be fine<br>   as long as ASPI4DOS.SYS is loaded LOW.<br><br>   On my system, NOT using SCSIHA.SYS with ASPI4DOS 3.0a would<br>   occasionally cause Windows 3.1 to crash upon restarting or exiting<br>   Windows, with the additional result of a corrupted disk (some of my<br>   C:\WINDOWS\*.GRP files would be corrupted).  For me, these crashes<br>   usually occurred while making a different program from PROGMAN.EXE<br>   the default Windows shell, and vice-versa.  This is the reason<br>   SCSIHA.SYS may be necessary.<br><br>   I have absolutely no idea if SCSIHA.SYS is necessary with versions of<br>   ASPI4DOS earlier than 3.0.<br><br>   Note that many people can use ASPI4DOS 3.0 or 3.0a without<br>   SCSIHA.SYS; they do not seem to have any problems at all.  I consider<br>   these people lucky.  Others, like me, have had all sorts of problems.<br><br>3. In my opinion, the best, but not necessarily the easiest, solution is<br>   to upgrade to ASPI4DOS 3.1.  The SCSIHA.SYS driver is no longer<br>   needed.  Unfortunately, while you could get previous ASPI4DOS<br>   upgrades from the Adaptec BBS, the ASPI4DOS 3.1 driver is not<br>   available from the Adaptec BBS.  As far as I know, there are only<br>   three ways to get a copy:<br><br>      * You can buy the new (as of November 1992) Adaptec EZ SCSI driver<br> kit, which supposedly includes ASPI4DOS 3.1 as well as other<br> drivers, such as CDROM drivers.  I believe the list price is<br> around $75.<br><br>      * If you already have a copy of an older version of ASPI4DOS, you<br> can supposedly contact Adaptec to upgrade it to EZ SCSI for<br> around $30.<br><br>      * A copy of ASPI4DOS 3.1 is included in Central Point PC Tools 8.0<br> for MSDOS.  Note that the documentation and driver are stored in<br> different directories.  Note further that only ASPI4DOS is<br> included; the CDROM drivers and drivers to support more than two<br> hard disks are not included.  This is where I obtained my copy<br> of ASPI4DOS 3.1.<br><br>Note, however, that I am now getting occasional parity errors with<br>Windows.  In all probability, defective hardware in my PC is causing<br>this, as I upgraded my motherboard just after I found the above<br>solutions.  However, because these parity errors occur only during disk<br>accesses, there is a very small, but definite, possibility that the<br>parity errors are driver-related (for example, changing the bus on/off<br>timing for certain disk transfers might cause this).  I've run various<br>memory tests for hours at a time, and these tests have found no<br>problems.  This problem is probably caused by memory with marginal<br>timing requirements, which cause parity errors during disk transfers<br>(this is why the memory tests didn't find any problems -- the problems<br>show up only under disk I/O).  However, I'm mentioning this just in case<br>it isn't a hardware problem.<br><br><br>***** Floppy-controller-based tape backup devices:<br><br>     There are two possible problems with using the Adaptec 1542 with a<br>floppy-controller-based tape backup device, such as the Colorado Memory<br>Systems Jumbo 250:<br><br>1. Tape backups/restores can take a very long time.  The tape drive<br>   constantly starts, stops, starts, stops, etc.<br><br>2. Tape operations may be erratic, or encounter too many tape errors.<br>   (This problem might be caused by defective hardware on my 1542.<br>   However, I've heard of other people having similar problems, and so<br>   I'm mentioning this just in case it is not a hardware problem on my<br>   1542.)<br><br><br>* Tape backups/restores take a long time:<br><br>     If you have a floppy-controller-based tape backup device, you may<br>have to adjust the Adaptec 1540/1542 ""bus on/off timing"" for best<br>results when using the tape drive.  Normally, while doing a tape backup<br>or restore, the tape drive motor should be continuously running, with<br>only an occasional pause.  However, the default bus timing on the<br>Adaptec 1540/1542 may cause the tape drive motor to start and stop,<br>start and stop, every few seconds.  This causes needless wear to the<br>tape and tape drive (however, note that a dirty tape head or a defective<br>tape drive can also cause this -- make sure your tape heads are clean).<br>This also causes the tape backup or restore to take much, much longer<br>than necessary.<br><br>     The problem here is that these tape backups use the floppy DMA to<br>transfer data in memory to/from the tape drive, and the Adaptec uses DMA<br>to transfer data in memory to/from the hard disk.  The floppy DMA needs<br>to feed data to the tape drive at a certain rate; if the tape drive is<br>not fed data quickly enough by the floppy DMA, the tape drive stops,<br>rewinds a bit, and restarts (once enough data is eventually fed to it).<br>The default bus timing on the Adaptec (which is really DMA timing) is<br>""too large"".  For example, when a backup is done, data has to be<br>transferred from a hard disk to memory, and then from memory to the<br>tape.  Because the default timing on the Adaptec ""hogs"" the memory too<br>much (too much time is spent transferring data from a hard disk to<br>memory), not enough time is spent transferring data from memory to the<br>tape drive.  As a result, the tape drive constantly starts and stops,<br>because data is not fed to it quickly enough.<br><br>     The solution is to change the Adaptec's bus on/off timing.  The<br>default factory setting is 11 microseconds on, and 5 microseconds off.<br>The ""bus on"" timing needs to be lowered to 2-4 microseconds.  This can<br>be done in one of two ways:<br><br>* If you have ASPI4DOS, you can use the ""/n"" option.  For example, I use<br>  a ""bus on"" timing of 4 microseconds, which means that I use the<br>  following line in my CONFIG.SYS file:<br><br> DEVICE=c:\aspi4dos.sys /n4<br><br>  Note that there is NO space between the ""/n"" and the ""4"".<br><br>* If you don't have ASPI4DOS, your only recourse is to try to find a<br>  program called ""SETSCSI.EXE"", which is very difficult to find.  The<br>  reason is that Adaptec, for reasons of their own, does not seem to<br>  want this widely distributed.  I once asked someone who worked for<br>  Adaptec, and they asked me to not upload it anywhere.  If you have<br>  anonymous ftp access to the Internet, you could try using archie to<br>  hunt down a copy; I believe that there are a couple of sites that have<br>  it.  If you do find a copy, you run it like so:<br><br> setscsi -n:4<br><br>  This adjusts the ""bus on"" timing to 4 microseconds.  Running<br>  SETSCSI.EXE without any arguments resets the bus timing back to the<br>  factory defaults.<br><br>  Note that it seems that you cannot use SETSCSI.EXE if you use<br>  ASPI4DOS; SETSCSI.EXE crashed my system if ASPI4DOS was loaded.  I<br>  could use SETSCSI.EXE with SCSIHA.SYS, however.<br><br>Do not lower the ""bus on"" timing below 2 microseconds, or increase it<br>above 11 microseconds.  If you lower it too low, the hard disk<br>throughput will suddenly drop; your system will feel slower.  For me, 4<br>microseconds works fine.  This value may work fine for you, or you may<br>have to adjust it downwards a little.<br><br>     Once you've lowered the ""bus on"" timing, tape backups and restores<br>should run faster.<br><br>     Also, do not experiment with the bus on/off times (with the other<br>options that I have intentionally not described), unless you know what<br>you are doing.  Bad combinations can cause parity errors and worse, by<br>starving memory refresh.<br><br>     A program called BUSTIFIX.EXE exists on the Adaptec BBS.  Unless<br>this has been upgraded since I last checked (which has been a while),<br>this is a self-extracting archive containing a batch file and a couple<br>of other files.  This batch file was supposed to allow one to set the<br>bus on/off times for the 1540/1542 and others.  However, when I tried<br>running this program with my 1542A, my system crashed.  At the time, I<br>was running SCSIHA.SYS, and I didn't check to see if there was a<br>conflict with it.  Maybe this old program works only with the 1542B,<br>although the docs say that it works with the 1542A?<br><br><br>* Erratic tape operations or too many tape errors:<br><br>     This ""problem"" may or may not exist.  Although it existed on my<br>system, a hardware problem just on my particular 1542 could cause it.<br>However, I've heard of other people having similar problems, and so I'm<br>mentioning this just in case it isn't a hardware problem just on my<br>1542.<br><br>     Symptoms of this ""problem"", which persists even after cleaning the<br>tape head:<br><br>1. Backing up to tape encounters ""unusable sector detected"" errors,<br>   resulting in an aborted tape backup.<br><br>2. Tape backup works, but the tape compare fails.<br><br>3. The tape drive starts, stops, starts, stops, etc. much too often.<br>   Unlike the above-mentioned problem (""Tape backups/restores take a<br>   long time""), where the tape drive starts and stops every few seconds,<br>   this kind of starting/stopping occurs every few 10-20 seconds or so.<br><br>4. Fastback Plus 3.1 does not find/see any tape backup devices.  Other<br>   programs, like Central Point Backup and the CMS Jumbo software<br>   (assuming that you have a CMS Jumbo 250 tape drive) can find/see the<br>   tape drive, but Fastback Plus 3.1 cannot.<br><br>5. Too many tape read errors.<br><br>     Although I do not know what is causing this problem, I discovered<br>that using a different floppy controller solves it.  A few months ago, I<br>upgraded my motherboard, which contained an integrated floppy<br>controller.  As I already had a floppy controller on the 1542, I<br>initially disabled the motherboard floppy controller.  After a while, I<br>decided to try disabling the 1542 floppy controller and using the one on<br>the motherboard.  When I did this, the tape drive (a CMS Jumbo 250)<br>reliability increased dramatically, and Fastback Plus 3.1 was suddenly<br>able to find and use the tape drive.<br><br>     I don't know if this was caused by a hardware problem on my 1542.<br>On the one hand, the floppy drives worked great when they were attached<br>to the 1542, which seems to say that there was nothing wrong with the<br>1542.  On the other hand, the tape drive didn't work well attached to<br>the 1542 floppy controller, but it did work when attached to a different<br>controller; this could be an indication of a hardware problem on my<br>1542.  I did change floppy drive cables, and so it is conceivable that<br>the problem was in the cables.  I don't know what the cause really is;<br>however, if you're having similar problems, you might want to consider<br>trying a new floppy controller.<br><br><br>***** Sound cards:<br><br>     Many popular sound cards can play or record digitized sound, and<br>this is typically done using DMA.  Like the tape drive DMA, the<br>Adaptec's DMA can conflict with the sound card DMA.  Unlike that of the<br>tape DMA, this ""conflict"" usually manifests itself as a parity error<br>(your system crashes with a parity error message).  What happens is<br>that, data is being transferred so quickly by the sound card and the<br>Adaptec, memory refresh cannot occur quickly enough, which causes a<br>parity error.  Usually, getting a parity error means that there is a<br>hardware problem with your system; in this case, however, the parity<br>error is not a symptom of bad hardware.<br><br>     I've found that such parity errors typically occur while recording<br>digitized sound, and the chances of such errors increase as you increase<br>the recording fidelity (e.g., higher sampling rate, recording in stereo,<br>recording using 16-bits instead of 8, etc.).<br><br>     Like the tape drive solution, the solution here is to lower the<br>Adaptec's ""bus on"" timing.  See the section on tape drives for<br>information on how this is done.  Note, however, that this may or may<br>not solve the problem; it may only reduce the probability of a parity<br>error.  The software used to record digitized sound can greatly affect<br>this problem (i.e., some software is inefficient).  Disk caches, the<br>speed of your hard disk, and the amount of disk fragmentation can also<br>affect this.<br><br><br>***** Miscellaneous info:<br><br>     This section contains miscellaneous hints, tips, and rumors.  Much<br>of it is merely information that I've heard or read about, and have not<br>verified.  I believe that the following information is correct, but I'm<br>not sure.  Use it at your own risk.<br><br>* With QEMM 6.00, 6.01, and 6.02, you need to specify the ""DB=""<br>  parameter (e.g., ""DB=2""), unless you are using the ASPI4DOS driver.<br>  If you don't, QEMM will crash/hang at bootup.  Although the QEMM<br>  manual mentions this, the install program does not seem to detect that<br>  a 1542 is present and automatically add this option to the QEMM<br>  command line (at least, this occurred with the QEMM 6.00 install<br>  program -- I haven't tested any other version).  Earlier versions of<br>  QEMM probably need this parameter, but I'm not sure (I've never used a<br>  version earlier than 6.00).<br><br>  If you use ASPI4DOS, you do not need to give QEMM the ""DB="" parameter.<br><br>* Some or all versions of the 1542 do not support hard disks over one<br>  gigabyte in size.  To support hard disks with capacities over 1GB, you<br>  need to get a new ROM BIOS from Adaptec.  I'm not sure if this is<br>  still true of the latest 1542Bs being sold by Adaptec.<br><br>* To connect a CDROM drive to the 1542, you need a SCSI CDROM drive and<br>  some drivers.  Note that some CDROM drives have proprietary interfaces<br>  (non-SCSI); these drives cannot be used with the 1542.  You have three<br>  choices for CDROM drivers (I have no idea how well the following<br>  solutions work, or even if they work -- the following is secondhand<br>  information):<br><br>     1. You can buy Adaptec's EZ SCSI driver package, which lists for<br> something like $75.  If you already have older Adaptec drivers,<br> you can supposedly upgrade to EZ SCSI for around $30.  Contact<br> Adaptec for details.  The EZ SCSI package supposedly contains<br> everything that you need.<br><br>     2. You can buy the CorelSCSI! driver package, which is made by the<br> same people that make CorelDRAW!  This package contains CDROM<br> drivers, SCSI tape drivers, WORM drivers, etc.  I do not know<br> the list price, but I've seen this package sold for around<br> $80-$90.  Note that CorelSCSI! does not come with the ASPI4DOS<br> driver, which is needed.  If you do not already have ASPI4DOS,<br> you may be better off getting Adaptec's EZ SCSI instead.<br><br>     3. [This method is obsolete, as the following drivers have been<br> obsoleted by Adaptec's EZ SCSI kit, but I'm mentioning it in<br> case someone already has these drivers.]  You can use the<br> drivers in the Adaptec ASW-1410 kit (ASPI4DOS) and the ASW-410<br> kit (ASPI CDROM drivers).  You will have to get a copy of<br> MSCDEX.EXE (a high-level CDROM driver), if it is not included in<br> the ASW-410 kit, but this is available from several bulletin<br> boards.<br><br>* To use a SCSI tape drive with the 1542, you need software that knows<br>  how to talk to a SCSI tape drive.  Software that I've heard about are<br>  (again, like the above section on CDROM drives, I have no idea how<br>  well the following solutions work, or even if they work -- the<br>  following is secondhand information):<br><br>     1. Central Point PC Tools 8.0 for MSDOS supposedly supports a large<br> number of SCSI tape drives.  It comes with SCSI drivers<br> (ASPI4DOS 3.1) as well as Central Point Backup.<br><br>     2. The CorelSCSI! driver package contains a SCSI tape backup<br> program (see the above section on CDROM drives for more<br> details).  However, note that CorelSCSI! does not come with, but<br> requires, ASPI4DOS.<br><br>* I've seen advertisements that sell the 1542 in three configurations:<br><br>     1. 1542 SCSI controller with hard disk ROM BIOS.<br>     2. 1542 SCSI controller w/BIOS and Adaptec ASPI drivers.<br>     3. 1542 SCSI controller w/BIOS, Adaptec ASPI drivers, and<br> CorelSCSI! drivers/programs.<br><br>  I imagine that Adaptec now sells the 1542 in a fourth configuration:<br><br>     4. 1542 SCSI controller w/BIOS and EZ SCSI drivers (including ASPI<br> drivers).<br><br>* Those people who use Unix might be interested in a version of GNU tar<br>  for MSDOS that talks to a SCSI tape drive via the ASPI4DOS driver (you<br>  need this driver before you can use this program).  I've never used<br>  this version of GNU tar, but I've heard that it works (I don't know<br>  how well, though).  If you have anonymous ftp access to the Internet,<br>  a copy can be found on wsmr-simtel20.army.mil and mirror sites:<br><br> PD1:<MSDOS.DSKUTL><br> ASPIBIN.ZIP  67841 920131 Gnu Tar for SCSI tape drives, Adaptec 154xx<br> ASPIPAT.ZIP  21206 920131 Patches for ASPIBIN relative to Gnu Tar 1.10<br> ASPISRC.ZIP 221370 920131 Src for Gnu Tar for SCSI tape, Adaptec ctrlr<br><br>  I have no idea if a copy can be found on Compuserve; UNIXFORUM might<br>  have it, if any forum does.<br><br>* As far as MSDOS is concerned, the 1542A and the 1542B controllers are<br>  the same; with MSDOS, the 1542A should work as well as the 1542B.<br>  However, the hardware for these two boards is not 100% identical, and<br>  there is at least one (NON-MSDOS) program that initially did not work<br>  with a 1542A, but did work with a 1542B (BSD386 -- a 386 version of<br>  BSD Unix).<br><br>* In case anyone's curious, here's an edited copy of my CONFIG.SYS file:<br><br> FILES=40<br> BUFFERS=40<br> BREAK=ON<br> STACKS=10,256<br> DEVICE=c:\sys\dev\aspi4dos.sys /d /n4<br> DEVICE=C:\QEMM\QEMM386.SYS on RAM ROM DMA=32 ST:M X=F800-FFFF<br> DOS=HIGH,UMB<br> DEVICEHIGH=c:\sys\dev\nnansi.sys<br> DEVICEHIGH=C:\DOS\SETVER.EXE<br> shell = c:\dos\command.com /p<br><br>  Note that I'm using QEMM and ASPI4DOS 3.1.  If I were using ASPI4DOS<br>  3.0 or 3.0a, I'd probably have to use a CONFIG.SYS that looked like:<br><br> FILES=40<br> BUFFERS=40<br> BREAK=ON<br> STACKS=10,256<br> DEVICE=c:\sys\dev\aspi4dos.sys /d /n4<br> DEVICE=C:\QEMM\QEMM386.SYS on RAM ROM DMA=32 ST:M X=F800-FFFF<br> DOS=HIGH,UMB<br> DEVICEHIGH=c:\sys\dev\scsiha.sys /V386<br> DEVICEHIGH=c:\sys\dev\nnansi.sys<br> DEVICEHIGH=C:\DOS\SETVER.EXE<br> shell = c:\dos\command.com /p<br><br>  If I weren't using ASPI4DOS, I'd probably use something that looked<br>  like:<br><br> FILES=40<br> BUFFERS=40<br> BREAK=ON<br> STACKS=10,256<br> DEVICE=c:\sys\dev\scsiha.sys /V386<br> DEVICE=C:\QEMM\QEMM386.SYS on RAM ROM DB=32 DMA=32 ST:M X=F800-FFFF<br> DOS=HIGH,UMB<br> DEVICEHIGH=c:\sys\dev\nnansi.sys<br> DEVICEHIGH=C:\DOS\SETVER.EXE<br> shell = c:\dos\command.com /p<br><br>  However, if I used a floppy-controller-based tape drive, or if I<br>  planned to record high-quality sound from a sound card, I would still<br>  need some way of changing the Adaptec's bus on/off times.  The first<br>  two versions of CONFIG.SYS take care of this, but this last version<br>  doesn't.<br><br>"

496	1	"Well, some quick math on my part shows that an 8.3MHz bus, 16 bits<br>wide, performing a transfer every two clock cycles will provide 8.3M<br>bytes/sec.  Someone said that it really takes 3 clock cycles to<br>perform a transfer, so that reduces the transfer rate to 5.5MB/s,<br>which is the commonly-used figure for ISA bus speed.  However, I<br>believe a two-clock transfer is possible (0 wait states)."	"Well, some quick math on my part shows that an 8.3MHz bus, 16 bits<br>wide, performing a transfer every two clock cycles will provide 8.3M<br>bytes/sec.  Someone said that it really takes 3 clock cycles to<br>perform a transfer, so that reduces the transfer rate to 5.5MB/s,<br>which is the commonly-used figure for ISA bus speed.  However, I<br>believe a two-clock transfer is possible (0 wait states)."

507	0	"<br> Hmmmm, why do I get the feeling that this is gonna start one of<br>those endless threads 'Mac Vs Win"" and might even end up as ""OS/2 Vs Win"".<br>Well, I dont know if Windows is a mature OS, if I have seen one (in which<br>case that has to be X-Windows :) ), but dont be so quick to judge... <br>First of all to try to use plain vanilla Windows is as courageous as to try<br>to use plain vanilla DOS. There are _lots_ of very nice commercial and<br>shareware packages/utilities that will boost up Windows past what MS itself<br>thought possible :)... For example, Norton Desktop for Windows 2.0 (a replace-<br>ment for ProgMan) will give you group-within-a-group capability and will<br>even change group icons, it will launch progs by association (well, FileMan<br>does that too) or by dragging the file in the apps icon (now Mac doesnt do<br>that, huh? :) )... And the list goes on and on... Now, Windows _is_ kinda<br>hard to finetune, boost and configure, but thats trhe price to pay for not<br>paying $$$ to get a Mac or an OS/2 capable machine (an entirely differet<br>story ...)... On the other hand if you dont like the idea of PM's icons<br>not correspnding to the files themselves, well they are not supposed to :)..<br>PM is a Program _Launching_ utility not a file manager... Modify your <br>settings to have FM as your shell and not PM, or get a couple of utilities<br>from cica that supposedly give you a 'Mac feel'... I dont wanna get in the<br>discussion which is a better system: Mac's are good in their own way -- they<br>are _different_ not better or worse than Win PCs-- (actually I am writing<br>this from a Mac lab as a user assistant - so dont think I am partial to Win:) )<br>By all means check out the stuff in cica (ftp to ftp.cica.indiana.edu under<br>the pub/pc/win3 subdir user: anonymous), or wait for StarTrek (Mac's OS on<br>a PC !!! -- the threads we are gonna have then !!! :) )...<br>Just trying to avoid another Mac-Win war...<br><br>"	"<br> Hmmmm, why do I get the feeling that this is gonna start one of<br>those endless threads 'Mac Vs Win"" and might even end up as ""OS/2 Vs Win"".<br>Well, I dont know if Windows is a mature OS, if I have seen one (in which<br>case that has to be X-Windows :) ), but dont be so quick to judge... <br>First of all to try to use plain vanilla Windows is as courageous as to try<br>to use plain vanilla DOS. On the other hand if you dont like the idea of PM's icons<br>not correspnding to the files themselves, well they are not supposed to :)..<br>PM is a Program _Launching_ utility not a file manager... Modify your <br>settings to have FM as your shell and not PM, or get a couple of utilities<br>from cica that supposedly give you a 'Mac feel'... I dont wanna get in the<br>discussion which is a better system: Mac's are good in their own way -- they<br>are _different_ not better or worse than Win PCs-- (actually I am writing<br>this from a Mac lab as a user assistant - so dont think I am partial to Win:) )<br>By all means check out the stuff in cica (ftp to ftp.cica.indiana.edu under<br>the pub/pc/win3 subdir user: anonymous), or wait for StarTrek (Mac's OS on<br>a PC !!! -- the threads we are gonna have then !!! :) )...<br>Just trying to avoid another Mac-Win war...<br><br>"

514	0	"Well, someone at Microsoft told you wrong.  Windows will use a swap file<br>larger than the recommended size.  Last summer I went to a Microsoft<br>Windows 3.1 Technical Workshop and they distributed A LOT of information<br>that the general public might not be aware of.  Anyway in the main book<br>they handed out they have a section on ""Creating larger than recommended<br>swapfile"".  I'll quote the information<br><br>  If you create a permanent swapfile larger than the recommended size, you<br>  will receive a message telling you that Windows will not use anything<br>  larger than the recommended size.  THIS ERROR MESSAGE IS INCORRECT, we<br>  will allow the use of the larger swapfile, up to four times the amount<br>  of RAM on your machine.<br><br>So as you see, Microsoft does know that the information is incorrect.  You<br>probably just ran into some doofball who was new on the job and was only<br>telling you what little he knew.<br><br>Be that what it may, I would really suggest to everyone to take the<br>opportunity to go to these Technical Workshops.  They aren't actually<br>incredibly in-depth, but you do get a lot of material about bugs and<br>optimization straight from those in the know.  Besides that they offer<br>you HUGE discounts on software.  If I remember correctly, you could pick<br>up Word 2.0, Excel 4.0, or whatever their presentation program is for $130.<br>That is the full blown version, not an upgrade or educational version.  You<br>could also pick up Microsoft Office for $500 or something like that.  Myself<br>I sprang for Word.<br><br>Well, hope that was helpful to someone.  And besides that I hope someone<br>will go to a workshop and save a little money.<br><br>And if anyone at Microsoft is reading this -- I really love your products.<br>I need a job once I graduate also, can we work something out?  ;-)"	"Well, someone at Microsoft told you wrong.  Windows will use a swap file<br>larger than the recommended size.  Last summer I went to a Microsoft<br>Windows 3.1 Technical Workshop and they distributed A LOT of information<br>that the general public might not be aware of.  Anyway in the main book<br>they handed out they have a section on ""Creating larger than recommended<br>swapfile"".  I'll quote the information<br><br>  If you create a permanent swapfile larger than the recommended size, you<br>  will receive a message telling you that Windows will not use anything<br>  larger than the recommended size.  THIS ERROR MESSAGE IS INCORRECT, we<br>  will allow the use of the larger swapfile, up to four times the amount<br>  of RAM on your machine.<br><br>So as you see, Microsoft does know that the information is incorrect.  You<br>probably just ran into some doofball who was new on the job and was only<br>telling you what little he knew.<br><br>Be that what it may, I would really suggest to everyone to take the<br>opportunity to go to these Technical Workshops.  They aren't actually<br>incredibly in-depth, but you do get a lot of material about bugs and<br>optimization straight from those in the know.  Besides that they offer<br>you HUGE discounts on software. And besides that I hope someone<br>will go to a workshop and save a little money.<br><br>And if anyone at Microsoft is reading this -- I really love your products.<br>I need a job once I graduate also, can we work something out?  ;-)"

There was an article about Chicogo in PC Week last August.<br> The Chicogo and NT development groups at Micro$oft are in intense <br>competition, so it is said.  However, I think a different relationship will <br>arise: NT will be the server (*N*etowrk *T*echonology), Chicogo will be the <br>client machine.  It is entirely possible for different OS's to work together, <br>partly because Chicogo is just a small NT (think of it that way, anyway).  <br>(Novell Netware creates an OS on the server that is truly not DOS, so don't<br>scorn the concept.)<br> Anyway, don't expect it soon. 518	1	"As described the manual the following steps must be done for th initialization<br>of the S3 card.<br><br>InitDisplay;<br> (*BIOS-Call<br>  with AX-Reg = 4F02H<br>  with BX-Reg = 105H for 1024 x 768 x 256 resolution<br>  Interrupt 10H *)<br>Unlock Register Lock 1 (CR38)<br> (* For access to S3 Register Set *)<br>Unlock Register Lock 2 (CR39)<br> (* For access to Syst. Control and Syst. Extension Register *)<br>Unlock Graphic Command Group (CR40)<br> (* Set Bit 0 to 1 in Syst. Configuration Register *)<br>Unlock Advanced Display Functions<br> (* Set Bit 0 to 1 in Function Control Register *)<br><br>After these operations the FIFO-stack of the S3 should be empty.<br>When we watch the status (Graph. Proc. Status), we always get<br>the value 0FH instead of 0H.<br>Full would mean 0FFH (8 places occupied), empty would mean 0H<br>(0 places occupied).<br><br>It is possible to read this register in two different ways. <br>Both times we get different results.<br><br><br><br>Our machine is a 486 DX/2 with EISA bus and a S3 86C805 local bus. <br><br>--> any ideas?"	"As described the manual the following steps must be done for th initialization<br>of the S3 card.<br><br>InitDisplay;<br> (*BIOS-Call<br>  with AX-Reg = 4F02H<br>  with BX-Reg = 105H for 1024 x 768 x 256 resolution<br>  Interrupt 10H *)<br>Unlock Register Lock 1 (CR38)<br> (* For access to S3 Register Set *)<br>Unlock Register Lock 2 (CR39)<br> (* For access to Syst. Control and Syst. Extension Register *)<br>Unlock Graphic Command Group (CR40)<br> (* Set Bit 0 to 1 in Syst. Configuration Register *)<br>Unlock Advanced Display Functions<br> (* Set Bit 0 to 1 in Function Control Register *)<br><br>After these operations the FIFO-stack of the S3 should be empty.<br>When we watch the status (Graph. Proc. Status), we always get<br>the value 0FH instead of 0H.<br>Full would mean 0FFH (8 places occupied), empty would mean 0H<br>(0 places occupied).<br><br>It is possible to read this register in two different ways. <br>Both times we get different results.<br><br><br><br>Our machine is a 486 DX/2 with EISA bus and a S3 86C805 local bus. <br><br>--> any ideas?"

To date, I have<br>not found ANYTHING available via FTP that could compare.  Reply to the<br>address in my .SIG for more info." 526	1	"Did you open up the tape cartridge and put the tape back on the reels?<br><br>If you have not yet, open it up by removing the two screws on the bottom of<br>the tape cartridge and snap the plastic shell away from the metal base.  <br>As you are pulling the tape through the assembly try not to touch any more <br>than you have to.  As you are doing it, look for a couple of little holes in <br>the tape.  These are the marker holes which let the tape drive know when it is <br>at the end of the tape.  The holes are spaced a couple of inches apart.  My best<br>guess is that the drive finds the first marker and then stops on the second<br>marker?  <br><br>Anyhow, If the tape has the holes, then check to see if the mirror on the tape<br>is clean.  The function of the mirror is to detect the marker holes.  The<br>tape drive shines a light at the mirror and has a pickup in the area where<br>the reflection would come out.  When the hole goes by, the pickup detects the <br>light that was allowed to pass and it knows when to stop.  If the mirror is dirty<br>or out of alighment (unlikely since it is made into the case) you might have<br>a problem detecting the end of the tape.<br><br>If the tape drive does it on all tapes and the tapes all look good, then either<br>the pickup or the LED of the sensor system has failed or is dirty.  If you open<br>the drive door you will see the sensor assembly to the left of the R/W head<br>assembly.  If it looks clean and nothing is in its way, then the drive may<br>need to be serviced.  It is possible that the LED is burned out or the sensor<br>is out. <br><br>If it is still in warranty, you might be able to send it back to CMS for<br>repair.<br><br><br>---<br>Scott Hiles<br>whiles@relay.nswc.navy.mil"	"Did you open up the tape cartridge and put the tape back on the reels?<br><br>If you have not yet, open it up by removing the two screws on the bottom of<br>the tape cartridge and snap the plastic shell away from the metal base.  <br>As you are pulling the tape through the assembly try not to touch any more <br>than you have to.  As you are doing it, look for a couple of little holes in <br>the tape.  These are the marker holes which let the tape drive know when it is <br>at the end of the tape.  The holes are spaced a couple of inches apart.  My best<br>guess is that the drive finds the first marker and then stops on the second<br>marker?  <br><br>Anyhow, If the tape has the holes, then check to see if the mirror on the tape<br>is clean.  The function of the mirror is to detect the marker holes.  The<br>tape drive shines a light at the mirror and has a pickup in the area where<br>the reflection would come out.  When the hole goes by, the pickup detects the <br>light that was allowed to pass and it knows when to stop.  If the mirror is dirty<br>or out of alighment (unlikely since it is made into the case) you might have<br>a problem detecting the end of the tape.<br><br>If the tape drive does it on all tapes and the tapes all look good, then either<br>the pickup or the LED of the sensor system has failed or is dirty.  If you open<br>the drive door you will see the sensor assembly to the left of the R/W head<br>assembly.  If it looks clean and nothing is in its way, then the drive may<br>need to be serviced.  It is possible that the LED is burned out or the sensor<br>is out. <br><br>If it is still in warranty, you might be able to send it back to CMS for<br>repair.<br><br><br>---<br>Scott Hiles<br>whiles@relay.nswc.navy.mil"		
527	1	"Actually, it does make a reasonable amount of sense. Fixed disk<br>sectors are buffered by the controller, and transferring them to<br>memory with a 'rep insw' (or whatever the instruction is called) is<br>quite efficient (single instruction, goes as fast as the<br>controller/cpu know how to use the bus). Since the 286 wasn't cached,<br>the bus is likely a critical resource relative to CPU performance, and<br>it's possible that DMA bus interference would cause as much or more<br>loss of CPU cycles (for 'computing') as does the 'rep insw' sequence.<br><br>The floppy, on the other hand, is not buffered, so that using the CPU<br>for floppy data transfer (as was done on the PC Jr, by the way) really<br>does stink."	"Actually, it does make a reasonable amount of sense. Fixed disk<br>sectors are buffered by the controller, and transferring them to<br>memory with a 'rep insw' (or whatever the instruction is called) is<br>quite efficient (single instruction, goes as fast as the<br>controller/cpu know how to use the bus). Since the 286 wasn't cached,<br>the bus is likely a critical resource relative to CPU performance, and<br>it's possible that DMA bus interference would cause as much or more<br>loss of CPU cycles (for 'computing') as does the 'rep insw' sequence.<br><br>The floppy, on the other hand, is not buffered, so that using the CPU<br>for floppy data transfer (as was done on the PC Jr, by the way) really<br>does stink."		
528	1	"The Adaptec 1540-series use bus mastering.  This means that the CPU<br>doesn't sit waiting for data bytes, it can go off and do other<br>computing - if you have an advanced multi-tasking OS, that is.  DOS<br>just sits and waits anyway.<br><br><br>Why don't you start with the spec-sheet of the ISA bus first? :-) IDE<br>was designed to plug into ISA virtually unaided - in essence, IDE *is*<br>ISA, on a ribbon cable.  Therefore it's specs are the same as ISA -<br>8MHz clock, 16 bit width, 5MB/sec.<br><br>This is why I've concluded that IDE on VL-bus is a waste of a fast<br>slot.  The card's job would to slow the VL-bus transactions to ISA<br>speed.  Heck, that's what ISA slots do - I'll just use one of those<br>instead."	"The Adaptec 1540-series use bus mastering.  This means that the CPU<br>doesn't sit waiting for data bytes, it can go off and do other<br>computing - if you have an advanced multi-tasking OS, that is.  DOS<br>just sits and waits anyway.<br><br><br>Why don't you start with the spec-sheet of the ISA bus first? :-) IDE<br>was designed to plug into ISA virtually unaided - in essence, IDE *is*<br>ISA, on a ribbon cable.  Therefore it's specs are the same as ISA -<br>8MHz clock, 16 bit width, 5MB/sec.<br><br>This is why I've concluded that IDE on VL-bus is a waste of a fast<br>slot.  The card's job would to slow the VL-bus transactions to ISA<br>speed.  Heck, that's what ISA slots do - I'll just use one of those<br>instead."

TypeAlign does the same thing<br>for Adobe Type 1 fonts; *and* Adobe has said that the next version<br>will work with both Adobe Type 1 and TrueType.<br><br>And TypeAlign does some things that TrueEffects does not - including<br>some things you apparently want ...<br><br><br>"	"<br><br>Yes, and the idea was ripped off from Adobe, which has had a program<br>called  TypeAlign for a few years now. 530	1	"The Amiga Zorro II bus is comparable with the ISA bus (7.16 vs 8.33 MHZ).<br>The Amiga has had a pre-emptative multi-tasking  OS since '85 and can<br>operate with 1 MB RAM!  SCSI is used almost exclusively on these systems.<br><br>A SCSI controller that transfers data by DMA allows the cpu to request data<br>from the hard drive and continue working while the controller gets the data<br>and moves it to memory.  A controller that allows reselection can operate<br>even better with multiple devices.  This is espically true with SCSI tape<br>units.  For example, when rewinding or formatting a tape, the command is<br>issued to the controller and the bus is released to allow access to other<br>devices on the bus.  This greatly increases productivity or, at least, do<br>something else while backing up your hard drive :-).  Which happens to be<br>what I am doing while reading this group.<br><br>Its a long story, but I still use IDE on my 486 except for the CDROM which,<br>thanks to SCSI, I can move between both machines.  If, and when, SCSI is<br>better standardized and supported on the ibm-clone machines, I plan to<br>completely get rid of IDE.<br>--<br>  Wayne Summer        //        AMIGA - Simply the Best.<br>  Palm Bay, FL. US  \X/        wayne@amtower.spacecoast.org"	"The Amiga Zorro II bus is comparable with the ISA bus (7.16 vs 8.33 MHZ).<br>The Amiga has had a pre-emptative multi-tasking  OS since '85 and can<br>operate with 1 MB RAM!  SCSI is used almost exclusively on these systems.<br><br>A SCSI controller that transfers data by DMA allows the cpu to request data<br>from the hard drive and continue working while the controller gets the data<br>and moves it to memory.  A controller that allows reselection can operate<br>even better with multiple devices.  This is espically true with SCSI tape<br>units.  For example, when rewinding or formatting a tape, the command is<br>issued to the controller and the bus is released to allow access to other<br>devices on the bus.  This greatly increases productivity or, at least, do<br>something else while backing up your hard drive :-).  Which happens to be<br>what I am doing while reading this group.<br><br>Its a long story, but I still use IDE on my 486 except for the CDROM which,<br>thanks to SCSI, I can move between both machines.  If, and when, SCSI is<br>better standardized and supported on the ibm-clone machines, I plan to<br>completely get rid of IDE.<br>--<br>  Wayne Summer        //        AMIGA - Simply the Best.<br>  Palm Bay, FL. US  \X/        wayne@amtower.spacecoast.org"

532	0	"And/or taking the rubber ball out of the mouse (should be directions<br>in the manual or on the bottom of the mouse) and cleaning it with<br>alcohol (isopropyl, I believe - the same alcohol as used for cleaning<br>your cassette deck).  This is good to do every so often, even if you<br>have a mouse pad.  Dust still gets caught in the mouse and on the<br>rubber ball.  As well, lint and other garbage may find it's way onto<br>the rubber ball and get into the mouse damaging the horizontal and<br>vertical sensors.<br><br>Hope this helps.  Good luck.<br><br>--<br>Sincerely,<br><br>Robert Kayman ---- kayman@cs.stanford.edu  -or-  cpa@cs.stanford.edu"	"And/or taking the rubber ball out of the mouse (should be directions<br>in the manual or on the bottom of the mouse) and cleaning it with<br>alcohol (isopropyl, I believe - the same alcohol as used for cleaning<br>your cassette deck).  This is good to do every so often, even if you<br>have a mouse pad.  Dust still gets caught in the mouse and on the<br>rubber ball. 538	0	"VC++ *is* considered an upgrade for C7.  There will be no product<br>called C 8.0 (although the command-line compiler of VC++ lists its<br>version as 8.00).  C7 is not a ""DOS""-only product -- it is a C/C++<br>compiler capable of producing executables for DOS or Windows, as is<br>VC++ (Pro. Ed.).  The (significant) difference is that VC++ comes with<br>many Windows-hosted tools (ide, etc) which assist developers in<br>creating Windows executables much more quickly (basically by<br>automating the thousands of lines of boilerplate code).  Initial<br>impressions have been very favorable.<br><br>Everyone who is a registered user of C7 should have received a<br>considerable amount of info regarding the specifics of C7. If you<br>haven't, call Microsoft and I'm sure they'd be happy to send you some!"	"VC++ *is* considered an upgrade for C7.  There will be no product<br>called C 8.0 (although the command-line compiler of VC++ lists its<br>version as 8.00).  C7 is not a ""DOS""-only product -- it is a C/C++<br>compiler capable of producing executables for DOS or Windows, as is<br>VC++ (Pro. Ed.).  The (significant) difference is that VC++ comes with<br>many Windows-hosted tools (ide, etc) which assist developers in<br>creating Windows executables much more quickly (basically by<br>automating the thousands of lines of boilerplate code).  Initial<br>impressions have been very favorable.<br><br>Everyone who is a registered user of C7 should have received a<br>considerable amount of info regarding the specifics of C7. 549	0	"Two things that annoyed me about the PC Magazine review:<br><br>1.  Their benchmarking technique is seriously flawed, as was clearly shown<br>    by the Graphite and #9GXE's ""cheating"".  Can't they just admit that<br>    their benchmark is to easy to optimize for and/or cheat on?  WinTach<br>    is much harder to beat...<br><br>2.  The big ""cheat"" that Hercules/IIT used was overlappipping BitBlit and<br>    PolyLine optimization, and Hercules sent them a new driver which didn't<br>    do this -- but produced almost identical scores.  Yet, the only thing<br>    PC Magazine says is that scores are not ""legitimate"" -- couldn't they<br>    at least make some comment about its real-world performance?<br><br>I'm not so much going by WinBench for performance, but, rather, by Steve<br>Gibson's results, which are more real-world based (like using Micrografx<br><br>    ""Despite these documented cheats, I have to say that in real-world<br>     applications the Hercules Graphite adapter actually draws faster than<br>     any other display adapter in the industry.   [...]  Even though it's<br>     just a modest ISA bus card, it outperformed every local bus adapter I<br>     have, including the Stealth 24 VLB, the Fahrenheit 1280VA/VLB, the<br>     ATI VLB Mach32 and even the Weitek P9000-based Diamond Viper VLB.""<br><br>This kind of praise is enough for me to be interested in it, bogus WinBench<br>or not!  :)<br><br><br>I already returned the ATI GU+.  My dealer had sold eight of them, and <br>seven were returned to him.  I'm now (temporarily) back to running an<br>original ATI GU, until I get my Graphite. Also, if you<br>don't know, Mouse Systems mice have three buttons. The driver includes<br>a utility that lets you assign keystrokes to the middle button.<br><br>Hope this helps someone else. That is the only thing that is making me lean more in favor<br>of the NEC 5FG (or now also available the NEC 5FGe - only difference,<br>no ACCUCOLOR ).  Any experiences or opinions from people who have used<br>the NEC 5FG would be appreciated since I want to get one right after<br>my exams are all done (ie: about a week from now).<br><br>-Tony<br>"
