561	0	"I have never gotten the _entire_ ctrltest app to run under BC++, but<br>the reason is that MS makes some bad assumptions about the order in<br>which static/global objects are initialized (i.e. some objects are<br>getting accessed before they are initialized).  The problem is in the<br>owner-draw menu code somewhere-- if you comment out that section, all<br>other pieces of ctrltest work fine.<br><br>Two other major gotchas I have found using MFC under BC++:<br><br>- The CFile::OpenFlags enum uses hard-coded numbers for the open mode,<br>  rather than the manifest constants defined in fcntrl.h (which differ<br>  between MSC and BC).<br><br>- All of the MFC collection classes depend on another bad C++<br>  assumption-- that a reference to a base object can used be in place<br>  of a reference to a derived object (true for pointers, NOT for<br>  references).<br><br>I am sure there are other problems along the same lines, but I have<br>not encountered them (yet).  I have not seen MFC 2.0 yet, but I hope<br>that some of these will be addressed.  If they are not, all of MS's<br>hype about portability to other vendor's compilers will be just that.<br>"	"I have never gotten the _entire_ ctrltest app to run under BC++, but<br>the reason is that MS makes some bad assumptions about the order in<br>which static/global objects are initialized (i.e. some objects are<br>getting accessed before they are initialized).  The problem is in the<br>owner-draw menu code somewhere-- if you comment out that section, all<br>other pieces of ctrltest work fine.<br><br>Two other major gotchas I have found using MFC under BC++:<br><br>- The CFile::OpenFlags enum uses hard-coded numbers for the open mode,<br>  rather than the manifest constants defined in fcntrl.h (which differ<br>  between MSC and BC).<br><br>- All of the MFC collection classes depend on another bad C++<br>  assumption-- that a reference to a base object can used be in place<br>  of a reference to a derived object (true for pointers, NOT for<br>  references).<br><br>I am sure there are other problems along the same lines, but I have<br>not encountered them (yet).  I have not seen MFC 2.0 yet, but I hope<br>that some of these will be addressed.  If they are not, all of MS's<br>hype about portability to other vendor's compilers will be just that.<br>"

564	1	"This is not the case: the ROM on the P9000 supports VESA modes of up to<br>1024x768 in 256 colors.  VESA-compliant applications should have no trouble<br>setting these modes. (But I'm forwarding your posting to our Software group,<br>just in case.  Can't be too careful.)  Not that I doubt that YOUR applications<br>are failing to run; lots of stuff depends on figuring out which exact SVGA<br>they're looking at, and don't use VESA calls (VESA is still pretty new).<br>Every new chip set confuses them.<br><br><br>I think we go to AT LEAST 76 Hz at 1024x768x8, and maybe more (and<br>it's a function of the RAMDAC speed, not the Power 9000). We need to<br>fix the problems you've noted (they were already on the list).  If<br>you're really interested, though, take a look at the text file<br>P9000RES.DAT, which holds the data from which the choices in the<br>P9000 monitor installation program are built.  Working by analogy,<br>you can build up a new monitor definition that has the right<br>combinations of refresh rates for your monitors.  Keep a backup copy<br>of the file!  Once you've built a new version of the P9000RES.DAT<br>file, run the P9000 installation program, INST, and your new choices<br>should show up.  (This assumes you have the WEITEK v. 2.2 drivers.<br>You can tell the rev number by looking at the modification time of<br>the driver: 02:20 is version 2.20.  Microsoft uses this gimmick,<br>too.)<br><br><br>The SPEEDY benchmark was put out by Hercules and IIT, who to my<br>knowledge were unencumbered by any motivations except making the<br>Hercules Graphite/IIT AGX014 card look really good.  So I'd take the<br>numbers with a ton of salt. (Texas Instruments did the same thing<br>with WINTACH, trying to make the 34020 look good compared to the<br>8514, as if anyone cared.)  It's safer (though not safe) to use<br>benchmarks from ""unbiased"" sources, such as testing labs, columnists,<br>etc.<br><br><br><br>I think you'll a large discrepancy between the results of SPEEDY and<br>the results of anything else in the universe on these things.<br><br><br>Font caching is a perfectly legitimate optimization -- Windows has<br>hooks for it built right into the GDI.  What's kind of silly is IIT's<br>use of a hardwired ""The quick brown fox jumped over the lazy dog then<br>sat on a tack"" string in their driver.  Not only is it useless in<br>real applications, it lacks the programming elegance of the ""Bart<br>Simpson optimization,"" in which you save the bitmap of the<br>most-recently drawn string in off-screen memory, and just do a<br>screen-to-screen bitblit if you happen to be given that same string a<br>second time in a row.  (We call it the ""Bart Simpson optimization""<br>because Bart's the only person we can see benefiting from it: he<br>could right ""I will not cheat on benchmarks"" a hundred times and be<br>done in half the time it would take to actually form each character.)<br><br><br>We don't have any lawyers -- they're all working for Intel.  There<br>used to be a lawyer in Montana who didn't, but he died.<br><br> -- Robert<br><br>"	"This is not the case: the ROM on the P9000 supports VESA modes of up to<br>1024x768 in 256 colors. It's safer (though not safe) to use<br>benchmarks from ""unbiased"" sources, such as testing labs, columnists,<br>etc.<br><br><br><br>I think you'll a large discrepancy between the results of SPEEDY and<br>the results of anything else in the universe on these things.<br><br><br>Font caching is a perfectly legitimate optimization -- Windows has<br>hooks for it built right into the GDI.  What's kind of silly is IIT's<br>use of a hardwired ""The quick brown fox jumped over the lazy dog then<br>sat on a tack"" string in their driver.  Not only is it useless in<br>real applications, it lacks the programming elegance of the ""Bart<br>Simpson optimization,"" in which you save the bitmap of the<br>most-recently drawn string in off-screen memory, and just do a<br>screen-to-screen bitblit if you happen to be given that same string a<br>second time in a row. 566	1	"<br>I hate to burst your bubble but you cannot ""slip in a B:"" to that<br>particular AMI BIOS setting. That setting only allows you to set<br>the *boot order* of the floppy A: with respect to the primary HD C:,<br>i.e., check A: first, then C: or check C:, then A:.<br>"	"<br>I hate to burst your bubble but you cannot ""slip in a B:"" to that<br>particular AMI BIOS setting. That setting only allows you to set<br>the *boot order* of the floppy A: with respect to the primary HD C:,<br>i.e., check A: first, then C: or check C:, then A:.<br>"		
567	1	"There is a way in which a multi-tasking computer actually gives you<br>more CPU power then you had before, and that is with I/O overlap.<br>With I/O overlap, your CPU can continue to ""think"" while disk<br>operations are underway, whereas without overlap, your CPU sits idly<br>waiting for each disk operation to finish - and disk operations take<br>an *eternity*, compared to a fast CPU.<br><br>So, when you've got multi-tasking, you want to increase performance by<br>increasing the amount of overlapping you do.<br><br>One way is with DMA or bus mastering.  Either of these make it<br>possible for I/O devices to move their data into and out of memory<br>without interrupting the CPU.  The alternative is for the CPU to move<br>the data.  There are several SCSI interface cards that allow DMA and<br>bus mastering.  IDE, however, is defined by the standard AT interface<br>created for the IBM PC AT, which requires the CPU to move all the data<br>bytes, with no DMA."	"There is a way in which a multi-tasking computer actually gives you<br>more CPU power then you had before, and that is with I/O overlap.<br>With I/O overlap, your CPU can continue to ""think"" while disk<br>operations are underway, whereas without overlap, your CPU sits idly<br>waiting for each disk operation to finish - and disk operations take<br>an *eternity*, compared to a fast CPU.<br><br>So, when you've got multi-tasking, you want to increase performance by<br>increasing the amount of overlapping you do.<br><br>One way is with DMA or bus mastering.  Either of these make it<br>possible for I/O devices to move their data into and out of memory<br>without interrupting the CPU.  The alternative is for the CPU to move<br>the data.  There are several SCSI interface cards that allow DMA and<br>bus mastering.  IDE, however, is defined by the standard AT interface<br>created for the IBM PC AT, which requires the CPU to move all the data<br>bytes, with no DMA."		
568	1	"CTX 14"": Nasty, low quality. Avoid.<br><br>CTX 15"" Proscan: Not as good as some other makes; however, cheap.<br>  Main problem seems poor quality control. Some reported pincushioning<br>  (the problem I had), others poor focus, etc, etc.<br><br>I complained about mine and it was 're-tuned' (I dodn't even pay<br>shipping) and returned to me in 2 days. <br><br>It's now clear, well-focussed and has no pincushioning or barrel<br>distortion at all. I'm very happy with it, and the digital<br>controls and mode memory are nice. Certainly, a Trinitron<br>(say) would be much nicer, but that's well out of my price range.<br><br>Conclusion: If you're on a budget, get one and be prepared to<br>send it back if it's not perfect. It probably won't be when you get it,<br>but has good potential."	"CTX 14"": Nasty, low quality. Avoid.<br><br>CTX 15"" Proscan: Not as good as some other makes; however, cheap.<br>  Main problem seems poor quality control. Some reported pincushioning<br>  (the problem I had), others poor focus, etc, etc.<br><br>I complained about mine and it was 're-tuned' (I dodn't even pay<br>shipping) and returned to me in 2 days. <br><br>It's now clear, well-focussed and has no pincushioning or barrel<br>distortion at all. I'm very happy with it, and the digital<br>controls and mode memory are nice. Certainly, a Trinitron<br>(say) would be much nicer, but that's well out of my price range.<br><br>Conclusion: If you're on a budget, get one and be prepared to<br>send it back if it's not perfect. It probably won't be when you get it,<br>but has good potential."

572	0	"This is a common problem with highly complex TrueType fonts.  Microsoft<br>admits to a problem with older versions of the PostScript printer driver,<br>but I've found it to be pretty generic.<br><br>You can get around the problem by adjusting the parameter OutlineThreshold<br>in the [TrueType] section of WIN.INI.  This entry specifies the number of<br>pels-per-em at which Windows will render TrueType fonts as outline fonts<br>instead of as bitmap fonts.  The default is 256.  I've generally been able<br>to get fonts to work by setting OutlineThreshold=160.  Depending on your<br>printer resolution and the point size you are using, you may need a<br>different value.<br><br>The Windows Resource Kit warns against going above 300.  Presumably, that<br>might cause fonts to print as square boxes or something.  :-|  (I'm not<br>smiling.)<br>"	"This is a common problem with highly complex TrueType fonts.  Microsoft<br>admits to a problem with older versions of the PostScript printer driver,<br>but I've found it to be pretty generic.<br><br>You can get around the problem by adjusting the parameter OutlineThreshold<br>in the [TrueType] section of WIN.INI.  This entry specifies the number of<br>pels-per-em at which Windows will render TrueType fonts as outline fonts<br>instead of as bitmap fonts.  The default is 256.  I've generally been able<br>to get fonts to work by setting OutlineThreshold=160.  Depending on your<br>printer resolution and the point size you are using, you may need a<br>different value.<br><br>The Windows Resource Kit warns against going above 300.  Presumably, that<br>might cause fonts to print as square boxes or something.  :-|  (I'm not<br>smiling.)<br>"

"If you bought your IDE drive from a dealer, you shouldn 't have to <br>perform a low level format. Even if the 1st HD is already partitioned<br>into C and D, FDISK will automatically assign the 2 nd HD to D and <br>change the 2nd partition of 1st drive to E."

579	1	"Ok once again with the SCSI spec list:<br>SCSI-1 {with a SCSI-1 controler chip} synchronous range is indeed 0-5MB/s<br> asynchronous range is slower at 0-3MB/s.<br>SCSI-1 {With a SCSI-2 controller chip}: 4-6MB/s with 10MB/s burst {8-bit}<br> Note the INCREASE in SPEED, the Mac Quadra uses this version of SCSI-1<br> so it DOES exist. Some PCs use this set up too.<br><br>SCSI-2 {8-bit/SCSI-1 mode}:          4-6MB/s with 10MB/s burst<br>{for those who want SCSI-2 but don't want to pay for the 16-bit or 32-bit<br> hardware or mess with the SCSI-2 software controllers.  Usable by SCSI-1<br> devices with close to 8-bit SCSI-2 speeds}<br>SCSI-2 {16-bit/wide or fast mode}:  8-12MB/s with 20MB/s burst<br>SCSI-2 {32-bit/wide AND fast}:     15-20MB/s with 40MB/s burst<br><br>On the other interfaces let DXB132@psuvm.psu.edu speak:<br>Again synchronous and asynchronous modes with asynchronous much slower<br> {Range 0-5MB/s}<br><br>One problem is the inconsitant use of the term 'SCSI' in articles and by<br>people.  Its PROPER meaning is ""The set of SCSI interfaces composed of<br>SCSI-1 AND SCSI-2""<br>Look at the inconsitant use of SCSI in the below quote:<br>(My comments in {})<br><br>PC Magazine April 27, 1993:29 ""Although SCSI is twice as fast as ESDI,<br>{This is asynchronous SCSI-1 with a SCSI-1 chip} 20% faster than IDE...""<br>{this is BOTH asynchronous SCSI-1 with a SCSI-2 chip AND 8-bit SCSI-2}<br>To read CONSITANTLY the quote SHOULD read:<br>{asynchronous SCSI-1 with a SCSI-1 chip}<br>""Although asynchronous SCSI-1 is twice as fast as ESDI, one third the <br>speed of IDE...""<br>or {asynchronous SCSI-1 with a SCSI-2 chip or 8-bit SCSI-2}<br>""Although SCSI-1 with a SCSI-2 chip and 8-bit SCSI-2 are eight times as fast as<br>ESDI, 20% faster than IDE...""<br><br>NOTE the NONUSE of 'SCSI' by itself.  This eliminates ambaguity.<br><br>SCSI-1 drivers are somewhat reasonable while 16-bit and 32-bit SCSI-2 drivers <br>are VERY expansive {8-bit SCSI-2 can use SCSI-1 drivers with little speed<br>degridation(the Mac Quadra does EXACTLY this.)}"	"Ok once again with the SCSI spec list:<br>SCSI-1 {with a SCSI-1 controler chip} synchronous range is indeed 0-5MB/s<br> asynchronous range is slower at 0-3MB/s.<br>SCSI-1 {With a SCSI-2 controller chip}: 4-6MB/s with 10MB/s burst {8-bit}<br> Note the INCREASE in SPEED, the Mac Quadra uses this version of SCSI-1<br> so it DOES exist. Some PCs use this set up too.<br><br>SCSI-2 {8-bit/SCSI-1 mode}:          4-6MB/s with 10MB/s burst<br>{for those who want SCSI-2 but don't want to pay for the 16-bit or 32-bit<br> hardware or mess with the SCSI-2 software controllers.  Usable by SCSI-1<br> devices with close to 8-bit SCSI-2 speeds}<br>SCSI-2 {16-bit/wide or fast mode}:  8-12MB/s with 20MB/s burst<br>SCSI-2 {32-bit/wide AND fast}:     15-20MB/s with 40MB/s burst<br><br>On the other interfaces let DXB132@psuvm.psu.edu speak:<br>Again synchronous and asynchronous modes with asynchronous much slower<br> {Range 0-5MB/s}<br><br>One problem is the inconsitant use of the term 'SCSI' in articles and by<br>people.  Its PROPER meaning is ""The set of SCSI interfaces composed of<br>SCSI-1 AND SCSI-2""<br>Look at the inconsitant use of SCSI in the below quote:<br>(My comments in {})<br><br>PC Magazine April 27, 1993:29 ""Although SCSI is twice as fast as ESDI,<br>{This is asynchronous SCSI-1 with a SCSI-1 chip} 20% faster than IDE...""<br>{this is BOTH asynchronous SCSI-1 with a SCSI-2 chip AND 8-bit SCSI-2}<br>To read CONSITANTLY the quote SHOULD read:<br>{asynchronous SCSI-1 with a SCSI-1 chip}<br>""Although asynchronous SCSI-1 is twice as fast as ESDI, one third the <br>speed of IDE...""<br>or {asynchronous SCSI-1 with a SCSI-2 chip or 8-bit SCSI-2}<br>""Although SCSI-1 with a SCSI-2 chip and 8-bit SCSI-2 are eight times as fast as<br>ESDI, 20% faster than IDE...""<br><br>NOTE the NONUSE of 'SCSI' by itself.  This eliminates ambaguity.<br><br>SCSI-1 drivers are somewhat reasonable while 16-bit and 32-bit SCSI-2 drivers <br>are VERY expansive {8-bit SCSI-2 can use SCSI-1 drivers with little speed<br>degridation(the Mac Quadra does EXACTLY this.)}"		
580	0	"And why they are considering using WinBench as a test, they may want<br>to read everything Steve Gibson has said on the subject in his<br>InfoWorld column the past couple of month.  In short, virtually<br>every board manufacturer cheats on the test by writing things in the<br>driver that is there only to make the board appear faster on the<br>WinBench suite.  So the WinBench score has no bearing in reality to<br>how cards stack up on real world tasks.<br><br>In the last PC-Magazine they benchmarked some of the new accelerators,<br>and admitted that many of them 'cheated' on WinBench.  Interestingly,<br>they 'allowed' one type of cheating behaviour (caching for bitblt<br>operations, no matter how unreal), yet did not allow a couple of other<br>types of cheating behaviour that some of the cards used.  At least<br>one card was eliminated from the ""Editor's Choice"" because of<br>cheating on the benchmark."	"And why they are considering using WinBench as a test, they may want<br>to read everything Steve Gibson has said on the subject in his<br>InfoWorld column the past couple of month.  In short, virtually<br>every board manufacturer cheats on the test by writing things in the<br>driver that is there only to make the board appear faster on the<br>WinBench suite.  So the WinBench score has no bearing in reality to<br>how cards stack up on real world tasks.<br><br>In the last PC-Magazine they benchmarked some of the new accelerators,<br>and admitted that many of them 'cheated' on WinBench.  Interestingly,<br>they 'allowed' one type of cheating behaviour (caching for bitblt<br>operations, no matter how unreal), yet did not allow a couple of other<br>types of cheating behaviour that some of the cards used.  At least<br>one card was eliminated from the ""Editor's Choice"" because of<br>cheating on the benchmark."

594	1	"<br>last update: 14.4.1993<br><br>collected by Carsten Grammes (ph12hucg@rz.uni-sb.de)<br>and published regularly on comp.sys.ibm.pc.hardware.<br><br><br>!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!<br>There is explicitly NO WARRANTY<br>that the given settings are correct or harmless. (I only collect, I do<br>not check for myself!!!). There is always the possibility that the<br>settings may destroy your hardware!<br>!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!<br><br><br>Since I hope however that only well-minded people undergo the effort of<br>posting their settings the chance of applicability exists. If you should<br>agree or disagree with some setting, let me know immediately in order<br>to update the list.<br><br>If you possess a HD not mentioned here of which you know BIOS and/or<br>jumper settings, please mail them to me for the next update of the list!<br><br>Only IDE (AT-Bus) Harddisks will be accounted for.<br>If not specified the Landing Zone should be set equal to the number of<br>cylinders. If not specified the 'Write Precompensation' should be set<br>65535. (There are BIOSes that don't even ask for it).<br><br>Another statement (maybe right):<br>IDE harddisk don't have Precomp and LZone. The precomp is a built-in parameter<br>and lzone isn't used because most if not every IDE disk has autopark.<br><br>The jumpers' names are given as printed on the HD's board, often only a<br>jumper number (JP12 means the jumper '12'). A zero means that the jumper<br>is left open, a one means that the jumper is closed.<br><br><br><br>***************************   C O N N E R   ***************************<br><br><br>  Conner Peripherals Drive Geometry<br><br>IDE/AT<br><br>Conner drives are low level formatted at the factory. It is only necessary<br>to run SETUP, FDISK, and DOS FORMAT.<br><br>Model   Heads  Cylinders  Sectors   PComp   L-Zone  Type  Table    LED<br><br>CP2034     2     823         38      0       823    *UT     3      N/A<br>CP2064     4     823         38      0       823    *UT     3      N/A<br>CP2084     8     548         38      0       548    *UT     3      N/A<br>CP3184     6     832         33      0       832    *UT     1       A<br>CP3104     8     776         33      0       776    *UT     1       A<br>CP3111     8     833         33      0       833    *UT     1       A(?)<br>CP3204    16     683         38      0       683    *UT     2       B<br>CP30064    4     762         39      0       762    *UT     2       B<br>CP30084    8     526         39      0       526    *UT     2       B<br>CP30104    8     762         39      0       762    *UT     2       B<br>CP30084E   4     903         46      0       903    *UT     3       C<br>CP30174E   8     903         46      0       903    *UT     3       C<br>CP30204   16     683         38      0       683    *UT     3       C<br>CP3304    16     659         63      0       659    *UT     3       D<br>CP3364    16     702         63      0       702    *UT     3       D<br>CP3504    16     987         63      0       987    *UT     3       D<br>CP3554    16    1054         63      0      1054    *UT     3       B<br><br>Table 1                                  Table 2<br><br>       Jumper Settings                          Jumper Settings<br><br>Single Drive = Jumper ACT and C/D        Single Drive = Jumper C/D<br>Master Drive = Jumper ACT, C/D and DSP   Master Drive = Jumper C/D & DSP<br>Slave Drive = No jumpers installed       Slave Drive = No jumpers installed<br><br><br>Table 3<br>                                     All Conner 20 Mbyte drives use<br>        Jumper Settings              Drive type 2.  All Conner 40<br>                                     Mbyte drives use Drive type 17.<br>Single & Master Drive = Jumper C/D<br>Slave Drive = No jumpers installed   *UT = Universal translate.<br>                                     Select a drive type that is<br>                                     close to but does not exceed<br>                                     the megabyte capacity of the<br>                                     drive.  The drive will<br>                                     translate to the megabyte<br>                                     capacity that you have<br>                                     selected.<br><br>  LED<br><br>  A:           B:                       C:         D:<br>  J-4          J-5                      J-5        J-3<br>  Pin 1 = +    Pin 3 = +                Pin 3 = -  Pin 3 = +<br>  Pin 2 = -    Pin 4 = -                Pin 4 = -  Pin 4 = -<br><br><br><br><br><br>***************************    F U J I T S U      ***************************<br><br>DETAILS OF FUJITSU DRIVES M261xT (Standard)<br><br>                   M2614ET     M2613ET     M2612ET     M2611T<br><br>Heads (physical)       8           6           4           2<br>Cyl (physical)      1334        1334        1334        1334<br>Sec/trk               33          33          33          33<br>Speed (rpm)         3490        3490        3490        3490<br>Capacity           180MB       135MB        90MB        45MB<br><br><br>              +-----------------------------------------------+<br>              |                                               |<br>              +--+                                            |<br>        PSU   |  |      CNH-2                                 |<br>              +--+          1                                 |<br>            1 |  |          .                    LED          |<br>              |  | CNH-1    9      CNH-3      Connector       |<br>              |  |   1           6..1            o o          |<br>      40-way  |  |   .                           | |          |<br>        IDE   |  |   .                                        |<br>              |  |   .                                        |<br>              |  |  12                                        |<br>              +--+                                            |<br>              +-----------------------------------------------+<br><br><br><br>                 Pin        Function<br>                 Position<br><br>                 *  1- 2    Active mode<br>                    2- 3    Slave present mode<br>                    4- 5    Pin 27=IOCHRDY<br>CNH-1 JUMPERS    *  5- 6    Pin 27=RESERVED<br>                    7- 8    2 drive system<br>                 *  8- 9    1 drive system<br>                   10-11    Pin 29=IRQ14 : Pin 31=RESERVED<br>                 * 11-12    Pin 31=IRQ14 : Pin 29=RESERVED<br><br><br>                 Pin        Function<br>                 Position<br><br>                    1- 2    SLAVE drive mode<br>CNH-2 JUMPERS    *  4- 5    MASTER drive mode<br>                    7- 8    ECC 4 bytes<br>                 *  8- 9    ECC 7 bytes<br><br><br>                 Pin        Function<br>                 Position<br><br>                    1- 2    Write protect enabled<br>CNH-3 JUMPERS    *  2- 3    Write protect disabled<br>                    4- 5 -6 Reserved<br><br>Key:  * (I guess!) marks factory default setting for jumper<br><br><br>BIOS SETTINGS<br><br>BIOS setting for the M2614ET in my system is 667 cylinders, 33 sectors<br>and 16 heads.<br><br><br><br><br>MODEL      CYLINDERS   HEADS    SECTORS   CAPACITY (Million bytes)<br><br>M2622T      1013        10        63         326.75<br>M2623T      1002        13        63         420.16<br>M2624T      995         16        63         513.51<br><br><br>There are 6 switches on the switch block on these drives.  Only 4 of <br>them have a use that I am aware of (from my M2624T manual):<br><br>Master/Slave        Master (*)      SW1-5 OFF<br>                    Slave           SW1-5 ON<br>ECC bytes           4 bytes (*)     SW1-4 OFF<br>                    7 bytes         SW1-4 ON<br>Write Protect       Disabled (*)    SW1-3 OFF<br>                    Enabled         SW1-3 ON<br>IO Channel Ready    Disabled (*)    SW1-1 OFF<br>                    Enabled         SW1-1 ON<br><br>I have no idea about the function of SW1-2 and SW1-6.  The values <br>listed with a (*) are the factory default settings.<br><br><br>***************************   K A L O K     ***************************<br><br>KALOK KL3100   105 MB<br>BIOS: cyl 979     heads 6 sectors 35<br><br>KALOK   KL3120    120 MB<br>BIOS:  Cyl 981     heads 6     sectors 40<br><br>The following jumper settings have been reported for KL3100 but are probably<br>also valid for other Kalok drives.<br><br>Single HD:<br>o o o o o<br><br>o o o o-o    <-- same row as pin 1 of the IDE connector.<br><br>Master (disk 1):<br>o o o o o<br>    |<br>o o o o o<br><br>Slave:<br>o o o o o<br>      |<br>o o o o o<br><br>These 5 pairs of pins are at the righthand side of the disk.<br><br><br><br>***************************   M A X T O R   ***************************<br><br>Model           Cyls    Heads   Sectors Precomp Landing Zone<br>---------- ----- ----- ------- ------- ------------<br>LXT-200A 816 15 32 0 816<br>LXT-213A 683 16 38 0 683<br>LXT-340A 654 16 63 0 654<br>LXT437A  842 16 63 0 842<br>LXT535A  1036 16 63 0 1024<br><br>Jumpers are as follows:<br><br>The bottom of the drive looks like this (well, sort of):<br><br>+[POWER] [IDE CONNECTOR]-----+<br><br>    Single drive   Dual Drive System<br>Pin numbers Jumper  System  Master  Slave<br>----------- ------  ------------ ------  -----<br>1-2  Slave Drive remove  remove  install<br>3-4  Activity LED optional optional optional<br>5-6  Slave Present remove  remove  optional<br>7-8  Master Drive remove  install  remove<br>9-10  Sync Spindle remove (n/a) optional* remove<br><br>* only one drive (the master) in an array should have this jumper installed.<br><br><br><br>Maxtor 7060A    16    467   17     62,0 J14 closed, J13 closed<br>Maxtor 7060A     7   1024   17     59,5 J14 open,   J13 open<br>Maxtor 7060A     4    762   39     58,0 J14 closed, J13 open<br>Maxtor 7060A     8    925   17     57,9 J14 open,   J13 closed<br><br>Maxtor 7120A    16    936   17    124,3 J14 closed, J13 closed<br>Maxtor 7120A    14   1024   17    119,0 j14 open,   J13 open<br>Maxtor 7120A     8    762   39    116,0 J14 closed, J13 open<br>Maxtor 7120A    15    900   17    112,0 J14 open,   J13 closed<br>Maxtor 7120A     8    824   33    106,2 J14<br><br>Jumpers for the above 2 drives:<br><br>                  J11  I/O-channel ready ( open: disabled; close: enabled )<br>                  J13  see above<br>                  J14  see above<br>                  J15  operation-status ( open: normal; close: factory )<br>       J J J J J            <br>       2 1 1 1 1<br>       0 9 8 7 6<br><br>Power  data-cable<br><br>J16: Idle mode latch ( open: disabled; close: enabled )<br>J17: drive model ( open: 7060A; close 7120A )<br>J18: ECC Bytes ( open: 7 bytes; close: 4 bytes )<br><br>Master/Slave: drive is master and alone    : J20 closed, J19 closed<br>              drive is master of two drives: J20 closed, J19 open<br>              drive is slave of two drives : J20 open  , J19 closed<br><br><br>Maxtor 7213A<br><br>Default (power-up) AT BIOS Translation Parameters (others possible)<br>Cyl   Hds  SpT  MBytes<br>683   16   38   212<br><br>There are two sets of jumpers. A set of 5 and a set of<br>4. With the power and IDE connector toward you, the set of 5 is<br>numbered (left to right) J16 - J20  , and the set of 4 is numbered<br>(bottom to top) J22-J25. <br><br>The only jumper of normal interest is J20. Jumper it for only<br>drive in a single drive system, or master drive in a dual drive<br>system.<br> <br>Remove the jumper J20 for slave drive in a dual drive system. <br><br>J19 is a dummy and may be used to store the spare shunt if the <br>drive is configured for a slave mode.<br><br>Jumpers J17, J18, J24, J25 are factory reserved. Abnormal operation<br>may occur if jumpered.<br><br>Jumper 22 is sync spindle enabled/disabled  (open=disabled)<br>Jumper 23 is sync slave/master              (open=slave)<br>Jumper 16 is I/O Channel Ready              (open=disabled)<br><br><br>Maxtor 7245A (245Mb IDE; self-parking; Universal Translate):<br>Drive type : User defineable<br>Cyl    Hds    WPC    LZ     S/T<br>967    16     0      0      31      (WPC and LZ optional)<br><br>Master(2):  J20 closed<br>Slave(2):   J20 open (use J19 for shunt storage)<br>Single:     J20 closed<br><br><br>**********************   M I C R O P O L I S   ****************************<br><br><br>Drive  2105A  2112A<br>----------------------------------------<br>Unformatted MB 647  1220<br>Formatted MB 560  1050<br>Platters 5  8<br>Heads  8  15<br>Cylinders 1760  1760<br>----------------------------------------<br><br>Performance (both):<br><br> Track to track (read)  1.5 msec<br> Track to track (write)  2.5 msec<br> Average    10 msec<br> Max    25 msec<br> Avg Rotational Latency  5.56 msec<br> Rotational speed  5400 rpm (+/- 5%)<br> Data Transfer Rate  upto 5Mbytes/sec<br> Internal data rate  24-40 Mbits/sec<br><br>BIOS Settings:<br><br>2105A  1084 cyl 16 heads 63 sectors<br>2112A* master 1024 cyl 16 heads 63 sectors<br> slave 1010 cyl 16 heads 63 sectors<br>  <br>* the 2112A emulates both master and slave<br><br><br>Jumpers (labelled J6 on the drive)<br><br> ----<br> |oo| W1\ only these 2 are used<br> |oo| W2/<br> |oo|<br> |oo|<br> |oo|<br> ----<br><br> W2 W1<br> -- --<br> in in 2112A only - drive emulates both master + slave<br> in out Drive is master, slave is present<br> out in Drive is slave<br> out out Drive is master, no slave present (ie single drive)<br><br><br>**********************   M I C R O S C I E N C E   ****************************<br><br>MicroScience <br><br>Model: 7100-00<br>Heads: 7<br>Cylinders: 855<br>S/T: 35 (?)<br>Size: 105M<br><br><br>Model # 8040-00.<br>Size 40M  5hd/17sec/977cyl<br><br>**********************   M I N I S C R I B E    ****************************<br><br>Miniscribe<br><br>MODEL   AT               CAP 423     Head 8 sect 26  WPcom 0  LZone 424<br> <br><br>Jumper JP12 JP13     (for all above NEC drives)<br>Single  0       0<br>Master 1 0<br>Slave   1       1<br><br>There have been reported difficulties in using WD Caviar as Master and<br>NEC drives as slave - the other way it works.<br><br><br><br>***************************   Q U A N T U M   *************************<br><br>Logical Specs for Quantum AT Drives<br>COMPLIMENTS OF COMPUTER BROKERS OF CANADA<br><br><br>Model       Cap     Avg Acc Cylinders     Heads    Sectors/Track<br>            (MB)     (ms)<br><br>40AT        42        19           965          5            17<br>80AT        84        19           965         10            17<br>120AT       120       15           814          9            32<br>170AT       168       15           968         10            34<br>210AT       209       15           873         13            36<br>425AT       426       14          1021         16            51<br>LPS  52AT   52        17           751          8            17<br>LPS  80AT   83        17           611         16            17<br>LPS 105AT   105       17           755         16            17<br>LPS 120AT   122       16           901          5            53<br>LPS 240AT   245       16           723         13            51<br><br>=================================================<br>Legend:  1=Jumper Installed  0=No Jumper<br>=================================================<br><br>40 & 80 AT Jumpers<br><br>DS  SS   Meaning<br>1   0    Single drive configuration<br>1   1    Master of dual drive<br>0   0    Slave of dual drive<br>0   1    Self-Seek Test<br><br>=======================================================<br><br>120, 170, 210 & 425 AT Jumpers<br><br>DS  SP  SS   Meaning<br>0   0   0    Slave when the Master is Quantum PRODRIVE other than 40/80A<br>0   0   1    Slave in PRODRIVE 40/80A mode<br>0   1   0    Slave when Master is non Quantum Drive<br>0   1   1    Not Used<br>1   0   1    Master drive PDIAG mode checking DASP for slave<br>1   1   0    Master in PDIAG mode using SP to check if slave present<br>1   1   1    Master in 40/80A mode using SP to check if slave present<br>1   0   0    Single drive<br><br>=======================================================<br><br>LPS 52, 80, 105, 120 & 240 AT Jumpers<br>DS  SP  DM*  Meaning<br>0   0   0    Slave in standard PDIAG mode for compatibility with drives that use<br>             PDIAG-line to handle Master/Slave communications<br>0   0   1    Slave in PRODRIVE 40/80A mode compat. without using PDIAG line<br>0   1   0    Self Test<br>0   1   1    Self Test<br>1   0   0    Master in PDIAG mode using DASP to check for Slave<br>1   0   1    Master in 40/80A Mode using DASP to check for Slave<br>1   1   0    Master in PDIAG mode using SP to check for Slave without<br>             checking DASP<br>1   1   1    Master in 40/80A mode using SP to check for Slave without<br>             checking DASP<br><br><br>======================================================================<br>* While my Spec form marked the jumper name DM, it is labeled as CS on<br>  my LPS 240AT drive.<br><br><br><br>The QUANTUM ELS series:<br><br>Model       Cap     Avg Acc     Cylinders     Heads    Sectors/Track<br>            (MB)     (ms)<br> <br>ELS42AT        42        -           968          5             17<br>ELS85AT        85        -           977          10            17<br>ELS127AT       127       -           919          16            17<br>ELS170AT       170       -           1011         15            22<br><br>Write precomp = 0 for all Quantum drives ( probably no significance)<br>Landing Zone = Cylinders<br><br>Straps: If an ELS drive is <br> master only, use DS<br> master with slave, DS or, DS and SP in some cases<br> slave, no strap<br><br><br>***************************   R O D I M E    *********************************<br><br>Information for RO 3008A and RO 3009A series hard disk drives:<br><br>Drive Types<br><br>   Model Cyls Hds Sectors/Trk  No. blocks Formatted Cap.<br>  ------- ---- --- -----------  ---------- --------------<br>  RO3058A 868  3     34     88,536  45.33 MByets<br>  RO3088A 868  5     34    147,560  75.55 MByets<br>  RO3095A 923  5     34    156,910  80.33 MByets<br>  RO3128A 868  7     34    206,584 105.77 MByets<br>  RO3135A 923  7     34    219,674 112.47 MByets<br> <br>  RO3059A 217 15     28     91,158  46.67 MByets<br>  RO3089A 325 15     28    136,737  70.00 MByets<br>  RO3129A 492 15     28    206,645 105.80 MByets<br>  RO3139A 523 15     28    219,735 112.50 MByets<br>  RO3209A 759 15     28    319,053 163.35 MByets<br>  RO3259A 976 15     28    410,211 210.02 MByets<br><br><br>Link Options<br><br>   In order to install the Rodime Ro 3000A series drives the dumpers for <br>the single/dual drive and LED operation on the drive need to be set as <br>described in the relevant product specification.<br>   I a single drive environment the drive is described as a Master.<br>   In a dual drive environment the drives are described as a Master and a<br>Slave. This is due to the protocal the takes place between the two drives <br>when performing diagnostics.<br>   There are four links, LK1, LK2, LK4 and LK5, adjacent to the 40 way <br>interface connector. They have the following functions and are described <br>in order as viewed from the end of the drive, with the first jumper <br>described nearest the 40 way interface connector.<br><br>LK2: LED <br>     When fitted, this jumper connects the LED drive to pin 39 of the<br>     interface. This allows a LED to be connected to the interface. An<br>     external current limiting resistor needs to be fitted in series with<br>     the LED when this option is selected. The value of the resistor will<br>     be dependant on the LED type chosen but will be in the range of 130<br>     Ohms ot 220 Ohms.<br><br>LK1: Dual Drives<br>     This jumper must be fitted when two drives are attached to a single<br>     bus. It fallows communication across the 40 way interface connector,<br>     indicating, to the Master drive, the presence of a Slave.<br><br>LK4: Master<br>     When fitted this signifies that the drive jumpered is a Master. If<br>     there are two drives connected on a single bus then only one may be<br>     jumpered in this way.<br><br>LK5: IOChRdy<br>     When fitted this connects the IOChRdy signal to the drive, it is <br>     fitted when the drive is used in host systems that have a higher<br>     data transfer rate than the drive i.e. greater than 4 MBytes per<br>     second when using 1:1 interleave. This jumper is not normally <br>     fitted as most hosts transfer at a lower rate than 4 MBytes per<br>     second.<br><br>   There are four possible Master/Slave configurations in which a drive(s)<br>may be jumpered:<br><br>     Master, single drive with LED on interface  LK2 & LK4 fitted.<br>     Master, single drive without LED on interface LK4 only fitted.<br>     Master, dual drive without LED on interface LK4 & LK1 fitted.<br>     Slave, dual drive without LED on interface  No jumpers fitted.<br>     Master, dual drive with LED on interface  LK4, LK1 & LK2 fitted.<br>     Slave, dual drive with LED on interface  LK2 only fitted.<br><br>   The Master drive will delay power-up for approximately two seconds to<br>reduce power surges in applications where dual drives are used.<br><br>   The other connections for a LED will be found close to the 28 way <br>connector at the other end of the drive. This LED driver is not affected<br>by the link options. An internal current limiting resistor is on the <br>drive for this LED driver. Refer to the product specification for further<br>details.<br><br><br><br><br>***************************   S E A G A T E   *************************<br><br>There is a list of most Seagate HD (including MFM, SCSI, ESDIand IDE) on<br>every Simtel mirror under<br><br>/msdos/dskutl/1seagate.zip<br><br>It contains info about the following drives:<br><br>     st1144a st138a     st274a st3283a<br>st1057a     st1156a st1400a     st280a st351ax<br>st1090a     st1162a st1401a     st3051a st9051a<br>st1102a     st1186a st1480a     st3096a st9077a<br>st1111a     st1201a st157a     st3120a st9096a<br>st1126a     st1239a st2274a     st3144a st9144a<br>st1133a     st125a st2383a     st325ax<br><br><br>********************* T E A C   **************<br><br>Model: SD-3105<br><br>                Cyls.   Heads   Sect/T  PreCmp  LZone   Capacity<br>                ------  ------  ------  ------  ------  ---------<br>Physical         1282       4      40       -       -   105021440<br>BIOS (AMI)        641       8      40       0       0   105021440 (100.2M)<br>     (Award)      926      13      17       0       0   104778752  (99.9M)<br>     (Phoenix)    776       8      33       0       0   104890368 (100.0M)<br><br>Connectors and Jumpers:<br><br>   +----+                    1           Jumper  Function<br>   |....| +---+ +-------/ /---+   2 0       0    ON:  -ACT selected (ext.LED)<br>   |    | |...| |::::::/ /::::|  ::::            OFF: -SLV PRESENT selected<br>   +----+ +---+ +-----/ /-----+  3 1        1    ON:  Two HDD's<br>     J2     J7  40    J1         ----            OFF: Single HDD<br>   Power (Power)    Signal      Jumpers     2    ON:  Master (/Single)<br>                                                 OFF: Slave (with 2 units used)<br>                                            3    ON:  -I/O CH RDY not output<br>                                                 OFF: -I/O CH RDY is output<br>Master Slave Settings:<br><br>Jumper no.:   1     2<br>-----------------------<br>Single....:   0     1                            1, ON  = jumpered<br>Master....:   1     1                            0, OFF = not jumpered<br>Slave.....:   1     0<br><br><br><br>********************* W E S T E R N  D I G I T A L  **************<br><br>Caviar series:<br><br>Name        Size (Mb)    Cylinders   Heads   Sectors<br>----------------------------------------------------<br>WDAC140      40.7         980            5        17<br>WDAC280      81.3         980           10        17<br>WDAC2120    119.0        1024           14        17<br>WDAC2170    162.7        1010            6        55<br>WDAC2200    202.8         989           12        35<br>WDAC2340    325.4        1010           12        55<br><br>Please note that these are the *recommended* CMOS parameters. All the disks <br>support so-called dynamic translation, and should thus be able to work with<br>any parameters having fewer sectors than the total number of sectors on<br>the disk.<br><br>Now, according to the manual, the jumper settings are as follows:<br><br>Jumper                               CP   MA   SL<br>-------------------------------------------------<br>Single                                0    0    0<br>Master                                0    1    0<br>Slave                                 0    0    1<br>Slave with Conner CP342 or CP3022     1    0    1   <br><br><br>Maybe there are 2 kinds of Caviar's floating around: <br><br>If your jumpers read MA SL and SI then use:<br>Jumper SI MA SL<br>Single 1 0 0<br>Master 0 1 0<br>Slave 0 0 1<br><br>There have been reported difficulties in using WD Caviar as Master and<br>NEC drives as slave - the other way it works.<br><br><br>WD93044-A  (40 MB)<br>BIOS-Settings <br>977 cyln, 5 heads, 17 sect, LZone: 977 ( wenn sie sie braucht )<br><br>+-------+ +---+---+---+  1: drive is master<br>+-------+ +---+---+---+  3: second drive is a conner-drive<br><br>No jumper set: this is the only drive.<br><br><br><br>********************  Useful telephone numbers...  ********************<br><br>Miniscribe:     <br>  303-651-6000<br><br>Maxtor:<br>  Info/tech support: 800-262-9867<br>  FAX-back: 303-678-2618<br>  BBS: 303-678-2222<br>  They list their 800 number as 1(800)2-MAXTOR.<br><br>Quantum:<br>  408-894-4000<br>  408-944-0410 (Support)<br>  408-894-3218 (FAX)<br>  408-894-3214 (BBS)<br><br>Seagate:<br>  Info/tech support: 408-438-8222<br>  FAX-back: 408-438-2620<br>  BBS: 408-438-8771<br><br><br>*******************   last but not least   *****************<br><br>If I could help you with my little collection and if you live in a<br>part of the world far away from me, how about a postcard for my pinboard?<br>I will surely answer!"	"<br>last update: 14.4.1993<br><br>collected by Carsten Grammes (ph12hucg@rz.uni-sb.de)<br>and published regularly on comp.sys.ibm.pc.hardware.<br><br><br>!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!<br>There is explicitly NO WARRANTY<br>that the given settings are correct or harmless. (I only collect, I do<br>not check for myself!!!). There is always the possibility that the<br>settings may destroy your hardware!<br>!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!<br><br><br>Since I hope however that only well-minded people undergo the effort of<br>posting their settings the chance of applicability exists. If you should<br>agree or disagree with some setting, let me know immediately in order<br>to update the list.<br><br>If you possess a HD not mentioned here of which you know BIOS and/or<br>jumper settings, please mail them to me for the next update of the list!<br><br>Only IDE (AT-Bus) Harddisks will be accounted for.<br>If not specified the Landing Zone should be set equal to the number of<br>cylinders. If not specified the 'Write Precompensation' should be set<br>65535. (There are BIOSes that don't even ask for it).<br><br>Another statement (maybe right):<br>IDE harddisk don't have Precomp and LZone. The precomp is a built-in parameter<br>and lzone isn't used because most if not every IDE disk has autopark.<br><br>The jumpers' names are given as printed on the HD's board, often only a<br>jumper number (JP12 means the jumper '12'). A zero means that the jumper<br>is left open, a one means that the jumper is closed.<br><br><br><br>***************************   C O N N E R   ***************************<br><br><br>  Conner Peripherals Drive Geometry<br><br>IDE/AT<br><br>Conner drives are low level formatted at the factory. It is only necessary<br>to run SETUP, FDISK, and DOS FORMAT.<br><br>Model   Heads  Cylinders  Sectors   PComp   L-Zone  Type  Table    LED<br><br>CP2034     2     823         38      0       823    *UT     3      N/A<br>CP2064     4     823         38      0       823    *UT     3      N/A<br>CP2084     8     548         38      0       548    *UT     3      N/A<br>CP3184     6     832         33      0       832    *UT     1       A<br>CP3104     8     776         33      0       776    *UT     1       A<br>CP3111     8     833         33      0       833    *UT     1       A(?)<br>CP3204    16     683         38      0       683    *UT     2       B<br>CP30064    4     762         39      0       762    *UT     2       B<br>CP30084    8     526         39      0       526    *UT     2       B<br>CP30104    8     762         39      0       762    *UT     2       B<br>CP30084E   4     903         46      0       903    *UT     3       C<br>CP30174E   8     903         46      0       903    *UT     3       C<br>CP30204   16     683         38      0       683    *UT     3       C<br>CP3304    16     659         63      0       659    *UT     3       D<br>CP3364    16     702         63      0       702    *UT     3       D<br>CP3504    16     987         63      0       987    *UT     3       D<br>CP3554    16    1054         63      0      1054    *UT     3       B<br><br>Table 1                                  Table 2<br><br>       Jumper Settings                          Jumper Settings<br><br>Single Drive = Jumper ACT and C/D        Single Drive = Jumper C/D<br>Master Drive = Jumper ACT, C/D and DSP   Master Drive = Jumper C/D & DSP<br>Slave Drive = No jumpers installed       Slave Drive = No jumpers installed<br><br><br>Table 3<br>                                     All Conner 20 Mbyte drives use<br>        Jumper Settings              Drive type 2.  All Conner 40<br>                                     Mbyte drives use Drive type 17.<br>Single & Master Drive = Jumper C/D<br>Slave Drive = No jumpers installed   *UT = Universal translate.<br>                                     Select a drive type that is<br>                                     close to but does not exceed<br>                                     the megabyte capacity of the<br>                                     drive.  The drive will<br>                                     translate to the megabyte<br>                                     capacity that you have<br>                                     selected.<br><br>  LED<br><br>  A:           B:                       C:         D:<br>  J-4          J-5                      J-5        J-3<br>  Pin 1 = +    Pin 3 = +                Pin 3 = -  Pin 3 = +<br>  Pin 2 = -    Pin 4 = -                Pin 4 = -  Pin 4 = -<br><br><br><br><br><br>***************************    F U J I T S U      ***************************<br><br>DETAILS OF FUJITSU DRIVES M261xT (Standard)<br><br>                   M2614ET     M2613ET     M2612ET     M2611T<br><br>Heads (physical)       8           6           4           2<br>Cyl (physical)      1334        1334        1334        1334<br>Sec/trk               33          33          33          33<br>Speed (rpm)         3490        3490        3490        3490<br>Capacity           180MB       135MB        90MB        45MB<br><br><br>              +-----------------------------------------------+<br>              |                                               |<br>              +--+                                            |<br>        PSU   |  |      CNH-2                                 |<br>              +--+          1                                 |<br>            1 |  |          .                    LED          |<br>              |  | CNH-1    9      CNH-3      Connector       |<br>              |  |   1           6..1            o o          |<br>      40-way  |  |   .                           | |          |<br>        IDE   |  |   .                                        |<br>              |  |   .                                        |<br>              |  |  12                                        |<br>              +--+                                            |<br>              +-----------------------------------------------+<br><br><br><br>                 Pin        Function<br>                 Position<br><br>                 *  1- 2    Active mode<br>                    2- 3    Slave present mode<br>                    4- 5    Pin 27=IOCHRDY<br>CNH-1 JUMPERS    *  5- 6    Pin 27=RESERVED<br>                    7- 8    2 drive system<br>                 *  8- 9    1 drive system<br>                   10-11    Pin 29=IRQ14 : Pin 31=RESERVED<br>                 * 11-12    Pin 31=IRQ14 : Pin 29=RESERVED<br><br><br>                 Pin        Function<br>                 Position<br><br>                    1- 2    SLAVE drive mode<br>CNH-2 JUMPERS    *  4- 5    MASTER drive mode<br>                    7- 8    ECC 4 bytes<br>                 *  8- 9    ECC 7 bytes<br><br><br>                 Pin        Function<br>                 Position<br><br>                    1- 2    Write protect enabled<br>CNH-3 JUMPERS    *  2- 3    Write protect disabled<br>                    4- 5 -6 Reserved<br><br>Key:  * (I guess!) marks factory default setting for jumper<br><br><br>BIOS SETTINGS<br><br>BIOS setting for the M2614ET in my system is 667 cylinders, 33 sectors<br>and 16 heads.<br><br><br><br><br>MODEL      CYLINDERS   HEADS    SECTORS   CAPACITY (Million bytes)<br><br>M2622T      1013        10        63         326.75<br>M2623T      1002        13        63         420.16<br>M2624T      995         16        63         513.51<br><br><br>There are 6 switches on the switch block on these drives.  Only 4 of <br>them have a use that I am aware of (from my M2624T manual):<br><br>Master/Slave        Master (*)      SW1-5 OFF<br>                    Slave           SW1-5 ON<br>ECC bytes           4 bytes (*)     SW1-4 OFF<br>                    7 bytes         SW1-4 ON<br>Write Protect       Disabled (*)    SW1-3 OFF<br>                    Enabled         SW1-3 ON<br>IO Channel Ready    Disabled (*)    SW1-1 OFF<br>                    Enabled         SW1-1 ON<br><br>I have no idea about the function of SW1-2 and SW1-6.  The values <br>listed with a (*) are the factory default settings.<br><br><br>***************************   K A L O K     ***************************<br><br>KALOK KL3100   105 MB<br>BIOS: cyl 979     heads 6 sectors 35<br><br>KALOK   KL3120    120 MB<br>BIOS:  Cyl 981     heads 6     sectors 40<br><br>The following jumper settings have been reported for KL3100 but are probably<br>also valid for other Kalok drives.<br><br>Single HD:<br>o o o o o<br><br>o o o o-o    <-- same row as pin 1 of the IDE connector.<br><br>Master (disk 1):<br>o o o o o<br>    |<br>o o o o o<br><br>Slave:<br>o o o o o<br>      |<br>o o o o o<br><br>These 5 pairs of pins are at the righthand side of the disk.<br><br><br><br>***************************   M A X T O R   ***************************<br><br>Model           Cyls    Heads   Sectors Precomp Landing Zone<br>---------- ----- ----- ------- ------- ------------<br>LXT-200A 816 15 32 0 816<br>LXT-213A 683 16 38 0 683<br>LXT-340A 654 16 63 0 654<br>LXT437A  842 16 63 0 842<br>LXT535A  1036 16 63 0 1024<br><br>Jumpers are as follows:<br><br>The bottom of the drive looks like this (well, sort of):<br><br>+[POWER] [IDE CONNECTOR]-----+<br><br>    Single drive   Dual Drive System<br>Pin numbers Jumper  System  Master  Slave<br>----------- ------  ------------ ------  -----<br>1-2  Slave Drive remove  remove  install<br>3-4  Activity LED optional optional optional<br>5-6  Slave Present remove  remove  optional<br>7-8  Master Drive remove  install  remove<br>9-10  Sync Spindle remove (n/a) optional* remove<br><br>* only one drive (the master) in an array should have this jumper installed.<br><br><br><br>Maxtor 7060A    16    467   17     62,0 J14 closed, J13 closed<br>Maxtor 7060A     7   1024   17     59,5 J14 open,   J13 open<br>Maxtor 7060A     4    762   39     58,0 J14 closed, J13 open<br>Maxtor 7060A     8    925   17     57,9 J14 open,   J13 closed<br><br>Maxtor 7120A    16    936   17    124,3 J14 closed, J13 closed<br>Maxtor 7120A    14   1024   17    119,0 j14 open,   J13 open<br>Maxtor 7120A     8    762   39    116,0 J14 closed, J13 open<br>Maxtor 7120A    15    900   17    112,0 J14 open,   J13 closed<br>Maxtor 7120A     8    824   33    106,2 J14<br><br>Jumpers for the above 2 drives:<br><br>                  J11  I/O-channel ready ( open: disabled; close: enabled )<br>                  J13  see above<br>                  J14  see above<br>                  J15  operation-status ( open: normal; close: factory )<br>       J J J J J            <br>       2 1 1 1 1<br>       0 9 8 7 6<br><br>Power  data-cable<br><br>J16: Idle mode latch ( open: disabled; close: enabled )<br>J17: drive model ( open: 7060A; close 7120A )<br>J18: ECC Bytes ( open: 7 bytes; close: 4 bytes )<br><br>Master/Slave: drive is master and alone    : J20 closed, J19 closed<br>              drive is master of two drives: J20 closed, J19 open<br>              drive is slave of two drives : J20 open  , J19 closed<br><br><br>Maxtor 7213A<br><br>Default (power-up) AT BIOS Translation Parameters (others possible)<br>Cyl   Hds  SpT  MBytes<br>683   16   38   212<br><br>There are two sets of jumpers. A set of 5 and a set of<br>4. With the power and IDE connector toward you, the set of 5 is<br>numbered (left to right) J16 - J20  , and the set of 4 is numbered<br>(bottom to top) J22-J25. <br><br>The only jumper of normal interest is J20. Jumper it for only<br>drive in a single drive system, or master drive in a dual drive<br>system.<br> <br>Remove the jumper J20 for slave drive in a dual drive system. <br><br>J19 is a dummy and may be used to store the spare shunt if the <br>drive is configured for a slave mode.<br><br>Jumpers J17, J18, J24, J25 are factory reserved. Abnormal operation<br>may occur if jumpered.<br><br>Jumper 22 is sync spindle enabled/disabled  (open=disabled)<br>Jumper 23 is sync slave/master              (open=slave)<br>Jumper 16 is I/O Channel Ready              (open=disabled)<br><br><br>Maxtor 7245A (245Mb IDE; self-parking; Universal Translate):<br>Drive type : User defineable<br>Cyl    Hds    WPC    LZ     S/T<br>967    16     0      0      31      (WPC and LZ optional)<br><br>Master(2):  J20 closed<br>Slave(2):   J20 open (use J19 for shunt storage)<br>Single:     J20 closed<br><br><br>**********************   M I C R O P O L I S   ****************************<br><br><br>Drive  2105A  2112A<br>----------------------------------------<br>Unformatted MB 647  1220<br>Formatted MB 560  1050<br>Platters 5  8<br>Heads  8  15<br>Cylinders 1760  1760<br>----------------------------------------<br><br>Performance (both):<br><br> Track to track (read)  1.5 msec<br> Track to track (write)  2.5 msec<br> Average    10 msec<br> Max    25 msec<br> Avg Rotational Latency  5.56 msec<br> Rotational speed  5400 rpm (+/- 5%)<br> Data Transfer Rate  upto 5Mbytes/sec<br> Internal data rate  24-40 Mbits/sec<br><br>BIOS Settings:<br><br>2105A  1084 cyl 16 heads 63 sectors<br>2112A* master 1024 cyl 16 heads 63 sectors<br> slave 1010 cyl 16 heads 63 sectors<br>  <br>* the 2112A emulates both master and slave<br><br><br>Jumpers (labelled J6 on the drive)<br><br> ----<br> |oo| W1\ only these 2 are used<br> |oo| W2/<br> |oo|<br> |oo|<br> |oo|<br> ----<br><br> W2 W1<br> -- --<br> in in 2112A only - drive emulates both master + slave<br> in out Drive is master, slave is present<br> out in Drive is slave<br> out out Drive is master, no slave present (ie single drive)<br><br><br>**********************   M I C R O S C I E N C E   ****************************<br><br>MicroScience <br><br>Model: 7100-00<br>Heads: 7<br>Cylinders: 855<br>S/T: 35 (?)<br>Size: 105M<br><br><br>Model # 8040-00.<br>Size 40M  5hd/17sec/977cyl<br><br>**********************   M I N I S C R I B E    ****************************<br><br>Miniscribe<br><br>MODEL   AT               CAP   CYC  H  RWC  WPC ENC  RATE ACCESS  SPT COMMENTS <br>8225AT            3.5""    21   745  2  -    -        8    28 MS    28<br>8051AT            3.5""    42   745  4  -    -        8    28 MS    28<br>8450AT            3.5""    42   745  4  -    -        8    40 MS    28<br><br>Master(2):  5-6<br>Slave(2):   1-2<br>Single:     1-3 (shunt storage)<br><br><br>***************************   N E C   *********************************<br><br>NEC     D3735,  40 MB<br>BIOS: Cyl 537     Head 4 sect 41<br><br>NEC D3755, 105 MB<br>BIOS: Cyl 625     Head 8 sect 41<br><br>NEC D3741, 44 MB<br>BIOS: Cyl 423     Head 8 sect 26  WPcom 0  LZone 424<br> <br><br>Jumper JP12 JP13     (for all above NEC drives)<br>Single  0       0<br>Master 1 0<br>Slave   1       1<br><br>There have been reported difficulties in using WD Caviar as Master and<br>NEC drives as slave - the other way it works.<br><br><br><br>***************************   Q U A N T U M   *************************<br><br>Logical Specs for Quantum AT Drives<br>COMPLIMENTS OF COMPUTER BROKERS OF CANADA<br><br><br>Model       Cap     Avg Acc Cylinders     Heads    Sectors/Track<br>            (MB)     (ms)<br><br>40AT        42        19           965          5            17<br>80AT        84        19           965         10            17<br>120AT       120       15           814          9            32<br>170AT       168       15           968         10            34<br>210AT       209       15           873         13            36<br>425AT       426       14          1021         16            51<br>LPS  52AT   52        17           751          8            17<br>LPS  80AT   83        17           611         16            17<br>LPS 105AT   105       17           755         16            17<br>LPS 120AT   122       16           901          5            53<br>LPS 240AT   245       16           723         13            51<br><br>=================================================<br>Legend:  1=Jumper Installed  0=No Jumper<br>=================================================<br><br>40 & 80 AT Jumpers<br><br>DS  SS   Meaning<br>1   0    Single drive configuration<br>1   1    Master of dual drive<br>0   0    Slave of dual drive<br>0   1    Self-Seek Test<br><br>=======================================================<br><br>120, 170, 210 & 425 AT Jumpers<br><br>DS  SP  SS   Meaning<br>0   0   0    Slave when the Master is Quantum PRODRIVE other than 40/80A<br>0   0   1    Slave in PRODRIVE 40/80A mode<br>0   1   0    Slave when Master is non Quantum Drive<br>0   1   1    Not Used<br>1   0   1    Master drive PDIAG mode checking DASP for slave<br>1   1   0    Master in PDIAG mode using SP to check if slave present<br>1   1   1    Master in 40/80A mode using SP to check if slave present<br>1   0   0    Single drive<br><br>=======================================================<br><br>LPS 52, 80, 105, 120 & 240 AT Jumpers<br>DS  SP  DM*  Meaning<br>0   0   0    Slave in standard PDIAG mode for compatibility with drives that use<br>             PDIAG-line to handle Master/Slave communications<br>0   0   1    Slave in PRODRIVE 40/80A mode compat. without using PDIAG line<br>0   1   0    Self Test<br>0   1   1    Self Test<br>1   0   0    Master in PDIAG mode using DASP to check for Slave<br>1   0   1    Master in 40/80A Mode using DASP to check for Slave<br>1   1   0    Master in PDIAG mode using SP to check for Slave without<br>             checking DASP<br>1   1   1    Master in 40/80A mode using SP to check for Slave without<br>             checking DASP<br><br><br>======================================================================<br>* While my Spec form marked the jumper name DM, it is labeled as CS on<br>  my LPS 240AT drive.<br><br><br><br>The QUANTUM ELS series:<br><br>Model       Cap     Avg Acc     Cylinders     Heads    Sectors/Track<br>            (MB)     (ms)<br> <br>ELS42AT        42        -           968          5             17<br>ELS85AT        85        -           977          10            17<br>ELS127AT       127       -           919          16            17<br>ELS170AT       170       -           1011         15            22<br><br>Write precomp = 0 for all Quantum drives ( probably no significance)<br>Landing Zone = Cylinders<br><br>Straps: If an ELS drive is <br> master only, use DS<br> master with slave, DS or, DS and SP in some cases<br> slave, no strap<br><br><br>***************************   R O D I M E    *********************************<br><br>Information for RO 3008A and RO 3009A series hard disk drives:<br><br>Drive Types<br><br>   Model Cyls Hds Sectors/Trk  No. blocks Formatted Cap.<br>  ------- ---- --- -----------  ---------- --------------<br>  RO3058A 868  3     34     88,536  45.33 MByets<br>  RO3088A 868  5     34    147,560  75.55 MByets<br>  RO3095A 923  5     34    156,910  80.33 MByets<br>  RO3128A 868  7     34    206,584 105.77 MByets<br>  RO3135A 923  7     34    219,674 112.47 MByets<br> <br>  RO3059A 217 15     28     91,158  46.67 MByets<br>  RO3089A 325 15     28    136,737  70.00 MByets<br>  RO3129A 492 15     28    206,645 105.80 MByets<br>  RO3139A 523 15     28    219,735 112.50 MByets<br>  RO3209A 759 15     28    319,053 163.35 MByets<br>  RO3259A 976 15     28    410,211 210.02 MByets<br><br><br>Link Options<br><br>   In order to install the Rodime Ro 3000A series drives the dumpers for <br>the single/dual drive and LED operation on the drive need to be set as <br>described in the relevant product specification.<br>   I a single drive environment the drive is described as a Master.<br>   In a dual drive environment the drives are described as a Master and a<br>Slave. This is due to the protocal the takes place between the two drives <br>when performing diagnostics.<br>   There are four links, LK1, LK2, LK4 and LK5, adjacent to the 40 way <br>interface connector. They have the following functions and are described <br>in order as viewed from the end of the drive, with the first jumper <br>described nearest the 40 way interface connector.<br><br>LK2: LED <br>     When fitted, this jumper connects the LED drive to pin 39 of the<br>     interface. This allows a LED to be connected to the interface. An<br>     external current limiting resistor needs to be fitted in series with<br>     the LED when this option is selected. The value of the resistor will<br>     be dependant on the LED type chosen but will be in the range of 130<br>     Ohms ot 220 Ohms.<br><br>LK1: Dual Drives<br>     This jumper must be fitted when two drives are attached to a single<br>     bus. It fallows communication across the 40 way interface connector,<br>     indicating, to the Master drive, the presence of a Slave.<br><br>LK4: Master<br>     When fitted this signifies that the drive jumpered is a Master. If<br>     there are two drives connected on a single bus then only one may be<br>     jumpered in this way.<br><br>LK5: IOChRdy<br>     When fitted this connects the IOChRdy signal to the drive, it is <br>     fitted when the drive is used in host systems that have a higher<br>     data transfer rate than the drive i.e. greater than 4 MBytes per<br>     second when using 1:1 interleave. This jumper is not normally <br>     fitted as most hosts transfer at a lower rate than 4 MBytes per<br>     second.<br><br>   There are four possible Master/Slave configurations in which a drive(s)<br>may be jumpered:<br><br>     Master, single drive with LED on interface  LK2 & LK4 fitted.<br>     Master, single drive without LED on interface LK4 only fitted.<br>     Master, dual drive without LED on interface LK4 & LK1 fitted.<br>     Slave, dual drive without LED on interface  No jumpers fitted.<br>     Master, dual drive with LED on interface  LK4, LK1 & LK2 fitted.<br>     Slave, dual drive with LED on interface  LK2 only fitted.<br><br>   The Master drive will delay power-up for approximately two seconds to<br>reduce power surges in applications where dual drives are used.<br><br>   The other connections for a LED will be found close to the 28 way <br>connector at the other end of the drive. This LED driver is not affected<br>by the link options. An internal current limiting resistor is on the <br>drive for this LED driver. Refer to the product specification for further<br>details.<br><br><br><br><br>***************************   S E A G A T E   *************************<br><br>There is a list of most Seagate HD (including MFM, SCSI, ESDIand IDE) on<br>every Simtel mirror under<br><br>/msdos/dskutl/1seagate.zip<br><br>It contains info about the following drives:<br><br>     st1144a st138a     st274a st3283a<br>st1057a     st1156a st1400a     st280a st351ax<br>st1090a     st1162a st1401a     st3051a st9051a<br>st1102a     st1186a st1480a     st3096a st9077a<br>st1111a     st1201a st157a     st3120a st9096a<br>st1126a     st1239a st2274a     st3144a st9144a<br>st1133a     st125a st2383a     st325ax<br><br><br>********************* T E A C   **************<br><br>Model: SD-3105<br><br>                Cyls.   Heads   Sect/T  PreCmp  LZone   Capacity<br>                ------  ------  ------  ------  ------  ---------<br>Physical         1282       4      40       -       -   105021440<br>BIOS (AMI)        641       8      40       0       0   105021440 (100.2M)<br>     (Award)      926      13      17       0       0   104778752  (99.9M)<br>     (Phoenix)    776       8      33       0       0   104890368 (100.0M)<br><br>Connectors and Jumpers:<br><br>   +----+                    1           Jumper  Function<br>   |....| +---+ +-------/ /---+   2 0       0    ON:  -ACT selected (ext.LED)<br>   |    | |...| |::::::/ /::::|  ::::            OFF: -SLV PRESENT selected<br>   +----+ +---+ +-----/ /-----+  3 1        1    ON:  Two HDD's<br>     J2     J7  40    J1         ----            OFF: Single HDD<br>   Power (Power)    Signal      Jumpers     2    ON:  Master (/Single)<br>                                                 OFF: Slave (with 2 units used)<br>                                            3    ON:  -I/O CH RDY not output<br>                                                 OFF: -I/O CH RDY is output<br>Master Slave Settings:<br><br>Jumper no.:   1     2<br>-----------------------<br>Single....:   0     1                            1, ON  = jumpered<br>Master....:   1     1                            0, OFF = not jumpered<br>Slave.....:   1     0<br><br><br><br>********************* W E S T E R N  D I G I T A L  **************<br><br>Caviar series:<br><br>Name        Size (Mb)    Cylinders   Heads   Sectors<br>----------------------------------------------------<br>WDAC140      40.7         980            5        17<br>WDAC280      81.3         980           10        17<br>WDAC2120    119.0        1024           14        17<br>WDAC2170    162.7        1010            6        55<br>WDAC2200    202.8         989           12        35<br>WDAC2340    325.4        1010           12        55<br><br>Please note that these are the *recommended* CMOS parameters. All the disks <br>support so-called dynamic translation, and should thus be able to work with<br>any parameters having fewer sectors than the total number of sectors on<br>the disk.<br><br>Now, according to the manual, the jumper settings are as follows:<br><br>Jumper                               CP   MA   SL<br>-------------------------------------------------<br>Single                                0    0    0<br>Master                                0    1    0<br>Slave                                 0    0    1<br>Slave with Conner CP342 or CP3022     1    0    1   <br><br><br>Maybe there are 2 kinds of Caviar's floating around: <br><br>If your jumpers read MA SL and SI then use:<br>Jumper SI MA SL<br>Single 1 0 0<br>Master 0 1 0<br>Slave 0 0 1<br><br>There have been reported difficulties in using WD Caviar as Master and<br>NEC drives as slave - the other way it works.<br><br><br>WD93044-A  (40 MB)<br>BIOS-Settings <br>977 cyln, 5 heads, 17 sect, LZone: 977 ( wenn sie sie braucht )<br><br>+-------+ +---+---+---+  1: drive is master<br>+-------+ +---+---+---+  3: second drive is a conner-drive<br><br>No jumper set: this is the only drive.<br><br><br><br>********************  Useful telephone numbers...  ********************<br><br>Miniscribe:     <br>  303-651-6000<br><br>Maxtor:<br>  Info/tech support: 800-262-9867<br>  FAX-back: 303-678-2618<br>  BBS: 303-678-2222<br>  They list their 800 number as 1(800)2-MAXTOR.<br><br>Quantum:<br>  408-894-4000<br>  408-944-0410 (Support)<br>  408-894-3218 (FAX)<br>  408-894-3214 (BBS)<br><br>Seagate:<br>  Info/tech support: 408-438-8222<br>  FAX-back: 408-438-2620<br>  BBS: 408-438-8771<br><br><br>*******************   last but not least   *****************<br><br>If I could help you with my little collection and if you live in a<br>part of the world far away from me, how about a postcard for my pinboard?<br>I will surely answer!"

597	0	"Since running any GUI over a network is going to slow it down by a<br>fair amount, I expect Windows NT will be multiuser only in the sense<br>of sharing filesystems. Someone will likely write a telnetd for it so<br>one could run character-based apps, but graphics-based apps will have<br>to be shared by running the executables on the local CPU. This is how<br>things are shaping up everywhere: client-server architectures are<br>taking over from the old cpu-terminal setups. <br><br>Note that the NeXT does this: you can always telnet into a NeXT and<br>run character-based apps but you can't run the GUI. (Yeah, I know<br>about X-Windows, just haven't been too impressed by it...)..<br><br><br><br><br><br><br>-- "	"Since running any GUI over a network is going to slow it down by a<br>fair amount, I expect Windows NT will be multiuser only in the sense<br>of sharing filesystems. 598	1	"[Tons of stuff deleted on SCSI vs. IDE question...]<br><br>Wow, you guys are really going wild on this IDE vs. SCSI thing, and I think<br>it's great!<br><br>Like lots of people, I'd really like to increase my data transfer rate from<br>the hard drive.  Right now I have a 15ms 210Mb IDE drive (Seagate 1239A), and<br>what I would say is a standard (not special, no cache I believe) IDE controller<br>card on my ISA 486-50.<br><br>I'm currently thinking about adding another HD, in the 300Mb to 500Mb range.<br>And I'm thinking hard (you should hear those gears a-grinding in my head)<br>about buying a SCSI drive (SCSI for the future benefit).  I believe I'm getting<br>something like 890Kb/sec transfer right now (according to NU).  How would this<br>number compare if I bought the state-of-the-art SCSI card for my ISA PC, and<br>the state-of-the-art SCSI hard drive (the wailing-est system I could hope for)?<br>Obviously money factors into this choice as well as any other, but what would<br>YOU want to use on your ISA system? And how much would it cost?<br><br>Along those lines, what kind of transfer rate could I see with my IDE HD's if I<br>were to buy the top-of-the-line IDE caching controller for my 200Mb, 15ms HD?<br>And how much would it cost?<br><br>I actually have a PAS-16, and could (what a waste I guess it would be...) hook<br>up a SCSI HD through it's SCSI port which yields an optimum of 690Kb/sec.<br>Actually, I have a borrowed 12ms Fujitsu HD hooked up through it now (and<br>own the Trantor HD drivers for the PAS-16 SCSI port).  Is this SCSI port a<br>SCSI-2 port?  How could I tell?  Is the Fujitsu 2623A a SCSI-2?  Are all SCSI<br>HD's SCSI-2?<br><br>Thanks for any comments on these rephrased questions." 599	0	"    CommandEnvSize=NNNN<br><br>""This sets the COMMAND.COM env size, where NNNN must either be 0 or<br>between 160 and 32768.  A value of 0 disables the setting.  If this<br>value is too small or too big, it is rounded up to 160 or down to 32768.<br>If the value is less than the current size of the actual environment,<br>this setting is disabled, as if it were 0.  If you specify the<br>environment size in a PIF file for COMMAND.COM, the PIF setting<br>overrides this setting.  The default is 0 with MSDOS versions earlier<br>than 3.2.  Otherwise, the default value is the /e: option in the<br>SHELL= command in CONFIG.SYS.  To set this value, you must edit your<br>SYSTEM.INI [and reboot].""<br><br><br>I have used this entry, as well as relied on the default /e: from<br>the CONFIG.SYS shell= line, and both give larger environments.  If<br>you don't use one of these, then the environment passed by windows<br>to each new DOS box is just a little bit bigger than the environment<br>_variables_ present when windows was started.  (No matter how big<br>the DOS env was, when windows starts, it truncates all unused space<br>except for a few bytes.)  This should allow your batch file to run,<br>but your mileage may vary.<br>"	"    CommandEnvSize=NNNN<br><br>""This sets the COMMAND.COM env size, where NNNN must either be 0 or<br>between 160 and 32768.  A value of 0 disables the setting.  If this<br>value is too small or too big, it is rounded up to 160 or down to 32768.<br>If the value is less than the current size of the actual environment,<br>this setting is disabled, as if it were 0.  If you specify the<br>environment size in a PIF file for COMMAND.COM, the PIF setting<br>overrides this setting.  The default is 0 with MSDOS versions earlier<br>than 3.2.  Otherwise, the default value is the /e: option in the<br>SHELL= command in CONFIG.SYS.  To set this value, you must edit your<br>SYSTEM.INI [and reboot].""<br><br><br>I have used this entry, as well as relied on the default /e: from<br>the CONFIG.SYS shell= line, and both give larger environments.  If<br>you don't use one of these, then the environment passed by windows<br>to each new DOS box is just a little bit bigger than the environment<br>_variables_ present when windows was started.  (No matter how big<br>the DOS env was, when windows starts, it truncates all unused space<br>except for a few bytes.)  This should allow your batch file to run,<br>but your mileage may vary.<br>"

606	1	"Andrew, yes there is a DX and DX2 version of the 50MHz 486.  If you are <br>considering buying one or the other, definitely go for the DX with a nice <br>size external cache!  The performance is far greater.<br><br>The DX2 only has the internal 8k cache to work with at 50MHz, while the DX <br>has a potentially much larger cache to work at 50MHz with.  Neither <br>systems could actually run a program out of main memory, since DRAM is <br>still too slow for that high of bus speed ( 60ns = 16.66MHz < 50MHz ).<br><br>-rdd<br><br>---<br> . 608	1	" The one thing that I was puzzled by was why there was not a<br>1024x768x32k color mode on the thing, either in full screen or<br>enlarged desktop mode.  My ATI Ultra Plus can handle that, given 2MB<br>of memory.  All the 2MB buys you on the Fahrenheit is 1280x1024x256.<br>Just ONE more mode.  GEEZ.  Had I known, I wouldn't have bothered.  I<br>asked them why, and all I got was ""Your point is well taken, but<br>Orchid's software developers are busy with other projects.""<br><br> So, to get to the point, finally, ARE there any s3 86c805<br>drivers out there that can handle high res hicolor modes?
