" The one thing that I was puzzled by was why there was not a<br>1024x768x32k color mode on the thing, either in full screen or<br>enlarged desktop mode.  My ATI Ultra Plus can handle that, given 2MB<br>of memory.  All the 2MB buys you on the Fahrenheit is 1280x1024x256.<br>Just ONE more mode.  GEEZ.  Had I known, I wouldn't have bothered.  I<br>asked them why, and all I got was ""Your point is well taken, but<br>Orchid's software developers are busy with other projects.""<br><br> So, to get to the point, finally, ARE there any s3 86c805<br>drivers out there that can handle high res hicolor modes?  I'd love to<br>get another card, but perhaps it will have to wait until the next<br>generation of cards comes out, since this card came bundled with my<br>system and it's not so easy to exchange these things unless they're<br>broken.<br><br> If you want these modes, steer away from Orchids s3 86c805<br>cards (ie. VLB or VA/VLB), at least until their developers are ""less<br>busy"".  If the magazines are to believed, I've only seen one s3 86c805<br>product thus far which can handle 1024x768x32k color (Genoa?),<br>although evenn that might be a misprint.<br><br> Please, if there are generic or semi-generic drivers out<br>there, let me know where I can get them.  800x600x32k is OK, but I<br>coulda gotten that with my ATI VGA Wonder XL."		
609	0	"WSM is a compilation of submissions from shareware/freeware authors in a single<br>Windows .HLP (Help System) file.  All types of software may be submitted for<br>entry in WSM - utilities, applications, games, programming tools, etc.<br><br>WSM benefits Windows shareware/freeware authors by allowing them to publicize<br>their software releases, inform users of updated versions, and to increase<br>their installed base of users.  Those searching for specific Windows software<br>will benefit by having a complete list of available software available at their<br>fingertips - complete with feature lists, current prices, and any other<br>relevant information.<br><br>Windows software authors may submit entries to Windows Shareware Monthly in the<br>following manner:<br><br>1. Compose a short summary of the function of the software.  Include all<br>   special features which are unique to your product and which set it apart<br>   from other programs in the genre.  Be sure to include specific details<br>   such as: the current release version, where the software is available,<br>   how much the registration fee costs, how much disk space is required, any<br>   special requirements (e.g. sound card, or VBRUN200.DLL, etc.), how the<br>   author may be contacted, etc.  Because text is highly compressible, the<br>   summary may be as long as is necessary, however, it is best to keep it<br>   short.  A good guideline is a single screenful of 12-point text at 640x480<br>   resolution.  Order forms and other such addendum may be included if desired.<br>   All submissions whould be in plain text (ASCII) format.  Formatting will<br>   be exactly as it is submitted - I will simply cut and paste text files<br>   into a Help Authoring system.  If you require special formatting <br>   conventions - such as boldface text or italics, or a larger font size,<br>   indicate so CLEARLY within the text file.  For best results, use Windows<br>   NotePad to create the .TXT file. <br> <br>2. Include up to 100k of Windows-format .BMP (bitmap) screen-shots which<br>   display the workings or special features of each program.  Special cases<br>   (rendering applications for example) which require 256-color bitmaps may<br>   submit up to 250k of .BMP files - all other should observe the 100k limit<br>   and use 16-color format.  For maximum compatiblity with the software which<br>   will be used to create the WSM .HLP file (Stefan Olson's Help Writer's<br>   Assistant for Windows), please save the bitmaps with Windows Paintbrush or<br>   WinGIF. <br><br>3. Include a 16-color .BMP of the program's icon (.ICO file).  Many programs<br>   are available to convert .ICO to .BMP format, or Windows Paintbrush may be<br>   used.  The .BMP will be embedded in the summary text.<br><br>4. Double-check for spelling errors, formatting corrections, etc.  <br><br>5. Compress the .TXT file, the .BMP of the program icon, and any additional<br>   .BMPs into a single file using PKZIP (any version).<br><br>6. Submit the entry by UUENCODING the .ZIPfile, and e-mailing it to:<br>   <br>   DAA7365@TAMUTS.TAMU.EDU<br><br>   if submitting via the Internet or Compuserve. If submitting via America<br>   Online, send a brief message indicating submission, and append the .ZIP<br>   file, then e-mail to:<br><br>   DiegoAA<br><br>7. If any changes are required, or a new version is released, complete<br>   the above procedures again.  Send all submissions to the @TAMUTS address,<br>   and any comments, suggestions, criticisms, to DAA7365@RIGEL.TAMU.EDU.<br><br>All entries received before the deadline will be included in the subsequent<br>edition of WSM.  The editor will not be held responsible for any errors, and<br>we reserve the right to make changes to the entries.<br><br>WSM is not limited to shareware/freeware software.  A special area will be<br>devoted to commercially available Windows 3.x and NT software.  Commercial<br>software authors should follow the same steps above, with the exception of<br>the limitations on size - the .TXT file and .BMPs may be as large as required<br>(and as large as is practical for transmission over phone lines).  There<br>is no charge for the publishing of either shareware/freeware or commercial<br>product entries.  <br><br>Advertisements for computer hardware, software, bulletin boards, etc. may<br>be submitted as well. Again, the same procedures apply, with the exception of<br>the size limitations.  There is no charge for advertising space.  The first<br>ten advertisements submitted each month will be included; subsequent<br>submissions will not be included due to size constraints.<br><br>WSM is currently looking for persons willing to devote the time to author<br>columns within WSM.  A C/C++ programing section, a Visual Basic section, and<br>two Windows-specific opinion/advice columns are envisioned.  All work will<br>be on a voluntary basis.  If you wish to aid WSM and author a monthly column<br>on one of the above topics, please send us mail at DAA7365@TAMUTS.TAMU.EDU or<br>DiegoAA on America Online." 613	0	"It certainly is multi-user. What I have seen from the March Beta is<br>that it doesn't yet come with the stuff which exploits multi-user<br>features. I remember somebody from MS stating that it doesn't allow<br>two users share one GUI. My interpretation of this was that one user<br>per console but all the networking and RPC based stuff you want. <br><br>I believe ftp and rlogin deamons for NT systems will come from third<br>party. Somebody already has a Beta version of an unsecure ftpd on the<br>net. There is no reason why one cannot write a posix based shell like<br>csh on Unix for remote logins. <br><br>In general I liked NT when I checked it out. It slow compared to<br>Win3.1 (just like any other real OS). The beta version, although being<br>slow, botts up much faster than my SUN workstation. Windows subsystems<br>also start up a lot faster than X windows. I believe Bill Gates was<br>right when he stated that NT was not for everybody. After playing<br>around with it for a while I was convinced. If I owned a busines using<br>a ""business computer"" from IBM or some other established vendor, I<br>would consider moving to NT platform because it would provide a much<br>cheaper solution (If you are running SQL servers etc.). It provides<br>the robustness such an application requires. <br><br>On the other hand if you like your DOS games, more or less forget<br>about NT. You can always boot to DOS  but in general that defeats<br>the purpose of using NT. Most of NT's features are visible in a<br>networked environment and in such an environment you can't reboot your<br>machine at will. For personal use, I would rather wait for the Win32<br>based Windows release (whatever you name it) than jump to NT bandwagon.<br>I expect most applications will keep on using Win16 until Win32<br>becomes widely available. <br>"	"It certainly is multi-user. What I have seen from the March Beta is<br>that it doesn't yet come with the stuff which exploits multi-user<br>features. I remember somebody from MS stating that it doesn't allow<br>two users share one GUI. My interpretation of this was that one user<br>per console but all the networking and RPC based stuff you want. <br><br>I believe ftp and rlogin deamons for NT systems will come from third<br>party. Somebody already has a Beta version of an unsecure ftpd on the<br>net. There is no reason why one cannot write a posix based shell like<br>csh on Unix for remote logins. <br><br>In general I liked NT when I checked it out. It slow compared to<br>Win3.1 (just like any other real OS). The beta version, although being<br>slow, botts up much faster than my SUN workstation. Windows subsystems<br>also start up a lot faster than X windows. I believe Bill Gates was<br>right when he stated that NT was not for everybody. After playing<br>around with it for a while I was convinced. If I owned a busines using<br>a ""business computer"" from IBM or some other established vendor, I<br>would consider moving to NT platform because it would provide a much<br>cheaper solution (If you are running SQL servers etc.). You can always boot to DOS  but in general that defeats<br>the purpose of using NT. Most of NT's features are visible in a<br>networked environment and in such an environment you can't reboot your<br>machine at will. For personal use, I would rather wait for the Win32<br>based Windows release (whatever you name it) than jump to NT bandwagon.<br>I expect most applications will keep on using Win16 until Win32<br>becomes widely available. <br>"		
614	1	"My detective work has shown that this jumper simply<br>connects/disconnects the BALE line on the 64-pin part<br>of the ISA bus.<br><br>The question I have is simple:<br>To those people who own this revision of the Speedstar 24X,<br>what does the manual claim that this jumper does?<br><br>To anyone with an ISA-reference, what is the function of the<br>BALE line?<br><br>On a related note:<br>Are there any FTP sites which contain a descriptive reference to<br>the ISA bus?  My motherboard manual has a simple pin-to-signal-name<br>chart, but that is it.<br><br>-Douglas<br>"	"My detective work has shown that this jumper simply<br>connects/disconnects the BALE line on the 64-pin part<br>of the ISA bus.<br><br>The question I have is simple:<br>To those people who own this revision of the Speedstar 24X,<br>what does the manual claim that this jumper does?<br><br>To anyone with an ISA-reference, what is the function of the<br>BALE line?<br><br>On a related note:<br>Are there any FTP sites which contain a descriptive reference to<br>the ISA bus? 615	1	<br>Many motherboards have jumpers to enable/disable the memory banks.  Did you <br>check that out?	<br>Many motherboards have jumpers to enable/disable the memory banks.  Did you <br>check that out?		
616	1	"However, I can tell you to stay clear of any board which uses the<br>Rockwell MPU (as opposed to the DPU) for an internal implementation.<br>This is because the MPU used ""speed buffering"" instead of having a<br>16550 interface.  Without the 550 interface, the number of interrupts<br>are still the same and thus may get dropped under multitasking<br>conditions (like in windows).  As far as I know, the ""speed buffering""<br>works OK for external modems if a 550 is used on the internal serial<br>port board.<br><br>Hope this helps...<br>Tom<br>"	"However, I can tell you to stay clear of any board which uses the<br>Rockwell MPU (as opposed to the DPU) for an internal implementation.<br>This is because the MPU used ""speed buffering"" instead of having a<br>16550 interface.  Without the 550 interface, the number of interrupts<br>are still the same and thus may get dropped under multitasking<br>conditions (like in windows).  As far as I know, the ""speed buffering""<br>works OK for external modems if a 550 is used on the internal serial<br>port board.<br><br>Hope this helps...<br>Tom<br>"

618	1	"Nice of you to DELETE BOTH YOUR responce and the item that prompted it.<br>to whit:<br>                                      ^^^<br>To which YOU responded:<br>To which I correctly pointed out the following:                         <br>As I said this is sloppy and DUMB {YOU should resounded by DISCOUNTING the Mac<br>NOT giving ""Maxtor 245 meg IDE drive for $320"" example.  By giving an<br>example you give the IMPLIED consent that for MAC info to be INCLUDED<br>in the SCSI discusion.}<br><br>Ok I will do this V E R Y  S L O W L Y so you can understand<br>REGUARDLESS of whether it is a Mac or a PC SCSI-1 and SCSI-2 are DIFFERENT<br>from each other as is asynchronous and synchronous SCSI-1.  All of these<br>have DIFFERENT SPEEDS and COSTS. Lumping them all together as 'SCSI' is<br>dumb and sloppy.  Take again the quote later on as an example of the problem <br>in the PC world {The spec list was so that you knew where the numbers were<br>coming from in the article.  It shows the article is CORRECT in it<br>staments about SCSI but not CONSITANT}.<br><br>With the way this thread has gone how do you tell :-).<br>Already GAVE them.  YOU keep deleting them! So here are the Specs<br>on everybody AGAIN {With some added info}:<br><br>SCSI-1 {SCSI-1 controler chip} asynchronous range: 0-3MB/s<br> synchronous range: 0-5MB/s  Both common to the PC world; difference is<br> mainly in software not hardware.<br><br>SCSI-1 {SCSI-2 controller chip; also called SCSI-2 (8-bit)}: 4-6MB/s with <br>10MB/s burst.  This is advertised as SCSI-2 in BYTE 4/93:159 FOR the<br> PC and AT THESE SPEEDS.{NOT the Mac, the PC.}<br><br>{I have not seen the following for EITHER the Mac or the PC}<br>SCSI-2 {16-bit/wide or fast mode}:  8-12MB/s with 20MB/s burst<br>SCSI-2 {32-bit/wide AND fast}:     15-20MB/s with 40MB/s burst<br><br>On the other interfaces let DXB132@psuvm.psu.edu speak:<br> asynchronous range: 0-5MB/s {infered from BYTE 4/93:159}<br> synchronous range: 0-8.3MB/s.<br><br>Note that I ALSO give the AVERAGE through put for SCSI-2 which holds true<br>a Mac OR IBM/PC clone with the correct hardware and software.<br>And since PC ADVERSIZEMENTS are using Theoretical performance figures WHY <br>CANNOT WE?<br><br><br>With PC articles like the following it is obvious that the problem is NOT with<br>SCSI but with the PEOPLE WHO REPORT IT! {Like YOU.}<br>Look at the inconsitant use of SCSI in the below quote: <br>(My comments in {})<br>""Although SCSI is twice as fast as ESDI,{This is asynchronous SCSI-1 with<br>a SCSI-1 chip} 20% faster than IDE..."" {this is BOTH asynchronous SCSI-1 with <br>a SCSI-2 chip AND 8-bit SCSI-2} PC Magazine April 27, 1993:29<br>The ARTICLE is confused, NOT SCSI.  The TERM is a mess from inconsitant use<br>NOT because the interface itself is a mess.<br><br>SCSI means ""The set of SCSI interfaces composed of SCSI-1 AND SCSI-2""<br>NOT 'SCSI-1' as some people want to use it.<br><br>To read CONSITANTLY the quote SHOULD read:<br>{asynchronous SCSI-1 with a SCSI-1 chip}<br>""Although asynchronous SCSI-1 is twice as fast as ESDI, one third the <br>speed of IDE...""<br>or {asynchronous SCSI-1 with a SCSI-2 chip or 8-bit SCSI-2}<br>""Although SCSI-1 with a SCSI-2 chip and 8-bit SCSI-2 are eight times as fast as<br>ESDI, 20% faster than IDE...""<br><br>NOTE the NONUSE of 'SCSI' by itself.  This eliminates ambaguity." It shows the article is CORRECT in it<br>staments about SCSI but not CONSITANT}.<br><br>With the way this thread has gone how do you tell :-).<br>Already GAVE them.  YOU keep deleting them! So here are the Specs<br>on everybody AGAIN {With some added info}:<br><br>SCSI-1 {SCSI-1 controler chip} asynchronous range: 0-3MB/s<br> synchronous range: 0-5MB/s  Both common to the PC world; difference is<br> mainly in software not hardware.<br><br>SCSI-1 {SCSI-2 controller chip; also called SCSI-2 (8-bit)}: 4-6MB/s with <br>10MB/s burst.  This is advertised as SCSI-2 in BYTE 4/93:159 FOR the<br> PC and AT THESE SPEEDS.{NOT the Mac, the PC.}<br><br>{I have not seen the following for EITHER the Mac or the PC}<br>SCSI-2 {16-bit/wide or fast mode}:  8-12MB/s with 20MB/s burst<br>SCSI-2 {32-bit/wide AND fast}:     15-20MB/s with 40MB/s burst<br><br>On the other interfaces let DXB132@psuvm.psu.edu speak:<br> asynchronous range: 0-5MB/s {infered from BYTE 4/93:159}<br> synchronous range: 0-8.3MB/s.<br><br>Note that I ALSO give the AVERAGE through put for SCSI-2 which holds true<br>a Mac OR IBM/PC clone with the correct hardware and software.<br>And since PC ADVERSIZEMENTS are using Theoretical performance figures WHY <br>CANNOT WE?<br><br><br>With PC articles like the following it is obvious that the problem is NOT with<br>SCSI but with the PEOPLE WHO REPORT IT! {Like YOU.}<br>Look at the inconsitant use of SCSI in the below quote: <br>(My comments in {})<br>""Although SCSI is twice as fast as ESDI,{This is asynchronous SCSI-1 with<br>a SCSI-1 chip} 20% faster than IDE..."" {this is BOTH asynchronous SCSI-1 with <br>a SCSI-2 chip AND 8-bit SCSI-2} PC Magazine April 27, 1993:29<br>The ARTICLE is confused, NOT SCSI.  The TERM is a mess from inconsitant use<br>NOT because the interface itself is a mess.<br><br>SCSI means ""The set of SCSI interfaces composed of SCSI-1 AND SCSI-2""<br>NOT 'SCSI-1' as some people want to use it.<br><br>To read CONSITANTLY the quote SHOULD read:<br>{asynchronous SCSI-1 with a SCSI-1 chip}<br>""Although asynchronous SCSI-1 is twice as fast as ESDI, one third the <br>speed of IDE...""<br>or {asynchronous SCSI-1 with a SCSI-2 chip or 8-bit SCSI-2}<br>""Although SCSI-1 with a SCSI-2 chip and 8-bit SCSI-2 are eight times as fast as<br>ESDI, 20% faster than IDE...""<br><br>NOTE the NONUSE of 'SCSI' by itself.  This eliminates ambaguity."

628	0	"  Zapp 1.1 from Inmark<br>  Zinc 3.5 from Zinc software<br>  C++/Views from Liant<br>  Win++ from Blaise<br><br>Some considerations I'm using:<br><br>  Being new to Windows programming (I'm from the UNIX/X world), the quality and<br>intuitivness of the abstraction that these class libraries provide is very <br>important.  However, since I'm not adverse to learning the internals of Windows<br>programming, the new programming methodology should be closely aligned with<br>the native one.  I don't believe arbitrary levels of abstraction, just for the<br>sake of changing the API, are valuable.<br><br>  Since we will be developing for the 32bit Windows NT system the<br>memory management issues and issues particular to the Windows 3.1 API are less<br>important. <br><br>  We will probably buy another C++ class library (something like Tools.h++ or Booch<br>components from Rational) to handle data structures and other miscellaneous stuff<br> (allocators etc...).  So those features are not that important for this toolkit to have.<br><br>The two that I have narrowed it down to are ZApp and Zinc, they seem to be the two<br>toolkits that have received the most attention from the media.  I was wondering if<br>anyone had any first-hand experience with any of these toolkits (especially ZApp and Zinc).<br><br>A couple of observations about these toolkits that seem particularly noteworthy are:<br><br>ZApp<br>----<br>  Seems to have the most extensive coverage of Windows functionality and<br>    also includes some other miscellaneous useful classes.<br>  Has new fancy 3D-style controls available, and support for custom controls.<br>  Has a Windows NT version (Essential)<br>  Redirectable graphics display/output architecture (useful for printing)<br>  Sizer class for automatically managing control layout after resize.<br>  Seems to be the newcomer, this could be an advantage in designing a better system.<br> <br>Zinc<br>----<br>  Has a platform independent resource strategy. I don't believe arbitrary levels of abstraction, just for the<br>sake of changing the API, are valuable.<br><br>  Since we will be developing for the 32bit Windows NT system the<br>memory management issues and issues particular to the Windows 3.1 API are less<br>important. <br><br>  We will probably buy another C++ class library (something like Tools.h++ or Booch<br>components from Rational) to handle data structures and other miscellaneous stuff<br> (allocators etc...). 632	0	"<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>All right.  Not saying I know any more than the average salesguy, I'll give <br>your question a shot. <br><br>The key issue that I bought my BJ-200 on was ink drying speed.  You really <br>have to try awful hard to get the BJ-200 ink to smear.  The HP DeskJets need <br>10-15 seconds to completely dry.  In both cases, however, do not get your <br>pages wet.  Unlike laser printers, the material on your pages is INK, not <br>toner.  But that should go without saying.<br><br>My PC has very little memory (only 2Meg RAM), so the BJ-200 takes a little <br>while to print ----- but every application I use takes a while to run.  Once <br>the computer is solely printing, it purs like a kitten and puts pages out <br>every 15-30 seconds, depending on how detailed your graphics are.  <br><br>The BJ-200 can do Windows soft fonts.  I'm assuming that the DeskJet can, or <br>HP wouldn't sell many......<br><br>Size is another factor.  The BJ-200 is much smaller, but the HP is built <br>like a tank.  I bet the BJ-200 would get damaged first.<br><br>Finally, the print quality.  I LOVE the BJ-200's resolution.  It looks like <br>a good laser quality print.  The HP's I've used.....they look like ink.  Not <br>as impressive.  "	"<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>All right.  Not saying I know any more than the average salesguy, I'll give <br>your question a shot. <br><br>The key issue that I bought my BJ-200 on was ink drying speed.  You really <br>have to try awful hard to get the BJ-200 ink to smear.  The HP DeskJets need <br>10-15 seconds to completely dry.  In both cases, however, do not get your <br>pages wet.  Unlike laser printers, the material on your pages is INK, not <br>toner.  But that should go without saying.<br><br>My PC has very little memory (only 2Meg RAM), so the BJ-200 takes a little <br>while to print ----- but every application I use takes a while to run. 633	1	"Your machine will run at whatever the bus is jumpered to/CMOS is set to<br>(usually wait states) regardless of what speed RAM is installed.  No<br>motherboard can sense the speed of the RAM installed, unless you call<br>failing as a sort of auto-sense.  This is how you can sometimes use<br>""slower"" RAM in a machine.  You either set the number of wait states to<br>accomodate the slow RAM (in which case, all memory will run at that<br>slower rate) or you reduce the wait states and take the chance that the<br>slower RAM will act like faster RAM and you won't crash.<br><br>Putting faster RAM in won't speed things up unless you tell the machine<br>it has faster RAM.  <br><br>Mixing fast and slow RAM will not help you if you have to keep the bus <br>slowed down to accomodate slow RAM.<br><br>JimL<br>--------------------------------------------------------------------<br><br>-- <br>Mailer address is buggy!  Reply to: jiml@strauss.FtCollinsCO.NCR.com"	"Your machine will run at whatever the bus is jumpered to/CMOS is set to<br>(usually wait states) regardless of what speed RAM is installed.  No<br>motherboard can sense the speed of the RAM installed, unless you call<br>failing as a sort of auto-sense.  This is how you can sometimes use<br>""slower"" RAM in a machine.  You either set the number of wait states to<br>accomodate the slow RAM (in which case, all memory will run at that<br>slower rate) or you reduce the wait states and take the chance that the<br>slower RAM will act like faster RAM and you won't crash.<br><br>Putting faster RAM in won't speed things up unless you tell the machine<br>it has faster RAM.  <br><br>Mixing fast and slow RAM will not help you if you have to keep the bus <br>slowed down to accomodate slow RAM.<br><br>JimL<br>--------------------------------------------------------------------<br><br>-- <br>Mailer address is buggy!  Reply to: jiml@strauss.FtCollinsCO.NCR.com"		
634	0	"tnx, steve"	"tnx, steve"		
635	0	"re: What to do after the high speed modem arrives.       Edition 01 Apr 93<br><br>This article applies only to Windows 3.0 and 3.1, and not to NT, OS/2<br>or DOS apps not running under Windows.<br><br>One of the unadvertised limitations of most current Windows PCs is that<br>their RS-232C (serial, COM) performance is seriously deficient.  Almost<br>everyone who purchases a high-speed modem (V.32bis, V.32, PEP or HST)<br>discovers the problem the first time they try to download a file or accept<br>an incoming FAX (at 9600+) after upgrading the modem.  Overrun and retry<br>errors abound, even when the only active application is the datacomm or<br>FAX program.  If the transfer completes at all, it may take even longer<br>than with the old 2400bps modem.<br><br><br>There are three reasons for the problem:<br><br>1. The Universal Asynchronous Receiver/Transmitters (UARTs) used in most<br>   PCs are primitive Ns8250 devices with single-byte FIFO buffers.  If the<br>   operating system/driver cannot read and flush each character at high<br>   interrupt rates, the next incoming character overwrites the FIFO and<br>   the previous one is lost.  DOS, being a fairly single-minded<br>   environment during datacomm, can usually keep up. Windows can't.<br><br>2. Windows has more operating system overhead than plain DOS, and<br>   interrupts often take longer to service.  Overruns are much more likely<br>   than under DOS.  As soon as you report to your PC/modem vendor that you<br>   are losing data, you may be advised that ""you need to upgrade to a<br>   16550"". More likely, since there seems to be a conspiracy of ignorance<br>   about this issue,  you'll get no useful advice at all.  Most of the<br>   store-front and mail-order sources I spoke with in attempting to solve<br>   my own problem had never heard the term ""16550"" and many didn't even<br>   know what a UART was.<br><br>3. Even your PC has Ns16550A UARTs (and PS/2's do), or if you can upgrade<br>   your mother/COM board or add a new COM board, you may STILL experience<br>   errors and overruns because the standard MicroSoft Windows COM drivers<br>   don't take full advantage of the 16550.  Windows 3.1 is improved in this<br>   regard over 3.0, but I still recommend a driver upgrade.  Applications<br>   like ProComm+/Win (which is what I use) cannot get around this problem<br>   by themselves.<br><br>If you have a modem CARD, you may not have a problem, as the modem part of<br>the card can be designed to be aware of the state of the UART, and avoid<br>overrunning it; however, I wouldn't want to bet that the card designers<br>were that clever, and will insist on a 16550 UART if I ever buy a modem<br>card.  Some modem cards don't even have conventional UARTs, but if they<br>are to work with standard Windows drivers, they need to simulate one.<br>Use MSD.EXE (below) to see what the modem card is, or is pretending to be.<br><br><br>The Hardware Situation.<br><br>The UARTs on most PC COM ports are based on National Semiconductor Ns8250<br>or Ns16450 chips (or megacells inside VLSI chips where you can't replace<br>them).  You can ID the UART type on your system by running the MicroSoft<br>diagnostic program \WINDOWS\MSD.EXE.  Be sure to run it in DOS *before*<br>bringing up Windows.   The Windows serial API may prevent MSD from<br>accurately identifying a 16550 if you run it from a Windows DOS prompt.<br><br>The Ns16550 UART has separate 16-byte transmit and receive FIFOs with<br>configurable trigger levels, and can run reliably at clock rates up to<br>460,800 bps, although with current modem technology, there's no point in<br>pushing your luck by going over 115,200 bps. The 16550 has shorted access<br>cycle times than the 16450 or 8250.  The 16550 also has DMA capability, but<br>it is not clear that any PC drivers ever use this.  For more technical info,<br>see National Semiconductor Application Note AN-491.<br><br>So, what UART component do you have?<br><br>Try to locate the UART on your mother board, multi-function I/O card, COM<br>board or ISA/MCA modem card.  If you can't find a socketed component with<br>the numbers ""8250"" or ""16450"", your COM ports are probably buried in VLSI,<br>and you won't be able to perform a chip replacement.  If you can DISABLE<br>your VLSI COM ports (as I chose to do), you can at least add an aftermarket<br>COM board.<br><br>If you have one or more socketed 8250 or 16450 chips, you can buy plug-in<br>Ns16550AFN or PC16C550CN (low power CMOS version) ICs from several<br>suppliers typically for $9 to $15 each.  The ""N"" chip is the normal 40-pin<br>dual-in-line package.  Other styles are available, but avoid any Ns16550<br>chips without the ""A"" (the 16C550C are presumably all OK).<br><br>Early Ns chips have bugs, although National will reportedly exchange those<br>of their own manufacture for free.  Clone chips are available from various<br>IC makers other than National.  The manual for the TurboCom drivers states<br>support for the following (apparently equivalent) chips:<br>National Semiconductor: 16550A, 16551, 16552<br>Chips&Technology:       82C607<br>Texas Instruments:      t16c550a<br>Silicon Systems:        73M550<br>VLSI                    16C550<br>TurboCom warns about the pre-""A"" Ns16550 and Western Digital 16C550,<br>says that problems have been reported with early IBM PS/2 55SX and 70<br>systems (IBM reportedly will upgrade them).<br><br>If you DON'T have socketed 8250/16450 chips, you'll need to buy an after-<br>market COM or multi-function board. If this is a modem card situation, you<br>may be hosed. To add a new COM or multi-function card, you'll need to<br>either disable the COM1/2 port(s) you are replacing, or re-assign them to<br>COM3/4 (although watch out for IRQ conflicts without TurboCom).<br><br>Although cheaper cards are available, in the interest of getting the<br>problem solved quickly I elected buy the Modular Circuit Technology<br>MCT-AIO+ card from:<br><br>JDR Microdevices<br>2233 Samaritan Drive<br>San Jose  CA  95124<br>(800) 538-5000 voice US<br>(408) 559-1200 voice other<br>(800) 538-5005 FAX US<br><br>The MCT-AIO+ (and the ""+"" is important) sells for $89.95.  It is an 8-bit<br>ISA card providing:<br><br>Port Type  Connector  Address and IRQ        Comments<br>COM        DB9M       COM 1,2,3 IRQ 2,3,4,5  Ns16550AFN in socket<br>COM        ribbon     COM 2,3,4 IRQ 2,3,4,5  Ns16550AFN in socket<br>Parallel   DB25F      LPT1,2,3  IRQ 5,7<br>Game       ribbon<br><br>The kit includes a ribbon cable and DB25F connector for the secondary COM<br>port, a ribbon cable/connector for the game port, two bulkhead plates for<br>the ribbon-based connectors and a 9F-to-25F adaptor cable.  Each port can<br>be individually disabled, and the COM ports have TX, RX, RTS, CTS, DTR,<br>DCD, and DSR jumpers.<br><br>JDR also sells a Super-I/O m-f card that also has IDE.<br><br>I have heard from several people about less expensive m-f I/O cards<br>with 16550s:<br><br>TSD Systems<br>(407) 331-9130<br>$19.95 for the card, plus $9.95 per 16550.<br><br>Greenfield Trading and Distributors<br>(518) 271-2473 (voice), (518) 271-7811(FAX).<br>Their card is $33 w/one 16550, $45 w/2, and they sell 16550AFNs for $13.<br><br>R&S DATA SYSTEMS, INC.<br>820 East Highway 434<br>Longwood, FL  32750<br>PHONE: (407) 331-1424<br>FAX: (407) 331-8606<br>2COM/LPT/Game card w/2 16550s for $39<br><br>I have no personal experience with any of the firms except JDR.<br><br>Meanwhile, back at the MCT card from JDR... I only needed two serial ports,<br>and am running out of IRQs on my PC, so I disabled my built-in VLSI-based<br>8250 ports. However, with the TurboCom driver (below), I could have set<br>the internals as COM3 and 4, using IRQ sharing.<br><br><br>The Software Situation<br><br>Simply upgrading to 16550 UARTs will not completely solve common overrun<br>problems.  The standard MS serial drivers don't take full advantage of the<br>16550. The Windows 3.0 drivers are even less capable, and the Windows 3.1<br>drivers have the following limitations:<br> - They enable only the receive FIFO, and only at rates above 2400 bps.<br> - They never enable the transmit FIFO, which  results in an interrupt<br>   rate of 10x during uploads.<br> - They set the trigger level at 14 bytes (too high - it's easy for 2<br>   more bytes to arrive before the driver can read the FIFO).<br> - The Ports menu of the Control Panel only allows speeds up to 19200.<br>   With a V.32bis modem,  sparse data and text can easily compress 3:1<br>   or more, suggesting that a host DTE connect rate of 57,600 bps would<br>   be effective.<br> - The API won't accept rates above ""CBR_128000"".<br> - The API won't let DOS programs know there is a 16550 there, and even<br>   if it did, DOS programs that aren't 16550-aware get little benefit<br>   from a 16550 port with the standard drivers.<br> - They don't allow IRQ sharing for COM3,4.<br> - The BIOS doesn't initialize COM3,4 properly in many systems.<br> - Windows provides no workaround for apps that don't provide port<br>   speed options above 19200 bps.<br><br>These problems are reportedly NOT solved in Windows NT or DOS 6.0, and may<br>or may not be addressed in any Windows releases after 3.1 (but before 4.0).<br>Rumors suggest they ""may"" be solved in Windows ""4.0"".<br><br>You can get replacement drivers that solve all of those problems by buying<br>a copy of ""TurboCom"", current version 1.2, from:<br><br>Bio-Engineering Research<br>Pacific CommWare Division<br>180 Beacon Hill Lane<br>Ashland  OR   97520-9701<br>(503) 482-2744 voice<br>(503) 482-2627 FAX<br>(503) 482-2633 BBS<br>MCImail:    344-5374<br>CompuServe: 71521,760<br><br>Price was around $50 as I recall.  Bio-Eng is not set up to accept credit<br>cards, so I had to send a check.  Egghead and 1-800-Software list TurboCom<br>but as far as I know, they don't stock it.  Bio is not a software company<br>per se.  They apparently needed reliable hi-speed serial connections for<br>an in-house instrument application, wrote their own driver, discovered a<br>market for it, revised it to be a general purpose COM driver suite. They<br>recently upgraded it for Windows 3.1.  It is run-time licensed.<br><br>I now have my host (DTE) connect rate set to 57,600 bps most of  my<br>datacomm apps, and I am having ZERO problems with downloads. I routinely<br>see transfer rates that exceed 2,000 bps. I am also using 115,200 bps<br>when linking an HP95LX to my PC, with lossless bi-directional I/O.<br>Uploads to various remote systems are another matter, because many hosts<br>are still using antique UARTs and drivers.<br><br>Note that 19200 is still the highest rate that the Windows 3.1 Port menu<br>in Control Panel will allow in configuring a COM port.  TurboCom gets<br>around this by allowing you to specify, on each port, a factor that will<br>set the real UART rate to a multiple of the rate passed through the<br>Windows APIs and dialog boxes.<br><br>I also have CTS/RTS hardware flow control enabled, and I suggest that you<br>do the same.  Even if you only ever transfer 7-bit ASCII data, Xon/XOff is<br>not a sufficiently reliable method of flow control.  The informal (DEC)<br>standard for Xon/Xoff hysteresis is that the sender may transmit another<br>16 (yes, sixteen) bytes after receipt of the Xoff from the receiving<br>system or device.  The 16 byte FIFO in the 16550 is clearly not big enough<br>to let us rely exclusively on Xon/Xoff.  A well-respected datacomm<br>engineer has informed me that the 16550's can't really do CTS/RTS all<br>by itself in the DOS/Windows environment, so using data rates above<br>115,200 may still be risky.<br><br>Even with hardware flow control, a 16550 with TurboCom can still<br>experience overruns in very busy systems, with lots of apps running and<br>serious swapping in progress. If this is your situation, you may need to<br>buy a co-processed COM board, but this will cost you more than a<br>16550/TurboCom upgrade.  A review of two such boards, and a review of<br>TurboCom, can be found in the Feb'93 issue of ""Windows Sources"" magazine.<br>I suggest trying a 16550/TurboCom upgrade first, and experiment with<br>process priorities and time slices if you are a ""power user"" whose<br>thrashing system still runs into comm problems.<br><br><br>Closing Soapbox Comments<br><br>The state of RS-232C serial datacomm support is an embarrassment across<br>the computer industry.  Because it is the oldest standard I/O interface,<br>the job of designing hardware and writing software often seems to be<br>assigned to the least senior or lowest ranked engineers at computer<br>companies.  The design of the average serial port is at least ten years<br>behind the state of the art. In my last job, with a major workstation<br>vendor, I lobbied for improved serial ports when they were doing the<br>initial designs of a new system.  That family of machines was<br>subsequently introduced with 16550 ports.  However, this is the<br>exception.  Few computer companies seem to have any champions for decent<br>I/O.<br><br>You may as well learn what you can about serial I/O, because this<br>situation shows no sign of improving soon.  When V.FAST arrives, I expect<br>cries of outrage from Windows users world-wide whose 8250 PCs ""sort of""<br>work today with V.32, but will fail miserably with V.FAST.  Without a<br>hardware-buffered UART (like the 16550) and without software drivers that<br>use that UART to best advantage, a V.FAST modem will be a waste of money.<br><br>Regards,                                          1001-A East Harmony Road<br>Bob Niland                                        Suite 503<br>Internet:  rjn@csn.org                            Fort Collins CO 80525<br>CompuServe: 71044,2124                            (303) 223-5209<br><br>                     Copyright 1993 Robert J. Niland<br>                           All Rights Reserved<br><br>  Permission is granted for automatic redistribution of this article, via<br>  electronic, magnetic and optical media, in an unedited form, through any<br>  Usenet newsgroup where the article is posted by the author.  Permission<br>  is granted for each CompuServe and Usenet reader subscriber and each<br>  person who received this article from Compuserve, an ftp site authorized<br>  by the author or via electronic mail from the author, to retain one<br>  electronic copy and to make hardcopy reproductions of this edition of<br>  this article for personal non-commercial use, provided that no material<br>  changes are made to the article or this copyright statement. All other<br>  copying, storage, reproduction or redistribution of this article, in<br>  any form, is prohibited without the express written consent of the<br>  author,  Robert J. Niland."	"re: What to do after the high speed modem arrives.       Edition 01 Apr 93<br><br>This article applies only to Windows 3.0 and 3.1, and not to NT, OS/2<br>or DOS apps not running under Windows.<br><br>One of the unadvertised limitations of most current Windows PCs is that<br>their RS-232C (serial, COM) performance is seriously deficient.  Almost<br>everyone who purchases a high-speed modem (V.32bis, V.32, PEP or HST)<br>discovers the problem the first time they try to download a file or accept<br>an incoming FAX (at 9600+) after upgrading the modem.  Overrun and retry<br>errors abound, even when the only active application is the datacomm or<br>FAX program.  If the transfer completes at all, it may take even longer<br>than with the old 2400bps modem.<br><br><br>There are three reasons for the problem:<br><br>1. The Universal Asynchronous Receiver/Transmitters (UARTs) used in most<br>   PCs are primitive Ns8250 devices with single-byte FIFO buffers.  If the<br>   operating system/driver cannot read and flush each character at high<br>   interrupt rates, the next incoming character overwrites the FIFO and<br>   the previous one is lost.  DOS, being a fairly single-minded<br>   environment during datacomm, can usually keep up. Windows can't.<br><br>2. Windows has more operating system overhead than plain DOS, and<br>   interrupts often take longer to service.  Overruns are much more likely<br>   than under DOS.  As soon as you report to your PC/modem vendor that you<br>   are losing data, you may be advised that ""you need to upgrade to a<br>   16550"". More likely, since there seems to be a conspiracy of ignorance<br>   about this issue,  you'll get no useful advice at all.  Most of the<br>   store-front and mail-order sources I spoke with in attempting to solve<br>   my own problem had never heard the term ""16550"" and many didn't even<br>   know what a UART was.<br><br>3. Even your PC has Ns16550A UARTs (and PS/2's do), or if you can upgrade<br>   your mother/COM board or add a new COM board, you may STILL experience<br>   errors and overruns because the standard MicroSoft Windows COM drivers<br>   don't take full advantage of the 16550.  Windows 3.1 is improved in this<br>   regard over 3.0, but I still recommend a driver upgrade.  Applications<br>   like ProComm+/Win (which is what I use) cannot get around this problem<br>   by themselves.<br><br>If you have a modem CARD, you may not have a problem, as the modem part of<br>the card can be designed to be aware of the state of the UART, and avoid<br>overrunning it; however, I wouldn't want to bet that the card designers<br>were that clever, and will insist on a 16550 UART if I ever buy a modem<br>card.  Some modem cards don't even have conventional UARTs, but if they<br>are to work with standard Windows drivers, they need to simulate one.<br>Use MSD.EXE (below) to see what the modem card is, or is pretending to be.<br><br><br>The Hardware Situation.<br><br>The UARTs on most PC COM ports are based on National Semiconductor Ns8250<br>or Ns16450 chips (or megacells inside VLSI chips where you can't replace<br>them).  You can ID the UART type on your system by running the MicroSoft<br>diagnostic program \WINDOWS\MSD.EXE.  Be sure to run it in DOS *before*<br>bringing up Windows.   The Windows serial API may prevent MSD from<br>accurately identifying a 16550 if you run it from a Windows DOS prompt.<br><br>The Ns16550 UART has separate 16-byte transmit and receive FIFOs with<br>configurable trigger levels, and can run reliably at clock rates up to<br>460,800 bps, although with current modem technology, there's no point in<br>pushing your luck by going over 115,200 bps. The 16550 has shorted access<br>cycle times than the 16450 or 8250.  The 16550 also has DMA capability, but<br>it is not clear that any PC drivers ever use this.  For more technical info,<br>see National Semiconductor Application Note AN-491.<br><br>So, what UART component do you have?<br><br>Try to locate the UART on your mother board, multi-function I/O card, COM<br>board or ISA/MCA modem card.  If you can't find a socketed component with<br>the numbers ""8250"" or ""16450"", your COM ports are probably buried in VLSI,<br>and you won't be able to perform a chip replacement.  If you can DISABLE<br>your VLSI COM ports (as I chose to do), you can at least add an aftermarket<br>COM board.<br><br>If you have one or more socketed 8250 or 16450 chips, you can buy plug-in<br>Ns16550AFN or PC16C550CN (low power CMOS version) ICs from several<br>suppliers typically for $9 to $15 each.  The ""N"" chip is the normal 40-pin<br>dual-in-line package.  Other styles are available, but avoid any Ns16550<br>chips without the ""A"" (the 16C550C are presumably all OK).<br><br>Early Ns chips have bugs, although National will reportedly exchange those<br>of their own manufacture for free.  Clone chips are available from various<br>IC makers other than National.  The manual for the TurboCom drivers states<br>support for the following (apparently equivalent) chips:<br>National Semiconductor: 16550A, 16551, 16552<br>Chips&Technology:       82C607<br>Texas Instruments:      t16c550a<br>Silicon Systems:        73M550<br>VLSI                    16C550<br>TurboCom warns about the pre-""A"" Ns16550 and Western Digital 16C550,<br>says that problems have been reported with early IBM PS/2 55SX and 70<br>systems (IBM reportedly will upgrade them).<br><br>If you DON'T have socketed 8250/16450 chips, you'll need to buy an after-<br>market COM or multi-function board. If this is a modem card situation, you<br>may be hosed. To add a new COM or multi-function card, you'll need to<br>either disable the COM1/2 port(s) you are replacing, or re-assign them to<br>COM3/4 (although watch out for IRQ conflicts without TurboCom).<br><br>Although cheaper cards are available, in the interest of getting the<br>problem solved quickly I elected buy the Modular Circuit Technology<br>MCT-AIO+ card from:<br><br>JDR Microdevices<br>2233 Samaritan Drive<br>San Jose  CA  95124<br>(800) 538-5000 voice US<br>(408) 559-1200 voice other<br>(800) 538-5005 FAX US<br><br>The MCT-AIO+ (and the ""+"" is important) sells for $89.95.  It is an 8-bit<br>ISA card providing:<br><br>Port Type  Connector  Address and IRQ        Comments<br>COM        DB9M       COM 1,2,3 IRQ 2,3,4,5  Ns16550AFN in socket<br>COM        ribbon     COM 2,3,4 IRQ 2,3,4,5  Ns16550AFN in socket<br>Parallel   DB25F      LPT1,2,3  IRQ 5,7<br>Game       ribbon<br><br>The kit includes a ribbon cable and DB25F connector for the secondary COM<br>port, a ribbon cable/connector for the game port, two bulkhead plates for<br>the ribbon-based connectors and a 9F-to-25F adaptor cable.  Each port can<br>be individually disabled, and the COM ports have TX, RX, RTS, CTS, DTR,<br>DCD, and DSR jumpers.<br><br>JDR also sells a Super-I/O m-f card that also has IDE.<br><br>I have heard from several people about less expensive m-f I/O cards<br>with 16550s:<br><br>TSD Systems<br>(407) 331-9130<br>$19.95 for the card, plus $9.95 per 16550.<br><br>Greenfield Trading and Distributors<br>(518) 271-2473 (voice), (518) 271-7811(FAX).<br>Their card is $33 w/one 16550, $45 w/2, and they sell 16550AFNs for $13.<br><br>R&S DATA SYSTEMS, INC.<br>820 East Highway 434<br>Longwood, FL  32750<br>PHONE: (407) 331-1424<br>FAX: (407) 331-8606<br>2COM/LPT/Game card w/2 16550s for $39<br><br>I have no personal experience with any of the firms except JDR.<br><br>Meanwhile, back at the MCT card from JDR... I only needed two serial ports,<br>and am running out of IRQs on my PC, so I disabled my built-in VLSI-based<br>8250 ports. However, with the TurboCom driver (below), I could have set<br>the internals as COM3 and 4, using IRQ sharing.<br><br><br>The Software Situation<br><br>Simply upgrading to 16550 UARTs will not completely solve common overrun<br>problems.  The standard MS serial drivers don't take full advantage of the<br>16550. The Windows 3.0 drivers are even less capable, and the Windows 3.1<br>drivers have the following limitations:<br> - They enable only the receive FIFO, and only at rates above 2400 bps.<br> - They never enable the transmit FIFO, which  results in an interrupt<br>   rate of 10x during uploads.<br> - They set the trigger level at 14 bytes (too high - it's easy for 2<br>   more bytes to arrive before the driver can read the FIFO).<br> - The Ports menu of the Control Panel only allows speeds up to 19200.<br>   With a V.32bis modem,  sparse data and text can easily compress 3:1<br>   or more, suggesting that a host DTE connect rate of 57,600 bps would<br>   be effective.<br> - The API won't accept rates above ""CBR_128000"".<br> - The API won't let DOS programs know there is a 16550 there, and even<br>   if it did, DOS programs that aren't 16550-aware get little benefit<br>   from a 16550 port with the standard drivers.<br> - They don't allow IRQ sharing for COM3,4.<br> - The BIOS doesn't initialize COM3,4 properly in many systems.<br> - Windows provides no workaround for apps that don't provide port<br>   speed options above 19200 bps.<br><br>These problems are reportedly NOT solved in Windows NT or DOS 6.0, and may<br>or may not be addressed in any Windows releases after 3.1 (but before 4.0).<br>Rumors suggest they ""may"" be solved in Windows ""4.0"".<br><br>You can get replacement drivers that solve all of those problems by buying<br>a copy of ""TurboCom"", current version 1.2, from:<br><br>Bio-Engineering Research<br>Pacific CommWare Division<br>180 Beacon Hill Lane<br>Ashland  OR   97520-9701<br>(503) 482-2744 voice<br>(503) 482-2627 FAX<br>(503) 482-2633 BBS<br>MCImail:    344-5374<br>CompuServe: 71521,760<br><br>Price was around $50 as I recall.  Bio-Eng is not set up to accept credit<br>cards, so I had to send a check.  Egghead and 1-800-Software list TurboCom<br>but as far as I know, they don't stock it.  Bio is not a software company<br>per se.  They apparently needed reliable hi-speed serial connections for<br>an in-house instrument application, wrote their own driver, discovered a<br>market for it, revised it to be a general purpose COM driver suite. They<br>recently upgraded it for Windows 3.1.  It is run-time licensed.<br><br>I now have my host (DTE) connect rate set to 57,600 bps most of  my<br>datacomm apps, and I am having ZERO problems with downloads. I routinely<br>see transfer rates that exceed 2,000 bps. I am also using 115,200 bps<br>when linking an HP95LX to my PC, with lossless bi-directional I/O.<br>Uploads to various remote systems are another matter, because many hosts<br>are still using antique UARTs and drivers.<br><br>Note that 19200 is still the highest rate that the Windows 3.1 Port menu<br>in Control Panel will allow in configuring a COM port.  TurboCom gets<br>around this by allowing you to specify, on each port, a factor that will<br>set the real UART rate to a multiple of the rate passed through the<br>Windows APIs and dialog boxes.<br><br>I also have CTS/RTS hardware flow control enabled, and I suggest that you<br>do the same.  Even if you only ever transfer 7-bit ASCII data, Xon/XOff is<br>not a sufficiently reliable method of flow control.  The informal (DEC)<br>standard for Xon/Xoff hysteresis is that the sender may transmit another<br>16 (yes, sixteen) bytes after receipt of the Xoff from the receiving<br>system or device.  The 16 byte FIFO in the 16550 is clearly not big enough<br>to let us rely exclusively on Xon/Xoff.  A well-respected datacomm<br>engineer has informed me that the 16550's can't really do CTS/RTS all<br>by itself in the DOS/Windows environment, so using data rates above<br>115,200 may still be risky.<br><br>Even with hardware flow control, a 16550 with TurboCom can still<br>experience overruns in very busy systems, with lots of apps running and<br>serious swapping in progress. If this is your situation, you may need to<br>buy a co-processed COM board, but this will cost you more than a<br>16550/TurboCom upgrade.  A review of two such boards, and a review of<br>TurboCom, can be found in the Feb'93 issue of ""Windows Sources"" magazine.<br>I suggest trying a 16550/TurboCom upgrade first, and experiment with<br>process priorities and time slices if you are a ""power user"" whose<br>thrashing system still runs into comm problems.<br><br><br>Closing Soapbox Comments<br><br>The state of RS-232C serial datacomm support is an embarrassment across<br>the computer industry.  Because it is the oldest standard I/O interface,<br>the job of designing hardware and writing software often seems to be<br>assigned to the least senior or lowest ranked engineers at computer<br>companies.  The design of the average serial port is at least ten years<br>behind the state of the art. In my last job, with a major workstation<br>vendor, I lobbied for improved serial ports when they were doing the<br>initial designs of a new system.  That family of machines was<br>subsequently introduced with 16550 ports.  However, this is the<br>exception.  Few computer companies seem to have any champions for decent<br>I/O.<br><br>You may as well learn what you can about serial I/O, because this<br>situation shows no sign of improving soon.  When V.FAST arrives, I expect<br>cries of outrage from Windows users world-wide whose 8250 PCs ""sort of""<br>work today with V.32, but will fail miserably with V.FAST.  Without a<br>hardware-buffered UART (like the 16550) and without software drivers that<br>use that UART to best advantage, a V.FAST modem will be a waste of money.<br><br>Regards,                                          1001-A East Harmony Road<br>Bob Niland                                        Suite 503<br>Internet:  rjn@csn.org                            Fort Collins CO 80525<br>CompuServe: 71044,2124                            (303) 223-5209<br><br>                     Copyright 1993 Robert J. Niland<br>                           All Rights Reserved<br><br>  Permission is granted for automatic redistribution of this article, via<br>  electronic, magnetic and optical media, in an unedited form, through any<br>  Usenet newsgroup where the article is posted by the author. All other<br>  copying, storage, reproduction or redistribution of this article, in<br>  any form, is prohibited without the express written consent of the<br>  author,  Robert J. Niland."		
636	1	I recently bought a Leading Edge 80386DX-33 <mini tower case> and everything<br>works fine. Leading Edge seems to be a decent brand and what-not. I would<br>tend to say that it is a decent deal. The only things you might want to be<br>wary about is that my L.E. computer has a back-plane mounted motherboard.<br>Ie: The motherboard itself is a card that can be plugged in to a backplane.<br>Some people don't like these configurations. The second thing is that<br>whoever set up my computer at the factory didn't really know what they were<br>doing. The installed windows video driver didn't even take advantage of the<br>SVGA card/Monitor. Look forward to configuring the system optimally<br>yourself.<br>	I recently bought a Leading Edge 80386DX-33 <mini tower case> and everything<br>works fine. Leading Edge seems to be a decent brand and what-not. I would<br>tend to say that it is a decent deal. The only things you might want to be<br>wary about is that my L.E. computer has a back-plane mounted motherboard.<br>Ie: The motherboard itself is a card that can be plugged in to a backplane.<br>Some people don't like these configurations. The second thing is that<br>whoever set up my computer at the factory didn't really know what they were<br>doing. The installed windows video driver didn't even take advantage of the<br>SVGA card/Monitor. Look forward to configuring the system optimally<br>yourself.<br>		
637	1	"<br>mouse.com could be started from the commandline after the booting and it<br>could - perhaps - be unloaded, if no other driver is loaded after it.<br>The working of both drivers is totally the same.<br><br>When I ran dos, I preferred loading most of the drivers in autoexec.bat,<br>because some programs won't run with some drivers and I could choose the<br>ones I needed during startup. But with DRDOS6, this advantage is gone,<br>because DRDOS lets you choose in config.sys which drivers should be loaded.<br><br>Michael"	"<br>mouse.com could be started from the commandline after the booting and it<br>could - perhaps - be unloaded, if no other driver is loaded after it.<br>The working of both drivers is totally the same.<br><br>When I ran dos, I preferred loading most of the drivers in autoexec.bat,<br>because some programs won't run with some drivers and I could choose the<br>ones I needed during startup. But with DRDOS6, this advantage is gone,<br>because DRDOS lets you choose in config.sys which drivers should be loaded.<br><br>Michael"		
638	1	Jude M. Greer<br>jmgree01@starbase.spd.louisville.edu	Jude M. Greer<br>jmgree01@starbase.spd.louisville.edu		
639	0	"If if remove (or disable) EMM386, windows is ok.  If EMM386<br>is active, with NOEMS, windows hangs.  If I use AUTO with<br>EMM386, the system hangs on bootup.<br><br>Dave.<br><br><br>-- <br>-------------------------------------------------------------------<br>David Clarke   ...the well is deep...wish me well...<br>ac151@Freenet.carleton.ca  David_Clarke@mtsa.ubc.ca  clarkec@sfu.ca"	"If if remove (or disable) EMM386, windows is ok.  If EMM386<br>is active, with NOEMS, windows hangs. 640	1	"I'm new to these groups and so please forgive me if my questions are frequently<br>asked, but I don't know the answer :) I've been recently having some problems<br>with my 386 computer with a Seagate 40 meg hard drive. 648	1	"I have a Maxtor 212MB on an ISA IDE controller, although my machine is<br>DX2/66 VLB. I has the save transfer rate of 0.647 MB/s regardless of<br>the variations of the ISA bus speed. 649	1	"The speaker connector should have two wires going to the speaker. <br>A speaker being a coil, it's bidirectional and makes no difference<br>which way you attach.<br><br>Turbo switch.   There are three wires to control how you want turbo<br>to become active- with the switch pushed in or the switch out.    I think<br>the middle wire is common.   Use an ohm meter to figure out which wire<br>connects with the common wire when the switch is pushed in, and which two<br>wires are connected when the switch is out.   Place the appropriate<br>two wires on the turbo berg connector of the motherboard.<br><br>LED's:   (Turbo and HD)  LED's are uni directional.  Depending which<br>way the wires are attached the LED will not light.  On my AMI motherboard,<br>if the turbo switch wires are not attached to the berg connector on the<br>board, the board will power up in default in Turbo mode.   If your motherboard<br>is like that... just attace the LED wires to the board.  If the LED doesn't<br>light, power off, reverse the connectors and try again.   It should work.<br><br>If it does, then attach the turbo switch to the board.<br><br>Hope this helps."	"The speaker connector should have two wires going to the speaker. <br>A speaker being a coil, it's bidirectional and makes no difference<br>which way you attach.<br><br>Turbo switch.   There are three wires to control how you want turbo<br>to become active- with the switch pushed in or the switch out.    I think<br>the middle wire is common.   Use an ohm meter to figure out which wire<br>connects with the common wire when the switch is pushed in, and which two<br>wires are connected when the switch is out.   Place the appropriate<br>two wires on the turbo berg connector of the motherboard.<br><br>LED's:   (Turbo and HD)  LED's are uni directional.  Depending which<br>way the wires are attached the LED will not light.  On my AMI motherboard,<br>if the turbo switch wires are not attached to the berg connector on the<br>board, the board will power up in default in Turbo mode.   If your motherboard<br>is like that... just attace the LED wires to the board.  If the LED doesn't<br>light, power off, reverse the connectors and try again.   It should work.<br><br>If it does, then attach the turbo switch to the board.<br><br>Hope this helps."

Silly me, believing<br> that the ""250"" logo on the front meant actual carrying capacity.<br> The people who do this sort of thing for a living call it <br> ""marketing.""  Lawyers who prosecute it call it ""fraud.""<br> Perhaps we can have a bunch of other duped buyers march on <br> their corporate headquarters.<br><br><br> This is a bit long.  My system takes about 45 minutes to do <br> the same thing.  Usually 4.5 hours, particularly if the tape <br> is grinding away the whole time means that your block size for <br> the write is too small.  Is there any way to change the block <br> size or write buffer size so it's bigger?<br><br><br> This is because the files are opened by DOS.  The files in the <br> TAPE directory are likely the executable file or the configuration<br> file for the tape system.  I would recommend running the backup<br> from DOS so it will make a complete backup of the TAPE directory.<br><br><br> The 250mb cartridges won't do you any good since the drive<br> won't write 250mb of physical data on the tape.  <br><br>"	" I have a similar configuration: Colorado 250mb on 66 DX/2 tower.<br><br><br><br> You got suckered in the same way I did. 652	1	"There is a simple answer.  If my memory serves me the scsi bios will only<br>work as the first or second drive.  Any ""built-in"" drives e.g. IDE are<br>installed first and then when the scsi bios runs it will try to install<br>as the next drive.  But if there are already two drives, then no can do.<br><br>The solution is simple: use the aspi4dos device driver and disable the<br>scsi bios (as it is useless in your case).  It works like a champ!  I<br>have seen a similar situation before.<br><br>Good Luck"	"There is a simple answer.  If my memory serves me the scsi bios will only<br>work as the first or second drive.  Any ""built-in"" drives e.g. IDE are<br>installed first and then when the scsi bios runs it will try to install<br>as the next drive.  But if there are already two drives, then no can do.<br><br>The solution is simple: use the aspi4dos device driver and disable the<br>scsi bios (as it is useless in your case).  It works like a champ!  I<br>have seen a similar situation before.<br><br>Good Luck"

662	1	"I read a recent article in Personal Computer World mainly about the new<br>digit audion formats (DCC and MD) but at the end talked about how nice<br>it would be to use these for data storage with a brief calculation of<br>how much data you could store. The author had been talking to someone<br>from Sony about these formats and mentioned this to get the reply ""MD<br>is a purely audio format, we wouldn't use it for data"", then when<br>pressed for info about MO the Sony man basically admitted that it was<br>no more than a slight adaptabtion on MD!<br><br>What I think the original poster was wanting was MO drives at MD audio<br>player prices. I'd assume that the problem here is that an MD system<br>can have higher tolerances than an MO system as the ear doesn't pick up<br>the occasional bit error as well as an archiving program!<br><br>--"

688	1	"B(>my concern is that without a complete enclosure to direct the<br>B(>cooling flow of air from the fan, ""hot spots"" may develop on my<br>B(>motherboard or elsewhere.<br><br>If you have an adequate supply of air moving over the system (most<br>offices or homes have positive ventilation) you can generally run a<br>system without the cover for extended periods without a problem. (I'm<br>talking about completely removing the cover - not just leaving the slots<br>uncovered.) HOWEVER, the biggest reason you have a cover to begin with<br>is RF sheilding. Operating a system without the full cover may create<br>problems with other equipment such as your neighbor's TV or Ham radio<br>station - very much a no-no in the eyes of the law.<br><br><br> * SLMR 2.1a * Remember - They're only tools, not a way of life!<br>"	"B(>my concern is that without a complete enclosure to direct the<br>B(>cooling flow of air from the fan, ""hot spots"" may develop on my<br>B(>motherboard or elsewhere.<br><br>If you have an adequate supply of air moving over the system (most<br>offices or homes have positive ventilation) you can generally run a<br>system without the cover for extended periods without a problem. 709	1	"   Upon unboxing it I found everything to be in perfect order. All the <br>peripherals I ordered were properly installed (Jumbo-250 & CD-ROM). I<br>was very impressed with the quantity and quality of the Gateway <br>documentation. All software came with the original disks and manuals.<br>The Gateway manual itself is in a nice 3-ring binder. The ATI GUP came<br>with build59 drivers. All other software I specified (Microsoft Office)<br>was properly installed. The machine came right up out of the box and <br>has been performing flawlessly. It's been on all weekend and it hardly<br>even reaches room temperature. I think the big roomy tower case has a <br>lot to do with it. <br><br>   It's up and running DOS 6.0 with no problems. I've also read about<br>some people having problems with high speed serial communications. <br>I used the DOS 6.0 InterLink program which lets me link to my old<br>computer via a serial port at 115.2K baud. It then ""maps"" the other<br>machines two hard disks as my disks F & G. You can ""cd"" to these<br>drives and either run programs or copy files. It's almost like a<br>peer-peer lan except you can also *run* programs on the other machine.<br>It's not a two way street. The other machine is the server and this<br>machine is the client. So thats where it seems to differ from the <br>peer to peer stuff. For a bundled DOS utility its very impressive. <br><br>  My Jumbo-250 took about 11 minutes to back up 117MB of data. I also<br>by-passed any potential Gateway monitor problems by taking the $430<br>credit and applying it towards a NEC 4FG. I love this monitor!<br><br>  So, I'm glad there is some good news Gateway stories and I'm glad it<br>was me. (Now if it just KEEPS working). :-)<br><br><br>     John<br><br>"	"   Upon unboxing it I found everything to be in perfect order. 712	0	"   -----Or, if you need to use a service bureau and they're only set up to use<br>   Type 1 fonts. From what I've heard (pure hearsay) the results of outputting<br>   TT fonts as Type 1 is _not_ as good as using high-quality Type 1 fonts in<br>   the first place.<br><br>Unless you `print' to file with the correct resolution set for the<br>final output device (image setter).  A problem with TT fonts in Windows<br>is that they do get converted to T1 format OK, and the hinting is even used<br>while this is done, but the resulting T1 fonts are NOT hinted.  The result<br>is that they WILL work fine on a device of the resolution assumed by the<br>printer driver when the PS file is generated, but they will not look<br>good when printed at a different resolution.  "	"   -----Or, if you need to use a service bureau and they're only set up to use<br>   Type 1 fonts. From what I've heard (pure hearsay) the results of outputting<br>   TT fonts as Type 1 is _not_ as good as using high-quality Type 1 fonts in<br>   the first place.<br><br>Unless you `print' to file with the correct resolution set for the<br>final output device (image setter).  A problem with TT fonts in Windows<br>is that they do get converted to T1 format OK, and the hinting is even used<br>while this is done, but the resulting T1 fonts are NOT hinted.  The result<br>is that they WILL work fine on a device of the resolution assumed by the<br>printer driver when the PS file is generated, but they will not look<br>good when printed at a different resolution.  "

715	0	"<br>No, we're not.  But we're also not going to promote pandering to<br>corporate paranoia when the real issue is convenience.  I don't *like*<br>dealing with floppies.  Personally, I have no use for changing the<br>registration info, but I see it as a valid need, and one that ought to<br>be solved using a quick little utility rather than a half-hour<br>reinstall that's just about guaranteed to mess up your settings in one<br>way or another.<br><br>So, while I'm not going to put much time into it myself, here's the<br>procedure for getting on your way to finding the encoded information:<br><br>1.  Copy all your Windows disks into the directory from which you want<br>to install it.  I've been using c:\WINSTALL myself.<br><br>2.  From there, copy that directory to something like c:\WINORIG.<br><br>3.  Install from c:\winstall.<br><br>4.  comp the two directories to determine changes.  <br>    i.e., comp *.* \winorig\*.* >\report.txt<br><br>5.  Look in the report file for the file(s) that change.  Assuming<br>they didn't cover themselves covering their own tracks, at least one<br>file should have a difference noted at a particular offset.  Locate<br>said offset in the original directory and see what's there using a hex<br>editor, and do the same for the modified one.<br><br>6.  You're on your own as far as breaking the code goes; I don't<br>really do cryptography.  It's probably just an xor key or something; I<br>think MS is more concerned with Joe Schmoe at the office personalizing<br>his copy than with ""real pirates"" who will probably just disassemble<br>the damned thing anyway.  This technique should work with just about<br>any obnoxious corporate product that tries to write to the original<br>floppies when you install; in some extreme cases you may not be able<br>to back the floppies up to hard disk, and will be stuck doing a<br>compare on floppies (Lotus stuff is probably like that).<br><br>As I noted before, if you can afford the space on the hard disk, and<br>don't do much in the way of customization, reinstalling from one<br>directory to another may be less arduous.  Doing some of the stuff<br>I've mentioned here may well void your license with Microsoft, as if<br>they'd ever find out.  If you aren't careful with the disk editor, you<br>could also mung something important... duh.  I guess that's a<br>disclaimer.<br><br>Have at it....<br><br>Rob"	"<br>No, we're not.  But we're also not going to promote pandering to<br>corporate paranoia when the real issue is convenience.  I don't *like*<br>dealing with floppies.  Personally, I have no use for changing the<br>registration info, but I see it as a valid need, and one that ought to<br>be solved using a quick little utility rather than a half-hour<br>reinstall that's just about guaranteed to mess up your settings in one<br>way or another.<br><br>So, while I'm not going to put much time into it myself, here's the<br>procedure for getting on your way to finding the encoded information:<br><br>1.  Copy all your Windows disks into the directory from which you want<br>to install it.  I've been using c:\WINSTALL myself.<br><br>2.  From there, copy that directory to something like c:\WINORIG.<br><br>3.  Install from c:\winstall.<br><br>4.  comp the two directories to determine changes.  <br>    i.e., comp *.* \winorig\*.* >\report.txt<br><br>5.  Look in the report file for the file(s) that change.  Assuming<br>they didn't cover themselves covering their own tracks, at least one<br>file should have a difference noted at a particular offset.  Locate<br>said offset in the original directory and see what's there using a hex<br>editor, and do the same for the modified one.<br><br>6.  You're on your own as far as breaking the code goes; I don't<br>really do cryptography.  It's probably just an xor key or something; I<br>think MS is more concerned with Joe Schmoe at the office personalizing<br>his copy than with ""real pirates"" who will probably just disassemble<br>the damned thing anyway.  This technique should work with just about<br>any obnoxious corporate product that tries to write to the original<br>floppies when you install; in some extreme cases you may not be able<br>to back the floppies up to hard disk, and will be stuck doing a<br>compare on floppies (Lotus stuff is probably like that).<br><br>As I noted before, if you can afford the space on the hard disk, and<br>don't do much in the way of customization, reinstalling from one<br>directory to another may be less arduous.  Doing some of the stuff<br>I've mentioned here may well void your license with Microsoft, as if<br>they'd ever find out.  If you aren't careful with the disk editor, you<br>could also mung something important... duh.  I guess that's a<br>disclaimer.<br><br>Have at it....<br><br>Rob"

719	0	"First off, I haven't used W4WG (but I think that's about to change!).<br><br>The problem is the LASTDRIVE command and the way NetWare in general (and<br>in this case NETX in particular) adds drives to the device chain. <br>Setting LASTDRIVE=Z means there are no ""unassigned"" (as opposed to<br>""unused"") drive letters for NetWare to use, as it tacks its drive<br>mappings -onto the end- of the existing list of drives.  W4WG obviously<br>attaches its network drives to ""existing, unused"" drive letters.<br><br>I'd guess the next thing I'd try is something like LASTDRIVE=M, which on<br>most machines will leave a fair swathe of drives for W4WG and still<br>allow up to 13 NetWare drive mappings as well."	"First off, I haven't used W4WG (but I think that's about to change!).<br><br>The problem is the LASTDRIVE command and the way NetWare in general (and<br>in this case NETX in particular) adds drives to the device chain. <br>Setting LASTDRIVE=Z means there are no ""unassigned"" (as opposed to<br>""unused"") drive letters for NetWare to use, as it tacks its drive<br>mappings -onto the end- of the existing list of drives.  W4WG obviously<br>attaches its network drives to ""existing, unused"" drive letters.<br><br>I'd guess the next thing I'd try is something like LASTDRIVE=M, which on<br>most machines will leave a fair swathe of drives for W4WG and still<br>allow up to 13 NetWare drive mappings as well."

722	1	"Like who, f'rinstance?  When I bought my system (November), no first, second,<br>or third tier vendor could touch the price for the hardware/software<br>combination I got from GW2000.<br><br><br>If you were selling as many systems as fast as GW2000, you'd end up with four<br>or five pissed-off customers too.  And four or five ecstatic ones.  And lots<br>of satisfied ones...<br><br><br>Don't minimize this; if you buy mail order, it's a good thing to know that<br>you'll get replacements parts, no questions asked, in a day or two, via FedEx.<br><br><br>Which they do in the vast majority of cases.  Remember that it's only the<br>people on the tails of the curve who are motivated to write -- the ones who<br>love it, and the ones who hate it.  You don't hear from the folks in the<br>middle very often..."	"Like who, f'rinstance?  When I bought my system (November), no first, second,<br>or third tier vendor could touch the price for the hardware/software<br>combination I got from GW2000.<br><br><br>If you were selling as many systems as fast as GW2000, you'd end up with four<br>or five pissed-off customers too.  And four or five ecstatic ones.  And lots<br>of satisfied ones...<br><br><br>Don't minimize this; if you buy mail order, it's a good thing to know that<br>you'll get replacements parts, no questions asked, in a day or two, via FedEx.<br><br><br>Which they do in the vast majority of cases.  Remember that it's only the<br>people on the tails of the curve who are motivated to write -- the ones who<br>love it, and the ones who hate it.  You don't hear from the folks in the<br>middle very often..."
