727	0	"*** THIS IS LONG ***<br><br>I have 16MB of memory on my 386SX (25 MHz), an Intel math coprocessor, and<br>a 120MB hard drive with 20MB free (no compression).  I have been running<br>Mathcad 3.1, under Windows 3.1 in enhanced mode, with a 5MB RAM drive,<br>2MB/1MB Smart drive, and no swap file (permanent or temporary) for<br>several months.<br><br>I am interested in the faster Mathcad 4.0, but I am concerned about reported<br>swap file requirements and the legitimacy of Mathsoft's claim about increased<br>speed.<br><br>TO 386SX USERS:<br><br>  Will Mathcad 4.0 run without a swap file, or insist that I use a swap file?<br><br>So far, in response to a less detailed description of my setup, or in<br>unrelated postings, the more informed answers, on the net or by E-mail,<br>appear to be:<br><br>  1) by fuess@llnl.gov (David A. Fuess) >><br><br>   >> According to Mathsoft, no. Mathcad uses the swap file extensively so as<br>   >> not to overburden the physical resources. They say this is actually a<br>   >> win32s feature. A figure of 10MB was indicated to me as a minimum. But<br>   >> you might try anyway!<br><br>  2) by bert.tyler@satalink.com (Bert Tyler) >><br><br>   >> I'm not all that certain that Mathcad is the culprit here.<br>   >><br>   >> I have a 486/66DX2 with 16MB of main memory (less 2MB for a RAMdisk and<br>   >> a bit for a DOS session that is opened as part of the startup process),<br>   >> which I have been running without any swapfile.  When I installed the<br>   >> WIN32s subsystem from the March Beta of the NT SDK, the WIN32s subsystem<br>   >> itself demanded the presence of a swapfile.  The only WIN32s program<br>   >> I've run to date is the 32-bit version of Freecell that came with that<br>   >> subsystem.<br>   >><br>   >> I gave Windows a small temporary swapfile (I'm leery of files that must<br>   >> remain in fixed locations on my hard disk), and all seems well.<br><br>  3) by bca@ece.cmu.edu (Brian C. Anderson) >><br><br>   >> What is Win32?  I upgraded to Mathcad 4.0 and it installed a directory for<br>   >> Win32 under \windows\system .  During the upgrade it told me that win32<br>   >> was required.<br><br>  4) by case0030@student.tc.umn.edu (Steven V Case-1) >><br><br>  >> MathCad 4.0 makes use of the Win32s libraries.  You've probably<br>  >> heard about Win32s, it is a 32-bit Windows library that provides<br>  >> much of the Windows NT functionality (no support for threads and<br>  >> multitasking and such) but can be run under Windows 3.1.<br><br>  5) by rhynetc@zardoz.chem.appstate.edu (Thomas C. Rhyne) >><br><br>   >> I also have 16 Mb of ram, and indeed Mathcad 4.0 insisted on a permanent<br>   >> swapfile; it would not run otherwise.<br><br>  6) by bishop@baeyer.chem.fsu.edu (Greg Bishop) >><br><br>   >> 3) MathCAD absolutely requires 4MB RAM (with 12MB swap file) or 8MB RAM<br>   >> (with 8MB swap file).  It will give you a not enough memory error if the<br>   >> swap file is less than 8MB.  It is a MAJOR resource hog.  If you do not<br>   >> load the symbolic processor or the smart math, it takes about 5MB of RAM<br>   >> (real or virtual) just to load (again, due to the win32s libraries.<br><br>********************************************************************************<br>*                                                                              *<br>* So it seems that in addition to the system requirements shown on Mathsoft's  *<br>* advertisement for 4.0, that you need a swap file, possibly as big as 12MB.   *<br>* Looks like I would just need an 8MB swap file, and would need to choose (or  *<br>* can I?) between a faster permanent swap file, or a slower temporary swap file*<br>*                                                                              *<br>* Apparently a Win32 subsystem ships with Mathcad 4.0 - how much disk space    *<br>* does this require?                                                           *<br>*                                                                              *<br>********************************************************************************<br><br>I also received these answers:<br><br>  1) by mfdjh@uxa.ecn.bgu.edu (Dale Hample) >><br><br>   >> If you've got 16 megs of RAM, why not configure 10megs as a ram disk for<br>   >> Mathcad?  DOS 6 permits different bootup configurations.<br><br>********************************************************************************<br>*                                                                              *<br>* Can Mathcad 4.0 + Win32 be configured to use such a RAM drive instead of a   *<br>* swap file?  If not, I don't see how using DOS 6.0 for an alternate bootup    *<br>* would provide Windows with this swap file.   Some time back I remember a     *<br>* discussion about the issues of using a RAM drive to support a swap file,     *<br>* but I thought this involved slower, < 8MB systems.                           *<br>*                                                                              *<br>* I have DOS 6.0 but for various reasons have not yet done a full installation.*<br>*                                                                              *<br>* By the way, is a full installation of DOS 6.0 required to avail oneself of   *<br>* the ""alternate bootup"" feature?  Which files from the installation disks are *<br>* required?                                                                    *<br>*                                                                              *<br>********************************************************************************<br><br>  2) by wild@access.digex.com (Wildstrom) >><br><br>   >> Presumeably, you mean without a _permanent_ swap file. If Windows needs a<br>   >> swap file, it will upo and create one if a permanent one doesn't exist.<br>   >> Permanent is generally faster though. I don't know why Mathcad wouldn't<br>   >> be happy with either type--Ver. 3.0 is and so should any program conforming<br>   >> to the Win specification."	"*** THIS IS LONG ***<br><br>I have 16MB of memory on my 386SX (25 MHz), an Intel math coprocessor, and<br>a 120MB hard drive with 20MB free (no compression). Fuess) >><br><br>   >> According to Mathsoft, no. Mathcad uses the swap file extensively so as<br>   >> not to overburden the physical resources. They say this is actually a<br>   >> win32s feature. If you do not<br>   >> load the symbolic processor or the smart math, it takes about 5MB of RAM<br>   >> (real or virtual) just to load (again, due to the win32s libraries.<br><br>********************************************************************************<br>*                                                                              *<br>* So it seems that in addition to the system requirements shown on Mathsoft's  *<br>* advertisement for 4.0, that you need a swap file, possibly as big as 12MB.   *<br>* Looks like I would just need an 8MB swap file, and would need to choose (or  *<br>* can I?) between a faster permanent swap file, or a slower temporary swap file*<br>*                                                                              *<br>* Apparently a Win32 subsystem ships with Mathcad 4.0 - how much disk space    *<br>* does this require?                                                           *<br>*                                                                              *<br>********************************************************************************<br><br>I also received these answers:<br><br>  1) by mfdjh@uxa.ecn.bgu.edu (Dale Hample) >><br><br>   >> If you've got 16 megs of RAM, why not configure 10megs as a ram disk for<br>   >> Mathcad? 729	1	"<br>80386:  True 32 bit processor.<br>        (cache?)<br><br>80386SX:  Emulates 80386 with a 16 bit bus.<br><br>80486:  True 32 bit processor.<br>        Internal mathematical coprocessor (Correct?)<br>        Internal cache (Correct? How big?)<br>        (extended instruction set in any way?)<br><br>80486SX:  Probably sorta like 80486...<br><br>80486DX:  Probably sorta like 80386...<br><br><br>Well, it's not much, but I'm sure there is a lot of people out there<br>who can add a lot of information. Post or email as you prefer."	"<br>80386:  True 32 bit processor.<br>        (cache?)<br><br>80386SX:  Emulates 80386 with a 16 bit bus.<br><br>80486:  True 32 bit processor.<br>        Internal mathematical coprocessor (Correct?)<br>        Internal cache (Correct? How big?)<br>        (extended instruction set in any way?)<br><br>80486SX:  Probably sorta like 80486...<br><br>80486DX:  Probably sorta like 80386...<br><br><br>Well, it's not much, but I'm sure there is a lot of people out there<br>who can add a lot of information. Post or email as you prefer."

731	0	"I had posted some questions regarding the new ATI Ultra Pro cards and<br>had asked confirmation of some opinions.<br><br>This message is a summary of the responses. Thanks to all of you that<br>replied.<br><br><br><br>a) The higher memory limits apply to ISA cards only, as far as I know.  The VLB<br>   and EISA version should have no problems.<br> <br>b) I'm pretty sure from my experience that the ISA version doesn't<br>   work in systems with over 16M Ram.  There is supposed to be way<br>   of switching the ""memory aperture"" feature off to prevent this,<br>   but apparently it doesn't work.  I posted some ""help me"" messages<br>   on the net and people indicated that the EISA card didn't have this<br>   problem.<br><br>c) FALSE<br><br>d) The VLB card, which I have, allows you to set memory aperture over 32M<br>   by using their configuration software.  No messing with jumpers necessary.<br><br>   The 32M problem is probably valid only for ISA cards.<br><br><br><br>a) Again, the memory aperture need only be disabled if you have more than 124M RAM<br>   (EISA and VLB) or 12 M (ISA).  32M should not be a problem for you. <br> <br>b) Dunno.<br><br>c) Depends on the bus. YES if ISA, NO if EISA or Localbus<br><br><br><br>a) Nope.  I can use 640x480 at 72hz, 24-bit and 800x600 at 70hz, 24-bit, all<br>   non-interlaced.<br><br>b) Yes - According to PC Magazine, they've tested a local bus version<br>   that does 1024x768 in 24-bit which may or may not be interlaced.<br><br>c) Not for the Pro. Sometimes for the Plus.<br><br>   Some modes may run only interlaced on certain monitors. This has nothing to <br>   do with 24 bits ... only with screen size. Note that for 24 bit color<br>   and Windows you MUST have 2 megs, memory size calculations notwithstanding.<br><br><br><br>a) They aren't perfect, but are much improved.  I don't recall the last time which<br>   I had to leave mach 32 mode (ATI GUP mode) and switch to 8514 or VGA mode due<br>   to software incompatibility.<br><br>b) True.  Many people recommended going back to Build 55 or 54.<br><br>c) They appear to be excellent, but have a few bugs. For example, certain<br>   graphs with dashed lines in Mathcad 3.1 do not print correctly, though they<br>   do display OK on the screen. They are about par for fancy cards ..<br>   other accelerated cards also have bugs.<br><br>d) Overall, I like the card, even if driver performance is somewhat less than<br>   satisfactory.  I am running the 1024*768 16 Color mode as that is all my<br>   NT driver for October NT version seems to allow.<br><br>   I will say this that Color performance is not quite as nice as a Diamond<br>   Stealth VRAM, but I have not been able to try out a lot of the options on<br>   the old driver.<br><br><br><br>a) It's quite fast, but whether or not its the fastest is open to debate.<br> <br>b) Yes - I'll admit it was very very fast in 16-bit mode, which is what<br>   I wanted to use it for.  Too bad it crashed (in many different ways)<br>   every 20 minutes or so...<br><br>c) Depends on many many things.<br><br><br><br>a) I like it.<br><br>b) Well - PC Magazine seems to think it is.<br><br>c) Yes, this appears to be true :-)<br><br>d) As to greatest thing since sliced bread, I doubt it.  Better cards are<br>   coming out.  Who knows, maybe ATI will come out with something faster yet.<br>   Several reviews I read rated one Pycon Winjet card as a superior performer <br>   at a cheaper price except for availability of drivers, which Pycon was <br>   developing at that time.  (PC Magazine, about two months or so back)<br><br>   Overall, the card has a lot of potential, but you have to be able to use it.<br> <br><br>-----------------------------------------------------------------------------<br>That is the end of the questions. These were the most discussed items in this<br>group so I thought they needed confirmation. For those of you not familiar<br>with the card I have included a summary here (from an ATI ad since I don't have<br>an Graphics Ultra yet.)<br><br>ATI Graphics Ultra Plus:<br>- Accelerated 1024x768 at 65K colours<br>- True colour(16.7M) at 800x600<br>- Multimedia Video Acceleration (for Indeo Video,RLE and Video 1 compressed)<br>  Stretch full motion video windows to full size<br>- Fast VGA<br>- Includes 3 button mouse (ISA versions only)<br>- Anti-aliased fonts (ed. avail in 16 colour mode only,I think)<br>- Real-time pan and zoom across large virtual windows desktop<br>- Around a 1/2 length card size<br>- Priced from $400 U.S.<br><br>ATI Graphics Ultra Pro:<br>- Everything in Graphics Ultra Plus<br>- Faster performance with VRAMS<br>- Accelerated 1280x1024 at 256 colours 74Hz non-interlaced<br>- Available in ISA, EISA and Microchannel<br>- Priced from $600 U.S.<br><br>ATI Technologies<br>(416) 756-0718<br><br>I hope this summary can be of use to you.<br><br>Al<br><br>P.S.  I am not associated with ATI Technologies in any way other<br>      than having used their previous ATI Ultra card for a few<br>      years (which I generally liked).<br><br>"	"I had posted some questions regarding the new ATI Ultra Pro cards and<br>had asked confirmation of some opinions.<br><br>This message is a summary of the responses. Thanks to all of you that<br>replied.<br><br><br><br>a) The higher memory limits apply to ISA cards only, as far as I know. 734	0	" Again, not true. The characters in a TT or Type 1 font depend on the <br> maker. If someone converts a Type 1 font to TT they'll only get the<br> characters in the font of orgin. TT allows for much more flexibility<br> in this area as well. You can have thousands of glyphs in a TT font<br> file (Mac/PS/Windows/Unicode char set) and use the characters<br> appropriate for the particular platform you are running the font on.<br><br>Well, yes, both Type 1 and TrueType fonts can contain lots of characters.<br>And in both cases plain text fonts will be reencoded to Windows ANSI<br>in Windows, and to Mac standard roman encoding on the Mac. <br>No difference there between T1 and TT!   <br><br>And as for fonts with thousands of glyphs, right know these are a liabiliaty<br>rather than a great new thing.  Reason is that a font with 3000 characters<br>is very large, and if you can only access 224 of them you are paying a heavy<br>price in downloading time and printer storage.  (And at the moment there<br>is only one program of that uses `partial font downloading')<br><br> For instance, all or our fontpack 2 TT fonts have the Mac/Windows<br> char set in them. The metrics of the fonts are such that if the font<br> is brought over to the mac the user will have access to the full mac<br> char set.  <br><br>Yes and T1 text fonts all have the `ISO Adobe' character set, which is<br>a superset of Windows ANSI and Macintosh standard roman enocding.<br><br>The question is whether you can get at the glyphs.  In Windows, for example,<br>you cannot get at the ligatures `fi' anfd `fl' (both T1 and TT)even though a<br>font may very well have them.<br><br>ANd, while it is somewhat painful to reencode a Type 1 font and to create a<br>new Windows metric file (PFM) for it, there are utilities out there to allow<br>you do this.  How do I reencode a TrueType font?  How can I get at the<br>`fi' and `fl' ligatures in Windows (or on the Mac)?  Are there utilities<br>that make it possible to circumvent the hard-wired Windows ANSI encoding?<br><br><br>   > Regards,                                            1001-A East Harmony Road<br>   > Bob Niland                                          Suite 503<br>   > Internet:  rjn@csn.org                              Fort Collins CO 80525<br>   > CompuServe: 71044,2124                              (303) 223-5209<br>"	" Again, not true. The characters in a TT or Type 1 font depend on the <br> maker. If someone converts a Type 1 font to TT they'll only get the<br> characters in the font of orgin. TT allows for much more flexibility<br> in this area as well. You can have thousands of glyphs in a TT font<br> file (Mac/PS/Windows/Unicode char set) and use the characters<br> appropriate for the particular platform you are running the font on.<br><br>Well, yes, both Type 1 and TrueType fonts can contain lots of characters.<br>And in both cases plain text fonts will be reencoded to Windows ANSI<br>in Windows, and to Mac standard roman encoding on the Mac. <br>No difference there between T1 and TT!   <br><br>And as for fonts with thousands of glyphs, right know these are a liabiliaty<br>rather than a great new thing.  Reason is that a font with 3000 characters<br>is very large, and if you can only access 224 of them you are paying a heavy<br>price in downloading time and printer storage.  (And at the moment there<br>is only one program of that uses `partial font downloading')<br><br> For instance, all or our fontpack 2 TT fonts have the Mac/Windows<br> char set in them. The metrics of the fonts are such that if the font<br> is brought over to the mac the user will have access to the full mac<br> char set.  <br><br>Yes and T1 text fonts all have the `ISO Adobe' character set, which is<br>a superset of Windows ANSI and Macintosh standard roman enocding.<br><br>The question is whether you can get at the glyphs.  In Windows, for example,<br>you cannot get at the ligatures `fi' anfd `fl' (both T1 and TT)even though a<br>font may very well have them.<br><br>ANd, while it is somewhat painful to reencode a Type 1 font and to create a<br>new Windows metric file (PFM) for it, there are utilities out there to allow<br>you do this.  How do I reencode a TrueType font?  How can I get at the<br>`fi' and `fl' ligatures in Windows (or on the Mac)?  Are there utilities<br>that make it possible to circumvent the hard-wired Windows ANSI encoding?<br><br><br>   > Regards,                                            1001-A East Harmony Road<br>   > Bob Niland                                          Suite 503<br>   > Internet:  rjn@csn.org                              Fort Collins CO 80525<br>   > CompuServe: 71044,2124                              (303) 223-5209<br>"

741	1	"<br>Yes, you can change the IRQ's for com3/4, but it depends on your other<br>hardware. com1 uses IRQ4, com2 IRQ3.  If you have only one printerport <br>( IRQ7 ), you can change com3 to IRQ5 ( normally 2nd printer ). For com4,<br>you can assign IRQ2, if its free. As far as I know, no other IRQ can be<br>used until your I/O-card is 16bit and caould access IRQ's > 8.<br><br>Michael"	"<br>Yes, you can change the IRQ's for com3/4, but it depends on your other<br>hardware. com1 uses IRQ4, com2 IRQ3.  If you have only one printerport <br>( IRQ7 ), you can change com3 to IRQ5 ( normally 2nd printer ). For com4,<br>you can assign IRQ2, if its free. As far as I know, no other IRQ can be<br>used until your I/O-card is 16bit and caould access IRQ's > 8.<br><br>Michael"

743	1	" ""These LPT1, COM1, disk controller are call devices.  There are<br> devices that requires exclusive interrupt ownership, eg. disk<br> controller (I6) and keyboard (I1).  There are also devices that<br> does not require exclusive ownership, ie. it will share an<br> interrupt with another device, eg. LPT1""<br><br>No.  In a standard ISA bus, the one that almost all non-laptop PCs use,<br>two separate interface cards cannot share an interrupt.  This is due to<br>a screwup in the bus design.  For example, if your Soundblaster wants<br>to drive interrupt number 7, then it must hold a certain bus wire to 0<br>or 1 at all times, depending on whether or not it wants an interrupt.<br>This precludes letting another card assert interrupt number 7.<br><br>When two or more devices in an ISA bus PC share an interrupt, it's<br>because they're implemented by a single card."	" ""These LPT1, COM1, disk controller are call devices.  There are<br> devices that requires exclusive interrupt ownership, eg. disk<br> controller (I6) and keyboard (I1).  There are also devices that<br> does not require exclusive ownership, ie. it will share an<br> interrupt with another device, eg. LPT1""<br><br>No.  In a standard ISA bus, the one that almost all non-laptop PCs use,<br>two separate interface cards cannot share an interrupt.  This is due to<br>a screwup in the bus design.  For example, if your Soundblaster wants<br>to drive interrupt number 7, then it must hold a certain bus wire to 0<br>or 1 at all times, depending on whether or not it wants an interrupt.<br>This precludes letting another card assert interrupt number 7.<br><br>When two or more devices in an ISA bus PC share an interrupt, it's<br>because they're implemented by a single card."

766	1	"I believe that any VL/EISA/ISA motherboard that uses the HINT chipset<br>is limited to 24-bit EISA DMA (where 'real' EISA DMA is 32-bit).  The<br>HINT EISA DMA has the 16 mb ram addressing limitation of ISA.  For this<br>reason I would pass.  I own one of these (HAWK VL/EISA/ISA) and am look-<br>ing to replace it for exactly this reason.<br><br>Please double-check me on this.  In other words, call the motherboard<br>manufacturer and ask them if the motherboard supports true 32-bit EISA<br>DMA.<br><br>Other than this limitation, the motherboard works quite well (I am using<br>mine with DOS 5, Windows 3.1, and UNIX S5R3.2).  Also with Adaptec 1742a<br>EISA SCSI host adapter.<br>"	"I believe that any VL/EISA/ISA motherboard that uses the HINT chipset<br>is limited to 24-bit EISA DMA (where 'real' EISA DMA is 32-bit).  The<br>HINT EISA DMA has the 16 mb ram addressing limitation of ISA.  For this<br>reason I would pass.  I own one of these (HAWK VL/EISA/ISA) and am look-<br>ing to replace it for exactly this reason.<br><br>Please double-check me on this.  In other words, call the motherboard<br>manufacturer and ask them if the motherboard supports true 32-bit EISA<br>DMA.<br><br>Other than this limitation, the motherboard works quite well (I am using<br>mine with DOS 5, Windows 3.1, and UNIX S5R3.2).  Also with Adaptec 1742a<br>EISA SCSI host adapter.<br>"

770	1	"you  need to massage few switches in your system.ini.<br>in the virtual memory section, flip the 32bitaccess switch on and the <br>associated driver (wdctl or some such) switch on.  this will enable<br>32bit access, but be sure you can use it, as not all hard drives<br>and controllers support it !  <br><br><br>...for seriously fast disk access:<br><br>1)  throw out WINDOZE<br>2)  install OS/2<br><br>i did this weekend - OS/2 is incredible.  finally a REAL OS for<br>the humble PC  :)"	"you  need to massage few switches in your system.ini.<br>in the virtual memory section, flip the 32bitaccess switch on and the <br>associated driver (wdctl or some such) switch on.  this will enable<br>32bit access, but be sure you can use it, as not all hard drives<br>and controllers support it !  <br><br><br>...for seriously fast disk access:<br><br>1)  throw out WINDOZE<br>2)  install OS/2<br><br>i did this weekend - OS/2 is incredible.  finally a REAL OS for<br>the humble PC  :)"		
771	1	"I'm sorry if I'm misunderstanding your post, but DRAM *does not* have to<br>be refreshed on *each access cycle*.  So cycle time does *not* have to be<br>twice the access time *because of refresh phase*.<br><br>The access time usually means the delay time from falling edge of raw<br>address strobe (RAS) to data bus driven.<br><br>DRAM access cycle timing chart can be roughly shown as following (some<br>signals are intentionally omitted);<br><br>ADDR --<RA><CA>-------<RA><CA>--------- RA=Raw Address, CA=Column Address<br>RAS  ~~~~\________/~~~~~\________/~~~~~  ~=High, _=Low, -=Floating<br>CAS  ~~~~~~~\_______/~~~~~~\_______/~~~  <..>=driven either H or L<br>DATA ---------<VALID>--------<VALID>---<br>         |-------+------|<br>         |-+--|  |<br>           |     +----------- cycle time<br>           +---- access time (or RAS access time)<br><br>Yes, the cycle time is more than twice as the access time but *not*<br>because of the refresh phase.  The refresh can be done either as a<br>trailing phase of normal access cycle or as an individual cycle.<br><br>[other stuff deleted]<br><br>Ken Nakata"	"I'm sorry if I'm misunderstanding your post, but DRAM *does not* have to<br>be refreshed on *each access cycle*.  So cycle time does *not* have to be<br>twice the access time *because of refresh phase*.<br><br>The access time usually means the delay time from falling edge of raw<br>address strobe (RAS) to data bus driven.<br><br>DRAM access cycle timing chart can be roughly shown as following (some<br>signals are intentionally omitted);<br><br>ADDR --<RA><CA>-------<RA><CA>--------- RA=Raw Address, CA=Column Address<br>RAS  ~~~~\________/~~~~~\________/~~~~~  ~=High, _=Low, -=Floating<br>CAS  ~~~~~~~\_______/~~~~~~\_______/~~~  <..>=driven either H or L<br>DATA ---------<VALID>--------<VALID>---<br>         |-------+------|<br>         |-+--|  |<br>           |     +----------- cycle time<br>           +---- access time (or RAS access time)<br><br>Yes, the cycle time is more than twice as the access time but *not*<br>because of the refresh phase.  The refresh can be done either as a<br>trailing phase of normal access cycle or as an individual cycle.<br><br>[other stuff deleted]<br><br>Ken Nakata"

777	1	"<br>Introduction:<br><br> This is the third (and final) Call For Votes (CFV) for the creation<br> of four OS/2 newsgroups and the renaming of one:<br> (a)  create comp.os.os2.programmer.porting     (unmoderated)<br> (b)  renaming of comp.os.os2.programmer to<br>      comp.os.os2.programmer.misc               (unmoderated)<br> (c)  comp.os.os2.setup                         (unmoderated)<br> (d)  comp.os.os2.multimedia                    (unmoderated)<br> (e)  comp.os.os2.bugs                          (unmoderated)<br><br> This is the second attempt at creating comp.os.os2.programmer.porting<br> and comp.os.os2.setup, and renaming comp.os.os2.programmer to<br> comp.os.os2.programmer.misc.  The first attempt failed in the summer<br> of 1992 (the voting deadline was August 31, 1992).  The voting rules<br> state that another attempt for creating newsgroups can be started<br> after a six month waiting period (in this case, it is March 1, 1993).<br> This is the first attempt at creating comp.os.os2.multimedia and<br> comp.os.os2.bugs.<br><br> This document contains:<br> *  the background showing the need for these proposals<br> *  the proposed charters for these proposals<br> *  voting instructions<br> *  a voting ballot<br> *  some example ballots<br> *  the voting rules<br> *  the voting schedule<br> *  the Mass Acknowledgement<br><br><br>Background:<br><br> The creation of two, free, 32-bit compilers for OS/2 2.x (gcc/2<br> and emx/gcc; read comp.os.os2.programmer for details) has spurred<br> a continuing deluge of software ported from UNIX platforms, such<br> as emacs, less, awk, grep, sed, xscheme, ispell, flex, yacc, and<br> much more.  Borland has released its C/C++ compiler for OS/2 2.x,<br> allowing for easier porting of DOS and Windows software.<br><br> Much of the PC hardware and drivers were written for DOS, and<br> later, Windows.  As more people are discovering OS/2 2.x, the<br> number of people asking questions about OS/2's compatibility<br> with their hardware increases, as does the questions on the<br> availability of drivers for their hardware, installation<br> procedures, etc.<br><br> Multimedia is becoming popular.  OS/2 2.0 supports Windows<br> Multimedia Extensions using Win-OS/2 3.0.  Furthermore, IBM is<br> including direct multimedia support in OS/2 starting with version<br> 2.1 (in addition to using Win-OS/2 3.1).<br><br> Any non-trivial software will have bugs -- OS/2 is not exempt,<br> especially since IBM is constantly adding new features to OS/2.<br> So far, IBM has issued system patches and corrective service disks<br> (e.g.  the Service Pak) for free (free from BBSs and ftp sites, or<br> for free plus a small media charge for diskettes -- read<br> comp.os.os2.misc for details).<br><br><br>Proposed Charters:<br><br> (a)  create comp.os.os2.programmer.porting (unmoderated)<br><br>  It will provide a forum for developers of ported software so<br>  as to coordinate efforts, avoid duplication of effort, and<br>  spur additional development.  The group will also cover<br>  topics such as porting from other platforms (such as DOS,<br>  Windows, UNIX, etc), toolkits which aid in program<br>  portability (including porting tools such as Mirrors), and<br>  so forth.<br><br> (b)  rename: comp.os.os2.programmer.misc (unmoderated)<br><br>  To keep the structure of the OS/2 newsgroup heirarchy<br>  orthogonal, comp.os.os2.programmer should be renamed to<br>  comp.os.os2.programmer.misc.<br><br>  comp.os.os2.programmer.misc will still be the newsgroup<br>  for OS/2 programmers to discuss programming issues and<br>  technical aspects of OS/2 in an unmoderated setting.<br><br> (c)  create comp.os.os2.setup (unmoderated)<br><br>  It will be devoted to OS/2 system setup topics, including the<br>  availability of device drivers, compatibility information,<br>  installation procedures, system requirements, and overall<br>  performance optimization.<br><br> (d)  create comp.os.os2.multimedia (unmoderated)<br><br>  It will provide a forum for discussion of multi-media issues.<br><br> (e)  create comp.os.os2.bugs (unmoderated)<br><br>  It will provide a forum for OS/2 system bug reports, bug<br>  diagnosis and work arounds, the availability of system<br>  patches and corrective service disks, and so forth.<br><br>  [Note that discussion of bugs in applications belong in other<br>  newsgroups, and discussion of bugs in OS/2 betas belong in<br>  comp.os.os2.beta]<br><br><br>How to Vote:<br><br> To cast your vote, fill out the ballot below and e-mail it to me.<br> Many newsreaders will allow e-mail to be sent by replying to this<br> post.  Be sure to send only the ballot, and edit out the rest of<br> this post.<br><br> 1)  Type in your vote for each proposal:<br><br>     If you favor the charter as proposed, put a ""yes"" after its name.<br>     If you oppose the charter as proposed, put a ""no"" after its name.<br>     To abstain, leave a blank after its name.<br><br> 2)  Type in your last name (i.e. your family name), a comma, and<br>     your first name (i.e. your personal name).<br><br> 3)  Cut out the ballot,  Please do not delete any lines of the<br>     ballot.<br><br> 4)  E-mail your ballot to mlevis@lonestar.utsa.edu before 11:59:59 pm<br>     (Central Time), April 24, 1993.<br><br><br>Ballot:<br><br>----------------cut here----------------cut here----------------cut here----<br><br>        (a) comp.os.os2.programmer.porting:<br>        (b)    comp.os.os2.programmer.misc:<br>        (c)              comp.os.os2.setup:<br>        (d)         comp.os.os2.multimedia:<br>        (e)               comp.os.os2.bugs:<br><br>        (f)       voter's last, first name:<br><br>        e-mail ballot to mlevis@lonestar.utsa.edu by April 24<br><br>----cut here----------------cut here----------------cut here----------------<br><br><br>Example Ballot #1:<br><br> (a) comp.os.os2.programmer.porting: yes<br> (b)    comp.os.os2.programmer.misc: yes<br> (c)              comp.os.os2.setup: no<br> (d)         comp.os.os2.multimedia:<br> (e)               comp.os.os2.bugs: no<br><br> (f)       voter's last, first name: Smith, John<br><br> In this example, John Smith favors comp.os.os2.programmer.porting<br> to be created, and comp.os.os2.programmer to be renamed to<br> comp.os.os2.programmer.misc.  He also opposes the creation of<br> comp.os.os2.setup and comp.os.os2.bugs.  He does not have a view<br> on the creation of comp.os.os2.multimedia. <br><br><br>Example Ballot #2:<br><br> (a) comp.os.os2.programmer.porting: yes<br> (b)    comp.os.os2.programmer.misc: yes<br> (c)              comp.os.os2.setup: yes<br> (d)         comp.os.os2.multimedia: yes<br> (e)               comp.os.os2.bugs: yes<br><br> (f)       voter's last, first name: Doe, Jane<br><br> In this example, Jane Doe favors the creation or rename of all<br> the proposals.<br><br><br>Voting Rules:<br><br> * One vote per person.  If you vote more than once, only the most<br>   recent vote will be counted.<br><br> * Votes must be mailed to me by the person voting.  Proxy voting,<br>   forwarding, posting votes to a newsgroup, etc. will not be counted.<br><br> * Do not ask how the votes are going.  The status of the votings<br>   will be revealed only after the poll closes.<br><br> * I will acknowledge votes by Mass Acknowledgement (ACK).  I will<br>   post the ACK twice (see Schedule below).<br><br> * If you need help for using your editor, using e-mail, how<br>   voting works in general, etc. then ask an expert at your site.<br>   Also see the ``How To Create a New Newsgroup'' article which is<br>   posted to news.answers on a regular basis.<br><br> * If you need any clarifications on voting procedures for this<br>   CFV, send me e-mail at mlevis@ringer.cs.utsa.edu.<br><br> * When the voting period is over (see Schedule below), a proposal<br>   passes if both of the following formulas are true:<br>   1)  the number of YES votes exceeds the number of NO votes<br>       by at least 100 (i.e. YES >= NO + 100, or YES - NO >= 100).<br>   2)  the number of YES votes exceeds at least twice the<br>       number of NO votes (i.e. YES >= 2 * NO, or YES - NO >= NO).<br>   In other words, a proposal passes if:<br>       YES - NO >= max (100, NO)<br>   where max() returns the highest number given to it.<br><br><br>Schedule:<br><br> The voting period started on March 29 when the first CFV was posted<br> by David Lawrence (the news.announce.newgroups moderator).<br><br> This third CFV is a repeat of the first CFV, but it also has the<br> Mass Acknowledgement (ACK) of names and e-mail addresses of those who<br> have already voted -- re-send your vote if it is not there.  If you<br> have not voted yet, vote now!<br><br> The voting period will end at 11:59:59 pm (Central Time), on<br> April 24, 1993.  Votes received after that time will not count.<br> The voting results and tally will be posted shortly after that<br> date.<br><br><br>Mass Acknowledgement:<br><br> Here is the list of people who have        tommy@msc.cornell.edu<br>Tiffany, Bernard          lbt@umich.edu<br>torremans, engelbert      etorrem%hvlpa@att.att.com<br>Tremain, Jim              JIM@BIOLOGY.watstar.uwaterloo.ca<br>Tsen, Maoee               tsen0001@student.tc.umn.edu<br>van der Lek, Petja        P.vanderLek@research.ptt.nl<br>Van Iwaarden, Ronald      rvaniwaa@copper.Denver.Colorado.EDU<br>van Woerkom, Marc E.E. ovillumsen@daimi.aau.dk<br>Wald, David               wald@theory.lcs.mit.edu<br>Wallace, Jack             grey@vnet.IBM.COM<br>Wantosch, Rainer          RAINER@sasowa.han.de<br>Watson, Brett             watson@s1.elec.uq.oz.au<br>Weber-Fahr, Christoph     weber@rhrk.uni-kl.de<br>Weeks, Larry              dev@ecn.purdue.edu<br>Werner, John              werner@SOE.Berkeley.Edu<br>West, Mike                west@esd.dl.nec.com<br>weyrich, orville          uunet.uu.net!weyrich!orville<br>White, Andrew             apwhite@csugrad.cs.vt.edu<br>Wiersema, Brian           brianw@umd5.umd.edu<br>Wimmer, Carsten           Carsten_Wimmer@train.fido.de<br>Wittenauer, Allen         Allen_Wittenauer@crispy.carb.il.us<br>Woodbury, Gregory         ggw@wolves.Durham.NC.US<br>Worthington, Stephen      stephen@actrix.gen.nz<br>Wright, Gregory           gregory@bcstec.ca.boeing.com<br>Wyble, Richard            transfer.stratus.com!schunix!rwyble<br>YOUNG, DAVID M.           dyoung@netcom.com<br>Zabbal, Christian         kris@binkley.cs.mcgill.ca<br>zawodny, jeremy           jzawodn@andy.bgsu.edu<br>Zou, Nan                  nan@matt.ksu.ksu.edu"	"<br>Introduction:<br><br> This is the third (and final) Call For Votes (CFV) for the creation<br> of four OS/2 newsgroups and the renaming of one:<br> (a)  create comp.os.os2.programmer.porting     (unmoderated)<br> (b)  renaming of comp.os.os2.programmer to<br>      comp.os.os2.programmer.misc               (unmoderated)<br> (c)  comp.os.os2.setup                         (unmoderated)<br> (d)  comp.os.os2.multimedia                    (unmoderated)<br> (e)  comp.os.os2.bugs                          (unmoderated)<br><br> This is the second attempt at creating comp.os.os2.programmer.porting<br> and comp.os.os2.setup, and renaming comp.os.os2.programmer to<br> comp.os.os2.programmer.misc.  The first attempt failed in the summer<br> of 1992 (the voting deadline was August 31, 1992).  The voting rules<br> state that another attempt for creating newsgroups can be started<br> after a six month waiting period (in this case, it is March 1, 1993).<br> This is the first attempt at creating comp.os.os2.multimedia and<br> comp.os.os2.bugs.<br><br> This document contains:<br> *  the background showing the need for these proposals<br> *  the proposed charters for these proposals<br> *  voting instructions<br> *  a voting ballot<br> *  some example ballots<br> *  the voting rules<br> *  the voting schedule<br> *  the Mass Acknowledgement<br><br><br>Background:<br><br> The creation of two, free, 32-bit compilers for OS/2 2.x (gcc/2<br> and emx/gcc; read comp.os.os2.programmer for details) has spurred<br> a continuing deluge of software ported from UNIX platforms, such<br> as emacs, less, awk, grep, sed, xscheme, ispell, flex, yacc, and<br> much more.  Borland has released its C/C++ compiler for OS/2 2.x,<br> allowing for easier porting of DOS and Windows software.<br><br> Much of the PC hardware and drivers were written for DOS, and<br> later, Windows.  As more people are discovering OS/2 2.x, the<br> number of people asking questions about OS/2's compatibility<br> with their hardware increases, as does the questions on the<br> availability of drivers for their hardware, installation<br> procedures, etc.<br><br> Multimedia is becoming popular.  OS/2 2.0 supports Windows<br> Multimedia Extensions using Win-OS/2 3.0.  Furthermore, IBM is<br> including direct multimedia support in OS/2 starting with version<br> 2.1 (in addition to using Win-OS/2 3.1).<br><br> Any non-trivial software will have bugs -- OS/2 is not exempt,<br> especially since IBM is constantly adding new features to OS/2.<br> So far, IBM has issued system patches and corrective service disks<br> (e.g.  the Service Pak) for free (free from BBSs and ftp sites, or<br> for free plus a small media charge for diskettes -- read<br> comp.os.os2.misc for details).<br><br><br>Proposed Charters:<br><br> (a)  create comp.os.os2.programmer.porting (unmoderated)<br><br>  It will provide a forum for developers of ported software so<br>  as to coordinate efforts, avoid duplication of effort, and<br>  spur additional development.  The group will also cover<br>  topics such as porting from other platforms (such as DOS,<br>  Windows, UNIX, etc), toolkits which aid in program<br>  portability (including porting tools such as Mirrors), and<br>  so forth.<br><br> (b)  rename: comp.os.os2.programmer.misc (unmoderated)<br><br>  To keep the structure of the OS/2 newsgroup heirarchy<br>  orthogonal, comp.os.os2.programmer should be renamed to<br>  comp.os.os2.programmer.misc.<br><br>  comp.os.os2.programmer.misc will still be the newsgroup<br>  for OS/2 programmers to discuss programming issues and<br>  technical aspects of OS/2 in an unmoderated setting.<br><br> (c)  create comp.os.os2.setup (unmoderated)<br><br>  It will be devoted to OS/2 system setup topics, including the<br>  availability of device drivers, compatibility information,<br>  installation procedures, system requirements, and overall<br>  performance optimization.<br><br> (d)  create comp.os.os2.multimedia (unmoderated)<br><br>  It will provide a forum for discussion of multi-media issues.<br><br> (e)  create comp.os.os2.bugs (unmoderated)<br><br>  It will provide a forum for OS/2 system bug reports, bug<br>  diagnosis and work arounds, the availability of system<br>  patches and corrective service disks, and so forth.<br><br>  [Note that discussion of bugs in applications belong in other<br>  newsgroups, and discussion of bugs in OS/2 betas belong in<br>  comp.os.os2.beta]<br><br><br>How to Vote:<br><br> To cast your vote, fill out the ballot below and e-mail it to me.<br> Many newsreaders will allow e-mail to be sent by replying to this<br> post.  Be sure to send only the ballot, and edit out the rest of<br> this post.<br><br> 1)  Type in your vote for each proposal:<br><br>     If you favor the charter as proposed, put a ""yes"" after its name.<br>     If you oppose the charter as proposed, put a ""no"" after its name.<br>     To abstain, leave a blank after its name.<br><br> 2)  Type in your last name (i.e. your family name), a comma, and<br>     your first name (i.e. your personal name).<br><br> 3)  Cut out the ballot,  Please do not delete any lines of the<br>     ballot.<br><br> 4)  E-mail your ballot to mlevis@lonestar.utsa.edu before 11:59:59 pm<br>     (Central Time), April 24, 1993.<br><br><br>Ballot:<br><br>----------------cut here----------------cut here----------------cut here----<br><br>        (a) comp.os.os2.programmer.porting:<br>        (b)    comp.os.os2.programmer.misc:<br>        (c)              comp.os.os2.setup:<br>        (d)         comp.os.os2.multimedia:<br>        (e)               comp.os.os2.bugs:<br><br>        (f)       voter's last, first name:<br><br>        e-mail ballot to mlevis@lonestar.utsa.edu by April 24<br><br>----cut here----------------cut here----------------cut here----------------<br><br><br>Example Ballot #1:<br><br> (a) comp.os.os2.programmer.porting: yes<br> (b)    comp.os.os2.programmer.misc: yes<br> (c)              comp.os.os2.setup: no<br> (d)         comp.os.os2.multimedia:<br> (e)               comp.os.os2.bugs: no<br><br> (f)       voter's last, first name: Smith, John<br><br> In this example, John Smith favors comp.os.os2.programmer.porting<br> to be created, and comp.os.os2.programmer to be renamed to<br> comp.os.os2.programmer.misc.  He also opposes the creation of<br> comp.os.os2.setup and comp.os.os2.bugs.  He does not have a view<br> on the creation of comp.os.os2.multimedia. <br><br><br>Example Ballot #2:<br><br> (a) comp.os.os2.programmer.porting: yes<br> (b)    comp.os.os2.programmer.misc: yes<br> (c)              comp.os.os2.setup: yes<br> (d)         comp.os.os2.multimedia: yes<br> (e)               comp.os.os2.bugs: yes<br><br> (f)       voter's last, first name: Doe, Jane<br><br> In this example, Jane Doe favors the creation or rename of all<br> the proposals.<br><br><br>Voting Rules:<br><br> * One vote per person.  If you vote more than once, only the most<br>   recent vote will be counted.<br><br> * Votes must be mailed to me by the person voting.  Proxy voting,<br>   forwarding, posting votes to a newsgroup, etc. will not be counted.<br><br> * Do not ask how the votes are going.  The status of the votings<br>   will be revealed only after the poll closes.<br><br> * I will acknowledge votes by Mass Acknowledgement (ACK).  I will<br>   post the ACK twice (see Schedule below).<br><br> * If you need help for using your editor, using e-mail, how<br>   voting works in general, etc. then ask an expert at your site.<br>   Also see the ``How To Create a New Newsgroup'' article which is<br>   posted to news.answers on a regular basis.<br><br> * If you need any clarifications on voting procedures for this<br>   CFV, send me e-mail at mlevis@ringer.cs.utsa.edu.<br><br> * When the voting period is over (see Schedule below), a proposal<br>   passes if both of the following formulas are true:<br>   1)  the number of YES votes exceeds the number of NO votes<br>       by at least 100 (i.e. YES >= NO + 100, or YES - NO >= 100).<br>   2)  the number of YES votes exceeds at least twice the<br>       number of NO votes (i.e. YES >= 2 * NO, or YES - NO >= NO).<br>   In other words, a proposal passes if:<br>       YES - NO >= max (100, NO)<br>   where max() returns the highest number given to it.<br><br><br>Schedule:<br><br> The voting period started on March 29 when the first CFV was posted<br> by David Lawrence (the news.announce.newgroups moderator).<br><br> This third CFV is a repeat of the first CFV, but it also has the<br> Mass Acknowledgement (ACK) of names and e-mail addresses of those who<br> have already voted -- re-send your vote if it is not there.  If you<br> have not voted yet, vote now!<br><br> The voting period will end at 11:59:59 pm (Central Time), on<br> April 24, 1993.  Votes received after that time will not count.<br> The voting results and tally will be posted shortly after that<br> date.<br><br><br>Mass Acknowledgement:<br><br> Here is the list of people who have already sent in their ballots<br> as of 12:01 am (Central Time) on April 15, 1993:<br><br>                          bdubbs@cs.tamu.edu<br>Aiyagari, Sanjay 783	0	"THESE FILES ARE UNSUPPORTED!  IBM has nothing to do with these files or<br>this post.  It's personal this time (and every time I post -- see the<br>signature).<br><br>Due to demand and requests, here are some additional DMQS files I've<br>collected for the XGA-2.  These files function with the latest revision<br>of the drivers for the XGA-2.  Not all these files will work under Windows<br>with the drivers available to the general public at this time.  All files<br>will function under the most recent OS/2 2.1 beta and those I've tried have<br>worked under OS/2 2.0+SP.  Not all files have been fully tested.<br><br>THESE FILES ARE UNSUPPORTED!  They represent a personal collection, not<br>anything resembling an officially supported set.<br><br>As a standard disclaimer I would like to point out the following facts:<br>1) Some of these files may run your adapter out of spec.  Doing so can<br>   stress the ICs on the card and may result in incorrect operation or in<br>   shorter life (how short depends on how much out of spec [boom!] :-).<br>2) Some of these files may run your adapter in a region that is out of<br>   spec for your monitor, resulting in damage to your monitor.<br>3) You should be knowledgable about your monitor and adapter's ability<br>   to use the mode you select.  Using these files represents hacking<br>   in a very true sense, so practice safe computing and don't play<br>   around too much if you don't like the risks and aren't knowledgable<br>   about what you're doing.<br>4) If you feel uncomfortable with all the warnings, use the DMQS files<br>   you have or wait until IBM releases official, tested DMQS files.<br>   Although you should be aware of warning 2) even with the IBM files.<br><br>THESE FILES ARE UNSUPPORTED!  By using them you may invalidate your<br>warrenty.  Not all have been fully tested -- I don't have that many<br>monitors.<br><br>Installation: unpack in your DMQSPATH environment variable, usually<br>c:\xga$dmqs.  Then use the methods described in your XGA-2 installation<br>diskette to change your adapter or settings.<br><br>Packing: these files have been packed with the latest INFOZIP utility.  <br>You will need PKZip 2.x if you don't have the INFOZIP utilities.<br><br>Submitting:  feel free to send me uuencoded versions of your favorite DMQS<br>files for your favorite monitors.  I'm always interested in collecting more.<br><br>Archive:  these files have been uploaded to ftp-os2.nmsu.edu in<br>pub/uploads/xga2dmqs.zip."	"THESE FILES ARE UNSUPPORTED!  IBM has nothing to do with these files or<br>this post.  It's personal this time (and every time I post -- see the<br>signature).<br><br>Due to demand and requests, here are some additional DMQS files I've<br>collected for the XGA-2.  These files function with the latest revision<br>of the drivers for the XGA-2.  Not all these files will work under Windows<br>with the drivers available to the general public at this time.  All files<br>will function under the most recent OS/2 2.1 beta and those I've tried have<br>worked under OS/2 2.0+SP.  Not all files have been fully tested.<br><br>THESE FILES ARE UNSUPPORTED!  They represent a personal collection, not<br>anything resembling an officially supported set.<br><br>As a standard disclaimer I would like to point out the following facts:<br>1) Some of these files may run your adapter out of spec.  Doing so can<br>   stress the ICs on the card and may result in incorrect operation or in<br>   shorter life (how short depends on how much out of spec [boom!] :-).<br>2) Some of these files may run your adapter in a region that is out of<br>   spec for your monitor, resulting in damage to your monitor.<br>3) You should be knowledgable about your monitor and adapter's ability<br>   to use the mode you select.  Using these files represents hacking<br>   in a very true sense, so practice safe computing and don't play<br>   around too much if you don't like the risks and aren't knowledgable<br>   about what you're doing.<br>4) If you feel uncomfortable with all the warnings, use the DMQS files<br>   you have or wait until IBM releases official, tested DMQS files.<br>   Although you should be aware of warning 2) even with the IBM files.<br><br>THESE FILES ARE UNSUPPORTED!  By using them you may invalidate your<br>warrenty.  Not all have been fully tested -- I don't have that many<br>monitors.<br><br>Installation: unpack in your DMQSPATH environment variable, usually<br>c:\xga$dmqs.  Then use the methods described in your XGA-2 installation<br>diskette to change your adapter or settings.<br><br>Packing: these files have been packed with the latest INFOZIP utility.  <br>You will need PKZip 2.x if you don't have the INFOZIP utilities.<br><br>Submitting:  feel free to send me uuencoded versions of your favorite DMQS<br>files for your favorite monitors.  I'm always interested in collecting more.<br><br>Archive:  these files have been uploaded to ftp-os2.nmsu.edu in<br>pub/uploads/xga2dmqs.zip."

785	1	"If you only do read/print then there is no reason for the joystick stuff<br>not to take 90% of the time even if it is efficient.<br><br><br>The truth is that int 15H joystick reading IS slow. I read it directly<br>from the hardware port. Note that doing so exposes you to intermittent<br>disturbance from interrupts, so you may want to read (say) twice in a<br>row and keep the lower results. Don't just turn interrupts off, it may<br>prove detrimental to the health of any high speed comms and other<br>devices.<br><br>Here is an example of how to do this:<br><br>/* ------------------------------ joy.c ------------------------------------- */<br><br>/* An example of how to read PC joystick port by polling the hardware port<br> * directly.<br> * Uses inp()/outp() for byte port access.<br> * Will timeout when 'int count=0' counts up to zero.<br> * This sample reads one port (A is presented and B is in the comments).<br> * You can read both at once by merging the two, but it will time out<br> * when either joystick is not connected.<br> *<br> * There is no need to optimize this routine since it runs for as long as<br> * the joystick circuitry needs.<br> *<br> * Written by Eyal Lebedinsky (eyal@ise.canberra.edu.au).<br>*/<br><br>#include <stdio.h><br>#include <stdlib.h><br>#include <conio.h><br><br>extern int readjoy (int *x, int *y, int *b1, int *b2);<br><br>#define JOYPORT 0x201<br><br>#define XJOY 0x01 /* for joystick B use 0x04 */<br>#define YJOY 0x02 /* for joystick B use 0x08 */<br>#define XYMASK (XJOY|YJOY)<br>#define BUT1 0x10 /* for joystick B use 0x40 */<br>#define BUT2 0x20 /* for joystick B use 0x80 */<br><br>int     /* returns 0 if ok */<br>readjoy (int *x, int *y, int *b1, int *b2)<br>{<br> register int count;<br> register char temp, joy;<br><br> temp = (char)XYMASK;<br> count = 0;<br> outp (JOYPORT, 0);  /* set trigger */<br> do {<br>  temp ^= (joy = (char)inp (JOYPORT));<br>  if (temp & XJOY)<br>   *x = count;<br>  if (temp & YJOY)<br>   *y = count;<br> } while (++count && ((temp = joy) & XYMASK));<br> *b1 = !(joy & BUT1);<br> *b2 = !(joy & BUT2);<br><br> return (!count);<br>}<br><br>/* This main() is for demonstration.<br>*/<br><br>int<br>main ()<br>{<br> int rc, x, y, b1, b2;"	"If you only do read/print then there is no reason for the joystick stuff<br>not to take 90% of the time even if it is efficient.<br><br><br>The truth is that int 15H joystick reading IS slow. I read it directly<br>from the hardware port. Note that doing so exposes you to intermittent<br>disturbance from interrupts, so you may want to read (say) twice in a<br>row and keep the lower results. Don't just turn interrupts off, it may<br>prove detrimental to the health of any high speed comms and other<br>devices.<br><br>Here is an example of how to do this:<br><br>/* ------------------------------ joy.c ------------------------------------- */<br><br>/* An example of how to read PC joystick port by polling the hardware port<br> * directly.<br> * Uses inp()/outp() for byte port access.<br> * Will timeout when 'int count=0' counts up to zero.<br> * This sample reads one port (A is presented and B is in the comments).<br> * You can read both at once by merging the two, but it will time out<br> * when either joystick is not connected.<br> *<br> * There is no need to optimize this routine since it runs for as long as<br> * the joystick circuitry needs.<br> *<br> * Written by Eyal Lebedinsky (eyal@ise.canberra.edu.au).<br>*/<br><br>#include <stdio.h><br>#include <stdlib.h><br>#include <conio.h><br><br>extern int readjoy (int *x, int *y, int *b1, int *b2);<br><br>#define JOYPORT 0x201<br><br>#define XJOY 0x01 /* for joystick B use 0x04 */<br>#define YJOY 0x02 /* for joystick B use 0x08 */<br>#define XYMASK (XJOY|YJOY)<br>#define BUT1 0x10 /* for joystick B use 0x40 */<br>#define BUT2 0x20 /* for joystick B use 0x80 */<br><br>int     /* returns 0 if ok */<br>readjoy (int *x, int *y, int *b1, int *b2)<br>{<br> register int count;<br> register char temp, joy;<br><br> temp = (char)XYMASK;<br> count = 0;<br> outp (JOYPORT, 0);  /* set trigger */<br> do {<br>  temp ^= (joy = (char)inp (JOYPORT));<br>  if (temp & XJOY)<br>   *x = count;<br>  if (temp & YJOY)<br>   *y = count;<br> } while (++count && ((temp = joy) & XYMASK));<br> *b1 = !(joy & BUT1);<br> *b2 = !(joy & BUT2);<br><br> return (!count);<br>}<br><br>/* This main() is for demonstration.<br>*/<br><br>int<br>main ()<br>{<br> int rc, x, y, b1, b2;"

I use NDW.<br><br><br>If you like things to be modular, I think you would love System 7.<br>Instead of adding a line to your autoexec.bat, you just drop the<br>icon into the extensions folder.<br>"	"<br>I don't. 794	0	"Try this:  flip your mouse over, and open up the cover that holds the<br>mouse ball in place.  Remove the ball, and inside you should see<br>(probably) 3 rollers.  If any of the rollers have a tiny layer of<br>caked-on dirt, dust, or otherwise unidentifiable scum on them, carefully<br>scrape it off with a small knife (Xacto works great).  *Be Careful*<br>You do not want to gauge the rollers, just clean off the dirt.<br>Put the ball back in, put the cover on, and there you are.  <br><br>I clean a couple of dozen of these every month here.  Another symptom<br>is that when you move the mouse, it seems to ""click"" along.  If this<br>doesn't solve your problem, at least you have a clean mouse.  I highly<br>recommend using a proper _soft_ mouse pad, and if you are a clean freak,<br>place it in your drawer every night or when you don't use it to keep<br>the dust off.<br><br>Personally I prefer track balls.  Oh, which brings me to another point:<br>if your mouse or trackball tracks optically, and the sunlight is <br>streaming through the window onto your mouse/trackball, you may notice<br>that it will stop working.  If this happens to you, close the curtains<br>or blinds, or simply shade your pointing device, and see if that helps.<br>"	"Try this:  flip your mouse over, and open up the cover that holds the<br>mouse ball in place.  Remove the ball, and inside you should see<br>(probably) 3 rollers.  If any of the rollers have a tiny layer of<br>caked-on dirt, dust, or otherwise unidentifiable scum on them, carefully<br>scrape it off with a small knife (Xacto works great).  *Be Careful*<br>You do not want to gauge the rollers, just clean off the dirt.<br>Put the ball back in, put the cover on, and there you are.  <br><br>I clean a couple of dozen of these every month here.  Another symptom<br>is that when you move the mouse, it seems to ""click"" along.  If this<br>doesn't solve your problem, at least you have a clean mouse.  I highly<br>recommend using a proper _soft_ mouse pad, and if you are a clean freak,<br>place it in your drawer every night or when you don't use it to keep<br>the dust off.<br><br>Personally I prefer track balls.  Oh, which brings me to another point:<br>if your mouse or trackball tracks optically, and the sunlight is <br>streaming through the window onto your mouse/trackball, you may notice<br>that it will stop working.  If this happens to you, close the curtains<br>or blinds, or simply shade your pointing device, and see if that helps.<br>"

799	1	"Another (albeit strange) option is using a program like 800 II<br>(available via anonymous FTP at many major sites), or FDFORMAT<br>(also available via anonymous FTP), that allows you to format<br>5.25HD disks to 1.44Meg, or 3.5""HD disks to 1.2Meg (along with<br>many MANY other formats!) so you can DISKCOPY (yes, the broken<br>MeSsy-DOS DISKCOPY!) the 5.25"" disks onto 3.5"" disks or vice<br>versa...  I use this techniques with ""NON-DOS"" self-booting <br>game disks on my old Tandy 1000, and it works...  Another program<br>named Teledisk (shareware--available on many major BBS's) will<br>also make the weird format disks, provided you have 800 II<br>or FDFormat installed....  Some disks that won't DISKCOPY<br>properly can be readily Teledisk'd into the proper format...<br>At least this is a software solution for a hardware/BIOS <br>deficiency, eh? <br><br><br>--<br>Joseph Zbiciak                         im14u2c@camelot.bradley.edu<br>[====Disclaimer--If you believe any of this, check your head!====]<br>------------------------------------------------------------------"	"Another (albeit strange) option is using a program like 800 II<br>(available via anonymous FTP at many major sites), or FDFORMAT<br>(also available via anonymous FTP), that allows you to format<br>5.25HD disks to 1.44Meg, or 3.5""HD disks to 1.2Meg (along with<br>many MANY other formats!) so you can DISKCOPY (yes, the broken<br>MeSsy-DOS DISKCOPY!) the 5.25"" disks onto 3.5"" disks or vice<br>versa... 805	1	"I just tried a few experiments. I cat'd a 20261-byte file (471 lines)<br>under various scenarios:<br><br>PC-Xview for DOS in a full-screen OS/2 window (1024x768x16):    18 sec<br>Telix (DOS) in an OS/2 window (1024xs768x256):                  107 sec!<br>Telix (DOS) is a full-screen OS/2 window (standard VGA):        11 sec<br>Telix (DOS) in a Windows 3.1 window (1024x768x256):             30 sec<br>UW/WIN in a seamless OS/2 window (1024x768x256):        gave up after 4 min!<br>UW/WIN in Windows 3.1 (1024x768x256):           faster, but gave up after 2 min<br>UW/WIN in a seamless OS/2 window using pg       30 sec, could have been a<br>                                                little faster (I had to keep<br>                                                hitting the space bar)<br><br>I was using an ATI Wonder XL video card, by the way.<br><br>So PC-Xview for DOS looks pretty good (and the line-by-line scrolling<br>in OS/2 desktop looks pathetic, although full-page redraws are pretty<br>good).<br><br>I tried it under PC-Xview using my normal (9x15bold or 10x20) font,<br>and with a very small font, and there was no difference in the times.<br>The modem receive light was on pretty solidly, so it looks like the<br>bottleneck was the 9600-baud modem, not the screen drawing.<br>"	"I just tried a few experiments. I cat'd a 20261-byte file (471 lines)<br>under various scenarios:<br><br>PC-Xview for DOS in a full-screen OS/2 window (1024x768x16):    18 sec<br>Telix (DOS) in an OS/2 window (1024xs768x256):                  107 sec!<br>Telix (DOS) is a full-screen OS/2 window (standard VGA):        11 sec<br>Telix (DOS) in a Windows 3.1 window (1024x768x256):             30 sec<br>UW/WIN in a seamless OS/2 window (1024x768x256):        gave up after 4 min!<br>UW/WIN in Windows 3.1 (1024x768x256):           faster, but gave up after 2 min<br>UW/WIN in a seamless OS/2 window using pg       30 sec, could have been a<br>                                                little faster (I had to keep<br>                                                hitting the space bar)<br><br>I was using an ATI Wonder XL video card, by the way.<br><br>So PC-Xview for DOS looks pretty good (and the line-by-line scrolling<br>in OS/2 desktop looks pathetic, although full-page redraws are pretty<br>good).<br><br>I tried it under PC-Xview using my normal (9x15bold or 10x20) font,<br>and with a very small font, and there was no difference in the times.<br>The modem receive light was on pretty solidly, so it looks like the<br>bottleneck was the 9600-baud modem, not the screen drawing.<br>"

808	0	"   : The key issue that I bought my BJ-200 on was ink drying speed.  You really <br>   : have to try awful hard to get the BJ-200 ink to smear.  The HP DeskJets need <br>   : 10-15 seconds to completely dry.  In both cases, however, do not get your <br>   : pages wet.  Unlike laser printers, the material on your pages is INK, not <br>   : toner.  But that should go without saying.<br><br>   I think the ink now used in the DeskJet family is water-fast. <br><br>I've had pictures ruined by a few drops of rain. These were colour pictures<br>from a DeskJet 500C. Mind you, it could have been acid rain:-)<br><br>I use a BJ10ex. Ink dries fast, but it really doesn't like getting wet.<br>"	"   : The key issue that I bought my BJ-200 on was ink drying speed. In both cases, however, do not get your <br>   : pages wet.  Unlike laser printers, the material on your pages is INK, not <br>   : toner. These were colour pictures<br>from a DeskJet 500C. Mind you, it could have been acid rain:-)<br><br>I use a BJ10ex. Ink dries fast, but it really doesn't like getting wet.<br>"

812	0	"Just a thought on resources,  It is very important if you do use a<br>multiplatform toolkit to check on how it uses resources.  I have<br>used Glockenspeil commonview under Motif and OS2.  I wrote a resource<br>converter from OS2 to Motif, but it really wasn't too easy, especially<br>the naming scheme. In Motif you cannot rename controls/widgets.<br>With windows you can call the OK button ID_OK in every instance,<br>this doesn't work for Motif, you'd have to call it Dialog1_OK,<br>and Motif expects a text string rather than a number.  So <br>your constructor should know how to convert a #define into the<br>proper resource identifier.<br>I'd check on how the toolkit expects names, and that if it does<br>use resources, that is uses resources for all platforms you intend to<br>port to. ( By the way, I would never use CommonView or Glockenspiel<br>for anything ) <br><br><br><br>Alex.<br><br>"	"Just a thought on resources,  It is very important if you do use a<br>multiplatform toolkit to check on how it uses resources.  I have<br>used Glockenspeil commonview under Motif and OS2.  I wrote a resource<br>converter from OS2 to Motif, but it really wasn't too easy, especially<br>the naming scheme. In Motif you cannot rename controls/widgets.<br>With windows you can call the OK button ID_OK in every instance,<br>this doesn't work for Motif, you'd have to call it Dialog1_OK,<br>and Motif expects a text string rather than a number.  So <br>your constructor should know how to convert a #define into the<br>proper resource identifier.<br>I'd check on how the toolkit expects names, and that if it does<br>use resources, that is uses resources for all platforms you intend to<br>port to. ( By the way, I would never use CommonView or Glockenspiel<br>for anything ) <br><br><br><br>Alex.<br><br>"

814	1	"IDE also uses DMA techniques.  I believe floppy controller also uses DMA,<br>and most A/D boards also use DMA.  DMA is no big deal, and has nothing to<br>do directly with SCSI.<br><br><br>You can thank your software for that.  If DOS had a few more brains, it<br>could format floppies etc. while you were doing something else.  The<br>hardware will support it, but DOS (at least) won't.  Again, this has   <br>nothing to do with SCSI.<br><br><br>And if you stick with DOS you'll wonder why you can't multitask."	"IDE also uses DMA techniques.  I believe floppy controller also uses DMA,<br>and most A/D boards also use DMA.  DMA is no big deal, and has nothing to<br>do directly with SCSI.<br><br><br>You can thank your software for that.  If DOS had a few more brains, it<br>could format floppies etc. while you were doing something else.  The<br>hardware will support it, but DOS (at least) won't.  Again, this has   <br>nothing to do with SCSI.<br><br><br>And if you stick with DOS you'll wonder why you can't multitask."

You have to create a new WIN.COM file.  Try<br> BS> the command (you will have to worry about what directories each file is in<br> BS> since I don't know your setup):<br><br> BS> COPY /B WIN.CNF+VGALOGO.LGO+VGALOGO.RLE WIN.COM<br><br> BS> (I grabbed this from _Supercharging Windows_ by Judd Robbins--great book)<br> BS> This is also how you can put your own logo into the Windows startup<br> BS> screen. 819	0	"The original RISCs had small instruction sets, and simple ones. The<br>idea was that a) every instruction should be completable in a single<br>clock cycle and b) to have no microcode and c) extensive pipelines.<br><br>A few comparisons (from Patterson: Reduced Instruction set computers.<br>CACM V28. 1, 1985):<br><br>CPU  Year Instructions Microcode<br>---  ---- ------------ ---------<br>IBM 370/168 1973 208  420Kb<br>DEC VAX 11/780 1978 303  480Kb<br>IBM 801  1980 120  0<br>UCB RISC 1 1982 39  0<br>Stanford MIPS 1983 55  0<br><br>While researching for the VLSI VAX, DEC discovered that 60% of the VAX<br>microcode is there to support 20% of the instruction set which<br>accounted for a mere 0.2% of all instructions executed. The uVAX 32<br>subsetted the architecture onto a single chip and used a software<br>emulator for these very complex instructions, the full VLSI uVAX<br>included the entire instruction set, was 5-10 times more copmlex but<br>only ranm 20% faster.<br><br>CPU  Chips Microcode Transistors<br>---  ----- --------- -----------<br>uVAX 32  2 64K  101K<br>VLSI uVAX 9 480K  1250K<br>"	"The original RISCs had small instruction sets, and simple ones. The<br>idea was that a) every instruction should be completable in a single<br>clock cycle and b) to have no microcode and c) extensive pipelines.<br><br>A few comparisons (from Patterson: Reduced Instruction set computers.<br>CACM V28. 1, 1985):<br><br>CPU  Year Instructions Microcode<br>---  ---- ------------ ---------<br>IBM 370/168 1973 208  420Kb<br>DEC VAX 11/780 1978 303  480Kb<br>IBM 801  1980 120  0<br>UCB RISC 1 1982 39  0<br>Stanford MIPS 1983 55  0<br><br>While researching for the VLSI VAX, DEC discovered that 60% of the VAX<br>microcode is there to support 20% of the instruction set which<br>accounted for a mere 0.2% of all instructions executed. The uVAX 32<br>subsetted the architecture onto a single chip and used a software<br>emulator for these very complex instructions, the full VLSI uVAX<br>included the entire instruction set, was 5-10 times more copmlex but<br>only ranm 20% faster.<br><br>CPU  Chips Microcode Transistors<br>---  ----- --------- -----------<br>uVAX 32  2 64K  101K<br>VLSI uVAX 9 480K  1250K<br>"

It<br>is basically the same as the Mustek scanner except for the resolution (400<br>dpi) and price ($149).  <br><br>Basically, I would like recommendations on which to buy.  I have heard that<br>Logitech makes the best and manufactures Dexxa scanners.  But which one is the<br>best buy?  Would 800 dpi really be helpful (output would be no better than HP<br>LaserJet III or Canon BJ-200 - 300x300 to 360x360)?  I am leaning toward the<br>Mustek because it offers the most features and is in the middle in terms of<br>prices. 823	1	"I'm not sure if this will work, but how about using one of those 'T' expanders<br>used in the low-profile cases.  They allow 3-5 slots staggered on either<br>side of the card.  You can install it in the last slot, and then (probably) <br>have 2 or 3 sideways slots.  This is actually how it is done in the low<br>profile cases - a standard motherboard, the 'T' connector in one slot, <br>and the expansion cards plugged into the 'T'.  I guess you could do this at <br>each end of the slots (1 & 8) to add even more.  <br><br>The 'T' connectors are simply tracks with slots on them - no electronics<br>on it.  The only downside - your case won't close, but for a homebrew system,<br>that may not be a problem.<br><br>Don't know about performance, though.  I'll leave that discussion to the <br>engineers."	"I'm not sure if this will work, but how about using one of those 'T' expanders<br>used in the low-profile cases.  They allow 3-5 slots staggered on either<br>side of the card.  You can install it in the last slot, and then (probably) <br>have 2 or 3 sideways slots.  This is actually how it is done in the low<br>profile cases - a standard motherboard, the 'T' connector in one slot, <br>and the expansion cards plugged into the 'T'.  I guess you could do this at <br>each end of the slots (1 & 8) to add even more.  <br><br>The 'T' connectors are simply tracks with slots on them - no electronics<br>on it.  The only downside - your case won't close, but for a homebrew system,<br>that may not be a problem.<br><br>Don't know about performance, though.  I'll leave that discussion to the <br>engineers."

831	0	"  Days ago people doubted that ms-windows is not a real OS. I can see why<br>they have such question. Ms-windows confuses many people. Microsoft<br>simulated Mac, but it did a lousy job.  For example:<br><br>(1) You can not create hierarchy groups. There is no way to create a group<br>    in a group. (If you know how, please tell me.)<br>(2) Too many system parameters to take care of. <br>(3) uncomplete documentation. It's not easy to find the reason why causes<br>    an unpredictable error.<br>(4) Group deleting/file deleting<br>    After deleting a group, users have to use file manager to delete files.<br>    But if users forget to delete some related files, the disk will be full<br>    of nonsense files.<br>(5) share problem<br>    Once you create two windows doing compilation and editing in some<br>    language (w/o good editor), there will be a sharing problem. You just<br>    can not open or save the program if it is loaded. It makes sense to<br>    prevent from saving, but not opening.<br><br>Microsoft try to compromise between DOS and windows, but they just make <br>ms-windows a graphical DOS with capacity doing mutiple DOS jobs; <br>the worst thing is they complicate the environment. The orginal purpose<br>of ms-windows should be to simplify the environment, and make PC easier <br>to use.<br>  <br>  It's by no means easy to satisfy everybody, but if Microsoft want to<br>keep their reputations, they should evaluate the user interface more<br>carefully before products distribute.<br><br>  No flame, please."	"  Days ago people doubted that ms-windows is not a real OS. I can see why<br>they have such question. Ms-windows confuses many people. Microsoft<br>simulated Mac, but it did a lousy job.  For example:<br><br>(1) You can not create hierarchy groups. There is no way to create a group<br>    in a group. (If you know how, please tell me.)<br>(2) Too many system parameters to take care of. <br>(3) uncomplete documentation. It's not easy to find the reason why causes<br>    an unpredictable error.<br>(4) Group deleting/file deleting<br>    After deleting a group, users have to use file manager to delete files.<br>    But if users forget to delete some related files, the disk will be full<br>    of nonsense files.<br>(5) share problem<br>    Once you create two windows doing compilation and editing in some<br>    language (w/o good editor), there will be a sharing problem. You just<br>    can not open or save the program if it is loaded. It makes sense to<br>    prevent from saving, but not opening.<br><br>Microsoft try to compromise between DOS and windows, but they just make <br>ms-windows a graphical DOS with capacity doing mutiple DOS jobs; <br>the worst thing is they complicate the environment. The orginal purpose<br>of ms-windows should be to simplify the environment, and make PC easier <br>to use.<br>  <br>  It's by no means easy to satisfy everybody, but if Microsoft want to<br>keep their reputations, they should evaluate the user interface more<br>carefully before products distribute.<br><br>  No flame, please."
